James Parnel, and was sorry, That ever he should have a hand in his
Persecution; which he saw, was stirred up by the Priests. But this is no
strange Work with the Presbyterian and Independent Priests, Matthew. 28.13, 14,
15.
to say, James Parnel fasted himself to Death; when the Priests, their
Forefathers, said; That Christ's Disciples stole him away by Night, while the
Soldiers slept. And this was the Work of their Day, to make Lies their Refuge,
and to sow them abroad, like Roger Williams, and the Whore, that Solomon
speaks of; to Wipe their Lips, as though they were Clean. And this may serve
Roger Williams and the Persecutors of New England, which have BANISHED, and
WHIPPED, and CUT OFF EARS, and HANGED the Servants of the Lord; and then Wipe
their Mouths and say, They are Clean, or Good Christians, and they have done
Christ Good Service in so doing. But Christ rebukes such, and tells them,
They know not, what Spirit they are of: for he came not to D^stroy Men's Lives,
but to Save them.

R. W. Thou say, We ( after the Devil's Method) make use of the Scripture as
a Shield or Buckler, to fence our selves against the Scripture; p. 95.
and as a Sword, to run through the Heart and Bowels of the Scriptures, the
Saints, and Christ and God himself, etc. and then fall'st a-railing.

Answ. Jer. 22. 2 Kings 17. 1 Cor. 11. These Scriptures do not prove this; nor
that we Disown Scriptures. Now R. W. and ye New-England-Priests, can the Heart
and Bowels of Christ be run through with a Sword? who can but tremble to hear
those Words! We do charge R. W. and the New-England-Priests (that say, The
Scripture is their Rule) to give us Chapter and Verse for these Words, that we
may see, where they be written? that we may Search for them. Is the
Incomprehensible God and Christ his Son (whom he has given all Power in Heaven
and Earth unto and at the Rig^t Hand of God) so light unto you, and of so low a
Value? does R. W. own any God or Christ, but whose Bowels and Heart may be run
through with a Sword? and is not that a false God and Christ? We tell him, the
true Christ and the living God is far above his Reach and Sword? and his unholy
Hands. And is not this Blasphemy to say, The Living God and his Son Christ
Jesus (who is at the Right Hand of God) can be run through with a Sword? we
tell him, He dies no more: but such as thou art, Crucify him to themselves a
fresh, Imprison and Persecute him in his people, as Christ says in Matthew. And
we own the Scriptures, and the Saints and the true Christianity; and not for
this wicked End* as thou wickedly speak. And as for thy Ladders and
Scaffolds, and a many such Ill favored Comparisons, that thou have in thy
Book, might'^t have kept them for thy self, with all the rest of thy Ungracious
Expressions.

R. W. The Merchants desire to see Effects, etc. the Jews, Pharisees; the
Papists and the Quakers do not own the Perfection.

Answ. But R. W. where are thy Effects of thy Religion and the rest of the
Priests? where are the Effects of true Christianity? where are the Effects of
the Fruits of a Good Spirit? for this is not the Language of the Spirit of God,
but of the Evil Spirit; is but of the Effects of the Pharisees and Papists thou
speak of, which are Envy, Bloodshed and Murder: And ye persecuting his
Servants with Tongue and Hand, and HANGING his people, these are not the
Effects of the Good Spirit, but of the Evil One; as the Apostle has described
it in the Scriptures.

And as for the Effects in the Practice of Religion in any Duty, that may
appear (for with whom do thou Meet, and Pray and Preach? or whether or no
thou art not found in the Manner of them, whom the Apostle condemns, and
exhorts the Saints not to have Fellowship withal, Heb. 10, 25.) we think,
thou may forbear to upbraid any, thy self bringing forth so little Effects,
but Effects of an Evil Heart and Unbelief, according to the Apostle's words.
And is not the Authority of the Scripture the Holy Ghost, that moved the Holy
Men of God, that spoke them forth, which lead the Disciples in all Truth of
them? which we witness. For do not thou say, They are of no Value, without
the Spirit of God set them home to the Heart? (as in Append. p. 94.) And so, if
they be of No Value, then that which makes them Valuable, is the Power and
Spirit of God: and then that must be the Authority of them.

R. W. But thou say; The Quakers and Papists call the Scriptures a Dead
Letter [and say, They are of no Value, etc. as before.]

Answ. And as for the Papists, thou had better joined them to thy self; they
are nearer thee, then we are. And where did we ever Throw Dirt at the Holy
Scripture, and said; It was a Nose of Wax, and a Leaden Rule? let the Reader
see, if there be any such words in G. F'.s Answer, or any other Books. And
truly, if any make a Nose of Wax of them, twisting them up and down, it is thy
own Condition; thou giving Meanings of them this Way and that Way, and find
fault with us, because we take them Literally. And 2 Cor. 3. that is nothing to
the purpose: If the King gives a Pardon for Death in Writing; this comes to a
Man, p. 96.
and preventeth his Execution. But what must we infer from R. W.'s Words here?
That every Man, that has the Writings of the Scripture, has the Pardon of
Eternal Death? and why does he cry against Papists then and all others? for
they have the Scriptures, therefore they have the Pardon. So in this R. W.
stops his own Mouth, and shuts out Revelation of the Son of God, which
Scripture speaks of, and Revelation of Faith, Revelation of Grace, Revelation
of the Gospel, Revelation of the Spirit, which is the Seal of all Believers of
the Pardon from Eternal Death by the Blood of Jesus Christ and the Witness with
themselves, by which they can set to their Seal, that God is True in all his
Promises, and Figures and Shaddows of his Son Christ Jesus, Blessed forever!

R. W. Brings ( G. F. Fol. p. 47.) Joshuah Miller saying, [ It is an Error
(if not Damnable) to say, Christ is the Means; and that there is no other Means
of Salvation.] G. F. Answ. [And Christ says, No man can come to the Father,
but by me: and he is Able to save to the uttermost; and, He shall be my
Salvation to the Ends of the Earth, says the Lord. And (says the Apostle) God
is in Christ reconciling the World to himself: And, He that has the Son, has
Life: the Father and Son are one; and there is no Salvation in any other.] And
R. W. replieth and says, His Adversaries would not Suffer him to meddle with
the Sense of G. F.'s words: [But G. F.'s words are Plain enough; and what does
he give a Sense of that? where is your Nose of Wax now?] Yet he thinks not,
that a man of Wisdom would call it an Error, to say, That Christ is the Means
to Salvation. Then he falls a-railing and says; For this Wretched Juggler
(to wit G. F.) subtily confounds the Instrumental Causes of Salvation with the
Efficient in God the Father, p. 97.
the Meritorious in God the Son, Christ Jesus.

Answ. How can this be? when G. F. says, God was in Christ reconciling the
World to himself? and God says, He shall be my Salvation to the Ends of the
Earth? And the Apostle says, ( Ephesians. 1, 17.) In whom we have Redemption through
his Blood, Forgiveness of Sin, according to the Riches of his Grace. And --

R. W. says, I know, this Juggler means not a Christ, nor his Blood, nor his
Death, as we mean, but an Imaginary Christ, etc.

Answ. This Knowledge of thine, and this Means of thine is false, the Lord
knows it; and the Imaginary is in thyself. -- But --

R. W. says, Christ's Messengers are said to Save.

Answ. And what then? is not this through Christ?

R. W. Secondly, Thou say; The Scriptures are said to make Wise to Salvation.

Answ. But why will not R. W. put in, THROVGH FAITH? as though the Scriptures
can Make Wise to Salvation without Faith, Thou say --

R. W. A Man may be God's Means to Save his Wife, and she her Husband.

Answ. And is not this Means FAITH, which Christ is the Author of? And thou
say --

R. W. That we are Saved by Hope, Faith, etc.

Answ. But does not Paul tell thee, That this Hope is Christ, and Faith he is
the Author of? And thou say --

R. W. Saved by Baptism.

Answ. And what! without FAITH? And --

R. W. Women are Saved by Childbearing.

Answ. But what! without Faith by Christ? And what! are all Women Saved by
Childbearing, all that are in the World, with their Bastards? for thou do
not say, Some Women; and thou do not put in FAITH. But can they grow up in
Christ the Savior without Faith? And then thou say --

R. W. All these Subtly and Wickedly G. F. sets at Variance with the
Meritorious Salvation by Jesus Christ.

Answ. G. F. Sets them not at Variance; but he says again, There is no
Salvation in any other Name under Heaven, but in the Name of Jesus Christ: And
thou that say, There is, give the Apostle the Lie, and do not own the
True Lord Jesus.

R. W. Thou tellest of a Man saving his Brother by a Rope, and a Midwife
saving a Woman in Childbed.

Answ. What is this? this is Outward from a Natural Death: but it is Christ
Jesus, that Saves his People from Eternal Death through Faith in him; which is
more, than from Outward Death. And --

R. W. Thou say; To talk of this Immediate Christ and Spirit without
Scriptures, without Preaching and other Holy Means, is as Silly, as Impious, as
Blockish, as Blasphemous, and as Bedlam and Frantic, as Wicked and
Antichristian.

Answ. R. W. has not described, what his Means are? But Reader, is not the
Means the Faith in Christ Jesus? and is not that Revealed? and is not the Means
the Holy Ghost, that Proceeds from the Father and his Son, that leads all
True Believers into all Truth? And they are not the True Preachers, that are
not in the same Holy Ghost, that gave forth the Scriptures, and all their Means
are good for nothing; seeing the Apostle says, That no Man knows the Things
of God, but by the Spirit. And so as for thy Ungracious Words, Silly, Impious,
Blockish, Blasphemy, Frantic, Wicked, Antichristian and Bedlam, thou may
keep to thy self; and so all thy Means, that have No Motion of Heavenly Things.
And all they, that be in the Faith of Christ, and the Holy Ghost, that leads
into all Truth, which the Ministers of the Spirit they have their Means from
Christ, in whose Name is Salvation; and Preach Christ, and not themselves: and
such we are One withal, and such cannot but own the Scriptures. So the Holy
Means are in the Holy Spirit: but what is this to the Means of all your Priests
and Thee, who ownest not the Light of Christ, but call it an Idol? -- And
thou talkest of an Immediate Christ without the Scripture: Will R. W. say, That
Christ and the Spirit is in the Scripture? is not Christ in Heaven? and the
Spirit of God was in them, that gave forth Scripture. And Christ says, Search
the Scriptures, for in them ye think, ye have Life; but ye will not come to me,
that ye might have Life. But we tell R. W. We, and whosoever else owneth the
Lord Jesus Christ, own the Scriptures, and cannot deny them, nor none of his
True Preachers, which carry their Message from Christ for the Good of People:
and such the World receives not, that come in the Name of the Lord; but such
as come in their own, they will Receive.

R. W. And again thou bring a Comparison of the King's Pardon sealed with
his Broad Seal to a Condemned Rebel: (which thou often bring'st over and over.)

Answ. What do thou think to prove by this? That the Scripture is the Pardon,
or is the Evidence? if it were, then the Papists, (that thou Comparest us so
often to) and many Wicked Men might have Pardon and Remission. But is it not
the Spirit, that Seals? (according to Ephesians. 1, 23.4, 30) and is it not
Christ, that Brings the Glad Tidings of Life unto the Soul, and by his Holy
Spirit bears Witness? (according to Romans 8.) and is not the Assurance thus
known?

R. W. brings Hosannah, etc. ( G. F.'s Fol. page 221.) saying, [ The Sure
Word of Prophecy the Apostle speaks of, is the Prophecy of Scripture.] G. F.
Answ. [Doth the Scripture shine in a Dark Place, until the Day Dawn? and are
they them, that must be Taken heed unto, as to a Light? Can any see the
Scripture, or know the Scripture, but by the Light within? cannot a Cain, a
Balaam, a Korah bring Scripture, that is gone from the Spirit of Prophecy
within; and then put the Letter for it?] R. W. Replieth, and begins with
Blasphemy and Railing, and says; I know, that Fox makes their Idol Within,
called Light, to be the More Sure Word of Prophecy; and his Usual Proof is, p.
98.
The Testimony of Jesus is the Spirit of Prophecy, etc. And why must all the
Prophets or Messengers of God, who from the Beginning of the World were God's
Mouth and Pens concerning the Birth, Life and Death of Christ, etc. here be
^ast out from the Word of Prophecy?

Answ. What! cannot R. W. endure to hear talk of the Scriptures? are not John's
Words (in Revelation) The Testimony of Jesus is the Spirit of Prophecy? and
thou deniest it, both Scripture and Spirit, who say; I Usually bring this
Proof? And Peter's Saying, We have a more Sure Word of Prophecy, which ye do
well to take heed unto, as unto a Light, that shintth in a Dark Place, until
the Day dawn, and the Day Star arise in your Hearts: This the Apostle lets them
see the Sufficiency of that Light, till they came to the Day-Dawning and the
Day-star-Arising. And what is this Day-dawning and Day-star-arising in the
Heart? if it be the Outward Scriptures of the Prophets, prove it by Scriptures.
And is this Day-Star-Arising in the Heart, and Day-Dawning and Idol? as thou
call the Light within an Idol, a More Sure Word of Prophecy, than the Voice
which was Heard in the Mount? And this is not to Cast away the Prophets: and
Peter, who directed the Saints to this Sure Word of Prophecy, (the Light, that
shines in a Dark Place) did not Cast out the Prophets* that Prophesied of
Christ's Birth, Death, etc. (as thou Dotingly speak;) no more do we, but own
them all. And Luke 1. and Romans 16. and the Apostles, that had this Light
shining, (this More Sure Word of Prophecy) they saw the Fulfilling of the
Scriptures in Christ Jesus; which none does without the Light of Christ, by
which he is seen. And --

R. W. Thou say; The Written Word or Prophecy of the Prophets is a more Sure
Word and Evidence to us, etc. than the Voice from Heaven, of which Peter here
speaks, etc.

Answ. Now what must we Observe from R. W.'s Words here? That the Written Word
or Prophecy of the Prophets shines in a dark place? Now R. W. says, that the
Scripture is the Rule and Touch stone; We do Charge him and the
New-England-Priests to make this Good by plain Scripture, and give us Chapter
and Verse, and a Rule for it either. And Secondly tell us, Where is this Dark
Place? and what it is, that this Written Word or Prophecies of the Prophets
shine in? (seeing he says, That the Scripture avails nothing without the
Spirit; (and yet, they are more) and then how can they Shine, when they avail
nothing?) And whether he does not now oppose Peter's Doctrine, who calls it a
Light, that shines in a dark place? and the Day-dawning, which shines in the
heart? so, if the Light be the Written Word, that shines in a dark place;
whether or no the Day-dawning and Day Star be the Written-Word? And this Light
(that shines in a dark place, which we are to take heed unto, until the Day
dawn, and the Day Star arise in our hearts) this Light and Day Star does own
all the Prophets from the Beginning of the World concerning the Lord Christ,
who fulfilleth them. And --

R. W. thou say, How sure is the Quakers Light, their Word of Prophecy? a
Sober Mind cannot but admire that Face and Forehead of Brass and Adamant, etc.
So that they blush not to prefer such a simple Image, a mere Baby and Child's
Puppet of their Immediate Word of Prophecy before the Word, the Mind and Will
of God by the Mouth of all the Prophets, etc. And do not thou say -- What
Cursed Opinions, horrible Uncleannesses, Bloody Murders and Slaughters have
been conceived and brought forth from the Spirit within, and Revelations from
Devilish Lights and Spirits, etc.

Answ. Let all the Moderate and Sober Christians Judge here of R. W.'s words,
and what work he has made against Peter's Doctrine, who says, That they have
a More sure Word of Prophecy, which they do well to take heed unto, as unto a
Light, till the Day dawn, and the Day Star arise in their hearts: which we do
own and stand unto. Now he calls this a Simple Image, a Mere Baby, a Child's
Puppet; and he would make this Light and Spirit the Author of Murder and
Bloodshed, and Cursed Opinions, and likewise the Author of Devilish Lights and
Spirits: see, how he blasphemeth Peter's Doctrine with Devilish Lights and
Spirits, Murders, Slaughters! he might have applied it at home to his own
Spirit and the New-England-Priests and Professors, (as in page 98.) -- And thou
bring Rev. 19. The Testimony of Jesus is the Spirit of Prophecy: and then in
the Margent thou say [ The workings of Satan by his Spirit and Inspirations
in all Ages] but not by the Testimony of Jesus, p. 99.
the Testimony of Prophecy R. W. but by such a Spirit, as thou art in. And thou
say --

R. W. Does not the Angel forbid John Worshipping of him? etc.

Answ. But has R. W. and his New-England-Priests forbidden this Worship? and
art not thou offended in speaking the Word Thee and Thou to every Body, and for
want of the Hat and Knee? etc. and thou have publicly declared thy self, that
we might be punished for not doing these things. But would not thou and the
New-England-priests and Professors be honored with Hat and Knee? and yet John
was not to bow down to the Angel.

R. W. And thou go on Railing, and say; And shall we say, that the Angels
too are Quakers? and Christ has Enlightened them also, as well as every Man?
etc.

Answ. where did ever we say, the Angels were Quakers? is there any such thing
in G. F.'s Reply to Hosanna, let the Reader see. But were not all things made
by Christ Jesus? and did not Christ, who is God, who made them, enlighten them?
if not, how should they see their Work they are to do, who are called
Ministering Spirits, Flames of Fire, etc. ( Hebr.)

R. W. And then thou tellest, G. F. mentions Cain and Balaam and Ko^e.

Answ. And very well he may Use it to thee, and to our Old Persecutors, and
such as thou and the New-England-Priests, who gainsay the Light of Christ, and
the Law of the Spirit (which makes us free from Sin and Death) as Core did the
Law of Moses: And we have not mist you, for you are worse, then Core, who did
not call the Law of God an Idol and a Fancy; as thou have called the Light of
Christ over and over in thy Book. And all the Prophets of God from the
Beginning of the World, they spoke from an Inward Sight and Light of God in
their hearts, which is heard, known and seen by the Light and Spirit of God in
the heart, which leads into the Truth of them: and thou, that would not
hear the Light within, and take heed unto in the dark place; thou would not
hear the Prophets and Christ Jesus, from whence it comes: And so Remember
Dives. And --

R. W. goes on Railing and says, G. F. is so used to Cursing, etc.

Answ. But let the Reader see, Whether there be any such words of Cursing in G.
F.'s Answer in page 97? -- And so, as for Horrible Wickedness, their Lying
Father, Ugly Spiders, Poison and blind Dreamer, thou might have applied to
thy self. And --

R. W. thou say, What a madness is it for this Blind Dreamer to ask, Whether
the Scripture shines in a dark place, until the Day dawn, and the Day Star
arise in the heart? etc. and then thou say, p. 100
All the subtle Foxes in the World must know, that if they attend unto
Whisperings and Peepings, and leave the Written Law, etc. and other Prophecies
of Scripture, etc. for all their Childish Vapourings and Prating of their
Light, the Eternal Father of Lights proclaims them to be Children of howling
Darkness, and that there is no Light within them. And thou say, He that
shall find a spark of true Light etc. in this their Fantastic Light, he shall
find the Living among the Dead, and prove the Prophets of God, and God, (whose
Word was Spoken) to be Liars, for saying, There is no Light within them.

Answ. All this Blasphemy and Railing is not so much against the Quakers, but
against Peter's Doctrine, to wit, the Light, which the Saints did and were to
Take heed unto, until the Day dawn, and the Day Star arise in their hearts. And
R. W. goes about to give Peter the Lie, and would seem to prove it by the Law
of God and his Prophets; but by this he has proved himself a Liar, and one
that hates the Light. And he brings Esa 8; but let him see, it is said in
the Margent there, And there is no Morning in them, if they speak not according
to the Law and Prophets; so we may speak to him. And R. W. this is not in him,
who speaks not according to the Law and Prophets, Christ and his Apostles:
for the Light, that Peter speaks of, that shines in Darkness (which they are
to take heed unto, until the Day dawn, and the Day Star arise) this was before
the Morning; they were come to the Morning. And so he gives Peter the Lie, and
John the Lie, and abuses Esaiah's Words, what John says, This was the true
Light (which he bore witness to) that Lights every Man, which was the Life in
the Word: and R. W. with all his Evil Speakings witnesses against it, and
calls it a Fantastic Light, a Childish Vapor, and Whispering and Peeping;
but he might have kept this at home. And [ The Father of Lights (he says)
proclaims us to he Children of howling Darkness, and that there is no Light
in them.] Answ. The Father of Lights proclaims no such thing, nor his Son;
but says: Every One, that does the Truth, comes to the Light; and every one,
that does Evil, hates the Light, and will not come to it, because it reproves
him: And this is R. W.'s Condition.

R. W. asks,, What Light have the Papists, Jews and the Devil, when they
bring Scripture to Christ? -- and so falls a railing.

Answ. But if the Jews and Papists do hate the Light, like R. W. yet I never
heard the Jews and Papists call it an Idol, and a frantic Light, as R. W.
does: and we say, neither he, nor the Papists or Jews can see neither the
Scriptures, nor Christ without the Light. And we never did say, That Christ did
enlighten the Devil himself with his true Light; for Christ says, There is no
Truth in him: but R. W. says, That there is something of God, that is, from
the Power and Wisdom of God, in the fallen Spirits and the Devils themselves;
which we Charge R. W. and all his New-England-Priests to give us Scripture for
those Words (as in his Append. p. 5:) and therefore why does R. W. ask G. F.
What Light has the Devil himself? And thou say, The Devil brings a
pertinent Scripture and Promise to Christ Jesus, as ever the Papists or
Quakers: This R. W. might have kept at home, with the Jesuitical, Diabolical
Reservations, and venomous and poisonous, with his Unsavory, Ungratious words.

R. W. brings Enoch Howet ( G. F. Fol. p. 14.) his sayings [ The Scriptures
to be the Only Weapon, whereby Christ overthrew the Devil.] G. F. Answ. [Who
bruiseth his Head (to wit Christ) was, before the Scripture was: yet the
Scripture is for Correction and Doctrine, furnishing the Man of God in his
place. And Christ the Seed was, before the Scripture was: and all that have
Scripture, and not Christ, cannot Overcome the Devil (ye and the Papists doing
his Work.) For they that Overcome him, it is with the Power of Christ [for
Christ says, Without me ye can do nothing:] and those have the Scriptures of
Truth, which the Devil is out of.] R. W.'s Reply: How does Christ's bruising of
Satan's Head, and being before Scripture was, disprove, etc. and so falls
a-railing; p. 101.
Who sees not Fox in his Borough?

Answ. R. W. does not or will not state G. F.'s words right, as he has spoken
them; as the Reader may see, viz: [ As Christ, who bruiseth his Head, being
before Scripture was] who bruiseth his Head by his Power, and destroys Death,
and the Devil, the Power of Death: who is manifest in Time, etc. And --

R. W. says; As for G. F.'s saying, [They that have the Scripture, and not
Christ, cannot overcome the Devil.] (And R. W. Replieth) What News does he tell
the World, which no body denies? and yet thou say again; How does this
deny, that Christ Jesus overcame the Devil by Scripture? [ which is the Sword,
the Only Sword, and is called a Sword, Append. p. 88.]

Answ. But R. W. thou must show us a Rule for it in Scripture, Chapter and
Verse, That the Scripture is the Sword, the Only Sword: and yet thou say (
Append. p. 94.) That it ( the Scripture) does not avail without the Spirit of
God. And how does this hang together R. W? That they that have the Scripture
without the Spirit, cannot overcome the Devil: and yet, The Scripture is the
Sword, and the Only Sword, by which Christ overcame the Devil? and, The
Scripture does not avail without the Spirit; and yet it is thy Only Sword? [and
in thy Book called Experiments (Epist. to Lady Vane the Younger, 1652) thou
say, That the Two-edged Sword is of his (God's) most Holy Spirit, which
pierces between the very Soul and Spirit, etc.] But these things are Answered
more Largely in the Appendix.

R. W. says; Is all Scripture or Writing given forth by Inspiration of God,
and is profitable ( though G. F. alleges the Scriptures by Halves) for
Correction and Doctrine, etc. and, Then it clearly follows, that as Christ
Jesus overcame the Devil by the Scriptures, so etc.

Answ. Christ was the Power of God: and the Devil brought Scripture to him and
said, It is written; but Christ overcame him by the Power, who is the Substance
of the Scriptures: And Christ through Death destroyed the Devil, the Power of
Death; and was that by Scripture? And G. F. does confess, he does not write all
the Scriptures, which thou Scoffingly call Halves; neither does R. W. write
all the Scriptures, nor half neither: And Christ did not Overcome the Devil by
the Scripture, when he corrected him by Scripture in his Power and Spirit. And
the Apostle says, All Scripture given forth by Inspiration of God, is
profitable for Doctrine, Reproof, for Correction, for Instruction in
Righteousness, that the Man of God may be perfect, and thoroughly furnished to
all good Works (2 Timothy 3.) and this he does not say to the Men of the World,
that be in the Evil Work, like R. W. and his New-England-Priests and Professors
are.

R. W. And thou say; So, by the same Weapon this Subtle Fox and all other of
Satan's Foxes must be corrected, confuted, caught and destroyed (except they
repent) for ever.

Answ. What! must the Scripture destroy us? and that which is of no value
without the Spirit of God R. W? but this is Answered (as I said before) Largely
in the Appendix.

R. W. And with Scoffing words to no purpose thou say; How he runs in and
out of his Holes, etc. As for the Quakers Power here pretended in Opposition to
the Scriptures, etc. and, Thus sometimes a Devil of Drunkenness, Swearing,
Stealing runs away from the Sermons of the Quakers, as a Naughty Devil,
sometimes as the Chiding and Conjuring of a good Witch, that he may get the
faster hold by etc. Self-Conceit and Contradiction to the Scriptures, p. 102.
by Will Worship and superstitious Inventions against the Holy Institutions and
Commands of the true Lord Jesus Christ.

Answ. R. W. and his New-England-Priests and Professors might have all those
Ungracious, Unsavory Words kept at home. But what is this good Witch he
speaks of? for we own the Holy Scriptures, and the Commands etc. of the true
Lord Jesus Christ, and his Worship in Spirit and Truth: And if thou had
Overcome the Devil by the Only Sword of the Scripture, we should never have
such Railing Expressions from thee, which proceed from him. -- And thou tell
a Story of the Devil, and how a Child lies down and cries; but thou might
have kept this at home, with all the rest of thy Railing Language: for thou,
who have him so often in thy Mouth, its like, thou art more acquainted with
him, than with Christ and his Light. And R. W. must not be called a Railer; not
He, but it is We must be the Railers: but see, if he finds any such words here
in G. F.'s Reply to Enoch Howet. And --

R. W. brings Francis Duke ( Fol. page 189.) saying, [ When Christ told the
Devil, that Man should not live by Bread alone, bu^ by every Word, that
proceeds out of the Mouth of God; That wa^ Be^ieving the Scripture: and this
Word of God in the Scripture was the Ground of Christ's Faith; and so to all,
that are his.] G. F. Answ. [Many may have the Scripture, and never hear the
Voice o^ God, as the Jews, Joh. 5. and they said, they believed the Scriptures;
though they were out of the true Belief. But receiving the Word from God, is as
they, that gave forth the Scriptures, which Man lives by, and not by Bread
alone; and so knows him, who was, before Scripture was given forth. And for
saying, That the Scripture was the Ground of Christ's Faith; he was, before the
Scripture was writ, and so fulfilleth their Words, and is the Author and
Finisher of the Saints Faith, which was, before the Scripture was given forth:
he by whom the World was made, is the Author of the Saints Faith, that bruiseth
the Serpent under his Feet, etc.] And R. W. Replieth, and falls arailing and
says; How Notorious for Tautologies are these Brutish Clamors! shall we
believe their Notorious Lies? etc. and so goes on railing and cries,
Childish, etc. Ancient, Doting Women, etc. so full of Idle Repetitions: and
cries, How brutish and impious, viz: That a Man may have the Scriptures, and
yet not be in the Belief; therefore the Word of God was not the Ground of
Christ's Belief? and again; The Devil and the Wicked Men may have the
Scriptures, and not Believe in them; and therefore Christ Jesus and the Saints
Believe them not neither.

Answ. This is a False Inference of thine, as to say, Christ and the Saints did
not believe the Scriptures; the Reader may see, there is no such thing in G.
F.'s Answer: and do not thou confess, That (many) they may have the
Scriptures, and not overcome the Devil? (p. 101.) But did those Jews, that
Persecuted Christ, and his Apostles and Prophets, Truly Believe in Christ? --
Now, as for Tautologies, and the Doting Woman, with Idle Repetitions thou
may apply to thy self: for how often in thy Book do thou call over and
over the Light of Christ an Idol, a Frantic Light? And read page 109. in
Append* and there thou may see thy Tautologies; Quakers, Papists, Papists
and Quakers, Papists, etc. where he mentions the Quakers and Papists a matter
of Twelve times over, as though R. W. would fill up his Book with it: and let
the Reader see most of the Pages throughout his Book, whether he has not done
the same. And R. W. may note, how often David and the Holy Men of God go over
the same thing; and the Apostles mention often the Name of Jesus: and if R. W.
and his New-England-Priests do say, That these are Notorious Lies, that which
G. F. says (as the Reader may see in his Answer) viz. [" Many may have the
Scriptures and hear not the Voice of God.] This is a Notorious Lie by R. W. (as
in Joh. 5.) [And the Jews would say, They Believed Scriptures; though they were
out of the True Belief and Receiving Christ, the Word of God: and Christ in
plain Words told them, They were of their Father, the Devil;] This is another
Lie of R. W. and the New-England-Priests. [But Receiving the Word from God, is
as they, that gave forth the Scriptures, (that received his Word, which Man
lives by, and not by Bread only;] And these R.W. calls Notorious Lies: [and
so knows him, that was, before Scripture was given forth (to wit, Christ] and
these R. W. says, are Notorious Lies. [And they say, that Christ was, before
the Scripture was writ, and fullfilleth the words, to wit, the Scripture:] This
is a Notorious Lie; shall we believe those Notorious Lies? says R. W. [and is
the Author and Finisher (to wit, Christ) of the Saints Faith.] Shall we believe
these Notorious Lies? etc. And --

R. W. thou say, Shall we believe their Notorious Lies, that the Light
within gave forth the Scripture? and that they speak and write, as they are
moved by the Spirit, when their Writings are so weak? etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if there be any such thing in G. F.'s Answer, That
the Light within us gave forth Scripture? but it was the Holy Ghost in the
Prophets and Apostles, that gave forth Scriptures; and with the Light of Christ
we see them, and are led into all Truth by the Holy Ghost. And again, as for
Tautologies, R. W. may read his page 84. of his Book, and see, where he 11 or
12 times goes over Juggler and Cheater, Juggler and Cheater, etc. in one and
the same page.

R. W. begins with Railing: Let Heaven and Earth hear and abhor the
Sophistry of these Deceivers! they would fain have no such Christ as Man, p.
103.
a Christ without, an Outside Christ, etc. And then thou contradictest thy
self and say, That We confess, that there was such a Man or Person, who came
according to Gal. 4.

Answ. Which we really believe: and we do not Cloak nor Cross our Principle in
saying, That Christ was before the Scripture; but thou wrongst G. F.'s words
again. For his words are not, That Christ bruised the Serpent's Head before the
Scripture was; but, Christ was, before the Scripture was; who bruiseth the
Serpent's head: for all things were made by Christ, (as the Reader may see page
102.) And does not Christ say, Before Abraham was, I am? And as for Sophistry,
and Deceiving, and speaking of an Outside Christ, those are thy own Railing
Words, not ours; and does not become an Old Man, nor Christian.

R. W. Let any of these Jugglers answer, if they speak honestly; If there was
really such a Man called Jesus at Jerusalem? etc.

Answ. R. W. begins with Railing here: but seeing, he querieth of us, we
shall answer him and all the World. We do believe, there was Such a Man, who
was born in Bethlehem, Christ Jesus, suffered without the Gates of Jerusalem,
after the Scripture was written: who was tempted of the Devil, and the Devil
brought Scripture to him; and Christ Reproved him with Scripture, and Overcame
him by his POWER. And Christ died and rose, and fulfilled the Prophets, and at
the Right Hand of God: who is the same that Descended, the same that Ascended.
But where does R. W. prove by the Scriptures, (and the New-England-Priests)
That the Scriptures were the Ground of Christ's Faith? this we must have
Scripture for, before we can receive it from R. W. and his New England priests,
to wit, That the Scripture is the Ground of Christ's Faith, and the Ground of
the Saints Faith: and yet he says, The Scripture avails nothing; is of no
value without the Spirit, etc: ( Append. p. 94.) And further we say: If the
Scripture was the Ground of the Saints Faith, and the Scripture avails
nothing without the Spirit; How was it, that the Pharisees and the Papists
(whom thou mentionest so often) had not Faith from that Ground? for they all
say, they believe Scripture. But what must we Observe from R. VV.'s Words here?
That the Scripture is the Ground of Christ's Faith? and yet he will
acknowledge, Christ was before Scripture; and Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, Abel,
Enoch and Noah had Faith, before Scripture was written. And now, if Christ be
the Author and Finisher of the Saints Faith, and they are to look unto him, I
query, Whether he be Scripture, if it be the Ground of the Saints Faith? And
the Spirit of God, which lead his Saints to give forth Scriptures, leads into
all Truth of them. And the Spirit and the Scriptures are not at Odds one with
another, neither did we ever set them so, as thou us in Effect chargest:
neither can the Children of God know the Scriptures given forth by the Spirit
of God, but by the Spirit of God within (which thou scoffingly call a Secret
Whispering Voice within, contrary to Scriptures.) And the Voice, that owneth
not the Scripture, is not the Voice of the Spirit of God, that gave them forth
both before Christ's Coming in the Flesh and since. And --

R. W. As to the Spirit's Leading into all Truth the Sons of God, thou
answerest and say; Is not Fox here in his Borough, not distinguishing
betwixt the Extra-ordinary Leading of the Holy Apostles appointed to be the
Eyewitnesses of Christ's Death and Resurrection? etc.

Answ. What must we Infer from R. W's. Words? That because the Leading of the
Apostles and Preaching the Resurrection of Christ Jesus by the Holy Ghost, that
others therefore were not reproved by the holy Ghost? and must not every Son of
God be led into all Truth to know Christ and his Resurrection? but G. F. does
not say, that all were Messengers and Apostles, etc. (1. Cor. 12.) And thou
^urther say; Yet all God's Children are Regenerated and Sanctified; p. 104.
[and do thou not say in another place, They must have a Combat all their
Life?] and thou say, That God's Children are Guided and Built up together an
Habitation; etc. And then R. W. must not the Spirit of God be within? and if
so, then thou ownest the Quakers Principle, and confessest that, which thou all
this while have been fighting against. And as for what David said, if he had
been in thy Day, thou would have cried against him, as thou do against us,
who said; I have hid thy Word in my Heart.

R. W. And this is the Devil's ( the Old Fox) his Devilish Subtlety, to make
the Cloak of the Spirit's extra-ordinary Assistance, etc. and the Angels
Extra-ordinary Protection a Ground of Christ Jesus and his Servants flinging
themselves down from the Pinnacle of the Temple: and thou pretendest to tell us
from God, that this will be the Break-neck of the People called Quakers
(without Repentance) every Soul of them.

Answ. How now R. W! have thou not here given rash Judgment against the
Assistance, and Protection and Sufficiency of the Spirit of Christ and his
Grace, which God says, is Sufficient to Paul in his Trouble? And have not thou
broken thy own Neck here, and falln down from the Pinnacle, who do not look
at the Grace of God, and his Light and Spirit to be Sufficient? Is it
sufficient to condemn them, that Err from the Spirit, and turn the Grace of
God into Wantonness? And God sent an Angel, and brought the Children of Israel
out of Egypt: and ( Exodus 23, 20.) Behold! I send an Angel before thee, to keep
thee in the Way: (verse. 23.) For my Angel shall go before thee, and bring thee,
etc. and Chap. 22, 24: And behold! my Angel shall go before thee: And was not
this Angel sufficient to bring them into the Land of Canaan, if they hearkened
unto him? and is not Christ Sufficient by his Light, Power and Spirit to bring
us out of Spiritual Egypt? and Christ says to his Sheep, that hear his Voice;
I give unto them Eternal Life, and they shall never perish; neither shall any
man pluck them out of my Hand (John 10, 28.) But R. W. how can thou say, Thou
passest thy false Judgment upon us from the God of Truth; and yet say, There
is no Voice nor Motion within to be lissen'd, or hearkened unto in Heavenly
Things, in Matters that are Super natural? (page 83.)

R W. Thou say; Our Principles and Practices are f^ll of Contradiction and
Hypocrisy.

Answ. Our Principles and Professi^n are Holy and Pure; and Contradictions and
Hyppocrisy thou might have kept at Home: for we Profess the Lord Jesus
Christ, and all the Prophecies and Things in the Law, that Figured them forth;
and the Things in the Law, as truly, as the Prophets and the Apostles did
Profess him: and own all that is Written in the Scriptures from Genesis to
Revelation. And we own the Worship in the Spirit and Truth, and are in it, that
Christ set up Sixteen-hundred Years since; and the Religion, that the Apostle
describes above Sixteen-hundred Years since, which is Pure and Undefiled
before God: And the One Faith, which Christ is the Author of; and the One
Baptism, and the One Spirit into One Body: and One God and Father of All, who
is above All, and through All, and in you All, as the Apostle speaks. And the
Lord Jesus Christ, who was Born of the Virgin, Conceived by the Holy Ghost;
etc. and Preached, and Suffered under Pontius Pilate, before whom he made a
Good Confession: and Died, and Rose again, and is at the Right Hand of God; and
remains in the Heavens, till all things are Restored: etc. who will Judge the
World in Righteousness, and Reward every Man according to his Works; and
therefore no Salvation in any other Name, but in the Name of Jesus, etc. And
let New-England-Professors see, if our Principles and Practice, Life and
Doctrine has not Out-stript theirs; let the Witness of God in them Answer! And
--

R. W. says; He told us of False Gods, and Worships and Prophets, etc. [but
this is nothing to the Purpose to prove his False Charge: for we are Not to
Believe thee and the False Prophets; but to Try them:] but thou say; We must
Try them with Fire it self.

Answ. Yea R. W. Ye and the New-England-Priests did Try us, God's True
Prophets, with FIRE; whom ye Tried with your HOT IRON, when ye BRANDED them,
and your GALLOWS, when you HANGED them: And so ye are TRIED not to be in the
true Principles and Profession of the Apostles and of Christ. And did not
thou say before, That the Scripture was to Try? and what R. W! is the Scripture
now become a FIRE? where is that written? But the Counterfeit, and the Dross,
and the Devil himself, as black a Fiend, etc. the Spirit of Darkness, Samuel's
Mantle, thou speak of, and Sheeps-Cloathing, and Deceiving and Covering your
Black Spirit withal; and then thou say: Thou told'st us, 'Twas Common for
the Papists and Turks; and Judas betraying his Master with a Kiss, and a many
such like Words (but we do remember few:) but this is nothing to prove our
Principles and Profession, what others were. And --

R. W. Thou say; Thou Remembrest, thou told'st us, That Paul tells Timothy
of some, that speak Lies in Hypocrisy; [What is this to us? this is thy own
Condition; this is no Proof:] and of Such, p. 105.
as knowingly ( for Devilish and Wicked Ends, and Preferment and Profit) take
the Leading-Staff in the Hand, etc. and then thou Tell of the Pope's and
Cardinals, and of Judas his Gain, that betrayed Christ, etc. of the Sechemites
and their Successors; of Nebuchadnezar's Idolatry, etc. And further, thou
Tell us of such, that the Lord Jesus Christ has positively foretold of,
that they should think to do God Service, to Kill himself in Killing his
Servants.

Answ. But R. W. gives us no Scripture for this, To Kill himself in Killing
his Servants; (except he means them in New England, that Crucified Christ
first to Themselves, and then Killed his Servants:) but all this is nothing to
us. Here thou do Confess and Wonder, that We bore all this Load of Stories,
which was to no purpose: therefore thou might very well Wonder at their
Patience: but R W. had not W. E. and the rest (which thou scoffingly say,
Broke out) Reason to call thee to prove thy Charge, when thou had run so far
beside the Matter? And we are, as we were, when we First came amongst you. And
--

R. W. Thou say, Thou told'st us, that we were Charged with denying the Man
Christ Jesus. p. 106.
But --

( Answ.) We say, thy Charge is False: For we own Christ, that died at
Jerusalem, more than thou and the New-England-Priests, as we said before; and
there is no such thing neither in G. F.'s nor in any of our Books. And let the
Reader see, whether there be any such Words in G.F.'s Book? It is R.W.'s own
false Charging to prove his Assertions. And our Books hold forth (without
Juggling, as thou Falsely Chargest us) Church-Ministry, Baptism, etc.
Resurrection, Eternal Judgment, Eternal Life now, and in the World to come.

R. W. And thou say; We deny any Church, but that Invisible.

Answ. The Church is in God; but their Bodies are Visible (1 These. 1.) And so
thy Principles are False, and thy Profession, that is not according to the
Apostle's. And that, which keeps us together in the Fellowship and Unity, is
the Spirit; which, as it does Move us, we Pray, we Preach, we Sing, as the Holy
Men of God did, who spoke, as the Spirit of God gave them Utterance: And this
is according to the Primitive Sense, Principle and Profession; though thou
may say Monstrous and Dissimulation. And we do pro^ess we have an Unction;
and Christ enlightneth every one, that comes into the world (and this as in
John 1.2.); and this is according to Sound Principle, and the Profession of the
Holy Men of God: and thou deniest this, and art in a false principle and
profession, contrary to the Apostle's.

R. W. And further thou say, That Christ, and the Spirit, and the Kingdom of
Heaven is in them ( as the Pharisees had, and the very same the Saints have.)

Answ. These are thy false professions and principles, and not ours. But that
which we do profess, we shall manifest; Know ye not, that Christ is in you,
except ye be Reprobates? And, He that has not the Spirit of Christ, is none of
his: And thou that deniest this to the Saints, art of a false principle and
profession, contrary to the Apostle. And Christ said, The Kingdom of Heaven was
in the Pharisees ( Luke 17.); but neither Christ nor We say, That Christ was in
them, as he was in the Saints: and the Pharisees, and their going from, and
hating the Light, which Christ has enlightened them withal, they are condemned
by the Light, and not Justified.

R. W. And then thou Scoffest at the Quakers She-Apostles and He-Apostles sent
into New England, Ireland, Scotland, Italy, p. 107.
and Turkey, etc.

Answ. Yea, they are gone thither, where R. W. and the New-England-Priests
durst not show their Heads (though they may Rail against the Turk and Pope
behind their Backs,) your Spirits are too Cowardly: And by all this thou have
not disproved our principles and profession. And we believe, if R. W. had been
in the Days of the Apostles, he would have joined with the Scribes and
Pharisees against Christ Jesus; and have Railed against Christ and his
Disciples, and against Mary Magdalen and other Women, that preached the
Resurrection of Christ Jesus.

R. W. Thou say, We profess the Scriptures to be the Words of God, and not
the Word ( and therefore We are in a false Principle and Profession.)

Answ. Are we? Is this thy Proof? And does not the Scriptures (which thou
say, is the Rule and Touchstone) themselves call a Declaration the Words of
God and Christ? Nay, do not thou call it an History? And so thou, that
call the Scriptures with other Names, than the Holy Men of God have called
them, thou art in a false profession, not we; who speak otherwise than the
Scripture speaks. And where did ever we say, If all the Scripture was burnt,
we have the Scriptures within us? We charge thee to make this good by any of
our Books or Writings; until then, we look upon thee as one that has Slandered
us to the World: And we abhor thy words, as Burning the Scriptures; and yet we
must not deny Knowing the Scriptures by the Spirit of God within.

R. W. And so thou say, By deceitful Owning and not Owning, as G. F. in his
late Book Exalting the Heathen --

Answ. This is thy false Charge: for we Really Own the Scriptures. And G. F.
Magnifieth the Lord, and Exalts that of God in the Heathen, which was
condemned by such, as thou and the New-England-Priests, that have no Scripture.
As, let the Reader read over the Book called Heathens Divinity, and let him
see, whether he does Exalt the Heathen, or the Lord on their behalf.

R. W. And thou say; How full are their Books against Persecutors.

Answ. And well they may be, for we have felt the stroke of it, even to DEATH
in New England; amongst whom there is manifest, both their Profession and
Principle to be False, and not according to the Primitive Church.

R. W. He brings ( G. F.'s Fol. 170.) John Stallam, saying: [ The Magistrate
is not to level the Law with the Light in every Man's Conscience. Again, If the
Magistrates be in the Light, and discern the Mind of Christ, and discern his
Law, is he to Compel all the Nation and Commonwealth to come to the Practice
of his Light?] G. F. Answers: [The Magistrate of Christ, the Help-Government
for him, he is in the Light and Power of Christ: and he is to subject all under
the Power of Christ into his Light, else he is not a Faithful Magistrate, (to
wit, the Higher Power.) And his Laws are Agreeable, and Answerable according to
that of God in every Man: p. 108.
When men act contrary to it, they do Evil. So he is a Terror to the
Evildoers, and discerns the Precious and the Just from the Vile: and this is
a Praise to them that do well.]

[ I Query of R. W. Whether the Fundamental Laws are not according to the
Spirit of God and Scripture? whether it is not said, The Laws of England hang
upon these two Hinges? and then, Whether Magistrates must not be according to
the Laws? And the Higher Power never did the Prophets cry against, but the
Corruption in Magistrates: neither does G. F. as here was testified in OLIVER's
Days, when these Priests-Opposers said, That we denied Magistrates. But R. W.
Must not the Christian Magistrates be in the Light of Christ? and must they not
punish Evildoers; to wit, Adultery, Fornication, Theft, Murder? etc. and are
not these Actions Contrary to Christ? And then, if they punish these things; do
not they subject unto the Light of Christ? For our Principle is, To bring all
people from those, and other Evils: Or, must not these Evils be punished, and
the Magistrate of the Laws keep down such Evils with his Higher Power? etc. But
what is this to matter of Religion, seeing R. W. says, That they are a Praise
of them that Do Well? Such as Do Well, walk in the Light, and walk in the
Spirit, that mortifieth Sin; and worship God in Spirit and Truth: Such the
Magistrate is a Praise unto, and does not Punish; except they turn their Sword
backward, (as the New-England-Priests) and let Evildoers at Liberty: But more
of this hereafter.] But let the Reader see, if there be any such thing in G.
F.'s Answer to John Stallam, That G. F. intends there, p. 139.
that Magistrates, in Christ must fight for their Christ against all Opposers.

Answ. This is R. W.'s false Surmising Charge: but these are the
New-England-Men, that Fight for their Religion and false Christ. But G. F.
says, The Magistrates in the Light are for the punishing of the Evil doers, as
the Apostle says. And will not R. W. have the Christian Magistrates enlightened
by Christ? and to have the Higher Power, that they may punish Drunkards,
Perjurous persons, Whoremongers and Thieves? etc. for such is G. F. speaking
of: he does not speak of Religion, and the worship of God, as the unprejudiced
Reader may see his Words.

R. W. Brings (Fol. G. F. p. 221) Hosannah, etc. saying: [ They know not
Absolute Perfection, that are admitting of Measures and Degrees; or come to the
Day of the Bright Morning Star: and the Bright Morning Star is not Risen.] G.
F. answers [Did not the Apostle speak, that they were Children of the Day,
and the Night was over, and knew the whole Body; and yet said, he would not go
beyond his Measure? and does he not speak of the Stature, and Measure and
Fullness of Christ? were they not come to Perfection* and spoke Wisdom among
them that were Perfect?] And R. W. Replieth, and falls a-Railing (his Wonted
Course) Monstrous Pride, etc. and then thou ask, whether Paul speaks of
his Measure in Holiness, or no?

Answ. What should it be in else? But R. W. is this thy Way to prove thy false
Assertions by asking of Questions? But let R. W. show these Words [ Omnipotent,
Omnipresent, Omniscient] in G. F.'s Book, or any other of our Books, where we
say, That we are in Power Omnipotent, Omnipresent and Omniscient, as he
charge us? And G. F. speaks of the Perfection, that God, and Christ and the
Apostles exhort unto. And thou make a great Story about Perfection; but to no
purpose. And Paul (says he) spoke Wisdom among them that were Perfect; but not
that Wisdom of this World, which denies Perfection. And as for all thy Railing
Expression and Unsavory Language, they are all returned home again to thee;
thou had better, to have kept them within. And where does G. F. say, That a
Child though Perfect, is equal to a Man? or a Cup is equal to a Tun or Pipe? p.
110.
all this thou might have kept at home: this is no Proof against our
Principle and Profession. As for Bl^ckish, Blasphemous Fallacy and
Contradictions R. W. thou might have kept at home thy Railing Expressions,
it does not become thy Gray Hairs; but that the whole Body may be known, which
serve to Complete the Saints into an Entire Stature (see Ephesians. 3, 18, 19. Col.
2, 10. and 4, 12.) and yet here may be a Growth still ( Ephesians. 4.13, 14.)

R. W. brings Hosannah, etc. ( G.F. Fol. p. 222.) saying [Christ is without
his Saints in Respect of his Bodily Presence.] G. F. Answ. [How are they Flesh
of his Flesh, and Bone of his Bone? How can they Eat of his Flesh, and Drink
his Blood? And how have they his Mind and Spirit, and he in them, and they in
him? and sitting in Heavenly Places? And he is the Head of his Church; and how
then is he Absent, ye poor Apostates from him, that feel not Christ! But he is
with the Saints, and they feel him.] And R. W. replieth, and asks; Is this
Eating of the Flesh of Christ, and Drinking his Blood Corporal (or Visible) or
Spiritual?

Answ. Why! Do not thou know R. W. Christ says, His Words are Spirit and
Life? And is this thy Proving, when to prove thy Charges, thou art asking
Questions? We tell thee, None can eat the Flesh of Christ without Faith. And
thou further Beggest Questions concerning a sitting in Heavenly Places in
Christ Jesus: We tell thee, the Apostle speaks, We sit together in Heavenly
Places in Christ Jesus ( Ephesians. 2.) and, He that Sanctifies, and they that are
Sanctified, are all of One (the Hebr. tells thee.) And we hold, that Christ
is the Head of the Church, as the Apostle did; and we do not direct you to the
Pope: But we bid you, Repent, and turn you from Darkness to Light, and so to
Christ; whom ye must come to know, Christ the Head. And did not the Heavens
open, so that Steven saw Christ by the Holy Ghost, at the Right Hand of God?
And what Body was that, that some did Eat (as the Apostle says) as ate and
drank Unworthily, nor discerning the Lord's Body? and then must not the Lord's
Body be discerned by True Believers? and was not this after Christ was
Ascended? And the Ground of R. W. and the persecuting Priests is, They would
neither have Christ, nor his Light to be within them; nor to feed upon his
Heavenly Bread, which comes from Heaven, which he calls his Flesh; nor drink
his Blood, which is the Saints Food, upon which they Live. And the Jews said of
Christ, How can we eat his Flesh? and so persecuted the Apostles, which were of
his Flesh and Bones.

R. W. falls a railing, and says; An Adulterous Wretch accuses Joseph of
Whoredom, etc. who was a Pattern of pure and holy Chastity: p. 111.
For, whom do these Whorish Brood of Foxians brand for Apostates, and fling
among them Firebrands, Arrows and Death?

Answ. This is R. W.'s and his New-England-Priests and Professors Condition; he
might well have kept this at home, who is Adulterated from the Light and Spirit
of Christ Jesus, and calls it an Idol. And now flingeth his and their
Firebrarnds at such, as be in the Purity and holy Chastity of Joseph, against
the Children of God, whom we are. That Spirit in the Whorish Egyptians, the
Whorish Jews, you the Whorish New England Men and R. W. casts his Firebrarnds
after us; but that, which the New-England-Professors BRANDED them withal, their
Marks are to be seen this Day! And these Railing Expressions do not prove R.
W.'s Assertion; but prove his own Principles false, and his Profession Railing.
And the Souls under the Altar, those that kept the Testimony of Jesus, as we
have done against Deluders (as thou speak of) and the First Churches, and
the Apostles of Christ, they did not call the Light of Christ an Idol; but they
saw Christ, who was Ascended into Heaven, and yet was manifest in them by his
Spirit. And the Apostle says, They came to sit down in Heavenly Places in
Christ Jesus (though he was Ascended into Heaven;) and was not this in Spirit?
And --

R. W. thou say, They mean no such Individual Man or Person, but a Mind and
Spirit; and such a Christ, as has no Individual, Bodily Presence, as we and
all men have.

Answ. Christ has no such Sinful Body, as all men have; If so, I would have R.
W. prove it by Scripture. But does not the Apostle say, He is made like unto
us, Sin excepted? But that by R. W. is left out; he would have his a
Corruptible Body, as himself (as we shall see hereafter, whether he does not
maintain Christ to have a Corruptible Body.) But we query of R. W. whether it
is not the Work of him (and all those Priests, that Opposed us in Oliver's
Days) to shut Christ and his Spirit, his Light and his Presence out from the
Saints? as is clearly seen: as one of these Priests Scoffingly and Carnally
said, How can a Man of four foot long be within us? And this is false for thee
to say, That we would have all the Saints of God to be Apostates, and fall from
God and Christ: Paul says, Christ is a Mystery; and so he is a Mystery still
to them, to whom he is not Revealed. And --

R. W. Thou say, If of G. F. when he is in New England, one should say, He
is in London in his Bodily Presence, and that his Friends feel'd his Bodily
Presence there, because they feel his Love and Affections there in their Minds
and Spirits, etc.

Answ. Is this a fit Comparison R. W? Does not the Apostle say of Christ, That
He is Ascended above All, that he might fill All? etc. and does not the Apostle
say, That they, that have no^ the Spirit of Christ, are none of his? And is not
he called the Heavenly Man? and is not he, as he is called the Heavenly Man,
the Head of the Church? is not he called the Second Man, the Lord from Heaven?
and the Apostle says; As we have born the Image of the Earthly, we shall bear
also the Image of the Heavenly: and now, The Saints shall bear the Image of the
Heavenly; my Query is, Whether Christ must bear the Image of the Earthly in
Heaven? (1 Cor. 15.) And --

R. W. Thou say, I will turn my Thoughts higher: O thou most Glorious Sun of
Righteousness, Truth and Holiness! shine forth, and let it be seen, how the
Devil calls the Lord Jesus Beelzebub.

Answ. But R. W. Do not thou Call the Lord Jesus Christ an Idol and a
Frantic Light? THOU art the Man. And do not thou say (in this page) his
People are Horrible, Egyptian, Canting (Languague,) Juggling, Whorish Brood,
Adulterous wretches, Whoredom, Firebrarnds? so thy High Thoughts are in the
Dirt; not fit, to take the Name of the Lord Jesus in thy Mouth. And --

R. W. Thou say, They boast with the Bloody Papists, and other Traitors and
Rebels against thee.

Answ. This thou might have applied to thy self and the New-England-Priests,
for it is thy own: for we have shed none of your BLOOD, the Lord knows it!
And when did we break down your Altars? and Burn your Temples and your Altars?
etc. R. W. Is not all this a false Profession and a false Principle? and is
this to prove our Profession and Principles full of Contradiction and
Hypocrisy? This is thy own Profession. And we do Challenge all you
New-England-Professors and Priests, what Altars have we broke down? and what
Temples have we burnt? etc? this is a Lying Spirit R. W. that leads thee, not
the Spirit of Christ.

R. W. Thou say, They cry up a false and Hellish Christ within them, p. 112.
etc. Christen him with the Name of Light.

Answ. R. W. Thou can not tell, how to invent Wicked Words enough against
the Lord Jesus Christ, that Died at Jerusalem, and is Risen, at the Right Hand
of God; who enlightneth every Man, that Comes into the World: surely, thy
Spirit would have Roared against the Apostle, if thou had been in his Day.
Now it is clear, thou neither ownest Scriptures, nor Christ there: And instead
of proving our Principles and Profession false, thou manifestest thy own to be
Wicked; and not so Wicked against us, but against the Lord Jesus Christ and his
Light, which he Lights every Man, that Comes into the World, withal. For (I
say) if thou had been in the Apostle's Days, he Preached Christ within the
Hope of Glory; and his Work was To present every Man Perfect in Christ Jesus:
and the Apostle said and told them, Christ was in them, except they were
Reprobates: and Christ said, I in you, and you in Me, etc. and prayed the
Father, That where he was, there they might be to behold his Glory: And what
do thou think, the Saints must behold his Glory now? And this Christ thou
call False and a Hellish Christ: O Wickedness! thou will find him a Heavy
Stone! Nay, do not thou call him a Conquered Slave? an Angel of Light? art
thou not worse than the Jews, that Crucified him, and Pilate? did they ever
give him such Names, as thou have done the Only Begotten Son of God? is this
thy N. England-Profession of the Only Begotten Son of God full of Grace and
Truth, which is manifest in his People? the LORD DELIVER all good Christians
from them! For we can expect no other Work, but what they have done (if R. W.
and their Principles be one concerning Christ Jesus, the Holy One of Israel)
but to HANG, BANISH, and WHIP, and BRAND with an HOT IRON, and SPOIL the GOODS
of the Members and Followers of Christ Jesus! Surely, all their Consciences are
not so seared with an Hot Iron, as R. W.'s is against the True Lord Jesus
Christ; who casts a Flood of Wickedness against him and his Light: but we
expect no other, it is nothing to us.

R. W. Brings James Brown, that says, [ The Kingdom of Heaven that is in the
Saints, is not in the Pharisees. (Fol. G. F. p. 259.] G. F. Answ. [That which
is in the Saints, is in the Pharisees in a Measure, though it be but as a Grain
of Mustard Seed, or as a Little Leaven: (But this is fully Answered in the
Append. where he brings it there.) And R. W. Replieth, and brings ( Luke
11.12.) Christ's Saying, If I by the Finger of God cast out Devils, no doubt,
the Kingdom of God is come upon you: And this R. W. Maliciously brings to
Oppose Christ's Words cited, when the Pharisees demanded of Christ, When the
Kingdom should come? he answered them and said; The Kingdom of Heaven comes
not with Observations, neither shall they say, Lo here, or Lo there: for
behold, the Kingdom of God is within you, (Luke 17.) Now, whether must we
believe Christ or R. W? And this he brings to Disprove our Principles and
Profession not to be True; and has here manifest his own Profession and
Principle not to be according to Christ. And --

R. W. Thou say, That the Pharisees expected a Temporal Kingdom: and yet
thou say, Christ's Visible Kingdom is his Church. And the Apostle tells
thee, His Kingdom stands in Power, etc. and the Holy Ghost; and what is
Visible, but Temporal? And we do not say, That the Pharisees had such a Kingdom
as the Saints, in Joy and Peace with the Holy Ghost; for their Darkness could
not comprehend the Light, therefore they were not like to receive such a
Kingdom. And what Kingdom was this in the Pharisees, if it was not a Measure of
the Seed, which Christ Sows in all Grounds, and of the Spirit, and of the
Light, which enlightneth every man that comes into the World?

R. W. And whereas thou Scoffingly say, What do We talk of Measures, but
that We are all one in Quality and Equality? etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if there be any such Words in G. F.'s Answer? R. W.
cannot bridle his Tongue, and keep in the Rule. But --

R. W. Thou say, What a Stinking Work do these proud Pharisees make of
Christianity! how justly, etc.

Answ. This R. W. might have applied at home, his Stinking Work and proud
Pharisees, etc. What! must not we own Christ's words, nor Scripture? Were not
they Fools, blind Guides and Pharisees, that would not own Christ's Doctrine?
and so it may be said Still of R. W.

R. W. Asks the Reason, Why this Seed does not Grow, and this Leaven does not
Spread within the Pharisees? Can a Nation be Subject to the King of England or
Spain, p. 113.
etc. and yet not know how? nor have no Knowledge or Feeling of it at all? Can
there be such a God, such a Spirit, such a Fire, ^ea, but such a Mustard Seed
or Leaven, such a Teacher, and yet not grow, not prevail, nor prosper, nor be
perceived? ye Fools and Blind! And so goes on a-railing to the end of page 113.

Answ. Here thou have manifest thy self to be as Blind as the Pharisees,
concerning the Doctrine of the Kingdom of Heaven within, as Christ preached.
For is it not the same Seed, that is sown upon all Sorts of Grounds by the
Seeds-Man; though Christ tell^th thee, Ye are Thorns and Stony Hearts, and what
ye do to the Seed? And is it not the same Light, that enlightneth every man
that comes into the World, which the Saints believed in; which Thou, and the
Pharisees and the New-England-Professors hate, and thou call an (...)? So
thy principle and profession is False, and not agreeable to the Primitive
profession and principle.

And is not the same Grace, which brings Salvation, appeared to All Men,
which the Wicked turn into Wantonness, and walk despitefully against it? And is
not the same Spirit, which is poured out upon All Flesh, by which the Sons and
Daughters Prophesy? etc. but if thou quenchest the Spirit, and turnest the
Grace of God into Wantonness, and the Carnal Mind choke the Seed, and err from
the Spirit, then thou may say; Why does it not Grow? Why does not Leaven
Spread? Why does it not Spring? Why don't it Grow? and, Why are they not
Subjects to the King? and yet thou art building the Tombs of the Righteous. And
all such, that err from the Spirit, turn the Grace of God into Wantonness, and
hate his Light, and by their Carnal Mind choke the Seed, and are Rebels to the
Kingdom of Heaven: and go, read the Talent of the Slothful Servant. However,
thou have improved the Devil's Talent, and hidden the Lord's, thou and the
New-England-Priests; and therefore ye persecute him with your Tongue and Hand:
and a many Unsavory Words, that are in this page, which are not worth
mentioning. And so in all this thou have proved thy self not to have the Spirit
of Christ Jesus; but an Opposer of his Doctrine, and proved thy own profession
and principle False, and contrary to Christ's and the Apostle's words.

R. W. Thou say, That the Quakers Religion is Heresy, p. 114.
and they themselves Heretics in the Matters of God's Worship.

Answ. The Religion we maintain, which the Apostles above 1600. years since set
up, which is Pure, etc. and therefore we forsake yours. And the Worship of God,
which Christ set up 1600. years ago, this we in Practice maintain: and we do
not differ from the Servants of God, the Prophets and Apostles; but we have
Unity with them in the Faith and Spirit of God, Glory to the Lord God for ever!
And we believe, we Shall prove thee in the Heresy thou speak of; which thou
confessest, John Stub stood up and said, That Heresy was defined by some, to be
an Opinion obstinately stood in against the First Christian Purity: and this
thou confessest too. First thou say R. W. That our Religion, Way or Sect was
False, etc. and upon this Ground R. W. will prove, Our Religion is not only
Heresy in Matters of Worship, but also in Doctrines of Repentance, Faith, etc.
Now come on R. Williams, make good thy Charge, and see, if thou have not thrown
thy self in the same Condition, as thou chargest us.

R. W. Thou say, First, as to Worship We deny the Converting or Gathering of
Saints into Visible Congregations, affirming the Church to be Invisible, the
Ministry Invisible, the Baptism and Supper Invisible.

Answ. Let the People in New-Eng^and Judge, whether we do not Gather people
into Visible Assemblies? let their Meetings there speak. And though we do say,
as the Apostle says (1 These. 1.2. 2 These. ^.) The Church is in God the Father
of our Lord Jesus Christ; yet the Saints Bodies were Visible upon the Earth:
and thou that deniest this Doctrine, deniest this Primitive Doctrine; and so
hold another Opinion, than the Apostles did: And the Ministers of Christ are
Ministers of the Spirit, though their Bodies be Visible, while they be upon
Earth. And we never said, That Outward Assemblies, or Outward Men, which did
eat Outward Bread and Wine, (which is Visible) were Invisible; this is a Lying
Charge from a Lying Spirit: But the Baptism with the Holy Ghost and with the
Spirit, which is the Baptism of Christ, we charge R. W. and his
New-England-Priests to prove that Visible, and by Scripture. But whom has R.
W. Converted in New England? who are his Assembly? if he cannot show them, his
Epistles, as the Apostles could, then he is gone away from the Institutions of
the Lord Jesus Christ and his Messengers, etc. and comes under his own Charge,
and not we: And where is the Assembly of R. W.'s, and with whom? And we tell R.
W. that he must come to Repentance from his Dead Works, and Faith toward God,
before he comes to know the Christians true Religion. And whereas --

R. W. speaks of the Two Doctrines of Laying on of Hands, and of Baptismes,
concerning the Circumstances of which God is pleased to permit his Children
lovingly differing and discussing, etc.

Answ. If these things, Baptism, Laying on of Hands, etc. Anointing with Oil
and Washing the Saints Feet be laid aside and practiced not by R. W. and his
New-England-Priests, and if that were Institutions, and delivered by Christ and
his Apostles for practice in worship or doctrine to be held up in the Church;
Then if you be gone from the practice of these things, then are you fallen and
gone away from the Institutions of the Lord Jesus Christ delivered by him, his
Apostles and Messengers, and so fallen into that, which thou chargest the
Quakers with: and so proved thy self a HYPOCRITE, to Charge others with Neglect
of that, which thou do not practice thy self.

R. W. Thou say; Repentance, it was an Heavenly and Saving Work of God upon
the Soul, etc. and it was preached by Moses and the Prophets, p. 115
by John Baptist, by Christ Jesus and his Apostles, Luke 24. And Christ sent
his Apostles to preach the Gospel to all Nations, etc.

Answ. This disproveth R. W.'s Charges against us. For as the Lord has
commanded us to preach Repentance, yea, in New England (as the people well
knows) yea, and to himself (as he has confessed) and to other Nations; but he
and his New England Priests, like a Company of Hard-hearted Jews, stopped their
Ears to it. But does R. W. and the New-England-Priests go into all Nations, and
preach Repentance and the Gospel according to his own Charge? if not, he and
the New-England-Priests are gone away from the First Institution of Christ, his
Apostles and Messengers; and your Repentance is no more than the Papists thou
speak on, who remain in your Persecuting Spirit Unrepented of. So it is no
true Repentance: and your principle and profession is no sound principle or
profession, whilst thou would have God's people PVNISHED; and the New England
Priests Persecute them: Those Christians, that are come to true Repentance,
they Love one another, and they Love Enemies; and their Repentance is beyond
yours, and the Scribes and Pharisees, which do Persecute. So it is clear, that
thine and the New England Professor's Repentance is no true Repentance, whose
Hands are full of BLOOD and Cruelty, and whose Tongue is full of Persecution.
And --

R. W. Thou say; The Protestants protested against this Repentance of the
Papists and Quakers.

Answ. And why against the Papists? but is it not clear, that R. W.'s and his
New-England-Priests and Professors Repentance is but like the Papists, Readiness,
Ahab's and Pharaoh's, and the Philistians and Judas's? For have not ye
Protestants in New^England manifested your Swords and Staves against the people
of God called Quakers, that have warned you to Repent? and HANGED, BVRNT with
an HOT IRON, CVT OFF EARS and SPOILED the GOODS of the people of God? and your
Repentance is not come so far as Judas's was, to make Restitution of the GOODS
you have SPOILED. And because R. W. lives under a Government, where he cannot
have the Magistrates to punish us; yet he says, he desires, that we might be
punished: So it seems, he wants Magistrates; yet we must be Punished, though
it be in Matter of Conscience. But Christ and the Apostles give him no such
Command: and therefore his Repentance is a false Repentance; and he is out of
the Spirit, that Christ and the Apostles were in, which was to Love Enemies,
and Overcome Evil with Good, if there were such a thing. And it is plain (and
true) that the Church of New England is the Whore, because the BLOOD of the
Saints is found in her: But God will reward her, and them that are in her and
cry her up! And --

R. W. Thou say; For all their Craking of Fear and Trembling* etc. there
has appea^ed no Sense of Godly sorrow, etc. and Brokenness of Heart in them
for their Sinful Nature, etc. but immediately upon their Bowing down to Satan,
p 116.
and Owning him as a Light, and Christ and Spirit within, etc.

Answ. R. W. Thou in the Spirit of Horrid Blasphemy against Christ, his Spirit
and Light within art not like to be Sensible of our Sorrows and Brokenness of
Heart! And here have not thou manifest thy self an Vn-repented Man, worse than
Judas? For did ever Judas or the Papists, nay the Turks call the Lord Jesus
Christ, the Only-Begotten Son of the Father (who is full of Grace and Truth, R.
W. is turned an Atheist.
who says himself, he is the Light of the World) did they ever call Christ,
and his Light and his Spirit Satan? and they, that Bowed down to Christ, a
Bowing down to Satan? O Blasphemer! what an Age of Darkness and Blasphemy are
the New-England-Priests come into, that hold ^orth such a Doctrine! And here is
it not clear (let all that fear God, see) how R. W. is Degenerated, and his
New-England-Priests (if this be their Doctrine) from the Doctrine of the
Apostle, as he falsely charge the Quakers? For the Apostle turned people from
Darkness to Light, etc. (this he confessed in his Examination, as may be seen
in the Acts) and opened the Eyes of the Blind, etc. and after that he had
preached Christ's Death and Resurrection, and at the Right Hand of God, and
many come to believe, he preached Christ within them, except they be
Reprobates; and told them, that the Light that shined in their Hearts, gave
them Knowledge. And so thou go on with many false Accusations; which are
Answered in other places. And --

R. W. Thou say, Why should they say Thee and Thou to the Aged, Learned,
Holy and High?

Ans. This R. W. brings, that we are gone from the Institutions of Christ and
his Apostles (as in page 114); but we Charge R. W. and the New-England-priests,
where Christ and the Apostles instituted, that we should say YOU to a Single
person? But who are these Learned, Holy and High? Is it R. W. and his
New-England-priests, that set themselves in the place of God, and call
themselves Holy and High? but it is himself* that is the Aged. And was not our
patience manifest, in bearing thy Cankcred Spirit, which uttered forth all
these railing words against us, let the people Judge?

R. W. And thou say, Why should they not s^t Silent? even Scores and
Hundreds of them ( possessed with a dumb Spirit) as in a Form and Order of
Christian worship, waiting for the Spirit.

Answ. R. W. Had better been Silent, who has brought forth such an Evil work;
and to have VVaited upon Christ, as we do, who speak, as the Spirit gives us
Utterance. Which was the practice of the Church of the primitive Times, which
thou art erred from; and now scoffingly call Dumb Spirit, because thy
Railing Spirit were not fed with words according to thy Will. And this is a
False Charge of thine [ We wait for the Spirit] But we VVait for the
Signification and Motion of the Spirit; for the Holy men of God spoke, as they
were Moved by the Holy Ghost: But thou say, There is no Voice nor Motion
within, that is to be turned to, lissen'd to, or hearkened to in Heavenly
Things (as page 83.) And now, Is not R. VV. gone into the Darkness, and from
the Way of all the Holy Prophets, and Holy Apostles, and Holy Men of God, that
Spoke, when they were Moved by the Holy Ghost? And is not R W. in the Steps of
the Jews, that Christ speaks to, that had neither heard the Voice of the
Father at any time, nor seen his Shape?

R. W. Thou say, The Protestants both English, French and Dutch have
manifested against the Papists, and therein against the Quakers, That
Repentance is a Turning of the whole Soul from all Sin as Sin to all of God, as
God.

Answ. What must we infer from his words in this place? If that R. W. and his
New-England-Priests and others be Turned so from all Sin by the Repentance to
God as God, that they are as Pure as God, as Holy as God, as Righteous as God?
and yet he finds Fault with this in the Quakers? But we must try R. W. by his
Fruits, and his Protestants, (especially in New England) if their Repentance
and his be not like to the Papists? and how dare R. W. speak of this
Repentance, when he Blasphemeth so much against the Light of Christ, and
calls it an Idol and a Frantic Light? But that which he casts upon us, is
come upon himself; who like the Pharisees of Old their Conversion and Sin is
from one Sin to another: and their Swelling Pride of a Dropsy and Tympany,
etc. (as he scoffingly speaks of) of his Conceited Faith, Repentance,
Justification, Sanctification, Mortification, etc. all this he might have
applied at home, and to his New-England-Priests, who all along proves himself
and his New England Professors to be the very people in the things, he Charge
upon us. And it were well, if ye could see nothing, but Hell and Damnation in
your selves, as thou speak of! but this ye cannot See, until ye come to the
Spirit and Light of Christ, which thou call Blasphemously an Idol and a
Fancy: and therefore art not like to See the true Savior, the Lord Jesus
Christ and his Light. And thou say --

R. W. How do they Superciliou^^y and Pope-like belch out as from Hell, God, I
thank thee, that I am not like these Publicans. p 117.


Answ. R. W. and his New-England-Priests might have kept this at home, with his
superciliou^^y, as he calls it (if he had found such a word in G. F.'s Book,
he would have roared and made some work at it, and shown it in print:) but
Roger has not hit our Conditions, but himself. And --

R. W. Thou say: How instantly do they rail, revile, condemn and curse,
breath out Fire, etc. as Fire and Brimstone from the mountains in Sicily, etc.
against all that oppose them; far from the Teaching of Christ and his first
Messengers, as Lambs, etc.

Answ. Let the Sober Reader look in R. W.'s Book and see, how he Condemns
himself and his Practice. But how does R. W. Rail against the Papists and
Mahomet, yea, Protestants too, as Formal! and has not R. W. and his
New-England-Priests done more than Breathing out Fire from the Mountains of
Sicily, who have Hanged, and Burnt with an Hot Iron? O! he and they might shame
(if they had any in them) thus to upbraid the People of God called Quakers, and
to tell them, they be in Cain's Nature, and Core's and Balaam's, and the
Pharisees, and Jezabel's and the Whore's, that drinks the Blood of the
Saint's, when Y^ have done it; and persecute for Religion, like Nebuchadnezar:
this is not Railing. And to tell R. W. when he calls the Light of Christ an
Idol and a Fancy, and tellest him, he is a Blasphemer; this is not Railing: And
when R. W. says, A Bowing to Christ his Light and Spirit is a Bowing to Satan,
(as in page 116.) to tell him, he is a Blasphemer against Christ's Light and
Spirit; this is not Railing. But we do not matter, what he and the
New-England-Priests say against us: but it wounds our Souls and Spirits, to
hear the Son of God, in whom he is well pleased, to be thus blasphemed by such,
that falsely calls himself a Christian! And Christ did not Rail, when he cried
