Woe against the Blind Scribes and Pharisees, calling them Whited Walls, and
said, They were of their Father the Devil: nor the Apostles, who called such as
he, Evil Beast and Slow-Bellies, and cried Woe against such, as went into the
Way of Cain. Neither did they Rail against Elymas and Simon the Sorcerer, which
Spoke Truth unto them. But thou, that give us Names, to the Lambs and
Children of God, and have no Motion within of Heavenly things of Supernatural
Light, art degenerated from the Spirit and Practice, the Saints were in in the
Primitive Times: I and J. B. do maintain and preach true Repentance toward
God, and Faith in Christ Jesus, as the Apostles did. And thou say, He
continued above half an hour, though not so long as W. Edmondson in preaching
this Doctrine: But why did not set it down? and thou confessest, They
delivered many holy Truths of God ( p. 119)

R. W. Thou go about to Prove, Our Faith is False.

Answ. But we shall see, if R. W. has not proved his own and his New England
Priests and professors Faith contrary to Christ's and the Apostles, and the
Faith of God's Elect, which Christ Jesus is the Author and Finisher of. And is
not R. W. erred from this Doctrine and Faith, who maintains with Fr. Duke,
The Scripture to be the Ground of Christ's Faith and the Saints? (page 102,
103, 104.) and so erred from the Apostles in the Primitive Times, who said,
Look unto Jesus, the Ground, Author and Finisher of Faith: He did not bid them,
Look to the Scripture, the Ground, Author and Finisher of Faith; but to Christ.
And --

R. W. thou say, That thou would demonstrate by Instances out of G. F.'s
Book all along, that he confounded and made all one both Faith and
Justification, etc. and made Believing in Christ but a mere Babel; p. 118.
and fallest a- railing, because that G. F. says, He that has Faith, has
Repentance, has Justification, Sanctification, etc.

Answ. But do not thou Confound thy self? for thou say, That Repentance is
a Turning of the whole Soul from all Sin as Sin to all of God as God (as this
is R. W.'s Form of Words:) and yet R. W. have not they then, that have
Repentance, Faith, Justification and Sanctification? And G. F.'s words are, He
that has Faith, has Repentance: Can any have Faith without Repentance? or any
Justification without Repentance and Faith? or any have Sanctification without
Repentance and Faith? and thou would have Justification and Sanctification
without Faith and Repentance; Thou may keep thy Babel to thy self. And Christ
Jesus, that preached Repentance, says, Believe in the Light, that you may
become Children of Light: and this Light thou call an Idol and a Fancy; and
so have plainly manifest, thou art no true Believer in the Lord Jesus Christ,
nor true Christian: and who would have Faith, Justification and
Sanctification without Repentance, have neither true Faith, Justification,
Sanctification. And so as for Babel, Nonsense, Confusion, Monstrous thou may
keep at home.

R. W. And thou say, Thou told'st us, that we and the Papists talk of Faith,
and G. F. talked much of Faith.

Answ. As for the Papists Faith, thou and the New-England-Priests might have
applied at home. But for the Saints Faith, it is the True, which Jesus Christ
is the Author of: and we have received it from him, and not from Men. And thou
in disproving our Faith, thou have proved thy self out of the True Faith in
Christ, which thou opposest.

R. W. And so thou say, They have put out the True and Living Faith; and have
put in a painted or Glass-eye in the Room of it.

Answ. This is thy own condition, who deniest the Faith in Christ Jesus, that
he is the Author and Finisher of: Which in all this Work thou go about to
overthrow, but thou can not.

R. W. And thou say, True Faith is Receiving of Christ Jesus as only King,
Priest and Prophet: it is believing on and receiving of Christ distinct from
God, Joh. 14. And, This true Lord Jesus Christ the Quakers turn into a mere
Fiction, Dream or Imaginary Christ in the Mind of Man, etc. And thou fall'st
a-railing, and tellest us, We are like the Papists, and say; The Quakers
Transubstantiation is worse, then the Fantastic Transubstantiation of the
Papists.

Answ. How can R. W. receive Christ Jesus as a Priest, King and Prophet, and
believe in him, who call'st the True Light of Christ an Idol, which John bore
Witness unto? Or be a Believer, as Christ Commanded and said, Be a Believer in
the Light; and he calls this Light a Fancy? So no Believer in the True
Christ, nor no Receiver of Christ, King, Priest and Prophet. Neither is R. W.
in the True Faith, which Christ Jesus is the Author and Finisher of, who
maintains, The Scripture is the Ground of Christ's Faith and the Saints; yet
he says, Christ is before Scripture: And he confesses, that Abel, Enoch, Noah,
Abraham, etc, had Faith before Scriptures; and again he says, That true Faith
is Receiving of Christ. But let R. W. and his New-England-Priests prove by
Scripture, That God (the Creator of all things) and the true Lord Jesus Christ,
his Son (whom we believe in according to Scripture, as the Prophets and
Apostles did) can be turned into a Fiction and Dream: let him make this
Blasphemy good by Scripture, if he can. And R. W. who calls himself Orator,
did the Apostles turn Christ into an Imaginary Christ, Dream and Fiction, when
they preached Christ in you, except ye be Reprobates? and is this Worse, than
the Papists Transubstantiation? prove this by Scripture: And thou art
degenerated and the New-England-Priests (if this be their Doctrine and
Preaching) of Christ and the Apostles in the Primitive Times.

R. W. And then thou say, that we say, All Spirit, and no Body; and so not
consisting of Flesh and Spirit: and yet thou contradictest thy self and say,
We are of his flesh, etc, And then thou fall'st a-railing, and thou say, That
we say, All must die and rot, and never rise again (and say) So you have
blown up and Juggled away the Flesh of Christ Jesus, both his and your own
altogether. And further thou say, We can give no Account of the Flesh of the
Man Christ Jesus: and thou fallest a-railing.

Answ. Do not thou see, how thou Contradictest thy self? but instead of
proving thy false Charge, thou have uttered forth many more false Charges.
Where did ever we say in any of our Books, That we shall not rise again, or,
That Christ is not risen? The same that Descended, is the same that is
Ascended, and at the Right Hand of God: did not we confess this before thee at
Newport? and yet thou Wickedly say, That we can give no Account of; when we
gave Account according to Scripture, as the Apostle says. And did not we say,
that we believe the Resurrection, as the Apostle did? and as we have born the
Image of the Earthly, so we shall bear the Image of the Heavenly? 1 Cor. 15.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers, which grant Christ Jesus to have been born,
lived and died, as we, etc. [and here thou overthrowest thy Babel of false
Charges:] And then thou Contradictest thy self and say, p. 119.
And yet now Transubstantiated into a Spirit and the Quakers Flesh; so that in
the upshot the Christ, in whom they believe, is vanished ( by an Hellish
Chemistry) into themselves, etc.

Answ. R. W. How far art thou degenerated from the Apostles Doctrine! did the
Apostles say so, when they preached Christ within and said, They were Flesh of
his Flesh, and Bone of his Bone? And Christ says, Except ye eat my Flesh, and
drink my Blood, ye have no Life in you, etc. and would thou keep us from our
Heavenly Food, by which we have Life? And art not thou worse then the Jews,
that loaded the Manna from Heaven, who addest Lie unto Lie to prove thy false
Charge? but the Father of Lies has set thee at Work, and the Day will come,
when Christ will reward thee, who Blasphemest him!

R. W. And thou say, They do believe on themselves, and that lying Spirit
within them.

Answ. R. W. Thou can not speak Truth, thou art not like indeed: this is
another false Charge. For we believe in the Lord Jesus Christ, as he has
taught and the Apostles, and deny Our selves and thy Lying Spirit within thee.
And we know thy condition, where thou art and the New-England-Priests, better
than thy self: and if you had been good, we would not have forsaken you. And --

R. W. Confessed, That J. B. had delivered many Holy Truths of God: and yet
thou say, At this there was a deep Silence, a^ If I had turned a Proselite;
at least it pleased them to be applauded.

Answ. Nay, R. W. we saw the Subtilty of the Serpent in thee: And if I B. had
spoken many Holy Truths, why did thou not join with them? it seems, thy
spirit could not join with Holy Truths. And then thou speak of Repentance,
and Being saved by the Blood of Christ Jesus, and of Living soberly and
righteously: Then how comes all this Ungracious Language from thee, if thou
art to live soberly and righteously? these are but Words R. W. And how can
thou be Saved by the Blood of Christ and Repent, and not believe in the Light,
as Christ commands, by which thou must see thy Sin and Evil Heart? And so
thou have proved thy Faith and Repentance to be Antichristian, and not at all
disproved ours. And so thy Faith and Repentance may go along with the Papists,
as thou speak of, who opposest the Faith of God's Elect, that purifieth
their hearts: and that is thy false Faith, that purifieth not the heart.

R. W. And thou scoffingly say, That we might have preached (to wit, I B.
and I S.) this Doctrine of Faith and Repentance before the Pope at Rome at his
Chapel.

Answ. Here R. W. scoffeth at True Faith and Repentance, and makes himself
unsensible of it: but its very well, he has manifested himself to be so much
One with them, and the New England Professors. But some of us have preached
Repentance and the Faith of Christ at Rome (where neither he, nor his
New England Priests dared to show their Heads) and suffered there Death for it;
though thou and the New-England-Priests may rail at them behind their Backs.
And so thou might have applied at home the Sayings of the Lord Jesus Christ,
Depart from me, ye Workers of Iniquity, I know you not: whose Light thou
call an Idol.

R. W. And thou say, Thou had intended to Charge us with the Falseness of
our Hope, Love, Peace and Joy, which they often Crake (thou say, p. 120
etc.) their Heaven consists, and all the Eternal Life to come they look for,
they are now in present and full Possession of.

Answ. Why did not R. W. do it there, what he Intended? But where does R. W.
prove these Lies, That our Heaven, etc. and all the Eternal Life, that is to
come, that we say, We are now in present full Possession of it? he has brought
no Proof for these his Lies. From the Seed, which Christ has sown in their
hearts, some brings forth Thirty, Sixty, Hundredfold in this Life, and in
the World to come Life Eternal: So these Words of his we turn back as R. W.'s
forged Lies. And as for true Love, Hope and Faith, he and his
New-England-Priests have banished that long ago.

R. W. Thou say, What Scripture is more Common in their Mouths and Pens, etc.
than Col. ^. Christ in you, the Hope of Glory? Whereby they insinuate Two of
their grand Deceits and Lies. 1. That there is no other Christ, but what is in
every Man in the World: 2. That there is no other Glory to be hoped for, or by
or with the Lord Jesus Christ, but what is in the Saints, etc.

Answ. The Reader may see R. W.'s Contradiction here in this very Scripture:
but still he is forging Lies, which we never heard of a fore. Christ in you,
the Hope of Glory; Mark, of Glory: And are not the Saints to grow up in the
knowledge of the Lord Jesus Christ unto a Perfect Man? and do not our Writings,
and has not our Mouth and Pens declared it? So as for Deceits, thou might
have kept this at home. But R. W. and the Rest of the Priests, which G. F. has
brought, could not endure to hear of Christ Within us, the Hope of Glory; but
ye would only have him Without, and so keep people in the Reprobate State. And
how can R. W. have him Within, when he calls his Light an Idol and a Fancy?
And So R. W. thou tell of Hopes like unto Spiders; but this thou might
have applied to thy self with the Hope of the Hypocrite, not to us.

R. W. And R. W. thou say, Do they not overthrow the very Nature of Hope,
which they prate of, and give the Spirit of God the Lie, which tells us, That
Hope is not of things in Possession, etc. (Romans 9.)

Answ. When did we tell to R. W. this Lie? he has forged it himself. And so as
for a Dead and Painted Hope thou might have kept thy self; for our Hope,
which is Christ, makes not ashamed: for we are Saved by Hope. But Hope that is
seen, is not Hope, etc. (Romans 8.) But R. W. brings Romans 9: but let the Reader
see, if there be the Word Hope in the Chapter. But the Living Hope (as Peter
speaks of) we witness (1 Pet. 2, 3.) We, whom Christ has begotten again to a
Lively Hope, ou^ Faith and Hope stands in God; and Christ our Hope of Glory
ankers our Immortal Souls, (see Col. and Hebr.) And our Hope is Steadfast, that
keeps us above all the Waves, and Storms and Floods, that R. W. and all the
New-England-Persecutors can cast upon us; for we have the Hope of Eternal Life
and Glory, as Paul writes to Titus: and we know, we are the Sons of God (1 John 3.) as the Saints did, that were the First Fruits.

But let us return again to Try R. W. and his New-England-Priests their Love,
Faith, Hope, and Peace, etc. whether they are not degenerated from the Love of
the Primitive Christians, and the Apostles and Messengers. First, does not the
Apostle say, Faith works by Love? and, Christ Jesus is the Author and
Finisher of Faith? and is not Faith called a Shield? now, is not R. W. and his
New England Priests degenerated from this Faith and this Shield, that works
by Love? have not their Fruits Manifested them by their HANGING, BURNING with
an Hot Iron, BANISHING and SPOILING the GOODS of God's people? and R. W. would
have them PUNISHED for Matter of Conscience. Nay, have not ye proved your
selves to be the Tinkling Cymbals, Sounding Brass? (1 Cor. 13.) have not they
persecuted such, as would not run after the Sound of their Tinkling Cymbals and
Sounding Brass? Charity suffers long and is Kind: have ye not been Unkind and
full of Envy, out of this Charity, Vaunting yourselves, pufft up and rejoicing
in Iniquity? And how did the Mayor General Vaunt and boast, when he told the
Prisoners, How Mary Dyer hanged like a Flag, when ye had Hanged her! This was
your Charity, and your Joy, and your Love to Enemies and to Christians. So
neither your Faith, Love, nor Hope, nor Peace nor Joy is according to the
Primitive Christians, your Practice shows your Error from them. And likewise
ye are not in the Wisdom of God, which is pure, gentle and peaceable, etc.
which the Apostles were in as in Jam:) and are gone into a Devilish and
Destroying Wisdom. And so Christ in the Saints, the Hope of Glory, has not
been yours, his Nature neither appears in R. W. nor in the New England
Priests and Professors.

R. W. And thou say, Can the Eternal God in any Literal Sense be called the
Hope of Israel? Jer. 4.

p. 121
Answ. Does not Jeremy call him the Hope of Israel, and the Savior? and was he
not so? and was not God Isreal's Savior, and was not his people to Hope and
Trust in him for it? and the Hope of Israel (to wit God) is the Hope of all his
peoples Comforts and Mercies, etc. And the Saying of the Apostle, If in this
Life only we have Hope, etc. is owned: and so, we have both the Hope in this
Life, and that which is to come.

R. W. And when thou have uttered a many false Charges, thou say; It Is true,
they will pretend to own Scriptures, Christ, Resurrection, Judgment, Faith,
Hope, Repentance, etc. and as true and sound, as any Protestants.

Answ. Pretended, is thy own Thrust-in: for we do really and more truly own
Christ's Resurrection, Judgment, Faith, Hope, Repentance and Scriptures, then
such Protestants, as thou and the New-England-Priests do. And --

R. W. thou say, It was reported, that some of us at our Death have used
these words, Lord Jesus, receive my Spirit; and some have Judged Charitably of
i^ ( our going presently to Christ Jesus:) but R. W. says; But as to the Truth
and Bottom, however they blind the World and weak Followers, etc. and so thou
go on railing, with more false and lying Charges, which we never thought on.

Answ. Here R. W. has manifest his false Love and false Charity: for when a
man is Dying in a sense of the Lord, and desires the Lord Jesus to receive his
Spirit, does he think, that men will dissemble at this Time, and do it in
Hypocrisy? what a senseless Man is R. W. and what a Malicious Spirit has he
manifested here! And we own the Resurrection, as the Scripture speaks: And is
not the Soul a part of God's Breath, which he has breathed into man? and have
not thou confessed thyself, That it goes unto God?

R. W. And thou say, p 122.
This Saying, Lord Jesus receive my Spirit, is no more then, Lord Jesus,
receive thy self.

Answ. These are R. W.'s Forgeries: for where does he prove it out of any of
our Books? and so goes on with Railing and scoffing at God's people on their
Deathbeds, when they say, Lord Jesus, receive my Spirit; and therefore thou
say, their saying is, Lord Jesus, receive thy self. Well R. W. thou may do
the Work, that thy Father sets thee about: but we do abhor thy forged Words!

R. W. brings John Bunyon ( G. F. Fol. p. 127.) his saying [ It is a
Counterfietlng (as thou call it) of a New Birth, to follow the Light,
wherewith Men coming into the World, are enlightened.] G. F. answers [Which
none comes to (the New Birth) but who comes to the Light, wherewith every
Man, that comes into the World, is enlightened; which believing in is a Child
of the Light, by believing and receiving Christ they come to receive Power to
be the Sons of God.] (And R. W. quoteth his Book for G. F.'s fol. 127. where
there is no such thing in that page: but we have so much Charity, to overlook
R. W.'s mistake, and not rail at him, as he does at G. F.) But this is fully
Answered in the Appendix, where he brings it again in his page 5, 6. (As for
the Word Counterfieting, whether it be the Printers or the Orator's Mistake, we
shall leave that) But thou confessest here, that Christ is the Author and
Finisher of Faith: and in another place thou say with F. D. That the
Scripture is the Ground of Christ's Faith and the Saints (page 102, 103. in thy
Book.) And thou ask, If this Light be Christ the Mediator.

Answ. We tell thee, Christ enlightneth every Man, that comes into the World:
and John tells thee, that This is the True Light, which enlightneth every
Man, that comes into the World, which is the Life in the Word, which became
Flesh, etc. And thou art no Believer, according to Christ's words, until thou
believe in his Light.

R. W. And thou say, Fox says, this Turning to the Light within is the
New Birth, and call it Our New Light (as they falsely and foolishly prate. p.
123
) But (Isa. 8.) they have no true Light, but a false and painted Light within
them.

Answ. Thou abusest Isa. 8. as well as us: He does not say of a False, Painted
Light within; but read the Margent, and thou will see, it says, There is no
Morning in them: and there is Light, before they come to the Morning. But thou
call it a New Light and a false New Birth; Here thy Malice appears against
Christ's Doctrine: So thy Doctrine is false, and thy Preaching. For Christ
says, Believe in the Light, that ye may become Children of the Light: so its
clear, thou art no Preacher of Christ, nor Messenger, nor know not
Repentance, that speak so much evil of them, that turn people from Darkness
to Light, as the Apostle did; and believe not in the Light: so thou art no
Child of Light, but art in thy own false Birth. And so it is thou, countest it
false and foolish Prating, to bid thee Repent and believe in the Light, that
thou may become a Child of Light: But the Light is true, thou shall find it,
that believe not in the Light, but call it a Fancy; which will be thy
Condemnation.

R. W. And he brings G. Willington's saying, [ That he is Justified by Faith
alone without Good Works. p. 124.
] G. F. Answ. (Fol. p. 44.) [What! without the Faith that Works by Love? have
thou concluded those Works the Works of Popery, which are the Works of Faith,
that works by Love, which Faith gives the Victory? For Faith and Works by
Love is owned; and he that believes, is ceased from his own Works, as God did
from his, and has entered into his Rest. And Faith gives Victory over all the
Popish Murdering Spirits; and both thine and their Works are out of it.] R. W.
Replieth and falls a railing, That G. F. makes true Justifying Faith to be
not one hairs breadth more, than the Faith that may be to God in the First
Covenant.

Answ. In this thou wrongest G. F.'s words, as the Reader may see; And Romans 3.
Therefore we conclude, that a Man is Justified by Faith, and not by the Works
of the Law: but R. W. leaves out James's, who says; Show me thy Faith by thy
Works: and these are the Works of the Gospel. But R. W. thou believe, There
is a God (and the New-England-Priests) thou do well, the Devils also believe
and tremble: For as the Body is dead without the Spirit, so Faith without Works
is dead. (Jam 2.) And so it is clear, R. W. and his New-England-Priests and
Professors profess Faith, but it is Dead, without the Works of Faith, which
Works by Love and purifieth the Heart: but your Dead Faith Works by Envy,
Malice, Persecution, Bloodshed and Murder. And so Poor Bancrupts ye may apply
to yourselves. And if ye were in the Grace, which comes by Jesus, your
Practice and thy Words would have been more Gracious: which testifies, you are
not in the Grace of God, which the Apostle was in; but have turned it into
Wantonness.

R. W. Brings Joseph Miller's Saying [It's an Error to say, we are Justified
by that which Christ does in us.] G. F. (Fol. p. 47.) Answ. [Contrary to the
Apostle, who says, We are Justified by Faith in his Blood: And the Faith is in
the Heart; and the Blood is in the Heart, that purifieth it: And the Mystery of
Faith is held in a pure Conscience. And the Word of Faith is within ( Romans 10)
and Faith gives Victory over the World; and that which gives Victory,
Justifies: and Christ is within, who is Justification, Sanctification, etc.
and if either of them is found within, thou art in an Error, and not fit to
talk of these things, thou understandest not.] R. W. Replieth and says, Grant
that in a true Respect and Sense Faith is within, and the Blood, etc. And then
he says, p. 125.
Will it therefore follow, twice over.

Answ. And does G. F. say, that they were not Without, before they were Within?
or else, how should they come Within? and does G. F. say any such word, that
they are one, in his Answer? So as for thy Babilonish Mystery, Jumbling and
Blending thou might have kept at home; who have confessed to the Truth, and
can not own it.

R. W. And thou say; It Is true, Christ dwells in our hearts by believing
(the Apostle says, by Faith) Ephesians. 3. and (thou say) Consequently his
Cross, his Manger, his Grave, his Literal Bloodshed are Within, etc. and his
Spear, Soldiers, Highpriests, Scribes, Pharisees, Pilate, Romans, Jerusalem
are literally within us.

Answ. This is thy own Brutish Fancy, (as thou call it) to talk at this
Rate, which neither we, nor the Apostle preached such a false Doctrine: and
therefore thou may take it home again, as a Forging by thy own spirit: And
cannot Christ be preached by the Apostles and his Servants now in the Hearts of
his Saints without all these Outward Things, as thou Maliciously bring here?
And the Reader may see, there is nothing in G. F.'s Answer for him to bring
these Words: For we own the Man Christ Jesus really, shedding his Blood without
the Gates of outward Jerusalem, etc. And a many Unsavory Words thou have here,
which thou may take home again. -- But can Christ Jesus be blown up, and
Vanish together with the Scriptures, (as thou affirmest, and according to thy
Consequence here?) O no he is Ascended far above thy Blowing up. But thy
Antichrist may be blown up, who call the Light of the true Christ an Idol
and a Fancy. And --

R. W. brings John Bunyan ( G. F. Fol. 10.) saying [ It is not Faith and
Works, that Justifies a Man before God; but it is Faith and Good Works, which
justify in the Sight of Men only: and such Works will not justify in the Sight
of God. And he says, That Works are only to justify their Faith to be true
before Men.] G. F. Answers [ Abraham was not justified only to Men by his
Obedience, p. 126.
but to God: and where is Faith, there is Justification, which works by Love.
And the Saints Faith and Works were not only to justify them in the Sight of
Men: For the Work of God is to do what he says, and his Will, which who does
not, are not justified in so doing; but are to be beaten with stripes. Who seek
to be justified by their Faith and Works in the Sight of Men, are in a Dead
Faith and Works both: for such seek to please Men more than God.] And R. W.
Replieth, and falls a-railing and says; G. F. maintains a Covenant of
Works.

Answ. But there is no such thing, as the Reader may see; but the Faith, which
works by Love, as the Apostle speaks of, the New Covenant: and this R. W.
(who is so Envious) cannot see. But he maintains the Faith of Christ Jesus,
and also the Faith of Abraham: and the Apostle says, They are of Abraham, who
walk in the Steps of the Faith of Abraham, who is the Father of the Faithful.

R. W. And thou say, The Work of God according to Christ's Doctrine is, to
believe in him, whom God has sent. It is true, it is the Command of God to
keep his Commands; but since the Deadly Fall of Man none, not one being able,
etc.

Answ. What! None can keep the Commands of God neither in the Old Testament,
nor in the New, that comes to Christ and does the Work of God, To believe in
his Son, whom God has sent? then None loves God, nor believes. For is not
this the Command and Work of God, to believe in his Son? What! are the Commands
of God in the New Testament only to be talked of, because they did not keep
them in the Old? Now, does not the Apostle say, The Law is fulfilled in one
Word; Love God, and thy Neighbor as thy self? We know, R. W. and his
New-England-Priests etc. have not kept this Command: for if they had Loved God,
they would not have killed his people; for Love does not kill, nor Envy. And
also R. W. if he had Loved God, and kept in his Love, we should not have had
this Envious, Evil Work brought forth. And --

R. W. says, They that do not God's Will, are not justified in so doing. And
therefore R. W. concludes, They that do God's will, are justified in so doing,
and that their Sins are pardoned; as Paul and David by pardon of Sin describe
justification. p. 127.
And thou say, That there is diverse Significations of this Latin Word
Justification.

Answ. What is this to the Purpose, as to Christ's words, They that do not the
Will of God, are un-justified in so doing? And wa not Paul's etc. Sin pardoned
by Christ through Faith, who Justified him? But do thou justify the Papists,
and the New England Priests and Professors Drinking the Blood of the Saints?
and thy self, who would have us to be punished? so, thou would have us
Beaten; and the New England Men did Beat us, because we did not do your Wills.
But you cry, Pardon of Sin by Christ Jesus, and are doing the Devil's Work, and
not Christ's Will and Command, which is, To love one another, and to love
Enemies. Thou say --

R. W. Does it follow therefore, that they that do not Steal, Whore, Murder,
etc. by this abstaining from Sin, and by this their Work they obtain their
Pardon, and stand by this their Work Legally right and justified in the Court
of Heaven.

Answ. R. W. Are they Justified, that Run on in their Sin, Stealing, Whoredom
and Murder? which the true Faith, that Christ is the Author of, leads from,
purifieth from, and gives Victory over such Evils; and sees Christ the Author
of their Faith, whom he has bought with his Blood. And so our Doctrine of true
Repentance and Faith, Love, Hope, Joy and Peace is according to Scripture and
the Primitive Church, and not R. W.'s nor his New-England-Priests. And we have
Examined Our selves, and proved ourselves by the Light of Christ Jesus, and
found him within us: and he is come, and we are no Reprobates; and has given
us an Understanding, and we are in him, Glory to God for ever! And as for
Counterfeit Christ, painted Faith and Hope, and dolefully Counterfeited
perishing Salvation, etc. R. W. might have kept at home; for it will fail him
in the End, which he speaks of: And this is thy own Condition, that thou
speak of the others, such as believe Lies for Heavenly Truths.

R. W. And thou say, Thou had purposed to have showed, how the Quakers have
followed the Cerdonians, the Priscillians and Valentinians, the Old Gnostics
and Manicheans.

Answ. R. W. might have kept these for himself, who calls the Light of Christ
Jesus a Fancy and an Idol: but where did any of those call it so? for we follow
Christ Jesus, and neither him nor them. And --

R. W. thou say, Thou confinedst thy self to the Terms of thy Position, and
declaredst the Quakers to be Downright Papists in many points.

Answ. Well, we shall see, what Points they are? and see, whether he and his
New-England-Priests are not nearer to the Papists, then the Quakers are.

R. W. Brings (from G. F.'s Fol. p. 214.) the Elders and Messengers of the
Churches, p. 128.
saying [ We are conceived in Sin, and brought forth in Iniquity.] And G. F.
Answ. [ David does not say, YE, who are conceived in sin, but [ I]: and R. W.
says, John was sanctified from the Womb; and the Scripture speaks of such,
as were Sanctified from the Womb, and Children that were Clean, etc. and this
is fully answered in Answ. to App. page 134, 135] And --

R. W. says, That the Protestants say, that their natural Births and
Conceptions are all defiled with Sin.

Answ. And so say the Papists. But what does R. W. and his New-England-Priests
say to Paul? [For the Believing Husband is sanctified by the believing Wife;
and the unbelieving Wife is Sanctified by the believing Husband: For else were
their Children Unclean, but now are they Holy.] I ask R. W. and his
New-England-Priests, Whether or no there be any such Believers in New England?
or, Whether they believe this Doctrine of the Apostle, or preach this? if not,
then are they degenerated. And this does not deny the New Creating of the Soul
and Spirit in Everlasting, Unchangeable Holiness and Righteousness after the
Image of him, that Creates him after him, etc. But R. W. if the Papists
confess, They are born in sin; and Paul says, The Believers Children are Holy:
How do the Quakers, and the Believers and the Apostle here Jump into one thing
with the Papists?

R. W. thou say, The Quakers are in one step with the Papists as to the power
of Nature in spirituals; and that every Man etc. in the World has a Sufficient
Light within him to see God and Christ, etc. Contrary to the Protestants, who
from the Holy Scripture maintain Natural Blindness and Darkness, and Man's
Natural Deadness: and that our Wisdom cannot discern any Spiritual thing, etc.
and that our Wisdom is Enmity to God.

Answ. Did ever the Quakers say to the Contrary, but that ye and the New
England-Professors were in this Condition? and ye might have taken the Papists
with you, and not to have joined them with the Quakers. And in this Condition
and Birth ye are still; though ye may make a Profession of God and Christ, the
Fruits of that Birth show it self forth. And indeed, how can ye be any other
ways, who call the Light of Christ Jesus a Fancy and an Idol, which John bear
witness to, and Christ said, Believe in the Light, that ye may become Children
of the Light. So here it is clear, that your Birth is not Changed: but (as thou
say) your Wisdom is Enmity, and ye are in Natural Blindness and Deadness, as
to Spiritual things. But we never heard, that the Papists did own the Heavenly
Light of Christ Jesus, that lights every one, that comes into the World, the
Life in the Word; for they persecuted us for preaching of it, as the
New-England-Professors have done. And whatever Christ has profer'd you, still
how can ye see it, except ye believe in the Light? -- And thou comparing us
with the Papists, thou have but manifest thy own Folly: for thou say; --

R. W. The Papists speak more like Men, and yield, that Men* and Women have
left them (since Adam fell) power to listen to, p. 129.
etc. and say, The Quakers talk ( like Brutes) of no Means, but Immediate
Revelation of the Spirit; and the Protestants affirm, that we have not a good
Thought, but from God, etc.

Answ. Let the Reader Judge, who speaks like Brutes? for if the Papists
listen to that, which is left them in Adam (as thou say) and ye say, ye have
not a good Thought, but what ye have from God; how have ye any thing that is
Good from God, but by that which Reveals it from God? which thou grantest, is
the Quakers Means. For the Apostle says, No man knows the things of God, but
by the Spirit of God (2 Cor. 3. Phil. 2. Romans 10. 1 Cor. 4.) And so now thou,
that deniest the Immediate Revelation of the Spirit of God to be the Means (and
the New England Professors) ye are as dark as the Papists: and so thou have
proved thy self a Nearer kin to them, then the Quakers. And thou confessest,
That God opened Lydia's Heart (Act. 16.) Was not this by his Immediate Spirit
and Revelation, by which she received the Gospel? And this is the Quakers
Means; but not R. W.'s it seems, who says: There is no Voice, to Motion
within to be lissen'd to, as often has been quoted. And do thou and the
New-England-Priests believe, There was no Motion nor Voice in Lydia's Heart,
when the Lord opened it, by which she gave Attention to the Gospel, and
received it from Paul?

R. W. Thou say, The Papists and Quakers maintain a Falling away from Grace.

Answ. And yet thou say; The Truth is, none of them seems to know it
experimentally: Then how can thou maintain, They fall away from that, they do
not know Experimentally? But as for the Papists, let them Answer for themselves.

R. W. And thou say of the Protestants, Though they grant great Fallings and
Desertions of the Children of God, yet they hold the holy Seed of God, the Holy
Spirit and Word of God, that Incorruptible and Eternal Seed, of which they are
begotten, never finally and totally to be Eclipsed.

Answ. Where did ever Quakers say, that the Holy Spirit of God or his Eternal
Seed ever fell away, of which his people are begotten, or that they fell away,
that came to that State? for I tell thee, If the Righteous fall, they shall
rise again. But neither the Papists nor thou (as ever we could meet withal) did
believe, that the Grace of God, which brings Salvation, has appeared to all
men: and is not that Saving, which brings Salvation? which the Wicked turn
into Wantonness, and walk despitefully against the Spirit of Grace. But what
does R. W. say of them, that had tasted of the good Word of God? (Heb. 6) I do
not believe, that ever he or the New-England-Priests came so far. And how can
R. W. talk of Falling away from Grace and Light, and is yet in the Fall, and
calls Christ's Light an Idol? and so not come to it.

R. W. And thou say, Thou told'st us, that the Papists and we were
Confederates in their Endeavors to raze the Heavenly Records, p. 130.
and to rob the Saints of the Holy Scriptures. [This is a false Charge: for we
esteem of the Scriptures more then thou and the New-England-Priests and they.]
And thou say, The Papists own the Snriptures to be the Word or Will of God,
etc. but the Quakers will not vouchsafe it the Name of the Word of God.

Answ. Here then the Papists differ, and are one with thee and the
New-England-Priests; and are Contrary to the Prophets and the Apostles, who
call the Scriptures WORDS, and Christ Jesus, who says, they are Words: and his
Name is called the Word of God, and not scoffingly (as thou call'st it) our
Simple Pretense, but really he is so. And thou, that give the Title to the
Scripture, which belongs to Christ, which the holy Men of God did not, art
degenerated from both Spirit and Speech.

R. W. And thou say; The Papists horribly abuse the Scrip^ures, and call it a
Nose of Wax, etc. and so do the Quakers, ^riumphing over it, etc. as over a
Dead Letter, a Carcass, etc.

Answ. R. W. These are thy own forged Words: Where did ever the Quakers call it
a Dead Carcass, and triumph over the Scriptures? for thou say thy self, The
Letter profits nothing without the Spirit. And the Apostle says, The Letter
kills, but the Spirit gives Life: and was he therefore a Papist?

R. W. And thou say; The Papists prefer the Vulgar Latin Copies before the
Hebrew, and say, Do not the Quakers simply and brutishly bind themselves to
the bare Letter of the Common English?

Answ. Here the Quakers and the Papists Dis-agree. And do not thou say, That
the Scriptures are the Word of God? which we say, are Words? And must not we
own Scriptures, as they call themselves? for do not thou say, They are the
Touchstone? and if the English Copies be not true, why do thou tell us, The
Scriptures are the Touchstone, and the Rule, and the Word of God? and why have
not thou and the New-England-Priests mended them all this time? And do not
thou say, That Ravius proclaims above a Thousand Faults to be in our Last
Translation? How now R. W.! and yet are they the Touchstone? and the Rule? and
the Word of God? how dare thou say, they are the Word of God, if there be a
Thousand Faults in them? And how dare thou say, They are the Touchstone, the
Ground of Christ's Faith and the Saints? (as in thy Book page 102.) and the
Priest says, They are the Means of Faith: yet thou do extol this Man,
calling him a most-Famous Hebraician, that says, There be above a Thousand
Faults in the last Translation of them. And --

R. W. says, The Papists set up a Judge in Controversy above the Holy
Scriptures, p. 131.
etc. and the Quakers say the same of their Spirit, etc.

Answ. But how can thou call it the Holy Scriptures, if thou say, There be
a Thousand Faults in them? And is not the Spirit above the Scriptures, that
gave them forth? and the Word of God, which was before they were, as thou have
confessed? But the Quakers are not agreed with the Papists here; but the Papists
are agreed with you: If the Spirit of God be not the Judge, and not to be set
above the Scriptures, ye and the Papists are of one Spirit; but not in that,
that gave forth the Scriptures, and the Word of Wisdom, which was, before they
were Written.

R. W. And thou say; The Papists will not deny, to make the Scriptures the
Rule to be tried by it; yet their Church and Pope must Interpret it.

Answ. That is like to you, that do Interpret them, and give Meanings, and find
Fault with us for taking it Literally: so ye and the Papists are agreed. And
then thou fall'st a-railing: But we tell you both, that the Holy Ghost
proceeds from the Father and the Son; the Spirit of Truth is that which
leads into all Truth.

R. W. And thou say: The Papists generally use not the Scriptures in their
Devotions in their Mother Tongue, but in Latin, (which thou call the Whore's
Tongue of Italy:) And then thou tellest a long Story of Luther, and say, The
Papists and Quakers slight the Holy Scriptures.

Answ. But here thou can not Join the Quakers with the Papists, for we do not
use in our Devotion to speak the Scriptures out of our own Language: Neither do
we justify the Papists in ^o doing.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers at first took off themselves, p. 132.
Families and Assemblies from any use of it, (to wit, the Scriptures.)

Answ. This is altogether false, all people knows, it is, that knows both our
Families and Assemblies.

R. W. And thou say, The Papists and Quakers say, If the Scriptures were
consumed, and quite taken out of the World, there would be no Loss, etc.

Answ. This also is false, the Quakers never said so; they never had such a
Thought in their Hearts, that we know of. But No man knows the things of God
in the Scriptures, but by the Spirit of God: and the Spirit of God leads us
into all Truth of the Scriptures both to the Comforting of our Assemblies and
Families.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers and Papists love the Scriptures no better,
then Goliath loved David's Stone.

Answ. And we may say to thee, Thou love the Scriptures no more, then thou
love the Light of Christ, who call it a Fancy and an Idol. But by the
Scriptures and the Spirit of God, that gave them forth, we have proved thee,
That thou neither love the Scriptures, nor the Spirit of God, which gave them
forth: which we love and esteem.

R. W. Thou say, The Papists and Quakers Shake hands in the most Hellish
Doctrine of Justification, by what Christ works within us.

Answ. Is the Apostles Doctrine Hellish and Popish, who are Justified by Faith?
and does not Christ work Faith within? how does it purify the Heart? And this
Faith within owneth Christ, it does not deny, that he died without the Gates of
Jerusalem for all men. And where do we put Justification for Sanctification?
and is not this Sanctification wrought within Men? And where do either ye or
the Papists confess, that Christ is the Author and Finisher of Faith? for thou
wrongst the Papists. For if they confess, that that Faith, that purifieth their
hearts, gives them Victory and Access to God, they need not plead for a
Purgatory, when they are dead; nor thou for a Body of Sin and Death to the
Grave.

R. W. Thou say, The Quakers are Papists in that Infallible Spirit, etc. [to
wit, the Spirit of Truth, which Christ and his Father has sent to lead us in
all Truth.]

Answ. This Holy Ghost the Papists have denied to our Faces: and therefore thou
Abusest the Papists. And ye have confessed, ye have not the same Holy Ghost, that
the Apostles had; and therefore they and the New-England-priests are of one
Nature, for they have said the same: And this Spirit shall reprove the World of
Righteousness, etc. as Christ says. And if all men did believe in the Light,
and not turn the Grace of God into Wantonness, nor grieve the Spirit, which God
has poured out upon them, it would Teach them and instruct them: And that we
do exhort people to, that they may escape the Dreadful Judgments of God, who
will Judge the World in Righteousness. And then thou scoffest against our
Preachers, etc. But we have preached the Everlasting Gospel in New England and
other places; and it had been very well, if thou had turned to the Spirit of
God within thee, that thou make slight of.

R. W. Thou say, The Quakers are Papists in a high, Lofty Conceit of
Perfection, p. 133.
when in Calvin's time this Spirit came from Hell, etc.

Answ. Do not thou Contradict thy self and say, The Papists hold a
Purgatory? then how are they like the Quakers, that hold Perfection? And so
they are near thee, that must have a Combat or a Fighting all thy Life, and no
Overcoming. And how dare thou to say, The Spirit and Doctrine of Perfection
came from Hell in Calvin's Time? etc. for it is the Doctrine of Christ and his
Apostles to his Saints and Followers.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers in the latter Years in Lancashire came from
the Grindletonians.

Answ. This is also false, the Grindletonians know otherwise, and the people in
Lancashire.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers and Papists are great Friends in their
Notions and Practice of Revelations, etc. and Inspirations.

Answ. How can the Papists own true Revelation, that own not the same Holy
Ghost, as they were in, that gave forth Scriptures? So their Dreams and Visions
are like thine; and so not like the Quakers, who know the things of God, that
are revealed by the Spirit of God. And thou that scoffest at Revelation,
Inspiration, etc. know not the things of God, but art in the Natural, dark
State thou speak of. And --

R. W. Thou say, What a Noise we make about Uncovering the Head, Knee,
Wearing of Lace, etc. and saying of You and Thou, and Music, and Painting; and
thou call it Idle, Popish Trash and Trumpery.

Answ. These are thou and thy Protestants, that make such a Noise about them:
Nay, would thou not have us to be punished for doing those things? (p. 200.)
And What must we infer from all this? R. W. would have his Music, and the Head
Uncovered and Knee bowed to him, and Wearing of Laces, and You instead of Thou
said to him: and he is offended at us, because we deny such things; and so are
the Papists, his Brethren. And we tell R. W. and his New-England-priests, that
they never shall know true Religion, till their Flesh be Silent to know, what
it is, to Tremble at the Word of God, and to work out their Salvation with Fear
and Trembling: for it is God, that works in us both to Will and to Do. But
this Voice and Motion has R. W. not known nor heard yet.

R. W. Thou say; The Papists and Quakers are Brethren in Iniquity in their
Affirming, that the Pope is not the Antichrist.

Answ. And how can this be? when G. F. said, Antichrist was come in the
Apostles Days, and the World went after him? And thou and ye
New-England-Priests, and the Papists, that are inwardly Ravening from the
Spirit, and Grace, and Truth in the heart, and Anointing, and Word and Faith
there, though ye do profess Christ and the Apostles Words in the
Sheeps-Cloathing, and drink the Blood of the Saints (as the Papists and
New England have done) must needs be the Whore and Antichrist, your Fruits
have declared it (and thou art Stirring up the Magistrates to punish us) who
were the Livery of the Bloody Whore.

R. W. Thou say, The Papists change their Names; and why the Quakers guided
by the same Hellish Spirit and Fancy, are so tender about owning their Old
Names.

Answ. Let the Reader see how Angry this Old, Doting Man is: where had any
Quakers changed their Names, as the Papists have done? this is no Comparison.
But I must tell thee, as John said, He that overcomes, has a New Name. And
Our Names are written in the Lamb's Book of Life; and does R. W. think, this is
the Old Name? nay, this is not: And yet we do not say, we are weary of our Old
Names, which our Parents have called us by. But will R. W. say, that was a
Hellish Spirit, that changed Paul's Name, and therefore was he like a Papist?
And if thou do call the Holy Ghost, the Spirit of Truth, a Hellish Spirit,
and so blasphemest against the Holy Ghost, remember Christ's Sentence.

R. W. Thou say again, The Papists and Quakers are led by one Spirit of
feigned Holiness, etc. Monkish Solitariness, etc. must be sequestered from
Wordly Business; p. 134.
is the Beggars Life: -- and, Paul wrought night and day with his hands; which
I never read of any of these Lying Apostles, Quakers, in all their Travails to
have done.

Answ. All people may Judge thee here Led with a Lying Spirit. For of whom has
our people Begged? and where are our Nuns and our Fryaries? thou fillest up thy
Book with such Lying Stories: The Spirit of God Leads us to no such things,
no more then he did the Apostles. But R. W. to prove us, that we are not
According, etc. (as thou say) because thou have not read, that we labor night
and day in our Travails, as the Apostles; and therefore our Doctrine, our
Practice, our Faith and our Religion must not he according to the Apostles:
Herein he has proved all his Priests in New England not to be in the Doctrine
of the Apostles, which have so much a Year, which the Apostles had not; and
that you are gone from the Religion, Practice and Profession of the Primitive
Messengers and Teachers. And it is known, that we have Labored night and day in
our Travails, though he has not read it: and have not been Chargeable to any,
and coveted no Man's Gold nor Silver. And let him enquire in Rode-Island and
Long Island, whether J. B. did not work there; or no?

R. W. (Thou might have kept that at home, to say) The Quakers Tongues and
the Papists are both spitting and belching out Fire from one Fire of Hell.

Answ. And this is thy own Condition; let any read thy Ungracious Words and
see, if the Papists can be worse?

R. W. Thou say, The Protestants hope and speak Charitably of the Salvation
of many of the Papists. p. 135.


Answ. But ye shall hear R. W.'s Charity, viz: If it please the most-High, Old
and New England may Flourish, when the Pope and Mahomet, Rome and
Constantinople are in Ashes, (in his Epistle to the King) And further (in his
Epistle to Baxter and Owen;) The Pope and Mahomet, whom some of you may live to
see flung in the lake, which burns with Fire and Brimstone. Here is R. W.'s
his Protestants Charity.

R. W. And thou say, G. F. and the rest, they Judge all that differ from
Christ, that is, themselves. --

Answ. This is a scoffing Word, to say, That Christ is Ourselves; for he
teaches us to deny Ourselves, who Lights every Man that comes into the
World. And they that hate the Light, hate Christ, from whence it comes; and
are not the true Believers, and have not Unity with Christ or with us (who walk
in the Light) or amongst themselves either. So with the Light they are
condemne^, that hate it* (Joh. 3.)

R. W. Thou say, The Quakers and Papists are Fire brands both in the matter
of Persecution, etc. and thou say: The Protestants cried out against all
Persecution -- and further: I say, the Quakers most vehemently cry out against
Violence, against Creatures; but against their Corruptions and Corrupt
Principles.

Answ. Is this good Sense R. W.? those are thy own words. And further, this is
a false Charge, as to say, The Papists and Quakers are Fire brands both in the
matter of Persecution: For this thou should have applied to the New England
priests, whose BLOODY HANDS have been embroiled in the BLOOD of the Lambs of
Christ. And therefore thou and the Papists are one, and not the Quakers, as
thou have proved them all along thy self, and the priests and Professors in
New England to be one with the Papists, and not the Quakers. For whom have we
IMPRISONED? whom have we WHIPPED? whose EARS have we CVT OF? Whom have we
BANISHED? and whose GOODS have we SPOILED, because they would not hear us? nay
R. W. Christ has given us better Weapons.

And we do believe, that the Word of the Lord, that we preached amongst you, is
Cutting: but thou art afraid, we shall get an Outward Sword. O! we have better
Weapons to maintain our Religion, the Lord has abled us withal; the Shield of
Faith and the Sword of the Spirit, etc. And what! is Cain, that killed Faithful
ABEL, now afraid? Well he may: but we leave God to revenge the BLOOD of his
Faithful Servants, which has been drunk in New England. And there is no such
thing neither in G. F. nor E. B: nor J. Stubs maintains, that any should be
punished for Religion, Conscience, Faith or Worship, as thou falsely chargest;
but that Magistrates are to punish Evildoers: and as Christ says, He that
does Evil (to wit, any Murder, Theft, Adultery, etc.) hates the Light.

And as for our Agreement with Papists, Arminians, Pelagians, etc. This is like
the rest of thy false Charges and Comparisons. And what do thou talk of
Election and Predestination, p. 136.
etc. when thou call the Light of Christ an Idol? For these are Mysteries to
thee, who art not come to take heed unto the Light, that shines in a dark
place.

R. W. And thou tellest us of the Protestants Doctrine: of a Certain Number of
God's Elect, that are Chosen and drawn by Mercy out of the Lump of lost Mankind.

Answ. Now, if they be drawn by Mercy, must not this be by the Spirit of God
within? And is not this contrary to thy own Doctrine, to say, There is no Voice
nor Motion within of heavenly things and supernatural Light? And thou speake^^
(...) his Call in Time, by his holy Word and Spirit, etc. And is not this
Spirit and Call within! then is there not a Voice and a Motion? And how can
thou talk of the New Birth, and believe not in the Light, to become a Child of
Light? Those things indeed ye New-England-Protestants hold in Talk, but not in
Possession.

R. W. And thou say, The Quakers are Brethren with the Socinians, etc. in
making Christ a Type and Figure -- an Example, how Christians ought to walk;
not that the Blood, that was shed upon the Cross at Jerusalem, was a sufficient
Price and Satisfaction etc. for the Sins of the whole world.

Answ. It Is like, thou wrongest the Socinians, as thou do us: For we tell
thee, thy Charge is false, and a Lie in thy Mouth. For we say, Christ is the
Substance of all Figures and Types: but does not the Apostle say, He left us an
Example, how Christians ought to walk, even as he did? But R. W. and his
New-England-priests cannot endure to hear talk of this Walking and this
Example; This is Socinian, this is Quaker's and yet the Apostle's Doctrine: and
thou, that deniest this, art degenerated from the Apostle's Doctrine, Practice
and Walking. For even hitherto were ye called, because Christ also suffered for
you, leaving you an Example, that ye should follow his steps (1 Pet. 2:) So we
can commit our Case to God, who judges righteously, and does not heed thy
false Judgment.

And so we own the Lord Jesus Christ both his Birth, Suffering, Death,
Resurrection; though thou falsely drawest this Consequence upon us, That the
Body, and Blood and Death of Christ is nothing but a Fancy. We have heard thy
Foul Words and Slander, the Lord knows, there is no such thing in our Hearts:
and if thou had the Fear of God in thy Heart, thou would never have
published such things, to defile peoples minds with such Lying Imaginations of
thy own Brain. And thou shall know one day, that the Lord will return Judgment
upon thee for all thy Hard Speeches against us.

R. W. And as for Devilish, Jesuitical Tricks thou might have kept at home,
p. 137.
who say; G. F. buggles at the Word Humane, as at a Ratle-snake.

Answ. Nay, he does not: but to give a New Name to Christ, which the Scripture
does not give, which thou say, is the Rule -- And we do not find the Word in
the Scripture: and therefore, why can not thou keep Scripture-Terms?

R. W. Thou say: Yet then examine them, (as I have done) what is become of
him? then he is vanished into a Spirit and Ghost.

Answ. R. W. had not a Word to say to G. F. when he was at Providence: where
was the Spirit and Ghost then (as thou call it?) but railest upon him behind
his back. And art thou like to Examine us or our Principles without the Light
of Christ, that call it an Idol? Nay R. W. thou know not thy own
Condition, and therefore thou art not like to Examine ours.

R. W. says, The Sabellians and Quakers are one, confounding Father, Son and
Spirit in one.

Answ. Then thou may say, Christ confounded the Father and the Son, when he
said, I and my Father are one: and that John confounded the Father, Son and
Spirit, when he said; The Father, the Word and the Spirit are one.

R. W. says: There it much Judaism in the Quakers Religion: And then thou
tellest of their Zeal ( as the Quakers) in the works of Righteousness; and, to
pacify God, they put Dirt, and Dung, and Swines Blood and Dogs Necks upon God's
Altar, etc. and Washing of Cups and Platters, etc.

Answ. Where does R. W. prove this, that the Jew put Dung and Dirt, and
Swines-Blood and a Dog's Neck upon God's Altar? let us see Scripture for it,
which is his Rule: And where do the Quakers do so? he should have quoted their
Books: those are false Charges without any Proofs. And as for outward Washings
of Cups and Platters, etc. truly, he is not come so far as the Jews and
Pharisees; for his and his New-England-Priests Outside is not Washed, they have
not so much as a fair Outside. For where did ever the Jews BANISH any of the
Christians upon PAIN of DEATH, and CVT OFF their EARS, and SPOILED their GOODS,
as the New England Priests have done? Nay, have not they Outstript the Jews in
their WHIPPING and in these things? where did ever the Jews BRAND any with an
HOT IRON? we challenge them to prove it by Scripture. And how dare thou speak
of the Father and the Son, and Pardon of Sin, and the Spotless Lamb, when thou
B^asphemously call his Light an Idol and a Fancy? And both yours, and the
Papists and the Jews Ceremonies we are come from, who Worship God in Spirit and
Truth.

And then thou fall'st a scoffing at Women-Ambassadors, etc. Thou might as
well scoff at those Women, that carried the Message and glad Tidings of the
Resurrection of Christ. p: 138.
And then thou speak of our Brutish Salutations of Strangers, Acquaintance
and Friends: and then thou contradictest thy self and say; Some of them will
say, How do ye do? and, Farewell: and when did any of us say, that we put
Holiness in these Tw^ Words? this is thy own Application.

R. W. And thou tellest of a New Way of Feeling and Grabling the Hand instead
of Kissing, and call it an Immodest Way.

Answ. Well! have not the New England Men made a Law against Kissing? And what!
does our Taking one another by the HAND offend thee, that thou call this a
New Way of Holiness? And did not Christ Take the Damsel by the Hand? Took the
Blind by the Hand? ( Mark 5.8.9.) Jesus took him by the Hand? ( Luke 8.) Took
her by the Hand? And ( Act. 9.) did not Peter take Dorcas by the Hand? Did not
the Captain take the Young Man by the Hand? ( Act. 23.) And what! is this a
Crime in R. W.'s Eye, that we Take one another by the Hand?

And was not the Word FAREWELL commonly used in the Scriptures? Does not the
Apostle say, Farewell? ( Acts 15, 29. and 18, 21:) Bad them Farewell? and (
Act. 23, 30.) Farewell? and (2 Cor. 13, 11.) Finally Brethren Farewell? Thou
art Offended, when we say nothing; and Offended, when we say, Farewell: what a
Discontented, Doting Man art thou!

R. W. And thou say: The Quakers dis-respect the Superiors: and some of you
have heard, the Quakers Children said to their Father and Mother, George thou
lie, and, Mary thou lie; a Language, which deserves little less than Death.

Answ. But thou have not mentioned, whose Children these were? nor where they
lived? nor who gave thee this Report? But R. W. says, It deserves little
less, than Death: But if R. W. and his Wife do tell their Children, That Christ
(that died for our Sins, and is our Mediator between us and God, who has
Enlighted us; and Christ says, Believe in the Light: And so if R. W. tells
his Children, that this Christ) is a Fancy and a Whimsical Christ, and his
Light is an Idol: and if his Children should say, He spoke not true, but it was
a Lie of his Father the Devil; then these Children for so saying must deserve
Death? for telling, They Lie and speak not the Truth, seeing it was a Lie, and
not the Truth, that they held forth? when such as R. W. are drawing them from
the true Christ, that died for their Sins? But we do not own nor love any such
thing, that Children should give their Parents the Lie, or be Uncivil or
Irreverent to them.

And we have all Men in Esteem, as they are God's Creatures: and them that Rule
Well, we say, they are worthy of Double Honor. But we ask R. W. and his
New-England-Priests, Whether all the Honor lies in Bowing the Knee, and
putting of their Hats? and saying You instead of Thou to a single Person? if
so, make it good by Scripture: and whether Superiors or Inferiors cannot be
honored without these? ( Secondly) What was the Honor, that the Chief Priests
and Pharisees did seek one from another? and Christ told them, How can ye
believe, while ye seek it? And what is the Honor, that comes from God? And --

R. W. Thou say of Their Crying down of Musicians and Music, so Excellent a
Gift of God, etc.

Answ. We do charge R. W. and his New-England-Priests to show us any Scripture
in the New Testament from Christ and his Apostles, where they said, That
outward Music was an Excellent Gift of God? For did not all the Outward Music
in the Time of the Law and Prophets type forth the Heavenly Music and the
Melody, that the Saints had and have in Christ in his Grace and Spirit? And
further we charge R. W. and his New-England-Priests, if that they had Music
and Musicians in the Church in the Primitive Times, Tell us the Names of those
Musicians, and the Outward Instruments, they Played upon?

And thou art offended at our Tuning and Singing, and call it Fantastical;
and it is like, it is Unprofitable to thee, who call Music the Gift of God.
But had thou been in the Days of the Apostles, their Singing with Grace, and
making Melody in their Hearts, thou would have called it Fantastical and
Absurd, as thou do now.

R. W. And thou say, We condemn Carving, Embroidering and Painting, page 139.
and say, It is commended by God himself in Scripture.

Answ. Here R. W. is one with the Papists, and cries against us as much as
they; and if it be not for Images, it is for the Lust of the Eye, and the Pride
of Life: And this R. W. cries up, as Commended of God; and that Quakers
condemn it. Though there was Carving, etc. in the Old Covenant of Works: But we
charge R. W. and his New-England-Priests, where God and Christ commended to his
Apostles and Disciples Embroidering, Carving and Painting in the New Testament?
and name the Names of those Carvers and Painters, etc. among the Church of the
Primitive Times. Here R. W. is one with the Papists both in his Music, and
Carving and Painting, in saying, They are commended by God, and a Gift of God.
And does not Christ the Substance End all those Outward Things in the time of
the Law in the Old Covenant?

R. W. And thou say, We cry out against Ornaments of Garments, and otherwise
against the Order, God has set in his Works, and the Variety of his Gifts for
Necessity, for Convenience, for Delight, etc.

Answ. How now Roger! art not thou one with the Papists here? Now, we charge R.
W. and his New-England-Priests to make it good by the Scripture in the New
Testament, where Ornaments of Garments are called the Order of God? and that
they should set forth his Works, and that Variety of his Gifts for Necessity,
for Convenience, for Delight? This is a Brave Ranting Doctrine of R. W.'s for
the Lust of the Eye, for the Pride of Life; which is not of the Father.

And art not thou degenerated here from the Apostle's Doctrine in the Primitive
Times, That the Women should adorn themselves in Modesty of Apparel? etc. not
with broidered Hair, or Gold, or Pearls, or Costly Array; but plaiting the
Hair? And Gold and Pearls and Costly Array sets out the Creature, and are
for Delight and Convenience: But the Apostle does not say to the Christians,
that those are for Convenience. But R. W. is angry with the Quakers, because
they Cry against such things (1 Timothy 2, 9. and 1 Pet. 3.4.) Who is Adorning,
let it not be that Outward Adorning of plaiting the Hair, and the wearing of
Gold, or of putting on of Apparel; but let it be in the Hidden Man of the
Heart. Now here ye may see, these things are forbidden by the Apostle; and R.
W. says, for Convenience, for Dilight. And here all may see, how he is
degenerated from the Apostle's Spirit and Doctrine, like unto the Vain People,
Papists and Jews; and how he opposes us, that stand for the Doctrine of the
Apostle: In this he will have Proselites enough, for Delight and Convenience,
his Vain Doctrine, Contrary to the Apostle.

And these are some of the Proofs to prove us to be Like unto the Papists,
Arminians, and Socinians and Judaism, and that we are not as they were in the
Primitive Times: which all these will receive this Doctrine from R. W. very
Joyfully; and so he is nearer to them, than the Quakers, which testify against
all such things. And so J. B. and W. E. might well tell thee, how thou have
charged them, and Proved nothing: and so, these things are left to every Man's
Conscience to Judge, whether R. W. has proved his Charges, or proved himself
to be the Man found in those things, which he has falsely charged upon us; the
Lord God and the Witness in People knows it! And --

R. W. Thou say, Thou asked'st us, where was the Man Christ Jesus now, that
we confessed was Born in Bethlehem, and died at Jerusalem?

Answ. We say, He is, where the Scriptures say He is, to wit, at the Right Hand
of God. He that Descended, is the same also that Ascended; and yet Manifest by
his Spirit in his People ( Ephesians. 4, 10.) To this --

R. W. says, Then musl his Body be Ubiquitary ( as the Transubstantiators and
Consubstantiators are forced to hold) then must his Monstrous Body come from
within his Saints, yea, from within all Mankind to Judgment.

Answ. This R. W. might have told to the Apostles, if he had been in their
Days, and compared Paul's Doctrine with the Papists Transubstantiation, who
told the Saints, that Christ was in them, except they were Reprobates. And what
must we Infer from this Doctrine? That Christ cannot be within his Saints by
his Spirit (who is at the Right Hand of God, and fills all things) but he
must be within them, as a Man of four foot Long, as the Priest says?

And whereas thou say, That then his Body must be Ubiquitary (that is Every
where;) thou may as well tell the Apostle so, who says, He that Descended,
is the same also that Ascended up far above all Heavens, that he might fill all
things. And was not this Christ, that must Judge the World according to the
Gospel?

R. W. And thou tell us of a Woman, Elizabeth Williams, that the Lord opened
her Mouth, and saying: This Man has discharged his Conscience, page 140.
he has fully proved, what he undertook against you; and the Words which he
has spoken, shall Judge you at the Last Day. And then thou go on pleasing
thy self.

Answ. But what! has this Woman set R. W. in the Room of Christ? and must his
Words Judge us? and must we believe, that R. W.'s Words, Lies, false Charges
and Slanders are equal with Christ's Words? So she has proved R. W. the
Antichrist, his Words must Judge us. But R. W. how could the Lord open this
Woman's Mouth, when thou say, There is no Voice nor Motion within in
Heavenly things? etc.

But how can R. W. tell us of the Father of Lights, when he calls Christ's
Light an Idol and a Fancy? And so, as for Deceived and Deceiving Souls R. W.
had better to have kept this at home.

R. W. Thou say, Thou presented'st a Paper to us at Providence ( which thou
had presented, p. 142.143.
at Newport) Anabaptists moving for the Reading of it.

Answ. And Wm. Edmond. might very well call upon thee to make good thy Written
Charges; for thou had written already more, than thou could make good: and
thou bringing in of fresh Matter to spend time, and to put by what was already
in hand. For the Business we had with thee was, to make good thy false Charges;
which thou neither could nor have: and we said well, If the Letter contained
Matter tending to prove thy (false) Charge, it should be read. Then ( R. W.
says) he put it up at the Motion of Capt: Holden. Now the Reader may see, that
we proffered fair, viz: If that it concerned the Matter of thy (false) Charge,
it should be read. And --

R. W. Thou say of John Green asking, Whether R. W. be here as a Delinquent
charged at the Bar, or as a Disputant upon Equal Terms? and thou say, We
waved this as well, as we could.

Answ. He might have seen, that R. W. charged us; and therefore it was but
Civil in all people, for to have heard him to make good his Charges, who
charged so many horrid false Charges against us (or joined with him, which we
offered fairly to them) and showed their Civility to us as strangers in the
Country. For it was he, that Summoned and Arraigned us; and not, that we
Arraigned him: which the Vnprejudic'd Reader may see in his Book over and over,
how he has Arraigned us, and Judged us and Condemned us; but was turned back
upon his own Head. So it had been but Civil for any of the people, that took
his Part, to have Joined with him; or else to have Ceased, differring any New
Matter, till he had done. And --

R. W.'s Seventh false Charge and Position is, viz: [ The people called Quakers
in Effect hold no God, p. 144. Se^ ^ow is W. d^tes ^ere!
no Christ, no Spirit, no Angel, no Devil, no Resurrection, no Judgment, no
Heaven, no Hell, but what is in Man.]

And R. W. brings in Alexander Ross ( G. F. fol. 273.) saying: [ It is horrible
Blasphemy to say, The Scriptures are not the Word of GOD; and to say, The Soul
is a Part of God.] G. F's Answ. [The Scriptures are the Words of God (Exodus 20.
and in the Book of the Revelations:) and Christ is the Word, in whom the
Scriptures end; and he fulfilleth them. And it is not Horrible Blasphemy to
say, The Soul is a Part of God ( to wit of his Breath) for it came out from
him: and that which came out from him, is of him, and rejoiceth in him.] And
these four Books of the Revelations was a Mistake in the Printer (though that,
which was the four Books of Moses, was Revealed to him.) R. W. Replies: G. F.
imagins such a God and Godhead, as maybe d^vided into parts and pieces, etc.
[And this is Answered in the Appendix (p. 108.109.110:) but nevertheless
something we shall say to it.]

(Answ.) And does the Apostle divide God into parts and pieces, when he says;
There is One God and Father of all, who is above all, and through all and in
you all? (Ephesians. 4.) And do not thou confess, The Soul is immortal? and
say; It Is true, in a secondary way ( a Posteriori) as they say, The Spirits
of Men and Angels are as a Lamp lighted up by the Most-High and Infinite
Majesty never to go out (page 49.) And John Stubs read the Words of G. F. and
said: The Reason was to be weighed, which G. F. used, which was; [For it came
out of him ( to wit, out of his Breath) and that which came out of him, is of
him, and rejoiceth in him.] And to this End he desired, the words in Genesis 2.
might be viewed; which he turned to and read, viz: God breathed into Man the
Breath of Life, and he became a Living Soul. And then Samuel Garton said [ If
it be affirmed, that God can be divided, and that Man was a part of God; the
Godhead was destroyed, and the Soul of Man:] But we say no such thing, neither
does G. F. say any such Words But does R. W. and Garton say, That it cannot be
a part of his Breath, by which Man became a Living Soul? and is not the Soul
called the Breath of Life? and does not Robeson say, That the Soul properly is
the Breath of Life, which God did breath into him at his First Creation? that
is his Immortal Soul, which is his Principle of all Breath, Motion and Life in
him. (p. 150.) And there is no such word in G. F.'s Answer of the Divine
Essence, as the Reader may see.

And all the Scriptures, that speak of the Soul, we own; and Christ's saying,
They may kill the Body, but not the Soul: yet God is able to cast both Soul and
Body into Hell; Who is to be feared.

And we own God, who is over all, and in us all, as well without us, as within
us: God, who is a pure, holy Spirit, and Christ at the Right Hand of God (who
has all power in Heaven and Earth given unto him) we own him without and
within, and his Kingdom as well without as within; who is God over all, who is
blessed for ever!

And we own the Angels, who behold the Face of God: and where and in what Book
did ever R. W. read, that we said, The Angels were within us? for if they be
Ministering Spirits, they must Minister to our Souls within us. For are they not
Ministering Spirits, sent forth to Minister to them, who shall be Heirs of
Salvation? ( Heb. 1.)

And Resurrection, and Judgment, and Heaven and Hell we hold without us, as
well as within us, according to the Scriptures. And we must tell thee, all
these Lies thou have of the Father of Lies as well without thee, as within thee.

R. W. And thou tell us a Story of One desirous to give Thanks at Dinner,
asked roundly, To whom should I give Thanks? p. 146.
etc. And thou say: Calvin relates, that one Quintinius, a Leader this Way,
being demanded, how he did? etc. answered resolutely, How can Christ do but
well? and yet at that time he was Sick.

Answ. Now Mark: Instead of proving R. W.'s Charges, he is telling of Stories;
which may be as false upon them, as his Charge is upon us. But R. W. says; In
his time a Leader this Way (to wit, the Quakers) etc. But the Lord knows and
his own Conscience, whether he does not wrong us! and Wm. Edmond. might well
reprove him. And then thou say; Thou would not trouble us with Proofs but
out of our own Writings: and yet thou can not keep out of these Old Stories.
Then --

R. W. Brings Magnus Bine (G. F. Fol. 88.89.) and this is

Answered in the Answer to the Appendix, where he brings it there (in his
page 47.) And well might Wm. Edmond. say to R. W. Let G. F.'s Words and thy
Meaning alone: and keep to his Words. And --

R. W. says: The Fullness of God is one thing, and another thing our (and all
his Works and Creatures) Partaking of that Fullness, p. 147.
etc.

Answ. Who says to the Contrary? But must not the Saints grow up to a Perfect
Man therefore? and unto the Measure and Stature, and the Fullness of Christ?

R. W. And thou say: To partake some Drops of the Ocean of his Wisdom,
Power, Goodness, etc. is not to become the Ocean of the Power, etc. it self.

Answ. But they may come into the Power. But let the Reader see, how he
perverts G. F.'s words all along and his Meanings: And we do believe, thou
wrongest Sam. Fisher as well as thou have us.

R. W. And when G. F. speaks of the Fullness of the Godhead dwelling in
Christ, thou say: He means the Body of the Quakers, etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if there be any such words in G. F.'s Answer. And
that 1 Timothy 3. God is manifested in the Flesh, we own, as the Apostle speaks
it: and S. Fisher's Book neither thou nor J. Owen could ever answer it; though
some of you pervert some of his words.

R. W. And thou bring Magnus Bine, etc. which is also Answered in the Answer
to the Appendix p. 108. -- And thou say: In these few Lines let him that has
his Senses, make Common Sense and English of some of them.

p. 148.
Answ. But let the Reader see in R. W.'s (if he be finding Fault with others*
how he spells Bishop, with Bist-(in his page --) but I can look over such
words, and never heed it.

R. W. Thou go on in thy Railing, and say; The old Serpent has taught
them, in so much that these bewitched Souls say and print, that this World is
God and the Godhead, etc.

Answ. The Reader may see, there is no such word in G. F.'s Answer; neither did
we say any such word at the Dispute at Providence, the people knows it. And
then thou call'st us Horrible and Blockish: thou might have applied this to
thy self, and to that which thou assertest upon us; which are thy own words,
not ours. -- And G. F. asks you the question concerning the Soul: but why
does not R. W. Answer it, and tell, what the Soul is? as the Reader may see in
page 147: in the Book. --

And then thou tell a Story of the Manichees; when this is nothing to the
purpose to prove thy Charge; but to fill up the Book and Time. And the Apostle
says, Beware of Dogs: and ( Cant^: 2:) Beware of Foxes (which thou bring:)
Then the Lambs must beware of such as thou, and of the New-England-Persecutors.

R. W. And thou say: You are to fly, etc. from these brutish Fancies,
brutish Barkings and Blasphemies against the infinitely Glorious and
Inconceivable Excellencies of God, etc.

Answ. Then they must Fly from such as thou, who call Christ's Light an Idol
and a Fancy: and therefore thou art not able to know neither Christ nor his
Godhead.

R. W. And thou qoutest ( G. F.'s Fol. p. 67) Fran. Higginson saying, [ That
one should say, He was Equal with God.] G. F. Answ. [And in the Catechism of
the Assembly of the Priests called Divines, which they have put forth to the
Nation, in which they have laid down (for young Children, and old Men and all
to Learn) That the Holy Ghost and the Son are Equal in Power and Glory with the
Father. Yet if any one come to witness the Son of God to by Revealed in him, or
any come to witness the Holy Ghost in them, as they did that gave forth the
Scriptures, or witness the Mind of Christ, or witness that Equal with the
Father, that Equality which you speak of; ye Priests destroy that which ye have
put forth to the Nation, and cry out; Horrible Blasphemy, etc.] R. W. Replieth,
and begins with Rai^ing and says: The Quakers say, that they are Equal in
Power and Glory with the Father, the Son and Holy Spirit, etc.

Answ. Now let the Reader but read G. F.'s Answer and see, how horribly he
abuses it! does he mention WE? but only the Holy Ghost, and Christ and the Son
of God to be Equal with the Father, according as the Priests said; and yet they
are against this Son and the Holy Ghost to be in Man and Woman.

And the Reader may see, how he has changed a many words in G. F.'s Answer, to
instead of or, and Equality for Equal: and so has changed the sense, and
cries out, Horrible Blasphemy; as ye may see in G. F.'s Answer: And besides he
has left out many of his words. An^ how can they, who are Witnesses of the
Holy Ghost, and Witnesses of the Son; how can it be meant, they be Equal, when
they are but the Witnesses of it? The Reader may see, if R. W. has not do^e
this on purpose, to wrong G. F.'s words.

R. W. Brings ( G. F.'s Fol. p. 282.) Da^. Gawdry saying, [Surely, they
cannot be Perfect here or hereafter in Equality, but only in Quality.] G. F.'s
Answ. [Christ makes no distinction in his words, but says; Be ye Perfect, as
your Heavenly Father is Perfect; page 149.
and be ye Merciful, as He is Merciful: and as He is, so are we in this World.
And that which is Perfect and Merciful, as he is Perfect and Merciful, is one
in Quality with the same thing.] And R. W. Replieth and says: The Quakers
challenge an Equality with God; and cries, Horrible Blasphemy!

Answ. But let the Reader see, if there be any such thing in G. F.'s words in
his Answer? but using Christ's words, Be ye Perfect, as your Heavenly Father is
Perfect; and Be ye Merciful, as He is Merciful: and as He is, so are we in this
present World. Now if these words be Blasphemy, then R. W. may as well call
John's and Christ's words Blasphemy: But none of those Stories proves his
Assertion. And there is not the word Equality in G. F.'s Answer, which R. W.
has basely thrust in. And --

R. W. Brings ( G. F.'s Fol. p. 248.) [ To say, that God is substantially,
etc.] Thou bring Names, and there is no such thing in that page; as the
Reader may see in G. F.'s Folio aforesaid. -- And then thou say: That the
Quakers make themselves Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.

Answ. All people may see, we have need of great patience, to hear all thy Lies
and false Charges; for it is thy own Confession. Thou say, that G. F.
Answers, That God will dwell in Man: and the Saints had Unity with the Father
and the Son; and this is Scripture, as in John 1. And how dare thou enviously
say upon these words of G. F.'s, They make themselves Father, Son, and Holy
Ghost? And thou say, We make no Distinction between Christ Jesus himself, and
his Saints or Believers in him: when often we declared, Christ in us, the hope
of Glory; and, Christ in you, except ye be Reprobates. And how did the Apostles
make the Saints the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost, who preached this Doctrine? R.
W. might as well charge the Apostles, as the Quakers.

R. W. And thou say, We make no other work of Redemption and Justification,
but what is wrought in our Spirits, Minds and Fancies, called within them.

Answ. R. W. we say, Christ is made unto us Redemption and Sanctification; we
make him not, God has made him so to us: For we know him so by his Light
within; and do thou pervert our words? And thou might as well have Charged
the Apostle with such sayings, as us, who says (1 Cor. 1, 30.) But of him are
ye in Christ Jesus, who of God is made unto us Wisdom, and Righteousness, and
Sanctification and Redemption: This we witness; Glory to God for ever. And --

R. W. Brings Christopher Wade ( G. F.'s Fol. p. 246,) saying [ God the
Father never took upon him Humane Nature.] G. F.'s Answ. [Contrary to
Scripture, who says, GOD was in CHRIST, page 150.
