reconciling the World to himself. And art Ignorant of the great Mystery, GOD
manifest in the FLESH: and his Name is called the Everlasting Father. As for
the word HVMANE, which is From the Ground, it comes from thy own Knowledge,
which is Earthly: and Christ took upon him the Seed of Abraham and David,
according to the Flesh, and this is Scripture-Language] R. W. Replieth and
says: page 151.
The Bottom of this is, to deny the Lord Jesus to be a Man, etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see and read G. F.'s words, how he wrongeth him; for G.
F. speaks no such thing. And does not Christ say to his Disciples, when they
asked him, Show us the Father: and he Answered them and said; Believe not
thou, that I am in the Father, and the Father in me? the words that I speak
unto you, I speak not of my self, but the Father that dwells in me, etc. (
John 14.) And --

R. W. Brings in Priest F^rgison ( G. F.'s fol. p. 293.) saying [ That
Christ, the Father and the Holy Ghost are not one, but they are Three,
therefore Distinct.] G. F.'s Answ. [This is a denying of Christ's Doctrine, who
says, I and my Father are One; and the Holy Ghost proceeds from the Father and
the Son, and he was Conceived by the Holy Ghost, and they are all One, and not
Distinct, but One in Unity. And that which comes out from him (to wit, the
Holy Ghost) leads the Saints into all Truth (and that was it, that ever was
given forth from the Spirit of Truth) and so up to God, the Father of Truth:
and so goes back, from whence it came.] R. W. Replieth and says, That G. F.
calls that Blasphemy, which the most-Holy and Eternal Lord calls Heavenly
Truth: he has like some Witches, etc. so inured himself, etc.

Answ. Why R. W? because he speaks Scriptures? art not thou like the
Pharisees, that could not endure to hear Christ say, That he and his Father was
One? And John said, They were One; will thou call him a Notorious Wretch?
Indeed, thy Spirit will call Christ a Deceiver. But R. W. and his Priests say,
They are Distinct: give us a Scripture, that says so, and that they are not
One; and How far are they Distinct one from another; then thou say something.

R. W. And thou say, That the Scripture tells us concerning these Mysteries,
that in this Life we know but in part, as through a Glass, darkly, etc.

Answ. Let the Reader read 1 Cor. 13. and see, whether R. W. has not adds [
In this Life] to the Apostle's words? and the Apostle does not mention [ in
this Life:] So here thou abusest the Apostle's words, as thou do ours. And we
know, Christ says, My Father is greater than I: And what then? does this deny
Christ's words, who said, The Father is in him, and he and the Father is One?
nay, do not your own Books say, They are One and Equal?

But thou wast finding Fault with the Socinians: nay, all the Proofs and
Evasions thou bring'st concerning G. F. and M. F. is nothing to disprove
Christ's words, who says, He and the Father are One. page 152.
And what do thou talk of the Four Points; of the Pather, Son and Spirit,
etc. Fall and Redemption, etc. of the Church Officers, Baptism, etc. and
Resurrection, Eternal Judgment, etc. Art thou like to see them, when thou
call Christ's Light a Fancy and an Idol? For all these we own, as Scripture
declares, both within and without, and therefore thy Charge is false.

R. W. And thou bring'st in Tho: Collier (in G. F.'s Fol. p. 38.) saying [ The
Kingdom is not come, nor the Refreshing from the Spirit of the Lord.] G. F.
Answ. [Which shows, they are like unto the Pharisees, Unconverted, gazing
here and there: and Christ told them, the Kingdom was in them. And they that
are not turned to the Light, which comes from Christ the Refresher, whereby
Refreshing might come, are not come to Repentance yet.] And R. W. Replieth and
says; Who sees not, that G. F. speaks not here of the Kingdom of Christ in
the future and to come, and the times of Refreshing; but that he cuts off all
future hopes and expectations to come.

Answ. The Reader may see, this is a false Interpretation upon G. F.'s words:
for did Christ Cut off all Future Comfort to come to his Saints, when he said,
The Kingdom of Heaven was in them? And they that turn to the Light, receive
Refreshing from the Lord. And G. F. says; They that turn not to the Light,
which comes from Christ the Refresher, whereby Refreshings might come, Receive
not: And how can R. W. say, G. F. cuts off all future Hopes and Expectations to
come? But what should we expect from him, that calls Christ's Light a Fancy
and an Idol?

R. W. says; That the Scripture tells him and Experience, that the Hypocrites
have no solid Peace and Joy here, nor solid Hope or Joy of Glory to come, p.
153.
etc.

Answ. Roger, this is thy own Condition: and if thou did not abhor the
Thoughts of a Judgment to come, thou would never have spoken such words. --
And Foolishly, Atheistically, Childish Dreams of no Heaven and Refreshing,
which thou speak of, thou might have applied to thy self. --

And let the Reader see, if G. F. say, There is no Heaven or Hell, or Torment
in us? etc. is there any such saying in G. F.'s Answer here? These are words of
thy own Forging: and then thou have charged them upon us, and criest; Foolish,
Childish Dreams, etc. which are thy own Sayings, and not ours.

R. W. Brings John Clapham ( G. F.'s Fol. p. 101.) saying: [ To witness
Heaven and Hell, and Resurrection within, is the Mystery of Iniquity.] G. F.'s
Answ. [Which shows, thou never knew'st Heaven in thy self nor Hell there, nor
Christ's Resurrection and the Life, which they are Blessed, that are made
Partakers of the first Resurrection, on them the Second Death shall have no
Power. And the Scripture does witness Heaven within; and if Christ, that was
offered up, the Resurrection and the Life, be not within thee, thou art a
Reprobate.] R. W. Replieth and says: If G. F. would speak of Heaven, and
Angels, and Hell, and Devils, and Resurrection, and Life to come by way of
Allusion and Similitude, or by way of First Fruits or Taste of them, he might
profitably do it.

Answ. All ye, that do not know a Resurrection of Life to come by Christ Jesus,
and know not the Kingdom of Heaven within you, how can ye know it without you?
And know Hell and the Strong Man cast out there, how will ye know the Eternal
Judgment, which is upon the Devil and his Angels? upon the Wicked (cast into
Hell, and the Lake which burns with Fire and Brimstone) which go to the Devil,
who is out of the Truth; who are gone from the Spirit of God, his Grace, his
Truth in the Inwards parts, and his Light which thou call a Fancy and an
Idol, which will condemn thee: and thou shall know a H^ll, which thou so much
pleadest for without thee. And we are not Revolted from the true Christians
Faith and Religion, that was in the Apostles Days, but thou, that deniest this,
art. And --

R. W. in the same page brings Some Nameless Author ( G. F.'s Fol: p. 214.)
saying: [ To say, the Heaven and Glory is in Man, which was before Man was,
they are s^ttish and blind.] G. F. Answ. [There is none have a Glory and a
Heaven, but within them, which was before Man had a being]

And he brings Tho: Pollard's Saying: ( G. F. Fol: p. 81;) [ For a perfection
of Glory to be attained to on this side the Grave, I utterly deny.] G. F. Answ.
[Where Glory is in the least Degree, it is in Perfection; and who have not
Glory, and do not Attain to Glory on this side the Grave, they are in a sad
Condition. For the Saints rejoiced with Joy unspeakable and full of Glory; and
they witnessed the Hope of Glory within them, while they were upon the Earth
(Col. 1:) and of that Hope they were to give a Reason, that was within them.
And they Saw the Glory of God, and of the Father; and so came to be Changed
from Glory to Glory, till they came into the Image of God. And the Apostle saw
etc.] And so ye may read at large in G. F.'s Fol: which is to large to be set
down here: but R. W. has taken about three lines of it, and left out the rest.
And --

R. W. replieth: As the Swinish Epicures and Dives's of this World, (whatever
they formally and loosly profess) have no solid Hope of Peace and Joy to come
after this Life: and therefore ( like Brute Beasts) practically confess it,
saying in their Hearts and Lives; [ Let us eat and drink, for to morrow we must
die, etc.]

Answ. What is this to the purpose for G. F.'s Answer? R. W. might have put
himself amongst his Company, and Judged himself, as well as others, for it is
his own Condition.

p. 154.
R. W. thou say, Thou know, that same of the Quakers will not believe,
that G. F. and others of them deny the Resurrection, etc.

Answ. And why should they believe a Lie, as thou do? and why should not we
stand by G. F.'s words, when he speaks Scripture? and thou that do not,
deniest Scripture, and the Light of Christ, and call'st it a Fancy. And the
Resurrection we own according to Scripture.

R. W. And here thou bring the Ninth false Charge, viz: All that the Quakers
Religion requires externally and internally to make Converts or Pr^selytes,
amounts to no more, then what a Reprobate easily may attain to and perform.

Answ. This is false: for Reprobates do not believe in the Light, and become
not Children of Light, and rec^ive not Christ in them, from whence the Light
comes.

R. W. And thou hopest, many of us will come to Abraham's Bosom. [But then why
do thou rail at us? And how can we come to Abraham's Bosom, and Attain to no
further, then to what a Reprobate may?] And then thou say: Thousands may have
gotten, all their Religion requires or performs, yea, all that their Principles
call for outwardly or Inwardly, and yet not be accepted but rejected from the
holy presence of God.

Answ. How now Roger! and yet come to Abraham's Bosom? O Roger, thy Darkness
cannot comprehend the Light, that see not our Condition, no more then thou
see the Saints in the Apotles Days; thou would have said the same of them,
had thou been in their Day. We know our Assurance of God, and our
Acceptance through Jesus Christ, his Beloved Son, through whom we have peace
with God: and we do know the Son by Revelation, and God that sent him, which is
Eternal Life, Blessed be his Name for Ever! And are grafted into him, and built
upon him, the Rock and Foundation of the Prophets and Apostles: and thy words
are but Chaff.

R. W. And then thou tell a story of Perkins, and appliest that to us, which
he spoke of the Papists: But thou had better to have applied this to thy
self. And thou fall'st a Judging the Common Protestants and Quakers, and
tell of their Great Reformations and Joys, etc. their enduring great
persecution and burning of their bodies, p. 155.
etc. and yet be far from the true Protestant Religion, either in the true
Doctrine and Principles, or in the true Life and Practice of it.

Answ. How can Roger Williams tell? why does he Judge such, that they were not
in the true Religion? -- Who was this Protestant? not in New England, nor R. W;
he never felt the Flame, nor was BRANDED with an HOT IRON: his Religion will
not lead him to undergo such suffering, (for why did he not stand, but go in
the Woods, when he was tried in Boston-Colony?) But R. W. would make people
believe, he was a High Protestant beyond all these; but plainly, he is nothing
but a Railer, as his Book does make manife^t. But let the Reader see, how he
has lost himself, and gone from G. F.'s Answer And --

R. W. Terms our Faith to Rotten Nature, etc: and our Prayyers, and Fastings
and Sufferings to Women's fil^hy Clouts, and dung of Men and Beasts, put into
the Balance of God's Infinite Justice, instead of the Infinite Righteousness
and Satisfaction of the Son of God, etc.

Answ. As for the Papists, they may Answer for themselves; but our FAITH Jesus
Christ is the Author and Finisher of: we had it not from Men nor Rotten Nature.
And we Pray, as we are moved by the Spirit of God; and ^ast, as we are ordered
by his Divine Wisdom: And our Sufferings amongst the New-England-Professors
have been for the Truth and the Name of the Lord Jesus Christ's sake, in whom
our Poor Souls have had Satisfaction. And we know Christ's words to be true,
Blessed are they, that Suffer for Righteousness sake, for theirs is the Kingdom
of Heaven (Matthew. 5.) And for all thy Ungracious Words the Lord will rebuke
thee in one Day; and in that Day of thy Torment remember, thou have wronged us.

R. W. And thou scoffingly say, That if a Notorious Drunkard be convinced,
and come to hearken to a Spirit within, to say Thee and Thou, and thinks
himself Equal and above all his former Superiors, etc. he is Justified,
Sanctified, etc. and so holy, that he cannot sin in Thoughts and Words, etc.
Thus they pretend Repentance, Faith, and a Change of Heart, because they have
changed their Talk and Garments.

Answ. The Spirit of God within leads to no such Sudden Thing; neither is the
Work so easily done, as R. W. here would foist into the minds of the World, to
make them load the Truth: neither shall he find it so easy himself, if ever he
should see a Day of Repentance. And the Spirit of the Lord leads to Humility,
and that is a good Spirit that Leads to Modesty in Apparel, and to True
Words, and from Evil Thoughts, and from Drunkenness. For after a Man is
restrained from Actual Sins without him, then he comes to know the putting off
the Body of it within, and cries as Paul did to Christ: for no Man can help
him then, but He that did help Paul, who Thanks God in Victory in the end. But
why should R. W. be so against the Spirit within, in saying THEE and THOU, and
putting off our needless Apparel, seeing it was the Practice of the holy Men of
God in the Scripture? has not he proved himself, that he is degenerated from
the Spirit, Life and Practice of the Primitive Church?

R. W. And thou say, John Bradford said unto God, Lord thou art Heaven, and
I am Hell.

Answ. And was not this Hell within him, think thou? and if so, why do
thou find Fault with the Quakers?

R. W. Then thou fallest on a preaching; but to no purpose to thy Position, nor
G. F.'s answer. -- And do thou not say, p. 156.
The Blood of God does Cleanse and Redeem (thee)?

Answ. And yet do thou not find Fault with the Quakers, for mentioning the
Blood of God? And the 2 Cor: 7. does not evidence thy True Repentance from a
Pharisee's. And --

R. W. Thou say, That no Papist nor Quaker by their Grounds could get up
this Jacob's Ladder, much less upon Higher Grounds or steps of casting off Self.

Answ. As for the Papists, they may Answer for themselves: and the Quakers Cast
off Self by the Light and Power of Christ, by which they see it; and by which
Light they see Christ, who is their Way to God. R. Williams, thou inventest
words, and then thou fightest against them, which are none of ours. And the
Quakers never said, That the Activity of Nature could advance and clime up any
higher then it self: for Natural Man (we do tell thee) knows not the things
of God; but they are Revealed by the Spirit. And so it is clear, thou art in the
Rotten Nature thy self, thou speak so much of, that hate the Light of
Christ, which call the Light of Christ a FANCY, which gives the Knowledge
of the Glory of God in the Face of Christ Jesus; who remains in the Heavens,
until all things be restored: and he is lifted up, and is drawing Men after him
with his Light, Power and Spirit.

And J. Stubs and we might well say to thee, Thou countest our Religion an
Easy Religion; but thou never trod'st in it. We know, where thou art, in the
Broad Way; for the Narrow Way is not so Easy: thou have not found it yet,
though thou may talk of it. For thou and the New-England-Priests are but
Holders of Opinions and Sayers, Pharisee-like: the Scriptures and your Religion
is but in your Lips, but ye never came into the Possession with God's Spirit of
that, of which they speak. And your Formalities, that ye have performed, have
but been with your own spirits, (that is clearly manifest) and the Evil Spirit,
by which ye have been led to Persecute God's People. And so have manifest your
selves, that ye are not in the S^irit of Christ, nor have his Mind to love
Christians, and to Love Enemies: worse than Ham, who laid open his Father's
Nakedness, for thou invent'st words to make us Naked to the World: But the more
we are Clothed; the Lord clotheth us: Blessed be his Name for ever!

But R. W. is talking of this body's and the other body's Religion, and of
Arminians, Papists and Socinians Religion; but he has not told the World, what
his own Religion is: and so W. Edmondson might very well tell thee, Thou
knew not, what true Religion was (as in thy page 157.) And --

page 157.
R. W. Thou say: Our Religion is like the Papists which is easy and
agreeable with Nature.

Answ. Had our Religion been Easy and Agreeable to Nature than your Corrupt
Nature had not Persecuted us, nor HANGED, nor WHIPPED, nor BVRNT us with your Hot
Iron: but our Religion is that Religion, which James speaks of, which is Pure
and Undefiled, etc.

R. W. And thou say, It is easy to persuade the Quakers, to change one foul
Devil for another.

Answ. Nay, ye New-England-Priests and Professors find it not so Easy, when ye
cannot do it with your HANGING, and WHIPPING, and BVRNING, and BRANDING with
your Hot Iron, and CVTTING OFF EARS: and it is thy own Condition To prate of a
Narrow Path, ( and changing one Devil for another, as thou speak of) but
never came into it.

R. W. And then thou tell a story of the Papists Whipping themselves: [What
is all this to tell such Tales and Stories, to prove thy Charge and Reply to G.
F?] And then thou tell a Story of Mahomet having Thirteen parts of the
World, being divided into Thirty: etc. and the Church of Rome, the great Whore.

Answ. What is all this to the purpose of proving thy false Position against a
Great People (as W. E. said to thee without Boasting) a great people, that thou
had slandered? But your New-England-Priests ( Pharisee-like) have WHIPPED the
Servants of God, instead of Whipping themselves. And --

R. W. thou say: It is to thee, and may be to all men Wonderful, p. 158.
that since the Religion of the Quakers is so Easy, etc. that Ten Thousands
more of People, etc. have not listed themselves under this New Mahomet, etc.

Answ. This is Scoffing R. W: and we must tell thee, neither thou nor Mahomet,
nor the Ten Thousands will find our Way so Easy; which is the Straight Way,
that leads to Life (For as Christ says, We are hated of all Men for his sake
(Mat. 10, 23.) His words are true) And is the New and Living Way, which the
Primitive Christians walked in: which any tenderhearted Christians may see and
savor, that thou art led by a foul Spirit in the broad Way, scoffing at them,
that are in the Narrow Way.

R. W. And thou say: It Is true, we pretend two Horns like the Lamb. [Where
is there any such Pretense in G. F.'s Reply, which thou will maintain thy
Slanders by?] And thou say: The Quakers only want a Sword, to subdue as many
Proselites, as Mahomet and the Pope: The Quakers some prate subtily, some
Childishly against Carnal Weapons, etc.

Answ. R. W. How does this hang together? do we Prate subtily and Childishly
against Carnal Weapons? and yet do we Want a Sword? Nay, we do tell thee, we do
not Want one; for we have the Sword of the Spirit, the WORD of GOD: and we have
and do deny outward, Carnal Weapons to convert people to Religion by, but those
are your Weapons of New England, their Fruits have declared it, whose Souls cry
under God's Altar; How long, O LORD! etc. And therefore let thee and them Dread
God's Vengeance from Heaven. So with your Carnal Sword ye are like Mahomet and
the Papists; for thou say, thou would have us Punished: and that must be
by such, as have the Sword.

And so thine and your Pretenses are Opposite to the Meek and Patient Spirit of
true Purity and Holiness: And what is your Principle then? AND how can thou
say, We are Led by a Dumb Spirit? when thou say (in page 133.) Our Apostles,
and Messengers and Preachers sent into New and Old England? etc. and yet thou
contradictest thy self and say, We are Led by a Dumb Spirit. And as for
Dogged, thou and thy New-England-Priests might have kept it to themselves. AND
thou talkest of Shameful Pride and Vapouring, and Mouthful of Cursing and
Railing, and to march under the Christian Name and Colors; This is thy own
Condition (see Append. p. 119.) Spitting out the Venom (as thou say;) There
thou may see thy self: thou art worse than Balaam, and as bad as Balak.

R. W. Thou say, It Is wonderful, how their Spirit professing to be
Protestants, can so wickedly strike in with the Bloody Spirit of the Papists
against the Witnesses and Martyrs of Jesus. page 159.


Answ. R. W. has not proved any thing of his Charge, not by G. F.'s words,
neither out of other Books: but because J. Parnel calls them Your Records,
this does not prove, that we Strike in with that Bloody Spirit of the Papists
against the Witnesses and Martyrs of Jesus; But it is thou and the
New-England-Priests, that have drunk in that Bloody Spirit, and have drunk the
BLOOD, as they did in Queen Mary's Days, etc. And had those Martyrs been in
your Days, Men and Women, that preached Christ, ye would have served them, as
ye serve us now: And -- Our MARTYRS of JESUS will be
Recorded to POSTERITY --
against you; for the Martyrs bore this same Testimony in many things, as we do.

And again thou speak over and over of our Women going stark Naked: but this
is Answered fully in other places.

R. W. Thou say: Thou wonderest, how any Godly Soul, how any Learned, etc.
who have studied the Primitive Copies of Hebrew and Greek Scriptures, can yoke
with such rude Bablings and Repetitions of simple, ignorant Praters.

Answ. R. W. might very well have applied this to himself: for let him look
back (and the honest Reader) and see his Simple Repetitions and Ignorant
Prating over and over; and therefore are we constrained to speak the same
things over and over: and then in some places we have left the same things,
because we have Answered them so often. And so its true, I do not know, where
Any Godly Soul, either in New England or here does Join with R. W. for he has
not discovered, what Fellowship he is of.

R. W. Thou say: The Hebrew, Greek and Latin, etc. which Helps most of the
Leaders of the Quakers want.

Answ. But what Fruits have either the Papists or R. W. and his
New-England-priests brought forth by these Helps, seeing ye are found in the
Spirit, that Crucified Christ? What Help was the Latin to the Romans, when they
persecuted the Martyrs of Jesus in the Ten Persecutions? What Help was the
Hebrew to the Jews, who Crucified Christ? What Help was the Greek to the
Grecians, seeing Christ faith, It is the Spirit of Truth, that leads into all
Truth? and, No Man knows the things of God, but by the Spirit of God? and, No
Man knows God, but by Revelation; And therefore what Helps are those Natural
Languages to any people concerning their Salvation? But R. W. have not thou
been poring and doting about the Natural Languages, till at last thou art grown
so dark with thy Helps, that thou call the Light of Christ an Idol and a
Fancy? And if we must study the Hebrew, Greek and Latin, as thou have done,
it is to no purpose: and may be some of the Quakers know these Languages better
than thou.

R. W. Thou tellest a great Story of the Ranters, (and thou seem to Join the
Quakers with them; but thou can not, when the Lord has separated them by his
Holy Spirit) where thou say, p. 160.
Thou have known the Ranters almost Sixty Years: -- and thou say (p. 28.)
The Ranters are but the Quakers Ugly Child and Daughter, and Rantism rose from
their Bowels. -- and then again thou say (p. 27.) The Quakers are but a
New-upstart Party or Faction, risen up little above 20. Years since in the
Northern Parts of England, Lancashire.

Answ. Now, let but the Reader read his pages, and see his Confusion and
Contradictions, and how he has Lost himself in his Accounts, in proving the
Ranters the Quakers Daughter; who confesses to his own Knowledge, He has
known the Ranters nigh 60. years ago: and says, The Quakers are but a
New-Upstart Faction, little above 20: Years since, so he has made the Child
(the Daughter) according to his own Knowledge, nigh 40. Years Elder then the
Mother. This is like the Rest of his doting Proofs, to prove our Religion
false. -- And as to the Adamites, and Monstrous Religion, thou might have
kept that to thy self, which the Spirit of God abhors.

R. W. Thou say: These Moderate Times have not driven the Quakers to bow
down to their Spirit for Fear of Persecution, etc.

Answ. This ye know well enough in New England, where it concerned our Lives in
the Heat of your Persecution; we could not Bow to your Image, no more then the
Three Children could Bow to Nebuchadnezzar's.

R. W. Thou say: Some are false and rotten in their Profession, and ready to
fall and tumble, when any strong Wind of Temptation blows upon them. p. 161.


Answ. This is the New-England-Priests and Professors, and R. W.'s own
Condition. For how did thou stand in Boston-Colony? And how did ye stand in
New England? And how have ye Received God's Servants, but with your WHIPS and
GALLOVSES? etc. And so the Lord has tried your spirit, and we have stood your
Tempests and Winds of Persecution, and did not Tumble down. And Christ bids his
Disciples, Take heed of the Leaven of the Scribes and Pharisees; Truly, so his
Disciples must still of you, who are found in that Leaven. And many things thou
writest here, which thou might have applied to thy self. And --

R. W. Thou say; They that are taken by the Quakers Bait, are such as never
Loved truly the Lord Jesus Christ in sincerity, (as the Scripture speaks)
neither within nor without, etc.

Answ. This is like the Rest, Roger: for we declare, None can Love the Lord
Jesus Christ in Sincerity and in Truth ( as the Scripture speaks on) within
and without; but such as own the Light of Christ, which he has enlightened them
withal, and believe in his Light. Then there is a Belief in the Heart, and with
the Mouth a Confession is made to Salvation: and this is not Opposite to Christ
without, as thou falsely speak.

And thou say: And some will plead with Christ at the Last Day, etc. Yea, R.
W. that will be a Sad Day to thee, when thou art rewarded according to thy
Works; who call'st his Light an Idol and a Fancy.

R. W. Then thou say: I told the Quakers, that their Theora John pretended
to write after the Spirit, etc. a Volumn in Hebrew, etc.

Answ. What is this? Why do thou call him Our Theora John, when he never was
no Quaker? But this is like the rest of thy Proofs. And then go on with thy
If's and thy And's to no purpose.

R. W. Thou say: It was a famous Principle of the first New England
Reformers, viz: p. 162.
To be Christianly careful, that their members gave Christian Evidence (so far
as Godly Eyes of Charity could reach) of the truth of their Conversion and
turning unto God; which (thou say) for ought thou know, is not changed by
their Successors.

Answ. Which if so, that the Successors Evidence be the same, that the First
New England Reformers was; then it cannot be the Evidence of a True Christian:
as witness their Fruits of Persecution and Cruelty in BLOODSHED, which never
was an Evidence of a true Church of the true Lord Jesus Christ; but the
Evidence of the false Church, the Whore, that drunk the Blood of the Saints, as
the Church of New England has Evidenced and proclaimed to Christendom and the
Indians also.

R. W. says, That our Religion, Principles and Practice arise to no higher,
then what a Reprobate may attain unto.

Answ. What! because New-England's Religion, Principle and Practice has ris^n
no higher, then what a Reprobate may attain unto? therefore he Judges, that
ours Attaineth no higher, than his own. And poor Man, how can he do otherwise,
when he blasphemeth against the Light of Christ, which We are commanded by
Christ to believe in, and to receive him in us; and so no Reprobates.

R. W. Brings forth his Tenth Position: That the Popes of Rome do not swell
with, and exercise a greater Pride, then the Quakers have expressed and would
aspire unto; although many truly humble Souls may be Captivated amongst them.

And R. W. Thou say: Thou have a spacious Field to walk in, the Pride of
Christ Jesus his pretended Triple-Crowned Vicar, and the Pride of the New
Papists pretending to be Christ himself. [and under the Papists he means us.]

Answ. As for the Papists (as we have often said) let them Answer for
themselves. And where did ever any of the Quakers pretend to be Christ Jesus?
we charge R. W. that he show it; there is no such thing in G. F.'s Answer,
which he quoteth to prove his false Charges. But as for his calling us New
Papists, truly, this hits himself and his New-England-persecutors, whose Image
they have born; their BLOODY HANDS and their Laws declare it, they be in the
Spirit of the Old Papists, and not we, who suffered Death by both of them both
in Rome, in France and in New England: and we may very well call it NEW ROME.

R. W. And thou tell us of the Devil's Pride and Condemnation in Spiritual
Gifts, Privileges and Excellencies: this was the Devil's Break neck, and will
be of the Pope's and Quakers, etc.

Answ. R. W. and do not thou say (page 154.) Thy Hope is, that many of us may
come to Abraham's Bosom? and now do number us with the Devil's Pride, and our
Necks must be broken with him and the Pope? And under the Devil's Condemnation?
R. W. might have applied this at home better, and to many of the
New-England-Church, then to the Quakers. But R W. and the New-England-Priests,
we would have you make good by Scripture, what Spiritual Knowledge the Devil
has, and Spiritual Gifts and Privileges, and Spiritual Excellencies? For
Christ says, There is no Truth in him (the Devil;) and then what spiritual
Knowledge, spiritual Gifts, spiritual Privileges and spiritual Excellencies
has the Devil? describe them, and let us see, where they be written in the
Scriptures, that Christ and the Apostles said so much of the Devil, as thou
have done?

R. W. Thou say: As to the Quakers, they know, it is not yet time to put on
the Eagle's and the Lion's, but the Sheep's and Foxe's Skin, and say; But if
-- let loose, the Quakers Spirit -- would scorn to come behind the Pope. p. 163.


Answ. Thou and the New-England-priests might very well have applied this at
home, who have gotten the Sheep's-Skin; but have been the Wolves and Foxes,
devouring the Lambs. But it is the Pope's Spirit, (and not the Quakers) who
have shed the Blood of Christ's Martyrs: So have the New-England-People SHED
our BLOOD for the Testimony of Jesus. But we and the Reader may understand,
that their Guilty Consciences are afraid of an Eagle to be let loose upon them:
And is not the Fourth Angel pouring out his Vial upon your Head, that makes
thee to Blaspheme? and the Fifth upon the Seat of the Beast, that you Gnaw your
Tongues so, and Blaspheme the God of Heaven? So it is clear, that ye are not
Come behind the Pope's Spirit, who have SHED the BLOOD of the Lambs of Christ:
And so the Comparison is true between you and the Pope, and not the Quakers,
whom thou wickedly slanderest.

And W. Edmond. saying, That thou had slandered many people both in Old
England, etc: Did this fright thee? This was not a Boasting of our Numbers, as
thou scoffingly say, W. Edmond. was a fit Man to make a Bonifacius or a
Hildebrand, and J. S. also, etc. and all of them are ready to cry up Diana,
whom all Asia and the World worshippeth.

Answ. Now let the Reader see, whether R. W. speak Truth or no? Do All call
Christ the Light (with which he Lights every Man that comes into the World)
and God (whom we worship in Spirit and Truth, as Christ commanded above Sixteen
hundred Years since) Diana, whom the World worshippeth? What an Enmity is in R.
W. against Christ, his Light and the Worship of God! (as John 4.)

And as for his Saying Bonifacius and Hildebrand, which W. Edmond. and J. S. is
so fit to make, This he might have very well applied at home to his
New-England-Priests, and see his Boniface there, and BLOODY pers^cution ready
made: J. S. they cast him in the Goal; and Nicholas Alexander a Justice of
Peace of Jamaica, when they came to visit their Friends, they cast him in the
Goal: And this was their Entertainment in New England.

R. W. And thou say: In their first Creeping ( like Hercules) out of the
Cradle, how does this Spirit dare the Spirits of Kings, etc. to Thou and Thee
to the Faces of Mighty Monarchs: with what ^r^zen, Faces, etc.

Answ. The Reader may see, what a plague the word THEE and THOU is to R. W! yet
was the Language of Christ and the holy Men of God both to Superior and
Inferior. And R. W. who calls himself an Orator, what! has he not read his
Accidence and Grammar, Plural and Singular? Is the Practice of this called
Brazen Face by R. W? Then why do they teach the Children Plural and Singular?
AND for their First Creeping ( like Hercules) etc. Plainly, this might the New
England-priests and professors very well applied to themselves: What
Protestations of Religion have they made in their First Creeping out? And how
at last they threw it all down, and turned it into Persecution both among
themselves and Strangers.

R. W. And thou art offended, because we do not Bow our Knee, and Uncover our
Heads (which thou call'st Reverence,) etc.

Answ. Is not R W. worse then the Turk here, and more fonder of his
superstitious Honor? For does not the Turk say: The Christian spends most of
his time in showing of his Bare Head? But where did the Apostles or Christ
command, that the Christians should Put off their Hats one to another, and Bow
their Knee, and say YOU to a Single Person? We do charge R. W. and the
New-England-priests to give some Scripture for it, seeing they make so much to
do about it. And W. Edmond. saying Whist, Whist, upon this thou scoffingly
call'st him Pope Edmondson: Nicholas Easton, p. 164.
the Governor was not offended at it; and what should R. W? but only proud
Pharisee-like, seeking the honor one of another, and is off^nded, because he
has it not. And if the Honor was sought, which comes down from above, this
would be laid into the Dust. BUT has not R. W. who looks so much at Putting
off the Hat, and Bowing the Knee, proved himself to be Like the Pope here, and
not the Quakers who Put off the Hat and Bow their Knee neither to him nor the
Pope, and neither King nor Governor are offended at it? So R. W. has proved
the New-England-priests and himself like the Pope, and not the Quakers, with
his Hat and Knee.

R. W. Thou say, That the Pope sits in the Temple of God, as over the
Churches and Consciences, etc.

Answ. So does R. W. and his New-England-priests BRAN^, HANG, WHIP and SPOIL
the GOODS of such, as will not Bow to the Image of their Religion, etc.

R. W. And thou say, That We do not regard; as the Ap^stle and the Bere^ns,
the Holy Scripture.

Answ. This is false: for we trying you by the Scriptures, makes you so to
Rage, whose words and practice is Contrary to them, and therefore you cry so
often for Meanings. And it is the Spirit of Truth, that proceeds from the
Father and Son, that leads into all Truth, and leads us into the Truth of
the Scriptures.

AND why should not we send Word to our Friends of Coming into the Country?
etc. this does Torment thee: Yea, and the Lord will Torment you more; who is
gathering his people, and drawing them to his Son, and bringing them from your
Barren Mountains: and he has set his Shepherd over them, Christ Jesus. Read
Ezekiel: 34. how ye have Marred Pastures and Foul'd Springs, and Thrust the Sheep
with your Shoulder. And --

R. W. is offended, because our Meetings are Established in New England. And
thou tell of Laws, Papers and Decrees, but thou have not produced them. And
it was always our Practice, as thou scoffingly say, [ There was not Liberty
for all to speak, as the Spirit gave them Utterance, till G. F. came into
New-England] That is false. And our Unity stands in the Holy Spirit of God,
which is the Bond of peace; if any go from it, they are reproved. And why
did not thou produce the Decrees, thou say, G. F. gave forth, p. 165.
of loosing from that brutish and dogged Behavior, etc. and commanding them to
be more Sociable and Man-like?

Answ. This is Untruth: for G. F. gave them no such Command: this is a base
Reflection upon thy Neighbors, for they were Sociable and Manlike before. And
as for brutish and dogged, Roger may keep at home: for he had not so much
Civility, as to speak to G. F. when he was at Providence; but snarling behind
his back, Base and Vn-manlike. And did not we Bow and Uncover our Heads in
Prayer, etc. before G. F. came to New England?

R. W. But thou say of G. F. uncovering his Head, and Bowing to the people,
and passing through the midst of them with his Hat in his Hand, with much
Respect and Civility: and he blames others, that did not so, etc. Therefore
thou Concludest, that either the Former Spirit or the Latter is not of God --

Answ. According to thy forged Lies or false Reports. Neither did G. F. Uncover
his Head, nor Bow to the people, when he past through them; it is not his
Practice: though he might take his Hat in his hand, when he was Hot, and walked
through the people. And G. F.'s putting off his Hat was in Reverence to the
Lord, the God of Heaven, and not to Man.

R. W. Thou say, The Pope lifts up himself as God over the Scriptures, and,
He is Sole Judge, etc: and dispenses of Oaths and Marriages, etc.

Answ, Might not R. W. have kept this at home, with his New-England-Priests,
that They must be the Interpreters of the Scriptures, and so Over the
Scriptures? For does not R. W. cry out against us for Want of Meanings, and
says, We take it Literally, and we are Fools and Silly, and will not own your
Meanings? And therefore do not thou claim the power of the Expounding, as the
Pope does. AND are not the New-England-Priests and Professors both the
Dispensers of Oaths and Marriages ( Pope like?) But we neither Swear, nor Marry
none, but are Witnesses to them.

R. W. For do not thou say, We admit of no Interpreter, but Our selves?

Answ. Nay R. W. It is not Self, that Interprets Scripture: we tell thee, they
were given forth from the Holy Ghost, and it is the Holy Ghost, that leads
into all Truth of them: which the Papists and ye cannot endure to hear of; and
so are of one Birth, that persecutes him that is born after the Spirit.

R. W. And thou say, That we said, We would be tried by the Scriptures; and
yet (thou say) We admit of no Interpreter, etc.

Answ. Then the Scripture it self is not the Trier, but the Meaning, which the
Interpreter gives, must be the Judge, according to thy sense: How is the
Scripture the Judge then, as thou say? And so the Meaning is set up, and not
the Spirit, and this makes the Confusion in the whole World: and is not this
One with the Pope? And we say, The Spirit of God is the Interpreter of its own
words, that gave them ^orth.

R. W. And thou say over and over, That the Papists and Quakers said, that
there would be no Loss if the Scriptures were gone out of the World.

Answ. These are but thy own words, to prove thy false Charges, that thou
say: We most horribly and hypocritically trample the Scriptures under our
proud Feet.

R. W. And whereas thou say, Tha^ the Quakers and Papists most Insultingly
lift up themselves against the Servants and Children of God all the World over,
p. 166.
that bow not to their Images.

Answ. R. Williams has mistaken himself; it is he and the
New-England-Professors, and the Papists: for never did the Quakers force any to
their Religion by WHIPS, etc: So they are Brethren in Iniquity. And so the
tender Babes have been TORN, and received MARKS in their Backs with your WHIPS,
and the BRAND with your Hot Iron, and your CVTTING OFF EARS, and your Immodest
STRIPPING of Women and Maidens at your Whipping-posts. NOW we do Charge R. W.
and all his New-England-Priests, where ever Christ, or the Apostles or the
Church in the Primitive Times did Strip Men and Women, Young and Old, as ye
have done? O! ye have been a Shame to Christianity among the very Indians!

R. W. says: And say not the Quakers ( as the Pope, etc.) All that believe not
in their pretended Light, their Repentance, Holiness Zeal, Preaching, etc. is
nothing.

Answ. The Papists do not own the Light; for Papists do not believe in the
Light, that lights every Man, that comes into the World, no more than thou,
and you of New England. And so in this thou can not compare us with the
Papists, but thee, that call the Light of Christ (which Christ bids us
Believe in, that we may become Children of the Light) an Ido^ and a Fancy: But
thou and they, that do so, are in a blind Zeal, and cannot see Repentance. And
what is your Holiness and Preaching good for without the Light of Christ, that
shines in the Heart, that should give the Knowledge of him? AND we do profess
and preach Christ, that Died without the gates of Jerusalem without us, and yet
is manifest to us by his Spirit, and dwells in our Hearts by Faith (Ephesians. 3)
yea, it is for his sake, that the Birth of the Flesh Persecutes us: and so we
follow the Lamb, his Leading.

AND so as for Apollo's Worshippers, by whose Priests the Devil gave Oracles,
R. W. might have applied at home, who owneth no Voice or Motion of Heavenly
things in him; and therefore how can he Worship God in Spirit and Truth? AND
this Hebrew Child, the Lord Jesus Christ, will stop thy Mouth, as he did the
Devil's, whom Apollo Consulted withal (as thou say) for neither he nor thou
have proved your Lying Charges: And G. F.'s words stand against thee clear from
thy Charges:

R. W. And why do thou say, We upbraid all other Ministers and people for
being out of the Infallible Spirit? page 167.


Answ. Do not your Ministers, and People and Professors Confess; Ye have not
the same Immediate Holy Ghost, as the Prophets and Apostles had? So then, are
not ye Fallible ( Pope and Papist-like) and not true Ministers and Overseers
made by the Holy Ghost* who are not led by the same Holy Ghost as the Apostles
were? and so degenerated from the Apostles Spirit in the Primitive Times: And
J. Stubs witnessing the Unction and saying [as in John, etc.) Hereby we know,
that we dwell in him, because he has given us of his Spirit ( John 1.] and W.
Edmondson, they did not proudly boast of the Spirit (as thou scoffingly say)
but they spoke, what they knew.

R. W. says: The Apostles were Eyewitnesses of the Resurrection of Christ,
etc. but who are you? etc.

Answ. Yea, but Who are you? and who art thou, that call the Light of Christ
a FANCY?

R. W. And thou say, That G. F. said at Providence, that he opened the Eyes
of the Blind.

Answ. But thou did not hear him say so, for thou wast not there: and yes, he
and we do, turning them from Darkness to Light. But thou, that call the
Light a Fancy, stoppest their Eyes? As for the Pope's and Balaam's (thou
migth'st have put in Balak too) Saying, This he and his New England Priests
might have applied to themselves, and not to the Quakers: for they have not
only railed and cursed, but HANGED; outstript Balak and Balaam.

AND as for the Quaker in London and She-Apostle, that called some Devil in
New England; That was not of God, that SHED his Servants BLOOD, nor that Envyes
them. page 168.
-- AND the Quaker at London carrying Dung in to the Priest; It was to show
him, that it was Like his and your Profession: who ventured his Life. But you
New-England-Professors could cast him into your Prison at Boston: That is your
Entertaining of Strangers at Boston.

R. W. Thou say: It is the great point of horrible Pride both among Papists
and Quakers, exalting Dung and Dirt of their own Qualifications, ^xcellencies,
Graces, etc. and so go on railing and say, That we count the Business of
this Christ ( as the Pope said) but a Fable.

Answ. This is false, the Lord knows it! It never entered in our Hearts. And
thou that art to prove thy false Charges with such horrid Lies, add'st Lie unto
Lie: and therefore what are your Qualifications and Excellencies, but Dung and
Dirt? which thou might have applied to thy self, and not to us. And let the
Papists Answer for themselves: And R. W. should go to Rome, and tell them so;
but there he dare not show his Head.

R. W. And thou say, That We exceed the Pope in our Doctrine of Perfection.

Answ. Yes Roger, and Thee too; who say, Thou must have a Combat to the
Grave, and be Fighting all thy Life time: and give the Apostle the Lie, who
said, He had Fought a good Fight, etc. and then he was not Fighting.

R. W. Thou say: G. F. mak^s a^ the Saints born of God.

Answ. What is a Saint R. W? The Apostle tells thee, He that believes, is born
of God. ( John 1, 5.) So thou manifestest, that thou art not a Believer, that
opposest his Doctrine. (But these and many other things are Answered; which he
brings over and over to fill up this Book.)

R. W. Thou say: They can prove, that the Three, that bear Record in Heaven,
and the Three that bear Record in the Earth, and the Scripture is within them,
they made it, etc.

Answ. R. W. Thou art a Forger of these words (which thou bring to prove thy
false Charge) and to say, That we are the Father, Son and Spirit; when we never
spoke such words: neither are such words in G. F.'s Book, neither did we ever
hear such words before, as thou have invented. What! because Christ says, He
and his Father are One: And, We have the Spirit of Christ, and he dwells in
us, and, We are the Temple of God; Does it follow, that the Apostle had
preached this Doctrine, and said, The Saints were GOD? And because John says,
There is Three, that bear Record in Heaven, etc. and therefore does it follow,
that They are the Three? Well! but R. W. thou may do thy work: and those
Lies may be Food for the Persecutors in New England, but not for the Children
of God.

And H. B. affirming, that which he spoke to you, was that God gave him, etc.
But what was his Ridiculous Folly acted amongst you at Barbados and London
since, that thou have not set it down? page 169.
And thou should have put down his Name at large; for we do not know, who it
is, thou speak of. But R. W. would have us to know, that His Words were from
God, yea, and his Sisters; but his Words and Spirit are favored not to be from
GOD.

AND J. Stubs spoke Truth, That it is our practice to pay Tribute to Caesar,
and Honor, to whom Honor, etc. But --

R. W. says: It was against our Principle and Practice, to show Respect to any
Person.

Answ. That is false: and thou know, much Respect was showed unto thee, and
Patience; yet thy Peevish Spirit was offended, because we called thee Old Man.
AND there are no such Words in G. F.'s Writings, that say, That we are the
Higher Power, the Dignities, the Most-High GOD; but that every Soul must be
Subject to the Higher Power. O. R. W! how dare thou speak those Forged Lies
without Shame, Blushing and Trembling, if thou ha^'^^ any Fear of God in thy
Heart! Do the Magistrates in Rode-Island profess any such thing, which have the
Government, or the Governors? And where did we desire Tribute of R. W. or the
New-England-Professors, or the whole Creation? We charge thee and them, to
Answer it: mention the Person and Time. And we are the same as ever we were. --

AS for Juggling and Dissembling, thou may keep at home: and it would be
well, if thou and the New-England-Priests and Professors could find a Day of
Repentance. For have not the New-England-Priests and thou taken the Authority
of God to Judge and Rule over Men's Consciences, which is the Seat of GOD?

R. W. And thou scoffingly say, That we read the Fourth Charge, as willing
to be out of Pain.

Answ. R. W. thou appearest to be Light, Frothy, Scoffing and Scornful, and not
like an Aged Man, that should be a Good Example to the Younger. And so thou
have plainly proved thy self and the New England Priests to be the Swellers,
thou speak of (in the Third false Charge, at Providence) exercised with
Pride; and that your Religion, Principles and Practice rise no higher, than
what a Reprobate may attain unto; Who hate and scoffest at the Light of
Christ, and call it an Idol: which thou must believe in, before thou art a
true Christian; or else it will be thy Condemnation.

R. W.'s (Eleventh) False Charge: The Religion of the Quakers is more
Obstructive and Destructive to the Conversion of Souls and People, than most
Religions, that are at this Day extant in the World.

Answ. Our Religion is the pure Religion and undefiled, which was in the
Apostles Days: and thy Religion and the New-England-Priests, (that call the
Light of Christ a Fancy, which John was a Witness to, and Christ said, Believe
in) is Destructive to people both to Conversion and Salvation. For how can they
see Christ their Salvation without the Light of Christ? And how can they see
the True Religion from the False without the Light of Christ? And therefore we
tell thee, without the Light of Christ thou know neither our Religion, nor
thy own, nor others in the World, which in thy Darkness thou would seem to
be a Judge of.

AND then to prove thy false Charges, thou bring'st us a great Story and Tale
of the Pagans, and the Pope's and Mahom^ts Worship, and the Jews, Who art as
Ignorant of theirs, as thou art of the true Worship, page 170.
Christ set up above Sixteen Hundred Years since.

R. W. And thou tellest, How the Protestants have revolted and separated
themselves from the Papists, and have cried up the Lord Jesus in the Scriptures.

Answ. But how is R. W. and the New England-Priests revolted and separated from
the Popes, when they are found in their Envious, BLOODY Spirit? And how does R.
W. cry up Christ in the Scriptures? Is Christ in the Scriptures? (to wit, in
the Writings?) Christ says, They testify of him; and what Sense is this, to
say, Ye cry up Christ in the Scriptures? The Apostles and the Quakers Preach
Christ at the Right Hand of God, which the Scriptures testify of. And Christ
says, And it is Written of me; he does not say, He is in the Scriptures: And
the Apostle does not say, Christ is in the Scriptures; if he does, let us see,
where it is Written? and keep to the Form of sound Words.

R. W. And then thou tell us a Story of the Episcopalians, and Presbyterians
and Independants, etc.

Answ. As though R. W. was a Judge of all these and many others, and yet
denies any Voice or Motion of Heavenly things within himself, and calls the
Light of Christ an Idol. Yet in all this he has not discovered his own
Religion, and what he is of himself? for we do not understand, that he is
settled or joined with any of these Protestants Religion in any way of Worship,
except by his Slanderous Book he may get into Favor with some Loose and
Persecuting Spirits.

R. W. And thou say, Those Religions differ each from the other, as the
Quakers do from the Papists.

Answ. And does not R. W. himself differ with them all? And R. W. if the
Papists and the Quakers differ, do thou say so? which wast making us one all
this while?

R. W. And thou say, That we are more Destructive to the Souls of Men, p.
171.
than the Papists, who wildly profess all Ordinances and Ministers to be
Invisible; and yet are found to be as Visible and Open as any.

Answ. Here is a false Charge; we never professed, but the Bodies of the Saints
and Ministers were Visible: but being Able Ministers of the Spirit, the Spirit
is Invisible. And we do believe, thou have more Love to the Papists, than to
us; and that we are more Destructive to thine and your Hypocritical Way and
Worship, than the Papists. But as for Destructive to the true Religion and the
Souls of People, this the New-England-professors and thou might have applied at
home, who call'st the Light an Idol; by which Light they should see their Sins,
and know their Savior, that died for their Sins, and saves them. AND it is in
vain for thee to tell of Repentance, and Faith, and Saving of Souls, and the
Worship of God in the Spirit and Truth, and know of no Voice nor Motion of
Heavenly things within thee to be hearkened unto; All thy Religion, and thy
Worship and Profession has been but from the Lips and the Mouth, not from the
Heart. And we never Cracked of Quaking and Trembling, as thou scoffingly
say; but we do Work out our Salvation with Fear and Trembling: It is God,
that works in us both to will and to do according to his pleasure. And all,
that come to Worship God in Spirit and in Truth, they must come to the Truth
in their Hearts, the Spirit of God there, to mortify their Evil Nature, etc.
and this they will not find Easy.

R. W. And then thou say: The Turks and Papists ( to thy knowledge) take
more pains in their Religion, than the Common Protestants; and thou Confessest,
they do all but paint and gild over Nature's old and rotten Posts.

Answ. This is thine and New-England's Condition, far of a true Faith and
Repentance; and that thou and you cannot see, that call the Light of Christ
a Frantic Light and a Fancy: And did Paul, that turned people from Darkness to
Light, etc. turn them to a Fancy? And --

R. W. Thou say; The Quakers come not near that Care of New England (I am
sure, at first) for the personal true Repentance and Holiness of their Churches
and Congregations: and in the Margent thou say; That the Quakers Conversion
is not comparable to the Way of New England.

Answ. What ever their Conversion was at the first, this we know, that the
Church in New England are not now true Converts; they are not turned from dead
Works to serve the Living God: Nay, they are not turned from the Cruelty,
Persecution and Envy of the Unconverted Jews and Heathens (as their Fruits at
large have manifested it) Then they are degenerated, from what they were at
first. Therefore the Comparison will not hold between the Quakers Conversion,
who like Lambs have suffered even unto DEATH, and yours, who Cruelly have
persecuted even unto DEATH: Therefore their Conversion is made no Conversion.

R. W. And then thou fall'st a-Railing again at our speaking THEE and THOU,
etc. and bowing down to a dumb Image and Worship, etc. and that we say, we are
God and Christ.

Answ. Which is Answered over and over, and thy false Charge denied: for we
never of our selves said any such thing; but God and Christ dwells in us. AND
why art thou angry so much at THEE and THOU? and yet thou confessest, It is
according to the Accidence and Grammar?

R. W. And then thou tellest us a Story of the Papists and Arminians
Flattering, etc. Flatterers.

Answ. Which thou better might have applied at home: and well might W. E.
say, We dealt plainly with thee, and you and all Men.

R. W. And thou say, Thou Intended'st to add, that the Quakers pretended to
be as fine Flower sifted* out from the Common Protestants, p. 172.
Independants and Baptists; And so go on a-Railing.

Answ. Thou do not know, what thou say, for we Pretend no such thing: for
we are the Offspring of the Lord, and of Abraham, who walk in the Steps of the
Faith of Abraham.

R. W. And thou said: As the Whore of Rome deceived whole Towns and Cities,
etc. so the Painted Quaker (as a drunken Whore) should follow the drunken Whore
of Rome ( drunk with the Blood of Jesus, etc.) etc.

Answ. R. W. here thou have falsely charged us, and speak a false Divination
of thy own Brain, and not from the Lord. But let the Quakers, and the
New-England-Professors and the Papists be examined, and see, who has DRVNK
BLOOD? and who is the Painted Whore? whether it be not R. W. and his
New-England-Professors? BUT R. W. Is the Whore of Rome Drunk with the Blood of
Jesus? (as thou say) Is the Saints Blood the Blood of Jesus, that cleanses
from all Sin? For John says here, Drunk with the Blood of the Saints; but does
not say, Drunk with the Blood of Jesus: We charge R. W. and the
New-England-Priests to make this good, that the Saints Blood is the Blood of
Jesus. For thou say, Drunk with the Blood of Jesus for the obtaining of the
Smoke of a Tobacco-Pipe, etc. We do believe, thou wrongest the Papists here (as
bad as they are) for to be Drunk with the Blood of the Saints (which thou
call Jesus) for the obtaining of ( the Smoke of a Tobacco-pipe) Riches, etc.
show us the Chronicle for this.

R. W. And after thou have told several Stories of David and Absalom, Joab and
Achitophel (which is nothing to the purpose to prove thy false Charge) thou
say; We and the Jesuits will be found at last to be Apostles, p. 173.
Messengers, Emissaries of Satan, sent out from Hell to predicate the Goodness
of rotten Nature, Hell and Damnation, that false Hellish Gospel: And so go
on railing.

Answ. R. W. might have kept this at home, and his New-England-Professors, who
have proved this already, from whence they came, with his Jesuits in their
bloody Practice; and not blasphemed the Everlasting Gospel, and say, It comes
from Hell: Which was Revealed to the Apostle, and Revealed now again; which is
the Glorious Gospel, CHRIST, which has brought Life and Immortality to Light,
and preserves us in Life and in Immortality. And this Gospel he cannot damn;
though he endeavors it with his Rotten Nature. And if he Saw but himself to
Know, whose Image he was, and whose Work he was a-doing; he would dread the
Lord God, that hears his Words, and sees his Work, and will reward him
accordingly.

R. W. And thou say: The Devil knows, that after the VVitnesses have done
their Work against Antichrist, and after their Slaughters, the Lord will send
his Messengers abroad, etc.

Answ. The Lord God has sent his Messengers abroad with his Everlasting,
Glorious Gospel, whom ye, like BLOODY Butchers, have slaughtered some of them
in New England; and your Gospel needs a Rope-maker's Shop to make WHIPS and
HALTERS, and needs a Smith's Shop to make you Swords, and Chains and
BRANDING-IRONS: which manifests, it is not the Gospel of the LORD JESUS
CHRIST.

But New Jerusalem is come down from Heaven among the Sons of God; and it is
you, that have been stirred up against them with your outward Swords and
Staves, like Mahomet or the Jesuits, (or Papists) who fish for smoke of this
World's Sodom, thou speak of; and not the Quakers.

R. W. And thou say: Cursed is that Charity, that puts out the Eye of
Reason, etc. and the Eye of true Affection to Christ Jesus.

Answ. And have not thou in this Cursed thy self, who call his Light, which
opens this Eye, which comes from him to see him, an Idol? And Christ said,
Believe in the Light, etc. and what think thou, this was an Idol, he bid
them believe in?

R. W. And thou say: As to the Saving of Souls, it was a Thunder from the
Heavenly Mouth of Christ Jesus [ They that t^ke the Sword, shall perish by the
Sword] As if he should say The Sword is not a Saving, but a Destroying Tool, in
Soul-humbling and Soul-Saving: making worlds of Hypocrites, but not true
Protestants and true Christians, and Followers of the true Lord Jesus.

Answ. HERE Roger Williams, who is going about to prove his false Charge upon
the Quakers, has proved himself and his New-England-Priests one with Mahomet
and with the Papists: he has proved them to be Hypocrites, and not true
Protestants, and no true Christians, and no true Followers of the Lord Jesus
Christ, no Soul-Savers by their Carnal Weapons: and proved them Disobedient to
the Commands of Christ Jesus from his Thundering, Heavenly Mouth, as he calls
it. For have not the New-England-Men forced and compelled by the Sword to
Religion? let their WHIPS, STOCKS, their GALLOVSES, their BANISHINGS upon Pain
of Death, their Cutting off EARS, their BVRNING and BRANDING with an Hot Iron
speak their Hypocrisy, and declare, that they are no True Followers of Christ
Jesus, nor no True Christians, nor no True Protestants, R. W. proves himself
and his New-England-Professors no true Christians.
but Destroyers and Makers of Hypocrites: nor no Soul-savers, (according to
R.W. his own Doctrine) and he amongst them; who would have the Magistrates to
PVNISH us. ( page 200.)

And is not this Destroying Tool still in your Hands, by which ye make
Hypocrites, and no true Protestants, nor Christians, nor Followers of the Lord
Jesus? And our Weapons is the Sword of the Spirit, the WORD of GOD: and this
R. W. calls Fantastic, and Weakness and Madness. And thou say --

R. W. Thou know, that the true Lord Jesus, his Holy Father and Holy Spirit
is as odious both to Jesuits, p. 174.
and most Papists and Quakers, as the Devil, yea, infinitely more than the
Devil himself.

Answ. R. W. These are Horrid Lies, and thou have spoken thy own Condition, who
call the Light of Christ Frantic* Therefore thou art not like to know Jesus
Christ, nor the Father, nor his holy Spirit. And as for the Papists, they may
Answer thee themselves: Thou do not matter, what thou say, thou think,
Thy Tongue is thy own: who vent'st all those Lies against us. For had we not
Loved Jesus Christ, and the Father, and been in his Holy Spirit, we had never
had such Language from the Evil Spirit in thee. And Fisher, Stubs and
Pennington, and Bishop, their Words and Books will stand as a Testimony against
thy persecuting Spirit in New England, and for the true Lord Jesus.

AND who are they, that Kill with Tongue, Pen and Sword, etc. that the
Inheritance may be theirs, but even R. W. and his New-England-priests? But let
the Pharisees and the Jews Judgment Answer them. And the True Lovers of the
Lord Jesus Christ will shine forth more and more, and the Lamb and his
Followers will have the Victory, but not with Carnal Weapons.

R. W. Thou say, That the Sufferings of the Quakers are no true Evidence of
the Truth of their Religion.

Answ. R. W. has marked himself, and his New-England-Priests and Professors.
For did ever such as persecuted the Prophets, Christ and his Apostles,
persecute them as true Men, and as their Religion was True? And have ye
New-England-Priests and Professors persecuted us with Tongue, Hand and Sword,
as True Men? or looking upon our Religion to be True? Now, have not they
clearly demonstrated themselves to be of the Lying Birth, born of the Flesh in
a blind Zeal? And the Apostle says, It was not only given us to believe, but
to suffer for the Name of Jesus: So this does Evidence the True Belief, which
does not persecute any for Religion.

R. W. And thou say, Thou could find no Jews, Papists or Protestants,
that did so magnify and so exactly insist upon their Sufferings, as the
Quakers did. And yet thou contradict'st thy self and say, p. 175.
That Paul did more particularize his Sufferings, then any other Saints in the
Scripture.

Answ. Here thou have contradicted thy self, and wrongest us: for we do not
Magnify our Sufferings; we Magnify the LORD, that upholdeth us in our
Sufferings. But it is like, it troubles thee and the New England Men, that our
sufferings are drawn up, and that ye are made manifest, that ye are no True
Christians, nor True Followers of Christ Jesus. And it is like, ye would not
have had us to print our sufferings, that it might not come to the Light, which
ye did in the Dark. And we know, the End of Paul's speaking of his sufferings
was, to manifest them that were not Real; but they were not Persecutors, as the
New-England-Priests are. But thou would have told the Prophets, Christ and
his Apostles, Their sufferings for their Religion for the Word of God and for
Jesus sake were no true Evidence of the true Lord Jesus Christ, of the Word of
God, and of the true faith or true belief.

R. W. And the Quakers Sufferings (thou say) are not to be compared with
Paul's.

Answ. And why? And yet we set down exactly every hour's Imprisonment, every
Stripe in Whipping (as thou say?) But this proves, that ye are the Birth
of the Flesh, and NO TRUE CHRISTIANS; but persecute with an outward Sword,
according to thy own Judgment.

R. W. And thou say. We publish our Sufferings to the World in print, as if
they were a Sign hung out, with this Inscription, etc. and then scoffest.

Answ. It is a Certain Evidence, that thou and you are in a Persecuting Spirit,
and the Lord supported us over your Murdering Spirit. AND thou art offended,
because G. Bishop has printed so much: Nay, thou will have more, as long as
thou continuest in this Birth of Persecution, and calling Christ's Light an
Idol, Frantic and a Fancy: here ye not only do persecute, but blaspheme. And
what G. Bishop has writ, it was not in a Childish Vapor, Ostentation and Vain
Glory (as thou say) but to manifest your Un-mercifulness and Cruelty: which
seems, it troubles thee and the New England Persecutors, that true
Christians and the World should know of your BLOODY Persecution. But why does
R. W. write such a Catalogue against the Pope, and yet would not have a
Catalogue of their own BLOODY doings manifest? who are ^ound in one Spirit,
drinking of Blood. But read, what the Apostle says: Even after that we had
suffered before, and were shamefully entreated (as ye know) at Philippi, we
were bold in our God to speak unto you (1 These. 2.) So that we our selves glory
in you in the Churches of God for your Patience and Faith in all your
Persecutions and Tribulations (2. These: 1.) And did not Jeremiah and all the
Prophets Record their Sufferings? and the Apostles Record the Sufferings of
John, and Christ and their own? (as ye may see in Acts)* though (I say) not
all; and we have not Recorded all our sufferings in New England. AND ( Act: 5,
40.) when such as your Spirit in New England had called the Apostles, and
beaten them, they commanded, that they should speak no more in the Name of
Jesus Christ: And they departed, rejoicing, that they were counted worthy to
Suffer for the Name of Jesus Christ: And yet they ceased not to teach and
preach Jesus Christ. R. W. would have said, They glory in their Sufferings;
Nay, they are Blessed, that Suffer for Christ, for theirs is the Kingdom of
God; We know it: but they that persecute, have not this Blessing, nor the
Kingdom.

And all these Sufferings We have suffered both for Christ within and Christ
without. p. 176.
Neither are our sufferings like either to Papists, nor you in New England; for
all ye (I know) will persecute others, though ye Suffer your selves. And it is
known by many, that our sufferings are, as the Primitive Church's sufferings,
who do persecute none, and make none to suffer; but only we suffer as Lambs.
And it is known, that never a Lamb worried or tore a Dog, or a Wolf or a Fox;
and therefore they are Wolves and Foxes, that may suffer, and yet make others
to suffer: and this is nothing. Yet in all our Sufferings we have Love still to
our Enemies, as the Disciples of Christ, and true Christians; and do pray for
our Enemies, who persecute us: And here in this we differ from all the
Persecutors or Suffe^ers in the World. And though we do give our Bodies to be
burnt, and our Goods so the Poor; yet still we retain the Love, which is the
Supreme over all, or else our sufferings are nothing. But this does not clear
R. W. and the New-England-Priests and Professors, but that they are the Birth
born of the Flesh, and that they are no true Christians, no true Protestants,
no true Followers of Christ (as R. W. confesses) but Hypocrites, and Makers of
Hypocrites, (p. 173.)

And R. W. brings E. B.'s Epistle, ( G. F. Fol. Epist. to the Reader, p. 12.)
which speaks of the Cruel Persecutors and Professors, Priests, and
Magistrates in Oliver's Days, whom the LORD has over-turned according to our
Prophecies to them. And Going NAKED -- As VV. S. went Three Years Naked;
sometimes in Sackcloth and Ashes, and his Face all Black; and so Black should
be the Persecutors; and so should they be stripped, as he was: which came to
pass. (And Paul Numbered his Stripes (as 2 Cor. 11.) but it would be hard to
Number ours, that we received in New England.) And the Mayor of Cambridge
received him in (and Several Persons of Quality took him in) and put his Gown
upon him; and did see, there was more in the thing, then the blind, dark Spirit
in R. W. that prints it over and over in his Book: who remains still in his
Envious spirit. Which some in New England have done the same, and have gone as
a SIGN, and a Shame of your Nakedness of that which ye professed; yet in the
Innocence of God's holy Spirit: Which they rather had chosen Death in their own
Wills, then to have gone, as they have done. And God* Almighty will Judge R. W.
for his Hard Speeches against them.

AND yet for all these Sufferings and Persecution ( Pharaoh^ like) as the Jews
Outward did grow, so the Jews Inward do grow for all the Persecutions of the
Spiritual Pharaohs: And Christ Jesus, the Captain of their Salvation, does lead
them in the Land of the Living; whose Praise is of God, and not of Man. And we
would have all the World to know, and all the New-England-Professors with R.
W. that we seek not the Praise of Men: and do expect no other, but that they
should speak all manner of Evil of us; that they might fulfill Christ's words.

R. W. But we do perceive, that R. W. is troubled, That we should print our
Sufferings, and give forth such a Catalogue of them. p. 177.


Answ. To evidence God's supporting Power and Hand, that does support them: and
to manifest New-England's BLOODY Hands; though we Appealed Three-Times to
England, but ye BLODY Persecutors regarded it not (although R. W. now in his
Epistle seems to Flatter the KING) yet in time ye may be reckoned withal,
when ye have filled up your Measure; the Al-seeing God will Reward you! And the
LORD GOD alone, who has been our Protector, and Helper and Supporter, (and we
had none in the Earth to help us, but him; and) HE is the Revenger of our
Cause: And so we leave it to him.

And Deuteronomy: 13: The false Prophets with the Signs and Wonders R. W. with his
New-England-Priests may keep at home, with all the rest, that is got up since.
Yet the Christians were not to do unto the false Prophets and Blasphemers, as
they did in the time of the Law; which was, To run them through, and Stone them
to Death: If so, Christ and the Apostles might have Run many false Prophets and
Blasphemers through, that blasphemed against him. But he told them the
Judgments, and Condemnation and the Misery, that would come upon all them,
that sin against the Holy Ghost: as R. W. is found in Blasphemy against the
Holy Ghost, and the Light of Christ, and calls it an Idol. Christ came not to
destroy men's Lives but to save them. And --

R. W. Brings ( G. F. fol. p. 64:) Jerem: Ives saying [ The Writings of the
Scriptures may be burned; but the Word of God contained in them may not b^
burned.] G. F.'s Answ: [If he had said, The Word, that it speaks of, or
testifies of, he had spoken proper, like Scripture; but to say, The Word of
God is contained in the Writings, and the VVritings say, It testifies of
Christ the Word, there is a Proof to thee, that the Quakers are sent of God,
who speak to thee of the Scriptures right as they are.] So R. W. has taken a
few of G. F.'s words, and left out the Ground and Reason of the Matter. And R.
W. brings his words to no purpose, meaning to maintain his false Position by.
And then thou tellest a Story of the Jews, Papists, Manasse Ben-Israel: and
Paul in his mad Conscience, etc. (p. 178.)

Answ. And in Paul's mad Conscience thou and the Priests and Professors in New
England, and the Papists are in, who bel^eve not in the Light of Christ, that
ye may become Children of Light: And so ye are in the Unconverted State, like
Saul.

R. W. And then thou tell a great Story of David slaying Uriah, and the best
Kings of Judah suffering the High Places and Asa's Imprisoning the Prophet, etc.

Answ. But did not that Prophet Suffer truly for the sake of the Word of God?
And so did the Apostles: And have not we amongst you? Yet we tell you, the
Word of God is not Bound.

R. W. And then thou tellest us of Peter's rash Using the Sword (to wit, the
Outward.)

Answ. But Peter did not Use it always: it has been the Devil's Aim in you all
To Afflict, to Punish one another to Death, page 179.
and Destroy about Religion; which was not the Practice of Christ and his
Disciples. And how can we slight the Saints, or Fellow Sufferers in all Ages,
when our Brethren Souls cry under the Altar (as the Martyrs of JESUS did of
Old) whom ye have HANGED and put to Death? And --

R. W. brings G. F.'s Fol. (p. 51, 253, 99.) Who forbids to receive into
their Houses --

Answ. Such as bring not the Doctrine of Christ, as John says Who-so-ever
transgresses, and abides not in the Doctrine of Christ, has not God.
Therefore if any come unto you, and bring not this Doctrine, receive him not
into your Houses, neither bid him God speed. Now, how can we Bid R. W. and the
New-England-priests GOD SPEED in their Persecutions with Pen, Tongue and Hand?
Yet we can receive them as Men, but not as Christians in the Doctrine of
Christ, nor his Believers in the Light, as Christ commands; for that he
calls an Idol. And how can thou be Received in our Houses as a Christian?
And how can we Receive any of the New-England-Persecutors as Christians, which
have so persecuted with the Sword, which thou say, are no true Christians
nor Followers of Jesus? yet as Men we can, but not as Ministers of Christ. And
had thou been in the Days of the Sufferings of the Martyrs, thou would
have spoken then as much against John Fox and the Martyrs, as thou do against
us: as the Papists now speak against them, and would not look upon them then,
as true Sufferers, no more then thou and the New-England-priests and professors
look upon Us now, as true Sufferers.

R. W. And whereas thou say: As it is possible for God's own Children to
hold (and that obstinately) false Principles, so it is possible, for other of
God's Children as obstinately to afflict and punish those others to Death, etc.

Answ. This is contrary to Scripture to affirm, That any of God's Children, who
are born of the Spirit, can be found in such a Practice, as to punish God's
Children, and true Christians with Death (according to thy own Assertion) or
any other upon a Religious Account. For though the Apostle says; He that was
born after the Flesh, persecuted him that was born after the Spirit; yet we
never read, that he that was born of the Spirit, did persecute him, that was
born of the Spirit, that was a Child of God: And so in this thou have affirmed
a false Assertion. And so our Sufferings differ from the Persecutors, as Light
from Darkness: For we maintain the Purity of the holy Scriptures and the Words
of God there, against all the vain Traditions, vain Meanings and vain
Imaginations of Men, and say, They are plain to all, that have an Understanding
of them by the Spirit of God.

And we have not suffered, as for Childrens Baubels, Fantastical Traditions of
Men, Inventions and Dreams, nor Earthly* Dignities, etc. but for the Pure Life
of Truth and the Name of JESUS (the Lord knows it!) by such, as got the Form
of Godliness, and the Sheeps-Clothing; and persecuted the true Sheep, that
heard Christ's Voice. And we do not Endeavor to Trample (as ye and the Pope do)
the Bodies of Saints under Feet. And John (in Revel.) he speaks of his
Sufferings and Tribulations, which we h^ve a Fellow-Feeling of: which our
Persecutors, page 180.
that cannot own the Light of Christ JESUS, have not, who scoff at us: and so
he would have done at the Apostle John, if he had been in his Days. And so as
for Fierce, Heady, Proud, Conceit R. W. might have kept at home.

R. W. And thou say: No question, some of them have a Notion of Wrath yet to
come: and therefore rather then to endure Fire of Hell, they will give up their
Lives to the Flames, and others of them Fast 40. Days, etc.

Answ. R. W. thou have manifest thy persecuting Birth and Ignorance both of us
and the holy Men of God: for it is not in Wrath we suffer, but in Love to God
and his Son. And ye Foul and Adulterous spirits would make Rapes of his
Virgins; and before they will loose their Dignity and their Testimony of JESUS,
they will DIE in Love to their Savior, that died for them And why do thou
scoff at Fasting? many of us have Fasted 30. or 40. Days together. And thou
often tellest of a John Fox; but I must tell thee and the New-England-Men, ye
have no Lot nor Part in that neither, who are Persecutors, in the Spirit of
them that persecuted them. And did not the Martyrs turn their Sufferings unto
the Glory of God? and so have we; though Ungodly Men, ( like Wolves,) have
hunted us ( like) Innocent Lambs and Christ's Chickens. And when ye have done,
we have said, The Lord forgive you, if it be his Will! And have not ye been
Unthankful for your Peace and Liberties, and forgotten the time, when ye were
called to an Account? And now ye are at Ease your selves, persecuting others
with Pen, Tongue and Hand. And it is known, the Quakers have Confessed their
Sins to him, that is able to forgive and pardon them, and has died for them;
therefore they do not come to the New-England-priests and R. W. and make them
Popes to Confess their Sins to them: who are Miserable Comforters, and will
tell them, They must have a Warfare with their Sins, while they Live, till they
go to the Grave.

R. W. And thou say: Some of them say, they can sin no more against God,
then God can sin against them.

Answ. It Is like, this is some of the Ranters; had it been the Quakers, R. W.
would have told their Names in print. But (however) R. W. might have put their
Names in print, and where they lived, then we might have known the truth of his
Assertion, and where they had been: for we deny all such Blasphemy and
Blasphemers.

But does not R. W. say often, That Repentance is a turning the Soul to God as
God from all Sin? (in his 6. false Charge) But is not your Confessing of Sin
like Pharaoh's and Judas's? For have not ye been Confessing these 20. or 30. or
40. years, but when will ye Forsake? Pharaoh was such a Confessor, as ye are,
and yet persecuted, so your Confession is Just like Pharaoh's. -- But has R.
W. and the New England-Priests and Professors showed any Meek or Patient
Spirit, or Thankfulness either? But we do not say, but they said over these
Words, (and so R. W. says) as the Papist Parrot said over the Pater Noster;
but ye have Persecuted the Meek, Patient, Thankful Sufferers of Christ Jesus:
And ye like a Frozen, Hard-hearted People have not been Sensi^le of his People,
nor God's Mercies to you.

And as for a People (thou speak of) professing Christianity, so Fierce, so
Heady, High-minded, Hardened, Censuring, Reviling, p. 181.
Cursing, Damning, Savage, Barbarous, etc. R. W. might very well have kept this
at Home.

And G. F. and G. B. do not Spit out Fire and Brimstone against
New-England-Persecutors; but tell you, what will be your Portion: and our
Desires are, that you might Repent.

R. W. And thou say; Some of their Predictions have and may come to pass, as
do also of Conjurers and Witches.

Answ. Nay R. W. ye shall find it the True Spirit and Power of God, and the
New England People; and not like Readiness Cause, that went to the Witch. But R.
W. we do very well remember* how the New-England-Professors Searched Two Women
of the Servants of God, under pretense of being Witches, to the Shame of all
Modesty and Christianity. But the Proverb concerning the Cow with Short Horns,
we have found the New-England-Priests and Professors Horns Long enough; but
thine is Short enough, because thou live under a Government, which does not
Persecute for Religion. But it has pleased God to put a Hook in your Jaws,
that ye take no more the Lives of the Saints of God. And --

R. W. Thou say: When the Devil is a Fisher, longing for troubled and
bloody Waters; yet God has graciously proved so many of the bloody Prophecies
of th^se VVaspish Prophets and Prophetesses, etc.

Answ. R. W. might have applied this at home, and his New-England-Priests, and
his Sister with him (as in p. 114. her Prophecy there.) AND what has R. W. and
New-England-Priests and Professors been Fishing in? and whose Fishers are they?
