Our Weapons are Spiritual, that he has armed us withal: and if ever thou
had set foot in the pure Religion, which the Primitive Church and the
Quakers walked and walk in, thou would not say, It is so easy. But thou
speak Evil of that which thou know not, and utterest forth the malice and
envy of thy heart. And we do pray to the Father to send forth Laborers into
his Vineyard; and that is his Work and not Men's: and can praise the Lord at the
Conversion of Sinners. And as for Hypocritical prating, that is thy own.

R. W. And thou say to M. B. Was there ever a Child of God in this world,
but he was a Nazarite, separate from worldly persons, etc. as he comes to see
them, and endures not, that the Evil One should touch him?

Answ. If this were your Faith and Practice both of New England, and all our
Old Persecutors, then we should be One with you. But have not all our Opposites
both here and in New England persecuted us for worldly Maintenances, which
Christ nor his Apostles never did; who said, Freely ye have received, freely
give? And if you could not endure the Evil One to touch you, then you would be
a People free from sin.

R. W. And then thou make a great Ramble, and call'st it Considerations
touching the Separate Churches: and say, Has not Gods Jealousy raged
against the Jewish Whore-mongers, who defiled his first Bed? and will he wink
at the Christian-Adulterers and Adulteresses either in worship or Conversation?

Answ. Nay: therefore has the Lord sent forth his Servants to bid you Repent;
whom you have persecuted: for you are fallen from the Tenderness you were in at
first, that the Lord knows.

R. W. Thou say: With what Conscience can I (a National Protestant) separate
from my Father the Pope, or my Mother the Church of Rome, and my Brethren and
Sisters the Papists, etc. and yet must not be a Christian for other Souls to
see further degrees of that Separation necessary; I must bring up the foot of
every man's Light, Sight and Conscience to my last.

Answ. Here thou acknowledgest The Pope to be thy Father, and the Church of
Rome to be thy Mother, and not the Primitive Church or Jerusalem that is above,
which is the Mother of us all: but thou would bring all to thy dark Last;
and so would every persecuting Spirit, and dark Conscience. And why do you talk
of Separating from your Mother or Father the Pope, when you are found in their
Spirit? but the Quakers would have every Man and Woman to turn to the Grace and
Light of Christ Jesus, and not bring them into a Form without the power, as
your New England Professors have done. And we labor to bring all People to
Christ Jesus; and if thou call him the Last, thou have given him a New Name:
but the New England Priests bring People to their Last and dark Conscience, as
is manifest.

R. W. Thou say: This is my main ground of my Controversy with the proud
Quakers in themselves, and condemn others.

Answ This is false: for we tell them, the Light is their Condemnation that
hate it. But we must walk in the Light, as Christ Commands, who has
enlightened us; by which Light we see you, where we have left you.

R. W. And thou say: But they magnify ( with the Papists and Arminians)
Cursed rotten Nature, their Converts and Proselytes have but a painted, p. 15.
Formal Repentance, Faith, etc. only if they can come to their Church, and Thou
and Thee, and disrespect all Superiors, then are they high Saints, and cannot
sin.

Answ. All these be Lies, and it is thy own Condition. And as for the Papists
and Arminians, they may answer for themselves: for Repentance, which is a
Returning from Sin to the Lord, is not Formal, and the Faith, which Jesus
Christ is the Author and Finisher of. And we do not say, Such as can say Thee
and Thou, are free from Sin; neither do we say, that they are High Saints, that
dis-respect all Superiors: for we say as the Apostle said, We must honor all
men; and, They that rule, are worthy of double honor. And we do challenge
thee, and all the Priests in New England, and all our Opposites that thou have
quoted, to show us, Where ever Christ or his Apostles for men to keep on their
Hats, and say Thee and Thou to them, dishonored them, and dis-respected
Superiors? so, the ground of thy Controversy is false. And whether that is the
Honor and the Respect, that they must show to all men, and to Superiors, as to
say You to a single Person, and put off his Hat to him? and whether this be the
Honor from above? and whether the Honor the Pharisees looked for, was not
some Outward Gesture, so distinguished from the Christians Honor? -- And as
for Converts of Cursed Rotten Nature, thou might have kept that at home; for
the Converts that we own, are such as are turned from Darkness to Light, and
from the power of Satan to God.

R. W. And whereas thou say: This was the Heavenly principle of those many
precious gallant Worthies, the Leaders and Corner-Stones of New England, they
desired to worship God in purity, according to those persuasions in their
Consciences, which they believed God had lighted up.

Answ. Here thou flatterest New England Persecutors, who have drunken the Blood
of Gods People, Whipped, Banished, and Spoiled their goods, because they would
not follow their Bloody Spirits Worship out of Truth: for thou might have said
as much for the Spirit of the Church of Rome. For the Professors of New England
have lost their Tenderness, that was first in them, and despised that
Birthright, Esau-like; and their Written and Printed Laws against the People of
God are abhorred, and make their Names stink in Europe, yea, and in America.
For thou will confess, the Devil is a Murderer, and Christ is a Savior, and
did not come to destroy men's Lives, but to save them: and therefore it is
manifest, whose Work thy Gallant Worthies and Leaders have done, and Thou, who
art joined in a Confederacy against God's People, uttering sorth thy Lies
against them in a peaceable Government, where thou have not power to Persecute
them.

R. W. And thou say; They desired such for their Fellow-worshippers, as they
(upon a Christian Account) could have evidence of to be true and real
Worshippers of God in Spirit and Truth also.

Answ. The New-England-worshippers, and the Joyners with them, their Practice
Evidenceth them in their Persecution not to be in God's Spirit nor his Truth.

R. W. And thou bring Priest E. B's. words, which says [The Spirit of God
does not teach to judge before the time] and others say [Saints shall not
judge, while they be upon the Earth.] And G. F. Answering says, [But the
Spirit did teach the Apostle to Judge, and his Time was come; and he told some
that they were of Old ordained for Condemnation, their Damnation slumbred not:
and then it was their time to Judge.] And because the Printer mistook, and put
in [ high] for [ their] and [ not] which should not have been in, but [ then]
which was the Printers mistake, therefore thou cryest Nonsense, etc. But (thou
say) to the point: The great Jugler has taught G. F. and his Foxians to
outface Death and Judgment, to keep the great Sessions, and call all the world
to their Bar and Judgment.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if there be any such words in G. F's. Answer? but
repeating of the Apostles words, that makes him to break out into such an
Outrage and Gust (as he calls it.) Therefore was the Apostle a Cheat, or a
Jugler, and out faced Death and Judgment, etc. because the Spirit of God did
teach him to Judge as before? And as for his terming of us like Mugleton with
his Curses; when a little before in the same page he says, A Cursed Rotten
Nature are the Quakers Converts: and art not thou of the same Spirit as Reeve
and Mu^leton, who have been as great Enemies to the Quakers, as thou art?

R. W. And thou say: It Is true, there is a Lawful judging, not according to
the rashness, or pride (as the Quakers is) but according to the righteous
Judgment. And say, The Spiritual man judges and discerns all things, that
looks into the Cause and Nature of things, Times and Persons: but what is
this to the Natural Death of all Mankind?

Answ. Reader, has G. F. mentioned any thing but the Apostles words? does he
mention the Natural Death of all Mankind? or showed any Rash Judgment here? or
called the World before the Bar of Judgment, as R. W. says, who has puffed out
a great deal of Air about it, and when he has done, he beats it? But it seems
he grants, That the Spiritual Man judges and discerns all things (but who it
is, and where he judges, he has not manifested or declared) and yet he
finds fault with G. F. for saying so ( page 80.) And as for Pride and Rash
Judgment, he might have kept that at home, and not applied it to the Quakers.
And the Apostle said, O Death where is thy Sting? O Grave, where is thy
Victory? the Sting of Death is Sin, and the strength of Sin is the Law: but
thanks be to God, who has given us the Victory through Jesus Christ.

R. W. And thou say: I know, the Foxians will turn this Scripture, p. 16.
and that Golden Chain, Heb. 6. the first Christian principles and Eternal
Judgment into Mysteries.

Answ. Here again thou wrong'st us. For we own Heb. 6 as it speaks; and we do
believe, they are Mysteries to thy Lying Spirit. For sometimes thou say, we
take them literally; and now thou say we turn them into Mysteries: thus thou
Contradicts thy self.

R. W. And that they now judge the secrets of Men by Paul's Gospel, Romans 2.

Answ. Is there any such word in G. F's. Answer to E. B. Priest? For the
Apostles words are, In the day, when God shall judge the secrets of men by
Jesus Christ, according to my Gospel: and this thou wickedly applyest to the
Quakers out of thy dark, airy mind, and then thou beatest the air.

R. W. And thou say, Therefore by looking on a man (to wit, the Quakers)
they can discern the Inward parts, what each person is.

Answ. The least Child of God may easily discern, what thou art, by what comes
out of thee, what is in thy Inward parts. And does R. W. think, that the Saints
did not know one another hearts, when they were of One heart, mind, and soul,
etc? and were the Epistles of Christ, etc. written not with Ink, but with the
Spirit of the living God in fleshly Tables of the heart? etc. and God that
given his Church a Discerning with the same Spirit in our day, as he did in the
Apostles.

R. W. And thou say: The Lord is no^ come (says Enoch, and Jude) in Ten
Thousand of his Saints; and now is the day appointed, in which God judges the
world by that Man Christ Jesus [ which Man they are] of which the Word of God
has approved, in that they are raised from the dead in souls and bodies to
keep the Eternal Judgment: though thou say, some of their young Scholars
will not believe it; but they spare not to own their High Court of Justice.

Answ. Where did thou ever read in any of the Quakers Books any such
Language, that say, the Quakers are the Man Christ Jesus? this is thy Forgery:
for let the Render see if there be any such word in G. F's. Answer to E.
Bradshaw in thy 15th page? And thou say, They are the Man Christ Jesus (to
wit, the Quakers) but have showed no proof for it: but how can thou make the
Saints to be the Man Christ Jesus? Yet for all thy Lies we cannot deny, that
Christ is in us. and has quickened us, which were dead in Sins and Trespasses
(as Ephesians. 2.) and Christ quickening our mortal bodies by his Spirit, that
dwells in us, Romans 8. and by his Spirit we can judge of such a Spirit as
thine is, by its fruits; whose Spirit is Eternal, which we received from
Christ, which thou Scoffingly call High Court of Justice. And Christ that
rules in the hearts of his Saints, he gives them a Judgment and Discerning to
forsake the Evil, and cleave to the Good.

R. W. And then thou tells a Tale in Hartfordshire, and termest us, Like a
Company of Drunken Sots, that kept a Court there, and had like to have brought
themselves to the Gallows.

Answ. But this may suit thine own and the New England Spirits best, that have
been Drunk with the Blood of the Saints: the Quakers are clear from thy Lies
and Slanders, and they do not touch them. And thou shall know Christ coming to
Judgment; who will reward thee according to thy works.

R. W. Thou say, That the Quakers confess, that Christ was a Real Man, as
any of us, etc. and thou say, They could not give an account, what was
become of him, at Newport.

Answ. There are more of thy Lies. For we tell thee, as we told thee, He is
risen, and at the Right Hand of God, Luke 22, 6, 9. Act. 2, 25, 23. Act. 5, 31.
Act. 7, 35, 36. Romans 8, 34. Ephesians. 1, 20. Col. 3, 1. Heb. 1, 3, 13. Heb. 8, 1.
Heb. 10, 12. 1 Pet. 3, 22. and if thou will not believe those Scriptures, thou will not believe us, where the Man Christ Jesus is: and yet Christ rules in
the hearts of his Saints; and this is a Mystery to thee. And it is like he is
not Come unto thee; for how should he? when thou art so Ignorant of his Light,
which he ligheth every Man that comes into the world withal: for how can any
come to Repentance and be Converted, and hate the Heavenly Light of Christ?

R. W. And then thou runs on, and have proved nothing, and say, That their
Pride, Scornfulness, rash Revilings, rash Cursings, Superstition, new
Inventions, their Blasphemies and Hypocrisies, Inhumanities, Impudencies, etc.
are such --

Answ. This R. W. and his Fellow-Priests might have kept at home; for he has
made a great Noise with words, but nothing signified. Did not the Patience of
the Lambs of Christ manifest otherwise, when they Hanged them, and Burned them,
and Cut off their Ears, and Whipped and Banished them? did they not suffer like
Lambs? What was their Reviling Languages? why did not thou and the Priests
of Boston Print them? for if they had Reviled, it is like we should have heard
of it before now.

R. W. And thou say: -- such, that render them so far from being the High
Saints and Judges of the World, that they fall under the Judgment of all sober
and modest persons.

Answ. Nay Roger, they must be such as thou and the New England Professors are,
that Judge us and not the Modest nor Sober persons neither in Old England nor
New: and thy Judgment and the Persecutors Judgment touches us not. And the
Apostle tells thee, The Saints shall Judge the World. 1 Cor. 6, 3.

R. W. [On G. F's. Answer to T. C.] If God please to appoint the Words the
Apostles used, to be still the Means of Conversion to the end of the World, p.
17.
that then he has thrown out himself? etc.

Answ. What! can any come to Conversion with the words of the Apostles without
the Spirit? may not all the Wolves in the World, false Prophets and
Antichrists get the Sheeps-Cloathing on the Outside, and use their tongue and
say: Thus says the Lord and the Apostle? like R. W. and those that would have
cast out Devils in Christ's and Paul's Name? But does not the Apostle say, He
that has not the Spirit of Christ, is none of his, Romans 8, 9. and therefore
how can any Convert any person with the Apostles words, and they having not the
Spirit of Christ are none of his? I confess, R. W. and the New-England-Priests
may bring them into a Form without the power; from such People are to turn
away, as the Apostle says to Timothy.

R. W. Thou say; Is not this God's Covenant with Christ and all Christians,
that his Word and Spirit should be in their Mouths to all Generations? Woe be to
all these wild, frantic Inferences, which disjoyn and separate, what the
Most-powerful and Wise and Holy has joined together.

Answ. We witness, that the Word and Spirit was, and is, and shall be in the
mouths and hearts (which thou have left out, and can not endure to hear of
it there) of all true Christians to all Generations; but what is this to
Convert People with a Means without the Spirit and the power of Christ in their
hearts to Salvation? But thou think to join the holy Men of God's words with
thy dark Spirit, which were not given forth from it: and wild frantic
Inferences thou may keep at home. And we do not Dis-joyn the Word, nor the
Spirit from the Scriptures; for it will own its own Words, and has Unity with
them, as thou falsely chargest us to Dis-joyn or separate: and all your
Converting of people with the Saints words without the Spirit of Christ in
their hearts, is but to make Proselites like Parishes.

R. W. And thou say: May there not be many Agents employed by one glorious
Efficient? as in Moses building the Tabernacle, etc. and Abraham sending his
Servant to Espouse a Bride to his Son, etc. Does not rather this mad Soul throw
out Abraham and Solomon, etc. yea his own brains (in a mad, proud frolic) all
overboard together?

Answ. Because Moses builded the Tabernacle, and Solomon builded the Temple,
and Abraham did such and such things, and Circumcised, therefore must all
Christians do the same? yea, and without the Spirit, as Moses, and Abraham and
Solomon was in? and thou that art without this Spirit, that they were in, art
in thy Mad frolicks thou speak of, and Throwest thy own Brains overboard,
and not the Quakers, that would have people to be led with the Spirit of Christ
to Conversion; who is the End of Solom^n's Temple, and Moses Tabernacle, and
makes his People his Temple, etc.

R. W. And as for that of Paul telling the Corinthians, that they were Gods
Husbandry and Building, etc. and as thou say, That Paul was a prime
Husbandman, and a Master Builder, etc. and that they were Messengers, and
Co-workers, and Laborers together with God.

Answ. We know this; but it was not without the Spirit of Christ: this was not
Saul, when he was a Literal Professor, like you.

R. W. And Paul Preaching, the Lord opened Lydia's heart; and Philip Preaching,
and the Lord opened the Eunuch's heart: and thou quotest John 14. for Barnabas,
that a great Multitude of Jews and Greeks believed.

Answ. What is all this to the purpose? All that have been, are, or shall be
Converted since the Gospel's Ministration, are Converted by the Apostle's Words
without his Spirit, as thou seem to say, are they? for we know, that Philip,
Paul and Barnabas were in the power and Spirit of God, and able Ministers of
the Spirit. And thou bring John 14. and Barnabas, that A great Multitude,
both of Jews and Greeks believed; and there is no such saying in John 14. for
if G. F. had done so, thou would have cried, Lame, Silly and Nonsense; but
if the Fault was in the Printer, we have so much Charity as to overlook it.
And then thou say; The Lord opened Lydia's heart: Then it is not the
Apostles words without the Spirit. And then thou bring Paul planting, Apollo
watering; which we do believe, with the Spirit of God, and wrought those
Miracles by the power of Jesus: but what is this to Plant or Water with the
Apostles words without the Spirit of Christ? for God gives increase to them
that are in his Spirit.

R. W. And thou say; G. F 's. his throwing God overboard, and his own
Reason and Sense.

Answ. Thou have not proved G. F, throwing out God; this is Blasphemy to say,
That God can be thrown overboard, who have over-thrown thy self. But thou and
the Priests, that would Convert people with the Apostles words, and leave out
the power and Spirit of God, do but beget people into a Form without the power:
and because G. F. says [That they cannot Convert people without the power and
Spirit of God, etc. though they may have the words of the Apostles] and the
Priest says [ That they are Converted by the Words of the Apostles] and G. F.
says [ In this they throw out the Spirit and power of God, by which the
Apostles did Convert] and about this thou make a great Rail against G. F. and
say, G. F. is throwing out God overboard, and his own Reason and Sense; and
yet thou confessest, The Lord opened Lydia's heart, and the Lord opened the
Eunuch's heart: so here thou Contradicts thy self. And we own God and Christ,
and use their Words and the Apostles by the Spirit, that leads into all
Truth, and do succeed them in the Spirit: and so are the Living Stones, and
built up together in the Church of God, which Christ is the Head of.

R. W. Thou say, There have been many Conversions to the Christian Name in
these parts of the world called Christendom: p 18.
and then thou Instancest, These (Conversions) the Papists brag to have
effected in all the 4. parts of the world; and how these were brought^ in
sometimes by the Sword, and sometimes by Marriages, etc.

Answ. How is it you N. England Priests and Professors would Convert the
Quakers? is it not by the same Bloody Way? as Instance, Whips, and Stocks, and
Swords? and are not these the Beast's Horns, and the Whore from the true
Church, and not Christ's Wife?

R. W. Thou tell us of the Waldenses, and Wicklevists, and Hussires in
Bohemia, and Lutherans and Calvinists, etc. that came out from this Bloody
Romish Whore (144000. Virgin Protestants thirsting after the Blood of Christ
only for Salvation.)

Answ. What is all this to R. W's. purpose, That people should be Converted
with the Apostles words, and leave out the power and Spirit of Christ,
according to G. F's. words to T. C? And Roger, why do thou cry out against
the Romish Bloody Whore, when thou and the New-England-Spirits, that thou
Commendest, are the same? for, where did ever Wickl^ff and Hus^ Hang any, or
Cut off the Ears of any, as your N. England Professors have done? And you that
would have us punished, are you like Virgin-Protestants, who thirst after the
Blood of Christ for Salvation? what! can you both thirst after the Blood of
Christ and after the Blood of his people, as the New England Priests have done?

R. W. And thou say, The Father of Spirits has stirred up some Witnesses in
all Protestant-Nations, to Preach against Formal, National Conversions, and
against the Formality and Profaneness of the common Protestants.

Answ. Then why art thou against G. F's declaring against Conversions without
the Spirit of Christ, and power of God, as he does to T. C? have not thou all
along been Contradicting thy self? and fightest against that which thou here
professest, like a blind Man, or one that doteth? And wast not thou Bragging a
little before of the Church in New England? and now thou tell of the Papists
bragging? and are not all these (thou speak of) Formal Conversions, brought
into the words without the Spirit and power? for there is no true Conversion,
nor Translation, but from Death to Life; and that is by the same power and
Spirit of Christ, that the Apostles were in, and the Church in the Primitive
Times.

R. W. And thou say: The Formality and Profaneness of the Common
Protestants ( all one in Life, and sometimes worse than the Papists) etc.

Answ. Roger, thou and the New-England-Priests and Professors may take it, and
apply it at home, and see, if you can find a place of Repentance; for yet you
hate to be Reproved. -- And as for the One hundred-forty-four-thousand spoken
of in the Revel., that sung the New Song, etc. which no man could learn, etc.
which were Undefiled, etc. which were Redeemed from the Earth, and which
followed the Lamb, etc. is R. W. and the New-England-Priests, and our Opposites
(that he brings) like unto these in the Lamb's Spirit? no such matter: for if
they were, they would not Persecute, Imprison us, and Cut off our Ears for
Visiting our Friends in the Prisons, and not bowing the Knee, and the Hat, and
saying You to them; and Persecute us, because we could not put in their mouths,
and give them Maintenance. So, here they manifest, that they are of the Earth,
and of the Bloody Whore that R. W. speaks of: so, they are not of their
Purity (which is spoken of in Revelations) neither in Life, nor Doctrine, nor
Worship, nor Church, nor follow not the Lamb, who says, Freely ye have
Received, freely Give.

R. W. Thou say (after thou have told a Story of the Jesuits) The
Pharisees, p. 19.
who by Land and Sea sent forth their Emissaries to make Converts to God, etc.

Answ. Is not this your own Work? seeing that G.F. says, Th. Coll. has thrown
out the Spirit and power of Christ, which is to Regenerate and Convert; and
say, That you can no more Convert by the Apostles Words, then the Pharisees
without the Spirit of God, and Power of Christ, that the Apostles were in? and
yet thou railest against G. F. for saying so. But have not thou Contradicted
thy self in saying, How the Pharisees Converted? when they in their Conversion
opposed Christ the Light?

R. W. Thou say, That Christ sent forth his Messengers with Glad News of a
New Bargain or Covenant of God with the Sons of men, viz. It pleased the God of
Heaven not to be thrown out ( as this Fox frantickly barks) etc.

Answ. Where does G. F. say (if it be him thou meanest) That God did throw out
his Apostles or Messengers with the New Covenant and Glad Tidings, which Christ
sent forth? And have not thou been barking against Papists and Pharisees, and
Formal Professors Converts? and are not they brought into a Form of the
Apostles words without the power? and into a Profession of Christ without the
Possession of him, like you Priests and Professors of New England? And G. F.
says; The true Conversion is by the power and Spirit of Christ, [which T. C.
leaves out] and so, do thou not see how thou Contradicts thy self? for were
these Virgins (thou speak of) Converted with the Apostles words without the
Spirit and power of Christ? Dare any of the New-England-Priests or professors,
or R. W. say, That you are sent out Immediately by Christ, as the Apostles
were? nay, Priests will say, They have No Call to this work to go Freely: but
they would find a Call to great Benefices.

R. W. And thou say: For slighting of this Pearl of this Glad News or Gospel
pub^ished by God to the world by Writing, or Preaching, Professing, Suffering,
etc.

Answ. This is from a false Birth: for we slight not the writings of the
Gospel, etc. nor the Preaching, Professing and Sufferings of the Apostles, but
receive them with Joy in the Spirit of God; etc. But it is you that slight
them, that do not Obey them, and persecute with Tongue and Hand them that do
obey them.

R. W. And thou say: It has pleased his Infinite Justice to Plough the
world with Popery, a Religion (a Bastard-Christianity) suited, etc.

Answ. Look thou and the New England-Priests at home, and shake hands with them
Roger: and let New England read their Laws, and read thy Book and theirs, and
see, if you have not Ploughed worse then they these late years.

R. W. And as for thy saying (A Bastard-Christianity) suited (as the Quakers
is) to Rotten Nature, and sit to carry the world after them, as Mahomet and the
Pope have done.

Answ. Nay Roger, you in New England have the Weapons, as the Pope and Mahomet
have in your Rotten Nature, your practice plainly declares it. For the Quakers
Weapons are Spiritual and not Carnal; and therefore thou do abuse them,
though it does not touch them.

R. W. And thou tells of Two great Worders in the world ( pretending to be
Christ's Messengers to the Nations) the Jesuits and the Quakers: their faces
look diverse, but they both carry Firebrarnds in there Tails, to burn up the holy
Scripture, all truly holy Christians, etc. and thou say, We are like Absalom
Beautiful, and fit to play Soul-Thieves, and steal the hearts, etc. from the
true David, the Lord Jesus Christ.

Answ. Thou might have kept a great part of this at home, for we do abhor
thy Lies. For whom have we wronged? or whom have we Burnt? except it be the
Fire of God's Word that is Entered among you, and burns your Esau. stuff. And
as for Burning the Scriptures, we abhor thy words: and did not thou say, The
Papists Owned the Bible, and the Jews part of it? and now thou fay'st, They
Burn it? how do thou Contradict thy self! But Gods Living Free Messengers we
have been to New England, etc. but you have Spoiled our Goods, Banished, Whipped
and Martyred to death, and Burnt our Books, which quote a many good Scriptures.
And as for Absolom's Beauty, you may look at home among your Whited Walls, and
fair Outside Professors: but they begin to look black with your Murdering
Laws. And it is thy own Spirit's work to draw Souls from the Lord Jesus Christ
with thy Lies, as the Old Serpent drew Adam and Eve from God's Teaching: and
you exceed Sampsons Foxes, that carried Firebrarnds in their Tails, for you
have Carried them in your Hands, by which you have Branded the people of God.
And we do Esteem the Scriptures, and the Practice of them better then you.

R. W. And thou say: They are fortified with the Faces of Men, and the Hair
of Women, like the Locusts, Rev. 9. such Pretenses, and such Illuminations, and
Appearances, and Assurances, and Confidences, and Feelings of Experiences, etc.
that it is God's Infinite Power and Wisdom, etc. to preserve the Scriptures a
Standing Record, of what the first Messengers and Churches, and first Doctrine,
and first Christians were; or else the world would fall down and adore Images,
etc.

Answ. It is by the Lord's Power and Wisdom, that the Scripture has been
preserved; yet we see such that have the Scriptures, and fall down to Images,
and others to the Imaginations of their own hearts, that are not in the Spirit,
that gave them forth. And as for those Locusts, that came out of the smoke of
the Bottomless-pit let R. Williams and the New England Professors keep that at
home, and apply it and their Experiences at home: but as for the people called
Quakers, it is that, which the Lord has wrought in them by his Spirit, and
opened to them by believing in the Light; that so they are become Children of
the Light, which you were and are Strangers to, and hate. And God has Sealed
us, and set his Mark in our Foreheads: but your Mark is easily seen to be of
the Beast's, that makes War with the Saints. And did Abraham, and Isaac, and
Jacob fall down to Images, before Scripture was written? for, as the Apostle
says, None can call Jesus Lord, but by the Holy Ghost: and though some people
have the Scriptures, yet they fall down to Images. But it is the Holy Ghost,
that brings them to fall down to God, and bow to Jesus their Lord, that leads
them into all the Truth of the Scriptures, that brought the Prophets and
Apostles to testify against them that Bowed to Images; yea, though they had
the Scriptures* as in the days of Jeremiah, and Ezekiel, and other Prophets.
And our Experiences and Assurances are of the Lords Christ.

R. W. And thou say: Thou know, the Counsels of the Father of Lights are
very deep; yea, the Revelation needs a Revelation, and the Prophets, and
Canticles, and Daniel, etc.

Answ. And thou confessest, this must be by the Spirit of God, etc. and in this
thou confounds thy self, who have been Railing against G. F. and the Quakers,
who says: T. C. has left cut the power and Spirit of God to Regenerate and
Convert, and that the Scriptures cannot do this without the Spirit or power of
Christ; and that it is the Spirit, that does Convert both Jews and Gentiles to
God: and this is the Quakers principle, according to Christ's words; I will send
you the Spirit of Truth, that will lead you into all Truth: as you may see in
John. And so it is all this while, thou have been Confounding thy self, and
Beating the Air.

R. W. And whereas thou speak, How that Jews and Gentiles must yet enquire
with Tears of Blood after the Blood of a Savior: p. 20.
sure they shall not awake out of their pits of Rottenness without some Means
and Messengers, etc.

Answ. And yet these have the Scriptures, and are not Converted: and yet thou
railest against G. F. because he says, They cannot be Converted and
Regenerated by the words of the Apostles, but by the power and Spirit of God;
and because that G.F. says, That I.K. in saying [The Scripture is the Means]
he throws out Christ and God, the Author and Giver of Faith (as page 9). Yet
now R. W. says, There must be a Messenger from Heaven to awaken Jews and
Gentiles; surely, this must be a Spiritual Messenger then: and here he
Contradicts himself, and throws down all his Railing stuff against G. F. as
aforementioned. And yet There is no Voice and Motion to be heard of Spiritual
things within?

R. W. And thou say: Surely, there shall be no other Words in their Mouths,
then what were in the Mouths of the first Messengers, and according to Christ's
prayer, etc.

Answ. We answer, Nay; The very same Word and Words, both in thy and your
Mouths, when you are Converted (if ever you be Converted) which now thou have a
Form of without the power; and Hold the Truth in the Unrighteousness: and so
that in John 17. and Isa. 59. and Act. 26. we own. And the Apostles which
Preached Christ Jesus, said no other Words, then what Moses and the Prophets
foretold, Act. 26. That Jesus Christ should come according to the Prophets:
and He is come, and has given us an Understanding, and we are in him.

R. W. And thou say: Therefore Fox and his Foxians, that tell us, They have
all by the Spirit, and need no Record, are Thieves and Robbers, whom Moses and
the Prophets, etc. and the Apostles abhorred to think of.

Answ. Moses and the Prophets were led by the Spirit of God, and saw Christ,
who fulfilled the Scriptures of the Prophets, etc. and the Apostle said: No man
knew the things of God, but by the Spirit of God: are not the Scriptures the
Things of God? And why do thou belie G. F. and the Quakers (if it be them
thou meanest) and say, that they say, They need no Record? which is false:
for There are Three, that bear Record in Earth, and Three, that bear Record in
Heaven, which they have need of. And there is a Record of the Son of God, and
there is a Record of John concerning Christ: John bore Record, saying, I saw
the Spirit descending from Heaven upon Christ, Joh. 1, 32, 34. and the Father
bore Record of the Son, Joh. 8. and God is the Record of his people, Phil. 8.
Joh. 1, 5, 7. And there is a Record of the Old and New Testament, which we have
the Comfort of: for we never read, that either Moses, the Prophets or Apostles
did abhor the Spirit of God to be their Leader, and call them Thieves and
Robbers: but those are Thieves and Robbers that do not hear the Voice of
Christ, but climb up another way to know the Scriptures, then by the Light and
Spirit of Christ.

R. W. And thou bring I. Deacon, who says [ The Enjoyment of Immortality is
not, till they have put off this body: G.F. 's Fol. page 40.] And G. F.
Answers, That [ Immortality was brought to Light through the Gospel, and the
Word of God: and Christ was in them, and was not that Immortal? And the Apostle
says: -- Christ Jesus, who has abolished Death, and has brought Life and
Immortality to Light through the Gospel, 2 Timothy 1.10.] -- R. W. (Upon G. F's.
words) says: That G. F. affirms an Immortality (that is, A Not-dying of the
Soul and Body.)

Answ. Now, let the Reader see, if he have not abused G. F's. words? and
whether he says any such thing, or no? for Christ says: They cannot kill the
Soul, though they may kill the Body. Yet R.W. says again, that the Quakers and
others say, All flesh is grass (speaking of the body) and yet he says, that G.
F. affirms, The Body cannot dye: what Contradictions are these R. W?

R. W. And whereas thou say: As for the Body, the Quakers say, When the Soul
is gone into God ( yea, the Soul of Judas, as well as the Soul of Peter, as
some of them say,) etc.

Answ. But what some of them are, thou have not quoted; though over and over
thou maliciously speak this in thy Book. Neither do I believe, that ever
thou heard any of them say so (may be, some Ranters said so, which he Fathereth
upon the Quakers,) for if thou had, thou would have quoted the Book, or
have named their Names, as thou have done G. F's. and belyest his words:
therefore we have good ground to believe thou wrongest others. And thou usest
many words to no purpose, about that what others say.

R. W. And thou say: -- Whatever these Foxians brutishly fancy of no
distinction between God and themselves, p. 21.
their Light and his, etc.

Answ. This is a False Charge. For we make a Distinction betwixt God and our
selves; for by his Gospel and Power Life and Immortality is brought to Light in
us, by which we see over the Devil, that has darkened us: so, In the Light of
Christ we see Light.

R. W. And thou confessest, That Christ has brought Life and Immortality to
Light through the Gospel [In this thou contradictest I. D. the Priest] and
say, But this is but the joyful Condition of the Souls and Bodies of the
Godly, their Souls and Bodies raised up with Jesus to a spiritual holy Life in
this world, and the Souls going to Jesus, and their Bodies sleeping in Jesus,
etc.

Answ. Here thou have made a pretty good Confession in words, if thou knew,
what thou say. But how do thou mean, when thou say, The Body sleeps
in Jesus; and yet, It turns to Rottenness? does that which sleeps in Jesus,
Rot? And the Apostle says: Thou Fool, that which thou sowest, is not quickened,
except it dye: and that which thou sowest, thou sowest not that Body, which
shall be, etc. but God gives it a Body, as it pleases him, 1 Corinthians 15. Thou
confessest, That Life and Immortality is brought to Light through the Gospel;
and because G. F. says so, thou say, He affirms an Immortality, that is, a
Not-dying of the Soul and Body: The Soul is Immortal; but G. F. does not speak
of the Body there.

R. W. says: As to this Immortality of G. F. all that can be known of his
mind, is H. Nichol's and the Nicolaitans mad fictions and fancies of their
becoming God and Christ.

Answ. Reader, see, if there be any such words in G. F's Answer to I. D. that
he should number us with the Nicholaitans mad fictions and fancies, as he
calls it; he had had better to have kept it at home, if this be his Charity.
And this Love, that he has to some of us, is not like the Love, that David had
to Absalom, but more like Ahitophel's, (which thou speak of) who neither
Loved David nor Christ Jesus; this Spirit of thine cannot in Sincerity, that
has spoken so Evil of God's people.

R. W. And thou say: I fear, instead of their fancied Immortality before the
Grave, they will meet with a dreadful Mortality, or Death of Soul and Body to
all Eternity.

Answ. This thou fear not for good, as thy words do manifest in thy 119.
page. Here R.W confesses Immortality in this Life; and yet he denies it unto
us.
But do thou not say before, That the Souls of the Godly, going to Christ
Jesus, etc. and now do thou fear, the Souls of the People of God, called
Quakers, shall meet with a Dreadful Mortality, or Death of Soul and Body to
Eternity? It Is like thou would have it so: but we tell thee, and all our
Envious Persecutors with tongue and hand, That Christ has brought Life and
Immortality to Light through the Gospel; and our Souls rejoice in him, and can
magnify God our Savior, blessed be his Name for ever, Hallelujah! But Roger
Williams, take heed, that which thou fear of the Quakers, come not upon thy
self; for it will be much, if it do not, for thou will find Misery, before thou
dye, for thy hard speeches against God's People.

R.W. And thou bring'st I. M. which says [ The wise Heathen- Philosophers had
a greater measure of Light in them (which is the first Adam) then I can think
any man has now.] --

And G.F. Answers [Which shows, that he knows nothing of Christ, the
Second Adam, the Quickening Spirit. He knows no New Creature; for they, who
are in Chirst, are New Creatures: nor None of Christ the Covenant of God, of
Light, of Life, of Peace, who was Glorified with the Father, before the world
began; which is beyond the first Adam: and has shut himself forth, not to be
as high as his Heathen-Philosophers. And many witness Christ In them, in this
Age, as in the days of the Apostles; which is above the Heathen-Philosophers.]
-- And R. W. replyeth to G. F. and says: It pleased God (in all Ages) to stir
up the spirits of some Men (as the Philosophers amongst the Greeks, etc.) to
improve that Excellent Light of Reason etc. above other men.

Answ. What is this to the Light of Christ, in Opposition to the Second Adam in
this Age?

R. W. And thou say, The Question then follows: If this Light of Knowledge
were Christ, p. 22.
as God, and King, and Mediator, why is it, that None of these Excellent men
knew Nothing of God, nor Christ, nor Spirit, etc. but only of the first
Creation? Can such a Court be kept, a Palace furnished, and such Royal and
Heavenly Guests be Entertained, and no body know any thing of it? etc.

Answ. What are all these words to the purpose, but that thou grantest I.M's.
Argument, That the Wise Heathen- Philosophers had a greater Light ( which is
the first Adam) then you, or any man can have by the Second Adam? if not, why
do thou Oppose G. F? And thou confessest, that All Jerusalem was moved, and
on an uproar, when Christ was born, or came to Jerusalem: and does not the
Apostle bid the Saints, Beware of Philosophy? etc. And the Apostle says also:
Certain of your Poets have said, that we are of his Offspring ( to wit, God's)
and Act. 17. Then certain Philosophers of the Epicureans, and of the Stoics
encountered with Paul, and some said; What will this Babbler say? and others
said, He seems to be a Setter-forth of strange Gods, because he preached
Christ Jesus and his Resurrection: Now, if R. W. and I. M. have no more
Knowledge of Christ, then these Philosophers, etc. in their Light of their
Carnal Reasoning, (which was Darkness to the Light of Christ) they may give
over talking of Christ. And these knew not God, nor Christ as King and
Mediator, which is known by his own Light: and such Philosophers or others, if
they did Know God or Christ, it was by his own Light. For that which G. F. does
affirm, is true, as concerning of Christ and their Knowledge in the
New Covenant: and Christ Enlightneth every man, that comes into the world, as
he is the Word, God. And the Spirit of man being the Candle of the Lord, he
Enlightneth their Spirit, their Candle, by which they might see him, as he is:
and as Christ says, No man knows the Father, but the Son, and he to whom the
Son Reveals him, etc.

R. W. Thou say: The utmost Reason of these Excellent Men (to wit, the
Philosophers) it is known I say, that the Activity of the highest Reason in
this world falls short in two grand particulars. (And thou say) 1. As to
the Creatures: for some of them must needs fall short, when Plato granted a
Creation, and a kind of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit in the Creation of it.
Aristotle pretends to see further then Plato and all his Arguments, and
Asserteth, The World to have no Beginning nor Ending.

Answ. What must we Infer from this, but that thou set up the Knowledge of
the Philosophers above thy own and others, and maintainest I.M's. Principles
and his Doctrine [That the wise Heathen- Philosophers had a greater measure of
Light in them, ( which is the first Adam) then I can think any man has now,
says I.M.] And are not these Philosophers contrary to Moses in Genesis, who
said, In the Beginning God Created the Heavens and the Earth? and thy
Philosophers, that thou bring, say, That the World had No Beginning nor
Ending, etc. and does not this oppose Christ's words? and 2 Timothy 9. Before the
World began? and Tit. 1, 2. Before the World began? And Christ says, The
Harvest is the End of the World, Math. 13, 39, 40. Math. 24, 21. Since the
World began. Now, let R. W. and the Philosophers read these Scriptures, and see
what work they are making about their great Knowledge? but if any of them did
know the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, they knew it by the Spirit,
and had it by Revelation, as some of the Heathen had: but it is very like, that
Many of the Heathen- Philosophers had more knowledge in the Creation, then R.
Williams. -- And then thou go on and tellest what the Philosophers say of
the Sun, and of the Globe, etc. but we tell thee, the Scriptures are a better
Book, then their Books concerning God and his Son, and his Creation.

R. W. And that which Paul speaks, Romans 1. thou say, That by the Creation
some come to know, there is an Eternal Power and Godhead: and thou say,
that Paul tells us, the World by wisdom knew not God, which must he Expounded (
or else swallow a Contradiction, as the Quakers guise is), etc.

Answ. Thou can hardly speak without Railing. For these Scriptures (1 Cor.
1. and Romans 1) need no Expounding; for they are plain, as they speak: for its
true, That the world by their wisdom knew not God. Some knew the Eternal Power
and Godhead: for the Apostle says, Because that which may be known of God, is
manifest in them, for God has showed it unto them; though they glorified not
God, etc: so with This of God in them, which God had showed unto them, they
knew Him, and his God head and his Creation, Rom, 1, 19, 20. So, the Guise thou
may apply to thy self, who have lest out That of God, which he has showed
unto people, who was their Teacher. Are these the wise Philosophers of R. W.
and I. M. that have more Light then any man now, that say, The world has No
Beginning nor Ending? and is this your Court and Palace furnished with such
Heavenly guests? etc. but to know God and Jesus Christ, that he has sent, is
Eternal Life. And then thou confesses, That a Natural man cannot perceive the
things of God; and yet, The Philosophers had a greater measure of Light, then
any man now?

R. W. And thou say, Yet this Foolish man makes every man's heart in the
world a Court of Heaven, p. 23.
a thing which all men may abhor to think of: and yet thou confessest, That
there is that of God in the Children of Disobedience and Reprobates. ( Appen.
p. 5)

Answ. But let the Reader see, if there be any such words in G. F's Answer to
I. M. as, The Court of Heaven is in every man's heart? But for all R. W's.
Railing, we cannot deny Christ's Doctrine, who said, The Kingdom of Heaven was
in the Pharisees: and Christ enligteth every man, that comes into the world,
Joh* 1. And it is very like, thou do Abhor to hear or think of this, whose
Foolish heart is darkened, and thy Wisdom is Enmity, hating God himself, as the
Scripture concludes, which thou may apply to thy self. Yet we believe,
Christ has enlightened thee, which will to be the Condemnation of them that
hate it.

R. W. Thou say: Moses built the Tabernacle, and Noah the Ark, and Solomon
the Temple, etc. which thou confessest, were the gifts of God to them. Then
thou call them the Excellent gifts of Nature, that reach not Heavenly and
Spiritual things, and say, What are all these to the Enlightening of my soul
with my Natural, Undone and Damned Condition? to a sight of Sin as Sin? etc.

Answ. Noah by Faith builded the Ark (as in Hebrews) and Moses saw Christ the
great Prophet; and God spoke to Solomon and David, who saw Christ, and called
him Lord: and if thou do confess, that this was a Knowledge beyond the
Heathen- Philosophers, yea, and such as said, The world had neither Beginning
nor Ending, then thou have overthrown thy own words, which thou have been
opposing G. F. withal. And was it by a Natural gift, that Noah built the Ark,
and Moses the Tabernacle, and Solomon the Temple? was it not by the Faith and
Command of God? were these done with Natural parts and good Education, as thou
speak of? how dark art thou in the Scripture! -- And the Temple, and the
Ark, etc. were Figures of the things of the Law, which Christ is the substance
of, who enligh^^eth every man, that comes into the world: and thou art as dark
about Christ, that enlightneth every one that comes into the world, as thou
art about the Temple, who call them Excellent Natural gifts in Noah, Moses
and Solomon.

R. W. And thou go on, and say, What are those to a sight of my utter
Inability to pay (or all the Creation for me) one farthing to God's Justice,
etc?

Answ. It Is Christ, that has Shed his Blood, and Tasted Death for all men, and
Enlightens all men; and he is above the Heathen Philosophers in the first Adam:
and so, all must believe in him the Light, (who has enlightened them) for Life
and Salvation. And many more slighting words there are in thy pretended Answer,
which are not worth mentioning. And how do thou Magnify the Gifts of God to
many, whom thou say, neither thou nor G. F. is worthy to hold the Candle to;
when thou art setting up the Wisdom of the Heathen- Philosophers, with the
Light in them ( which is the first Adam) above, then any man has now (as I. M.
thinks)? And what is this to know Christ and the New Creature, and he the
Quickening Spirit, and the New Covenant? for they that Magnify Christ, will do
as John did, Bear witness to Christ, who enlightens every man that comes into
the world.

R. W. And thou say: Who knows not, how full the world is of Admirable men
and women, that are not Christians? and yet what a base Esteem has this proud
Spirit of all men, yea, of all Christians too, that dance not after his foolish
pipe, etc.

Answ. Here thou abusest G. F. and the Quakers again (if it be them thou
meanest) who hold forth the Universal Love of God to all Mankind through
Christ Jesus, who shed his Blood and dyed for all, and enlightens all, and his
Grace has appeared to all: and we exhort them to Believe in the Light, that
they may become Children of the Light. And the Grace of God will teach them,
and bring their Salvation, if they do not turn it unto Wantonness: and do
thou call this sound Doctrine Foolish Pipe?

R. W. And whereas thou bring I. M's. words [ The Prophets are more certain,
then any other Revelation.] And G. F. Answers [Was not the Son of God Revealed?
p. 24.
etc. and did not he Come in the Volumn of the Book to do the will of God? and
so they that had the Prophets and the Law (to wit, the Jews) knew not the Son,
etc.] And R. W. Answers and says, To pass by G. F*s. Un-English and
Nonsense, etc.

Answ. It Is like, this may be Nonsense to him, though there may be some fault
in the Printer; but Charity would have past this by, as I have often done in R.
W.'s. Book.

R. W. And thou say, that G. F. knows not, that the Question is not here,
whether Christ be the End of the Law and the Prophets? etc. and whether Christ
was not more Revealed at his coming? etc: but whether the Written Word of the
Prophets, of which Peter speaks, be not a more sure word of Command and
Comfort to us, then any now to be expected? etc.

Answ. I. M. says, The Prophets are more certain, then any other Revelation;
and what is this to R. W's Questions? And I say, Christ being revealed, which
is the End of the Prophets and the Law, etc. He is a More and a Certain
Revelation, etc. for he is the Salvation and the Foundation that the Law Typed
forth, and the Prophets Prophesied of; for he is the Substance. For many may
have the Law and the Prophets in words, as the Jews had, and not receive the
great Revelation of Christ Jesus: and many have the New Testament of the
Apostles and Christ; but Christ says plainly, None knows the Father, but the
Son, and to whom he Reveals him, though they may have the Prophets, like
Jews, and know him not. -- But thou say: But whether the Written words of
the Prophets, of which Peter speaks, be not a more sure word of Command and
Comfort to us, then any now can be expected? What is this to the Revelation of
the Son of God? And thou wrongest Peter's words; for Peter says also: We have
a more sure word of Prophecy, (not of the Prophets, as thou have thrust in)
whereunto you do well, that you take heed unto, as unto a Light that shines in
a dark place, until the day dawn, and the Day Star arise in your hearts. And is
this Sure word of the Prophets of Command and Comfort to you, more then any can
be expected? what! do thou not own Christ the End of the Prophets, a greater
Comfort and a Revelation then the Prophets, who is the Foundation of the
Prophets and Apostles? But what dark place is this, that the Light shines in,
that people must take heed unto, until the day dawn, and the Day Star arise in
their hearts? for we say, that all the Prophets of God did foretell of Christ,
which the Apostles and Peter preached, Christ the Fulfilling of them, praised
be his Name for ever!

R. W. And thou say, That God called his Mind his Word, his works his Word,
his writings his Word, and his Providence of Mercy and Judgment his Word in a
way of Condescension to our Capacity, etc: And this thou comparest with Rulers
and Masters of Ships word, etc. or Records and Deeds with Hands and Seals, etc.
And then thou say, The word of God in the mouths of the Prophets, written
for after-generations, etc. and then thou tellest, that the Jews have their
Talmud, and The Turks their Alcoran, and the Pope his Decretals, and the
Protestants the Written Word or Scriptures.

Answ. Thou have made many Words here, if God's Work (his Creation, etc.) be
his Word, and if Scriptures (which signifies Writings) be his Word: and thou
confessest, the Word was in the Prophets; which is true, none opposes that.
But the Scriptures of Truth are called the Words of God (as Exodus 20. and in
the Revelations) and Christ calls them Words, Joh. 5, 47. And if any man hear
my Words, Joh. 12, 47, 48. 14, 23. -- John 15, 7. My Words abide in you: Jer.
5, 14. I will make my Words in thy mouth fire. Isa. 51, 16. I will put my Words
in thy mouth. And Job. 42, 7. After the Lord had spoken all these Words. So
here you may see, they are called the Words of the Lord; and Christ's Name is
called the Word of God. Now the Apostle says, Through Faith we understand,
that the worlds were framed by the Word of God; but where does R. W. prove,
that God's Works are called his Word? he has given no Scripture for this. And
why do the Schoolmasters make Books for Children, and tell them, that
Scriptures signifies Writings (as in the English Schoolmaster, and other
Books)? and you say, They are the Word, and give them the Title, that belongs
to Christ: and why cannot you give them the Title, that the Holy Men of God
gave to them, which gave them forth, who called them the Holy Scriptures of
Truth? And thou need not tell us, What the Pope, and the Jews and the Turk
have: and the Jews had the Scriptures of Moses and the Prophets, but would not
receive Christ the Word.

R. W. And thou tellest of a written Pardon, sealed with a broad Seal of a King
or State, p. 25.
and say; What a fancy is it for a Condemned wretch first to hearken to a
Pardon within, to a King within, a Writing within, a Seal within, and to slight
the true Pardon in the King's way to be Conveyed from without to the Mind and
Spirit within? and to lose his pardon and deliverance, as thousands of poor
cheated souls must do.

Answ. The King's written Pardon to Condemned men sets them free, but the
Written in Scripture does no^ set men free, nor Pardons men's Sins and
Trespasses: but it is Christ, that dyed for their sins, and shed his Blood for
them; and this the Scriptures testify of, that he has purchased them with his
Blood, and he is the Offering for Sin. And if the written Scripture be the
Pardon of Sin of the Condemned World, as the King's written Pardon is for
Condemned persons, then all that have the Scripture, have their Pardon by thy
meaning: but page 64. thou say, The Scriptures avail nothing, without the
Spirit of God set it home upon us; so here thou contradicts thy self. And
Christ says, Search the Scriptures, for they testify of me, and in them you
think to have Eternal Life, but you will not come to me, that you might have
Life. So the Life is in Christ, and he that has Christ, has Life; and they
that have not him, have not Life: and they that have not the Spirit of Christ,
are none of his, though they may have the Scriptures. And they who had their
Garments made white, it was by the Blood of the Lamb, and not by written
Pardons: and they that are the true Believers in Christ the Light, and are in
the New Covenant, as Heb. 8. he blotteth out their Sins and Trespasses, in whom
God writes his Law in their hearts. And 1 Cor. 15, 3. Christ dyed for our Sins
according to the Scripture: so it is not a written Pardon, though the
Scriptures declare this. And Christ dyed for the Ungodly, Romans 5, 6. Christ
dyed for us, 1 These. 5, 10: So he it is that Pardons. And the Apostle said,
This is a faithful saying, and worthy of all Acceptance, that Christ Jesus
came into the world to save Sinners, of whom I am chief, 1 Timothy 1, 15. so it is
God and Christ, that does Pardon and Forgive Sin, Col. 2, 13, and Luke 5, 20:
and they that witness this, their Sins are forgiven them. For the true
Believers are Sealed with the Spirit of God (and the Spirit of God is within)
and hear the Voice of Christ their Shepherd, Thy sins are forgiven thee; and so
have their Testimony of pardon within: and so come to be built upon Christ the
Rock and Foundation. So it is one thing to have the Writings, and another thing
to have the Seal of the Spirit of Christ, as they had that gave forth the
Scriptures: and they that are Sealed with it, have the comfort of God and
Christ, and the comfort of the Scriptures, etc.

R. W. And thou bring'st R. H. which says [ It is against the Light of Nature
for Women to preach, etc.] And G. F. Answers R. H. and says [Contrary to the
Apostle's Doctrine, and the mind of God and the Prophets, who said, God would
pour out of his Spirit upon All Flesh, and his Sons and Daughters should
prophecy. So that he is a Limiter of the Holy One, and a Quencher of the
Spirit, and in Darkness: and this is above the Light of Nature.] And R. W.
Replyeth and says, What is the Light of Nature, but that Light, in which every
man comes into the world with ( as the Quakers speak) which differs from the
Light of Beasts, etc.

Answ. What is this to G. F's. Answer? for G. F. and the People of God in Scorn
called Quakers (which thou in Scorn call Foxians) do not say, That the true
Light, which is the Life in the Word, which enlightneth every man that comes
into the world (which is a Light to be revealed to the Gentiles, as Simeon
speaks) is a Natural Light, or Light of Nature. For this is the Supernatural
and Light from Heaven, which John speaks of in the Scripture; and as God
said, I will give him for a Covenant, and a Light to the Gentiles, and he shall
be my Salvation to the ends of the Earth: and where does John or the Apostles
call the true Light (which is Life in the Word, which Lights every man that
comes into the world) a Natural Light or Light of Nature? And then thou go
on, and tellest a great Tale of the Natural Light in man, which is nothing to
the purpose to G. F's Answer.

R. W. And then thou say; It Is true, that in Religious and Christian matters
there is no respect of persons with God, p. 26.
as of man before the woman: otherwise then to Order Natural and Civil. And
thou say: It Is true, the Wisdom of God prefers some Women before
thousands of men, etc. as Lady Jane and Q. Elizabeth, etc. And (thou say)
Christ appearing to Mary Magdalen, and other Women, and sending them to carry
the first Tidings of his Resurrection to his Apostles, etc. and Mirjam and
Huldah, etc. Prophesying before Christ's coming: and at his coming ( according
to Joels Prophecy) his Spirit on his Daughters as well as his Sons, etc. and
yet this favor of God toward Women destroys not the Order, which the God of
Order or Nature has set in those Bounds, Limits and Distinctions between Male
and Female, etc. Though the Holy Scripture were silent, yet Reason and
Experience tells us, that the Woman is the weaker Vessel, that she is more
fitted to keep and order her House, etc. And the Lord has given a Covering of
longer hair to Wom^n, as a sign of covering Modesty and Bastfulness, Silence
and Retiredness, and therefore not so fitted for Manly Actions and Employments.

Answ. Here does not R. W. contradict himself? Though the Apostle does say,
That the Woman is the weaker Vessel; and it is so known: yet is not Christ and
his Spirit as strong in the Female, as he is in the Male? For thou say,
There is no respect of persons with God, as the Man before the Woman; and God
prefers some Women before thousands of Men, as Lady Jane and Q. Elizabeth,
and Deborah: and yet thou say, Women are not so fitted for Manly Actions and
Employments; These were Manly Actions, and Godly of Q. Elizabeth and Deborah.
etc. And then thou say^st, She being the weaker Vessel, she is more fit to keep
and order her House and Children, etc, in Silence and Retiredness, etc. but in
this thou confoundest thy self; for these were Fitted with Manly Actions: and
Mary Magdalen, and other Women that first declared the Tidings of the
Resurrection of Christ to his Apostles, those were Godly Actions. Neither was
Mirjam and Huldah forbidden in the time of the Prophets, nor Philip's four
Daughters in the time of the Gospel; neither did any say to them (as R. H.
does) It was against the Light of Nature for Women to Preach. And the Spirit of
God, by which these Famous Women were led then and now, does keep Gods Order
and Distinction in the Sex of Male and Female; and they know a time to speak,
and a time to be silent: and it teaches them Modesty, and to know the Fruits
of the good Spirit, which leads them to Prophecy.

R. W. And thou say, Therefore, because of Joels Prophecy, or be^cause we
must not limit or quench the Spirit, as G. F. says, there is no ground in Gods
ordinary course of Nature to permit Women to pretend to be Apostles and
Messengers to the Nations, or Preachers and Teachers in the public Assemblies.

Answ. And Reader see, if he has not abused G. F's. words, who brings the
Apostle's, and the Holy Men's Doctrine. I say, All those that Quench the Spirit,
and hate the Light of Christ, and have the Form of Godliness, and deny the
power, they are to be turned away from; they are not Fit to preach neither in
Nations, nor in public Assemblies: but those that are led by the Spirit of
God, Male or Female, are not to be Limited and Quenched. -- And were not Mirjam
and Huldah Prophets in the Assembly? and to whom did Philip's four Daughters
Prophecy? and did not Mary Magdalen Preach Christ's Resurrection to the
Assembly of the Apostles. And the Apostle says, Every Woman that Prays and
Prophesies with her head Covered, etc: where did these Women Prophecy and
Pray, if not in the Assemblies of the Corinthians? 1 Cor. 11. And yet R. W. (
in his 140. page) justifies a Baptist-Woman (she being his Brother's Wife) her
Loud speaking or Preaching in the Assembly at Newport at the End of the
Dispute, she saying; R. W's. words shall judge you at the Last day. So he
Contradicts himself.

R. W. And thou say: Because we find no such Commission (to wit,
Women-Messengers and Speakers in Assemblies) given by Christ Jesus, or any such
practice amongst the first Believers.

Answ. What! No such Commission given by Christ? had not Mary Magdalen and
other women Commission? and such as Prophesied? as 1 Cor. 11: and Phebe, a
Servant to the Church? and Priscilla? do not thou Contradict thy self here
again? And thou sayd'st before, A Woman was not so fit for Manly Actions; and
yet thou bring Lady Jane and Q. Elizabeth whose Actions were Manly and
Godly: and do thou not Contradict thy self here again? for thou do not
make a Distinction of Women here in this Head.

R. W. Thou say, The Lord has set a preventer, etc. with the Reasons to the
Corinthians, and to Timothy to Answer those Scriptures with a flam, viz. That
Eve the Transgressor, and Women that be Tatlers, p. 27.
are forbidden, and the Woman Jezabel, etc. And, why may not Women be Lord
Mayors, and Bailiffs, and Sheriffs, etc. and Generals and Commanders, etc.

Answ. What is this to the purpose? because Eve the Transgressor, and Tatling
women and Jezabel are forbidden to Teach, does the Apostle forbid Sons and
Daughters to Prophecy? does not the Apostle Preach to the Jews of Sons and
Daughters Prophesying, which was the practice among the true Believers, though
not among you? And do not thou say, There is no Respect of persons with God,
as of man before a woman; and yet thou say, The Lord has set a Preventer to
prevent the Women of such unnatural boldness? and Eve in Transgression, and
Tatling Women and Jezabel, that disobey the Lord; such are Forbidden; for, are
they like to exercise the Office of the Spirit of Prophecy? -- And Women-
Mayors, and Bailiffs, and Sheriffs (as thou Scoffingly bring'st) what is this
to Sons and Daughters Prophesying? for thou dare not say, but that Deborah
and Q. Elizabeth were Commanders and Rulers, which the Lord called them to:
which is not very common to Women. And R. W. why had thy Sister such Unnatural
boldness to Preach so loud, and pass such a Sentence without thy Reproof at the
end of the Dispute at Newport? which Unnatural Boldness thou have justified,
and put her in Print.

R. W. And thou say: That Reason, that the Spirit gives to the Corinthians
for the Vailing of Women in public Assemblies, makes much more for their
Vailing and Silence in matter of Prophesying and Praying, etc.

Answ. The Apostle says no such thing, (1 Cor. 11.) that women should be
silent either in Praying or Prophesying but he shows them, how that they were
to Pray and Prophecy Covered: and therefore thou wrongest the Apostle and the
Scripture in saying, It makes much more for their Vailing and Silence in
matters of Prophecy, and Preaching and Praying. For the Apostle there makes a
distinction of men and women exercising their gifts, and the Man praying
Uncovered, and the woman praying Covered: he gives the Reason, and explaineth
it himself to him that has an Ear.

R. W. And thou tellest the world a Story of Two Mary's, that came from London,
and bid thee Repent, and Hearken to the Light within, etc. And thou ask them
the ground of their Travel and Employment; and they alleged Joels Prophecy,
etc. And thou say, These Women animated the Seamen to Fight, and
Prophesyed, that an hair of their head should not perish; and then thou say,
They were slain, and Tidings came on this whole matter, etc.

Answ. But R. W. who told thee this Story? for their Names thou have not
declared to the World. And if Two Mary's did bid R. W. Repent, and hearken to
the Light of Christ within him, he stands in need enough of it; for had he
Repented, and come to the Light of Christ, he would have been out of this Evil
work. And as for his saying, the two Marys told him the ground of their Travel,
they alleged was Joels Prophecy: and this is like unto that, They Animating
the Seamen to fight, etc. but these are Scoffing words, which do not become an
Old Man, much less a Christian, to tell such Stories to the world.

R. W. And then thou say; In some extraordinary Case, as in Abraham's Case
with Isaac, etc. but we must not tempt God. But if God has poured out his
gifts of Knowledge and Utterance upon some women more then others, they have
three large Fields to walk in mentioned in the Scripture, (viz) Of their
Instructing their Children. (2.) As occasion justly calls them from home, of
Instructing other women, especially the Younger. (3.) Of confessing boldly the
Name of Christ, when he suffers Tyrants to bring persecution on them.

Answ. Are these the Large Fields the Scriptures mention for Sons and Daughters
Prophesying? and must it be the Occasion, and not the Spirit, to cause the
Elder women to Instruct the Younger, as Occasion calls them from home? and is
it not their Duty? and do thou make this a Comparison with Abraham in the
Case of Isaac, as thou say? surely no; for it is the Duty of all Christian
Women in their Families, To instruct their Children. But what is this to
Daughters Prophesying? for did not Priscilla Instruct Apollo as well as Aquila?
and does not the Apostle speak of Women that Labored with him in the Gospel?
(Phil. 4) and were these only their Families, or as occasion justly called them
from home? Did Mary Magdalen and other Women preach Christ's Resurrection, As
occasion called them from home, or as Christ sent them? and did not they
confess and preach Christ at other times, as well as in times of Persecution?
and all true Christian Believers, that Believe in the heart, with the mouth
they will make Confession unto Salvation, Romans 10.

R. W. And thou bring T. H. that says [ The Sight of the Godhead without
Faith in Christ, p. 28.
is the foundation of all false Worships.] And G. F. Answers to T. H. [Can any
see the Godhead, or have a sight of the Godhead, and not see Christ, and have
Faith in Christ? and who has Faith in Christ, do not they see the fullness of
the Godhead, and dwell in Christ? And were not their minds turned To that of
God in them, which declared the Invisible things of him from the Creation of
his Eternal power and Godhead, which the Apostle found fault withal, etc. Romans
1? let all Examine and Judge, and Read the Scripture and try.] -- R.W. Replyeth
to G. F. and says, I have Conversed with all the Indians of New England, etc.
and I have read Romans 1. often, and I find, that first theris generally in all
Mankind in the world a Conviction of an Invisible and Omnipotent, and Eternal
Power and Godhead: and thou say, That this Conviction does arise from the
Creation, etc. And then thou tellest what men hold, etc.

Answ. Do not thou here speak contrary to the Apostle's Doctrine? for does
not the Apostle say, Because that which may be known of God, is manifest in
them, and God has showed it unto them? why do thou speak contrary to the
Apostle's Language, and say, It rises from the Creation? And must not that,
which Is general in all Mankind in the world, be the Spirit of God, which
Convicteth them of the Invisible and Omnipotent, and Eternal Power and
Godhead? (and yet thou say, There is no Voice nor Motion to be hearkened to
in Heavenly things, in matters of Supernatural Light. p. 83.) for the Apostle
says, That, which may be known of God: so it is Of God, which God has showed
unto them; therefore God will Judge the world in Righteousness, who acts
contrary to that, which he Shows them, Romans 1, 19.

R. W. says, I find not, that every man or men ( by all their Natural Light or
Wit, or Christ within) could find out, how the world, or himself, man or woman
were Created; though]. Naylor tells us in Print, that if never a Letter of
the Scripture had been writ, yet their Spirit could tell them all things.

Answ. We do believe thee, that thou and All men in their Natural State, or
Natural Light cannot find out the worlds, nor how they were made, etc. because
that Solomon says, The world is set in thy heart, etc. Eccles. 2. And whereas
thou say, Nor the Light of Christ within; In that thou speak Ignorantly:
for the true Light of Christ, which is Life in the Word, by which All things
were made, this Light, that shines in their hearts, gives them the Light of
the Knowledge of the Glory of God in the Face of Christ Jesus the Word, by whom
All things were Created. -- And as for I. N's* saying, that If they had not had
the Scripture, yet the Spirit of God teaches them all things; and why not? Did
not the Spirit of God teach them all things. that gave forth the Scripture? and
is not the Spirit of God the same, which led the holy men of God to give forth
Scriptures, which the Holy Ghost now leads into the Truths of them? -- And the
Apostle says, By Faith we understand, the worlds were made by the word of God,
etc. Heb. 11. and so by the same Faith it is understood now: in the same Faith
Moses describes it, who saw him that was Invisible, and saw Christ, who is the
Author and Finisher of this true Faith; which Faith thou and the
New-England-Priests are erred from, as is manifest.

R. W. Thou say, All men confess, that the Will or Mind of God is pure; and
as they could come to know it, it is to be adored and kept and observed: and
that it was ever, and is wickedness to sin against it.

Answ. Then must not this be the pure Spirit of God, that makes them to
confess to his pure Will or Mind? and to confess, that it was ever sin and
wickedness to sin against it?

R. W. And thou say, None ( for all the Light and Spirit in every one) could
ever find; how Sin, and Death and Sorrow came into the world? nor how such
Inclinations and Dispositions of sin came into themselves?

Answ. Then thou art out of the Faith, and Spirit and Light, that Moses was in,
and the Apostles; for the Apostle, that turned people from the Darkness to the
Light of Christ, Explaineth it ( Romans 5.) And do not thou think, that he saw
it with the Spirit of God within, and the Light of Christ which lights every
man, that comes into the world? and that Moses did not see it with the same
Light of Christ, and the Spirit of God, because thou say, None ( for all the
Light and Spirit in every man) could find it? And such that did understand
Visions and Dreams, and the Scriptures, etc. it was by such, as Obeyed the
Spirit of God; and the Spirit of God Revealed such things to them.

R. W. And further thou say, Thou find in all Men a Conviction, p. 29.
that God is just and powerful, and does bring Plagues and Punishments upon
persons for gross sins, as Adultery and Murder, etc.

Answ. And before thou confessest more General, That it was ever, and is
wickedness to sin against it (to wit, the Mind of God, page 28.) And will not
this Teach them to Resist the Devil, that Teaches them to Forsake sin? and
will not that Teach them to Glorify God, as he is God, if they obey it? and
what is all this, that thou have spoken in thy Answer here to the purpose? for
sometimes thou grantest what G. F. says (in Rom.) and then thou speak
slightingly of the Light of Christ, and call it Natural, which is from the
Spiritual man. But all that see their Happiness, and their Blessedness in the
world, that is without End, they must see it by the Divine Light of Christ and
do Resist the Devil with the Faith, that Christ is the Author of.

R. W. And thou say Hence ( according to G. F. 's Opposite) all Man kind
have invented so many false Gods, false worships, etc. yet out of no more Love
to God, then the Lamb bears to a Lion, etc. and then thou quotest the
Philistines, Samaritans and Sechemites, etc.

Answ. Thy words are General, All Mankind all the world over. What! did
Methuselah, and Jared, and Lamech, and Abraham, and Moses, and the Prophets and
the Apostles Invent? did they Invent any False Gods? for thy words are, All
Mankind have Invented so many false Gods and Worships all the world over.
What! is there no part of the World free? has not God his Seven Thousand
still, as he had in the days of the Prophets, that Do not bow their knee to
Baal? 1 King. 19. And did not all those that Invented all those false ways and
worships, go from that of God In them, which God had showed unto them?

R. W. And then thou say: The Sechemites for fear of Lions, or hope of Gain
will be of any Worship or Religion, as most this day in the World will be; yea,
all and every soul, except to whom ( in and from the Holy Scriptures) the Holy
Spirit Reveals the Incomprehensible Mystery of a Mediator.

Answ. Then they are not All Mankind. And as for Being of any Religion for
hope of Gain, that thou and the Priests might have kept at home: for the Gain
that Gods Servants got, that were sent to preach the Gospel among you, was
Gallowses, Whips, Prisons and bad Language. And they that own the Holy Spirit
to Reveal Christ the Mystery, the Mediator (which Holy Spirit leads into all
Truth) they will own us, and not them that talk of it, and live out of it.

R. W. And then thou bring'st I. H. his saying [ The Justification and
Redemption by obeying the Light within is a Mystery of Iniquity] G. F. Answ.
[He that believes, is justified from all things, and comes not into
Condemnation; for he has the Witness in himself: and that lets him see (to
wit, the Light of Christ) the Redeemer the Savior; the Light, which walking in
it he is cleansed from all sin. So no Mystery of Iniquity; for the Mystery of
Iniquity is out of the Light: and none sees Justification and Redemption, but
with the Light which comes from Christ, who has enlightened them] To this R W.
Replyeth, and begins with his Foul Language, and says, This is subtle; but
being examined, it will be a Mystery of Hellish Iniquity, and lighter then
Vanity it self.

Answ. Poor Man! he might very well have kept this at home. And then he goes
on and says, G. F. confounds Justification, and the Light of Christ, and
Faith and Obedience ( after his Babilonish wont) all in a Juglers Box within
together; so that the English of it is, Faith is Christ, Obedience is Christ,
Justification is Christ, etc. And then thou say, It is true Figuratively.

Answ. If it be True Figuratively, why do thou call it Babilonish and
Juglers Box, and Lighter then Vanity, and Hellish Iniquity? but G. F.'s words
are plain enough, as they speak; but thou, that art in the Hellish Iniquity,
and the Juglers box, etc. may Cavil at them.

R.W. And because that G.F. says [None see Justification and Redemption (
which comes from Christ, who has enlightened them) but with the Light within]
R. W. says, That G. F.'s words may be in plain English thus rendered [None sees
Christ and Christ, p. 30.
but with the Christ within, which comes from Christ, who has Christed him.

Answ. Now Reader see, if G. F.'s words speak, as he Maliciously says. For,
can any see Christ Jesus their Sanctification, Justification and Redemption,
but by the Light, which Christ has enlightened them withal? for with the same
Light they see their sins, and Christ their Savior and Redeemer, etc. -- And
thou say, It is a Mystery, or a subtle Trick of Hell, to call Faith
Obedience, and Obedience to the Light Justification, etc. Reader, read G. F.'s
words, and see, if G. F. has either mentioned the word Obedience, or Faith (p.
29.)? So R. W. Inventeth words, and then he called them a Mystery, and a subtle
Trick of Hell, to call them, as he has invented them; which is his own subtle
Trick of Hell, for there is no such word in G. F.'s Answer. And then he calls
it True sense, and says, True Sense (as Money) answers all things; but we
cannot deny the Apostle's Doctrine, how that Christ is made unto us Wisdom and
Righteousness, Sanctification and Redemption: and thy Distinguishing of
Heavenly matters is like thy Distinguishing of G. F.'s words, as has been
showed before in thy Contradictions.

R. W. And then thou say, It is another Gospel, and yet not another: but is
a Dream and dead Picture of an Image or an Idol, to put-in our Obedience and
Working.

Answ. What Contradictions and Confusions are these! and what work make thou
about Obedience! for G. F. has not mentioned the word Obedience; but thou
fightest with thy own words: but seeing thou make such work with Obedience,
read Romans 1, 5.6, 16.16, 19. and 2 Cor. 7, 15.10, 5, 6. 1 Pet. 1, 2.

R. W. And then thou say, I know, they Father this Bastard upon the
most-Holy God himself, saying, It is His Obedience, His Righteousness and His
Working in the room of the Death and Bloodshedding, the Sufferings and Merits
of the Lord Jesus.

Answ. I did never hear so many foul words, and such Perversions from any man
in my Life! the Reader may see in R. W.'s own Book, there is not the word
Obedience in G. F's. Answer, which he replyeth to. And we do say, that Christ
Jesus was Obedient unto Death, even the Death of the Cross, Phil. 2: and the
Apostle says, As by the Disobedience of one Man many were made Sinners, so by
the Obedience of One (to wit Christ) many were made Righteous. And the Saints
are Obedient to Christ's Faith and Spirit, etc.

R. W. And then thou go on, and tellest of Laban changing wages, etc. and
then thou tellest us of the Papists and Jews etc. and the Bargain of Do this
and Live; and a Bargain of Saving our selves, and a Bargain of Flying out of
our selves only to Gods Mercies in the Mediation of Christ Jesus: and then
again render our selves so Holy, so Obedient, so Righteous, so Loving, so
Chaste, so Meek, so Patient, so Temperate, that in thought, word or deed we sin
not. And this our Holiness is Christ, and God, and Spirit, and Justification,
etc.

Answ. Reader did thou ever hear, how he has jumbled things together here?
