Where did Christ and the Apostles use these words, as Making of Bargains with
his People? it is like, R. W. thinks, he is Wiser then they, that gave forth
the Scriptures, and their words are too simple for him to speak: but R. W.'s
Scoffing Expressions here do not touch us; he may apply this at home. And this
we say, Every one that follows Christ, must Take up his Cross, and deny
himself, he that will be his Disciple: and they must Die with Christ, if they
Live with him; and suffer with him, if they Reign with him: and his Spirit
teaches Temperance, Patience and Holiness, yea, to deny that which is Unholy
both in Word and in Thought. And the Righteousness of Christ Jesus is our Fine
Linen; and it is God and Christ, that does justify by the Spirit, who art
thou that do Condemn? And where did we say, that Our Holiness is Christ and
God? though we cannot deny Christ to be Our Holiness, etc. who deny
Self-holiness.

R. W. And thou say, I know, the Writers of the Quakers make this high
Obedience to be the Crown of some high Saints among them, as the Papists do;
and that others come not so high, are taken by the fleshly Spirit, and Repent
and Confess, and be more watchful, as they say, in a Contradiction of J. Naylor.

Answ. These are most horrid Lies; and Reader see, if G. F. speaks any of
these words in his Answer to T. H. as to the Crowning of high Saints ( like the
Papists) for their Obedience, or Making their Obedience a Crown: for it is the
Lord Jesus Christ, that Crowns his Saints, that believe in his Name, and grow
up in his Grace and Truth. And as for a Fleshly Spirit, and Repent, and
Confess, this you may apply at home; for we own no Repentance nor Confession.
but what is made by the Spirit of God, in which we have Unity: and for
Exhorting to the watchful, that is Christ's Doctrine. And it is no
Contradiction to say, He that is born of God, cannot sin: for the Apostle John
explaineth this in his Epistles better than thou can, which the Quakers own;
which thou make a great Jumble about. For the Apostle says, He that
believes, is born of God, and overcomes the world: and is not that the world
in men's hearts? and he writes to Young Men and Fathers, which had Overcome the
Wicked one; and to Little Children, that they sin not: and if any man sins,
we have an Advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the Righteous, and he is a
Propitiation for our sins; and not for our sins only, but for the sins of the
whole World, 1 John 2.

R. W. Thou say, Yet again ( in a horrible Mystery of Iniquity) they exclaim
against the Protestants for saying, A Child of God cannot fall from the true
Grace Finally or Totally.

Answ. Here are no such words in G. F.'s Answer to T. H. Or how hangs this
together? thou say, They say, He that is born of God, cannot sin; then how
Can they Fall from the true Grace? But what say thou to them, that Crucify
the Son of God afresh, and do despite against the Spirit of Grace, and turn it
into Wantonness? and these are such, as do not Own the True Grace of God, which
is their Teacher, though it has appeared to them; nor do not Believe in the
Light of Christ Jesus, but hate it. And If the Righteous Fall, they rise again;
but the Wicked Fall into Mischief.

R. W. And thou say, Here is a Mystery of Hellish Iniquity, in that they
confess, such a Man, Christ, to have been, and his Bloodshedding, p. 31.
the Types, and real Predictions and Figures of him, a real Death, Resurrection
and Ascension; yet upon the point ( by a Devilish Chemistry) evaporate all
these, and leave nothing but a Christ within, as God and Man, whose Name is now
Light, etc. Motions within --.

Answ. As for Hellish Mystery of Iniquity, and Devilish Chemistry, thou may
keep at home: for according to the Scriptures of Truth we do believe Christ
Jesus his Birth, Sufferings, Resurrection, and Ascension; who fulfilled the
Prophets, and the Types and Shadows of him. And what! must we not call God and
Christ, as the Scriptures call them? for God is called the Light; and Christ
says, I am the Light. And though Christ is Risen, and Sits at the Right
hand of God, yet he does dwell In his Saints, his Temple, according to the
Apostle's Doctrine, as you may see, 1 Cor. 6. and 2 Cor. 6. -- And what! must
not God's people Obey the Motions of the Spirit of Christ and his Light, and to
take heed to it? by which they may see Christ their Savior, and Justification
and Salvation, and the Lord their Righteousness? and the Apostle stirred up to
Perfection and to Holiness, which all the Saints are to follow.

R W. And thou say, It is a Hellish Mystery of the Devil, to Cosen poor
souls with a Notion of the Difficulty and Hight of their profession, and of
Worshipping God in Spirit and Truth; which they say, no body in the world does,
but they. -- Spirit within --.

Answ. Our good Profession, which we make, is of Christ Jesus our Lord and
Savior, who has enlightened us to follow him and his Worship* that he has set
up in Spirit and Truth: and they that quench the Spirit, and hate the Light,
and will not come to Truth, cannot worship God in Spirit and Truth, John 3.4.
And this Truth and Spirit of God is Within people; and thou or they, that draw
people from the Truth in the Inward parts, and Spirit within, you draw them
into the Hellish Mystery, and Cosen poor souls (as thou speak of) for coming
to Christ and his Worship. -- And whereas thou say, Thou toldest them of an
Image in the Bed, but David was gone etc. but this is thy own Condition. And
then thou say, That their Religion is one of the Easiest in the world. Nay,
thou never trod the Path, thou do not know what it is; the Gallowses, and
Goals and Whip-Stocks manifest, whether Our Religion be Easy.

R. W, And whereas thou tellest us, What will delight our Ears and Minds, to
wit, various Tunes of Music, etc.

Answ. But that which Delights Us, is the Lord Jesus Christ, and his Holy
Ghost: and the Joy of the Lord is our Strength. And that which thou applyest to
Us, thou may keep at home; it is thy own, and none of ours.

R. W. And thou say, If a poor soul give way an Inch, and lets in one
thought of yielding to the Voice of a Spirit within, they are filled and
ravished with Curious Notions of Justification, Holiness and Righteousness, God
and Christ, and the Spirit within them.

Answ. How endlesly do thou speak against the Voice of the Spirit of God in
his People! And the Apostle exhorts, Not to walk after the Flesh, but after
the Spirit, Romans 8, 1, 2, 5, 6, 9, 10, 11, 13, 16, 26, 27. Romans 12, 11. and 1
Cor. 6, 20, 34. 1 Cor. 12, 13. Gal. 5, 5, 16, 18, 25. Ephesians. 4, 3, 5, 9. Phil. 1,
27, That you stand fast in one Spirit: Phil. 2, 1, If any fellowship of the
Spirit etc: and those are the Poor souls, that do not hear, what the Spirit
says to the Churches. And they that Obey the Voice of God and Christ, must
Obey the motions of the Spirit: and the Holy Spirit leads to Holiness, and to
him that Justifies freely by his Grace; and without Holiness none shall see
the Lord. And does not the Scripture say plainly, that God says, I will be
your God, and ye shall be my People, and that he would dwell in them, and walk
in them, 2 Cor. 6? and does not the Apostle say, that None can call Jesus
Christ Lord, but by the Spirit? and is not that within?

R. W. And thou say, They can now Thou the King, and they need no
Scriptures, nor Teachers.

Answ. May be thou art offended, because we say Thee and Thou to thee; for I
never heard the King was. And such Teachers as thee, we have No Need of, we can
praise the Lord: and the Scriptures we have the Comfort of them, and can praise
God for them.

R. W. And thou say, Thus, as in a Dream, their great Debts of Thousands and
Millions are paid and dis-charged.

Answ. Yes, by the Blood of Christ Jesus, who dyed for our Sins; and is risen
again for our Justification. And we can praise God, that we are come out of
your Cage (that thou speak of) and can say, The Turtle-Dove is heard in our
Land: and Christ does Deliver us from the Devil, of Hell and Death, and gives
us the Victory. -- And what, if some have been Rapt up into Paradise (as Paul
was) and speak and see Unutterable Joys (which thou Scoffingly speak of the
People of God) and what is this to them, that Followed Absalom? And thou
speak of Jewels fallen into the Dirt; truly this is thy own Work, that art
flinging thy Dirt at God's People*

R. W. And then thou say, As I hope in the Parishes of the Protestants and
Papists also, who being only Ignorant, (as the Disciples were) of main points
of Christianity, yet aim uprightly at God, truly love him, and labor to
increase in the Knowledge and Grace of Christ.

Answ. How now R. W. What! art thou now flattering the Papists and the
Parish-Protestants? and before The Papists would burn the Bible? And do not
thou say, Old and New England may flourish, when the Pope and Rome are in
Ashes? and such, as have True Love to God, and labor to increase in the
Knowledge and Grace of Christ? and yet, The Papists will burn the Bible? And as
for all the sober Protestants, they will be ashamed of thy foul words; and if
they read thy Book, they will see, how thou have abused us with foul words, the
Lord knows.

R. W. And thou bring'st Jer. Ives's saying, [ There may be a Light to Convince
of Sin, and not yet within man] -- G. F. Answ. [There is no people Convinced of
Sin, but they are Convinced within themselves, and with the Light within them.
p. 32.
It is the Light, which makes manifest to a Man, when he is Convinced: it
answers to something, and reaches to something in their particulars; though
the words be spoken without them from the Light]. R. W. Replyeth against G.
F.'s words (which are very good Truth) and cries; It is doleful Business to
read and hear, how Satan ( in his Chains of Darkness) yet has Liberty to
appear abroad, as an Angel of Light from Heaven, thus Vaporing and Swaggering
under the Cloak and Colors of Light --.

Answ. R. W. cannot endure to hear talk of the Light of Christ; but like the
Jews, who said, That Christ by the Prince of Devils cast out Devils. And how
does R. W. prove, that it is the Devil, that is as an Angel of Light from
Heaven in his Transforming, and not the Light of Christ in us? for Christ
says, he is Out of Truth; but we know, that this Light and Spirit leads Into
all Truth. And we do believe (according to the Scriptures of Truth) that the
Light (which enlightneth every one, that comes into the world) is the Life in
the Word, by which all things were made: and Christ, who said, I am the Light
of the world, was Glorified with the Father, before the world b^gan. And they
that believe in the Light of Christ, do become Children of the Light, and no
man can Come to God, but by Christ the Light, and to Salvation, but by the
Light of Christ, which gives them the knowledge of it. -- And this Light of
Christ R. W. calls a Devil in Samuels Mantle, and a Dragon, and a Devil of
Darkness, the God of this world, Vapourings, Crackings and Cheatings; and, He
labors to keep all in Blindness, or to beat out the Eyes of those, whom God
has truly enlightened: this is thy own Condition R. W. And thou say, That
God was Light, etc. then why do thou rail against the People of God called
Quakers, for professing, That God and Christ is Light?

R. W. And thou Scoffingly say, That the Quakers confess, That the Natural
Man perceives not the things of God; only they say, that beside Natural Light
and Reason; there is the Holy Seed, God and Christ within every Son; and to
this Spirit and Seed in Prison they preach. And Fox in our Discourses alleges
and affirms, God (in every man) to be a Cart laden with Sheaves, pressed
under, and as it were in Prison, etc. Blasphemous wretches, etc.

Answ. Reader see, if there be any such words in G. F.'s Answer to Jer. Ives,
as R. W. brings here? And whereas he says, Fox in our Discourses alleges,
etc: G. F. had never no Discourse with R. W. And whereas he says, That God and
Christ is the Seed within in all men, Those are not our words: for we say, that
Christ is the good Seeds man, that Sows the good Seed on all sorts of ground.
And to say, That the Eternal God is in Prison, these are his own Blasphemies:
and, The Natural man perceives not the things of God, that is true; and is his
own Condition. -- And as for the Lord's saying, He was pressed under the
Transgressing Jews, as a Cart with Sheaves; and therefore R. W. says, that the
Quakers say, God was in Prison: which is false. And we say, That which may be
known of God, is manifest in Every Man, which God has showed unto them: which
we tell all people of, as the Apostle did, and turn them to the Light and
Grace, that comes from Jesus, that they may turn to God and Christ, from
whence it comes. And thy Ungodly, Railing words touch us not.

R. W. And thou confessest, All Light or Truth Natural, Civil or Divine, it
comes from without, and is received by an Internal Faculty, p. 33.
according to the Capacity etc. of it: from thence it is conveyed to the Court,
etc. to be Examined.

Answ. What! is not this Court (or Guard, or Captain within) the Light of
Christ within to know Truth from Falsehood? And then thou say, That G. F.
urges [There must be a Receiver, and something that Answers,] and thou
say, That Natural Truth, or Moral etc. are soon received by Moral
Understandings. G. F. does not speak of Morals here, but the Light of Christ,
which Convinces, which is Supernatural, that brings the Christians (that
love the Light) to Discern Spiritual and Heavenly things from Natural. And
therefore Christ said, The Spirit of Truth should lead them into all truth: and
the Apostle says, Whatsoever does make manifest and reproves, is Light. And
what is all this to the purpose that thou speak ( page 31, 32 and 33)? and
who denies, but that the Natural receives Natural, and the Spiritual
Spiritual? for thou seem sometimes to grant, and sometimes to oppose: for
that, which G. F. speaks, is concerning the things of God.

R. W. And then thou tellest us, How that Christ asked his Disciples, how many
Loaves they had? [But what is this to the Light of Christ? those are Natural
things]. And then thou tellest us, How that Christ asked his Disciples, whom
say they that I (the Son of Man) am? and thou say, This was a Divine and
Supernatural Question; and for the outside and truth of the Fact, the Devils
could answer as well as the Disciples.

Answ. This R. W. might very well have kept at home, and his New England
Professors. For had R.W. and them known, that there had been a Christ, if the
Scripture had not declared it? for, have they the same Revelation, as Peter had
of Christ, Beyond flesh and blood? And was not this Revelation Within Peter by
the Spirit of God? and did not he see it with the Light of Christ, and with
that, which thou confessest, that will say, The Mind of God is pure? etc. (as
in thy 28. page) and then thou Grantest the Quakers Principle, which thou do
Oppose. And thou say, All true Believers hearts do receive and wel-come all
truly Divine and Heavenly Doctrines; Then there is the Light of God within to
receive them, if they do not hate it: and if they quench the Spirit, they are
not like to receive them; but choose the evil, and hate the good.

R. W. And then thou say, G. F. talks of something within, which is
preached to.

Answ. Thou abusest G. F.'s words, for G. F.'s words are, Reached to, as the
Reader may see.

R. W. And thou say, That the Natural Man perceives no Spiritual matter;
but when he is born again, then he acts and works, etc.

Answ. Here again thou abusest the Scriptures, and Christ's words, and
contradictest thy self. For thou say, There is a Conviction in all Mankind
in the world of an Invisible, and Omnipotent, and Eternal power and God head
(page 28.) And Christ says, Believe in the Light, while ye have it, that ye
may become Children of Light; and he that believes, is born of God: which
Christ shows, that they have the Light, before they be born again; or else
how can it be the Condemnation of them, that do not believe? And Natural men,
that hate Christ's Light, and grieve his Spirit in them, they are not like to
perceive the things of God. p. 34.
And then thou ramblest on and tell, what the Protestants say, but to no
purpose to G. F's. Answer.

R. W. And thou say; G. F. says, There is a Something, a Seed, though but
as a Grain of Mustard Seed, a Seed of God, of Christ, of the Spirit, to which
Christ the Word is preached: and then thou say, Horribly abusing the
Scriptures.

Answ. Now Reader see, if there be any of these Words in G. F's. Answer to Jer.
Ives? and see, if he has not abused G. F's. Words? And why does he scoff at
the Preaching to the Spirit? for, did not the Apostle Preach to the Spirit? and
sow to the Spirit? and of the Spirit reaped Life Eternal? and was not this
within People? And is not Christ the Seeds-man, that sows his Seed upon all
Grounds? And does not Christ compare the Kingdom of Heaven to a Grain of
Mustard Seed? read Matthew. 13. R. W. cannot endure, that G. F. should speak
Scripture.

R. W. And thou say, They maintain, though Men be dark and dead; yet Christ
within is Light and alive in them, and them only.

Answ. Here again thou wrong'st our Words; though we say, That Christ
enlightneth every one that comes into the World, which is the Life in the
Word: and this is the Condemnation of them that hate it. And they that receive
the Light, receive Christ; from whence it comes, that has Englightned them.

R. W. And thou say, G. F. his lying Cheats of a Sufficient Light within to
lead to God and to Salvation, a Teacher within etc: And thou further say, It
is a simple Superfluity, to hold a Candle of Out-ward Words to awaken and
englighten such a glorious all-sufficient Sun within.

Answ. Here thou do not know what thou say; thy Enmity against the Light
of Christ has blinded thee. We say, The Light of Christ is no Cheat; it is
Sufficient to believe in: for, He that believes, is Saved. And the Light that
shines in the Heart, gives the Knowledge of the Glory of God in the Face of
Christ Jesus; and it is Sufficient to take heed unto, Until the day dawn, and
the Day Star arise in their Hearts. And the Jews, though God poured out his
Spirit upon them, and they transgressed, God sent his Prophets to turn them to
his Spirit, which they had grieved and erred from, and so to God. And Christ
sent his Apostles, to turn them to the Light etc; and so do God's Messengers
now (though they hate them and it) to the Intent, that they may turn to Christ,
the Sun of Righteousness, from whence it comes. And all the Believers in the
Light are in fellowship with it, and can declare, What Christ has done for
their Souls; and praise God in the Assemblies.

R. W. Thou ask, Where is this Something of God ( yea, God and Christ?) and
say; If he Answer in the Understanding, he grants it Dark etc; if in the
Heart and the Affections etc, he confesses, all there is hard and dead.

Answ. They that hate the Light, and will not come to the Light, because their
Deeds be evil, and because it will reprove them; they Know all this with the
Light. And they are like to have their Understandings darkened and hardened, when
they hate the Light; that should soften them; so, their Understandings are
darkened: and Christ does quicken them, that are Dead in Sins and Trespasses,
that believe in this Light. And thou say, It is God and Christ, which the
Quakers do not say; but it is the Light of Christ, that they may believe in it,
and be graffted into him.

R. W. And thou say, Christ the Sun of Righteousness arose with saving rays
or wings of Salvation; but the blind Jews could not own him for their Messiah.

Answ. This is thine and your own Condition, Transgressing Christians, who will
Not own Christ the Light, who enlightneth every one that comes into the World.
And thou say, Though no Man sees it [to wit, Christ that lightneth every
Man, that comes into the VVorld]: Though R. W. and the New-England-Professors
Sees it not (because their Darkness cannot comprehend it), yet the Believers in
the Light See it, and Christ, the Sun of Righteousness, from whence it comes;
and receive him, the Messiah, though thou, and the Jews will not. And they that
come to the Light of Christ, they See how Christ enlightneth all Men, that come
into the World, by the Life in the Word; and how the Word was made Flesh.

R. W. And thou say; What is this to a mixture of Light and Darkness?

Answ. Nay, we must tell thee, that the true Light does not Mix with Darkness:
though it shines in darkness, darkness does not comprehend it; but the Light
comprehends darkness. And what was that the Pharisees closed their Eyes to, and
stopped their Ears, and pricked Saul, and made him kick again?

R. W. And after thou have rambled to no purpose, thou say; When God in his
own Means ordinarily works the Will to hear, p. 35.
to turn, to believe, to pray etc. And being thus turned with Ephraim etc.

Answ. The Apostle says; It is not him, that Wills. And is it the Will of
Man, that hears? and was it not the Spirit of Ephraim that Heard, seeing God
had poured out his Spirit upon the House of Israel? and Christ says, He that
has an Ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the Churches. And thou have
not seen thy Undone Condition yet! And if thou wast in a Mourning lamenting
state, thou would not be in this Work; who say, When he turns our
Wilderness etc, into a Garden: it seems, It is Not Yet; which we do believe
thee.

R. W. And thou say; Then we bring forth sweet Fruits, Flowers etc: and,
When he turns the Wolf into a Lamb, then we are meek, innocent, and patient.

Answ. Mark, When; it seems, it is Not Yet: and therefore, have these Weeds
and Wolfish Nature appeared etc. in New England, that have Worryed the Lambs;
who have showed forth such an Impatient, Vnmeek, and Vn-innocent Spirit, not to
be the Spirit of Christ; and so, No true Christians.

R. W. And thou say; But to talk of the Preaching to the Spirits in Prison
etc: and the Seed of God in Prison etc: when the Lord speaks of his warning and
moving Men by Noah 's Preaching in the Old World (as may be evidently evinced)
is like the profane Teaching of Parrots to prate of Grace etc: and as the
Parrot in France could say her Paternoster, her Creed etc: and yet knew as
much of the working of God in the Soul, as the Popish Teachers.

Answ. Do thou think, the Popish Teachers knows no more of the Grace of God,
which has appeared to all Men, than a Parrot? and do not thou Contradict thy
self, and say, That the Papists aim uprightly at God, and truly love him,
and labor to increase in the Knowledge of Grace? ( Page 31.) And (in thy
Epistle to the King and Baxter) would thou not have the Papists etc. in
Ashes, burnt with Fire and Brimstone? and now, That their Teachers know but as
much as a Parrot, of the Grace of God working in their Souls, (and that is)
Nothing at all? -- And why do thou show thy self so dark, and so envious
against the Seed of Christ being in Prison? for, does not Christ say [ I was in
Prison etc?] and was not that his Seed? and [ Why persecutest thou me?] and was
not that Christ in his Members? And why do thou compare Christ's Preacking to
the Spirits in Prison by his Spirit in the days of Noah, to a Parrot? like
unto the Parrots profane Preaching in France etc? And all may read (1 Pet. 3,
18, 19.) how Christ preached to the Spirits in Prison by his Spirit in the
days of Noah; Peter does not say, that it was Noah, but it was Christ: and the
Prisoning comes by Disobedience. And does not Christ say to the Prisoners,
Show your selves forth? and so, it is not Means Ordinary (as thou speak of)
for People To Believe in the Light, but a great Work of God; and that makes
you so stumble at the Light.

R. W. And thou say; They often say, God is All.

Answ. Does not the Scripture say the same, That God may be All, and In All, 1
Cor. 15? and Ephesians. 4. One God the Father of All, who is above All, and through
All, and in you All? but thou can not speak our Words right.

R. W. And thou bring Jer. Ives's Words, who says; [ It is a known Error to
say, That a Man was in Hell, and in Heaven] And G. F. Answ. J. I. and says
[Who in this shows his Ignorance of Scripture* For it gives Testimony of
Men, that did witness, that they had Been in Hell, in the Nether-most Hell; and
witnessed again, that they were In Heaven, and Sat in Heavenly Places in
Christ Jesus: and such were In Heaven, as is spoken of in the Revelations.] And
this Truth according to the Scriptures, R. W. calls a Lame, cheating Answer,
who cannot speak without Reviling: but let the Reader judge. And R. W. says,
That G. F. and Millions more, talk of Heaven, as the Parrot; but this he might
have applied at Home.

R. W. And whereas thou say; They talk as the Parrot of our Forefathers,
some from the Scriptures, and some out of Reasons Light talk of Places of Joy
Eternal for the Righteous, and Misery for the Wicked.

Answ. What R. W! have thou a Parrot, that has as much Light and Reason to
talk of these things, as G. F. and Men? And did not thou say before, Thou
find all Men to confess, that the Mind or Will of God was pure, and to be
observed? and that it is ever wickedness to sin against it? and now to say; G.
F. and Millions talk like a Parrot? what! is not Reason and Light in Men beyond
the Parrots Knowledge? Truly, Enmity has darkened thee, and thou art ignorant
of thy own Condition; therefore, thou judge others with thy Contradictions.
And thou tellest the Parable of Dives and Lazarus ( Luke 16.); but take heed,
thou do not know, how soon thou may be in Dives's state, who art so much
against the poor Lazarus's, that believe in the Light of Christ Jesus, and have
no Helpers, but God and Christ: and thou needs not tell us, what the Intent of
Christ's speaking of Dives and Lazarus was etc.

R. W. And thou says, He knows (to wit, G. F.) the state of Sorrow and
Bitterness is called Hell, and the state of Death and the Grave is set out by
the Word Hell etc: and so to either of these he wickedly applies the Third
state, of which the Lord Jesus so clearly speaks, p. 36.
viz. the State of the Ungodly after this Life, in the Life and World to come.

Answ. Here thou pervertest G. F's Words. For, in his Answer he does not speak
of the World to come* and the Wicked are turned into Hell, Psalm. 116. Psalm.
139. Jonah 2.
after they die; but as David spoke, Though the Gates of Hell took hold of him;
and as Jonah cried out in the Whales Belly in Hell, in Misery. For thou say;
G. F. knows, the state of Hell is Sorrow and Bitterness, and Death and Grave;
and yet thou say in thy Contradiction, G. F. talks of Heaven and Hell, as
the Parrot: R. W. does the Parrot know, that Hell is called Sorrow and
Bitterness, Death and Grave?

R. W. And thou say; That he (G. F.) knows, the Visible state of the true
Profession of Christ is called Heaven. [But can every Visible Eye see this
Heaven?] And thou say, Such as have an Interest in Christ Jesus, have sitten
down with him in those Heavenly Mansions, into which he is entered bodily, and
gone to prepare for their Reception and Coming.

Answ. If thou and the New England Professors were in this which thou speak
of, they would not persecute the People of God called Quakers. And then thou
tellest of the Third Heaven, the Place of Paul's Rapture of Joy and Blessedness
etc, when these Heavens and Earth are burnt up and consumed. What! are the
Heavenly Mansions and Glories to be burnt up, which they that have an Interest
in Christ, have sitten down in him in those Heavenly Mansions? for we know,
what Heavens and Earth the Apostle tells of, that must be Burnt up and
Consumed.

R. W. And thou say; It Is like, G. F. has been occasioned to these thoughts
by the Papists Fables about Heaven, and Hell, and Purgatory.

Answ. No such matter.

R. W. And then thou go on with a great Story of the Papists (which thou
had better to have kept at home), and thou say; G. F. knows, how that the
Papists get a great world of Money of these Notions of Heaven and Hell etc.

Ans. And G. F. knows, that the New England Priests get a great deal of M^^* as
well as the Papists, by telling People of Heaven and Hell; and make a trade
with the Scriptures, as the Papists do, with their Inventions.

R. W. And thou say, G. F. not believing these Fables, he fancies, that Hell
is some Apprehensions in the Mind of Wrath to come, and that is Hell and Wrath
it self: and having had flashies of Pride and Peace in their Minds, these are
the Joys of Heaven.

Answ. Then this is above the Parrot ta^king of Heaven and Hell; for has the
Parrot had such Apprehensions? And as for Pride and the Fables, keep at home
Roger; for we have known (as David and the Holy Men of God did) what Hell is?
and the Righteous passes through in this Life: and it is well, if thou have
have not made Agreement with Hell, Isa. 15.18. And has not Hell enlarged her
self by thee, and such as speak so much Evil against the Light of Christ, and
the Believers in it? and see, if thy TONGVE BE NOT SET ON FIRE OF HELL, Jam. 3.
and the Wicked, that Christ speaks of, That must go into Hell, thou shall
know that (I warrant thee) except thou Repent, Mark 9, 43, 45, 47. And thou,
and the New England Priests and Professors, may read your Conditions Matthew. 13,
15. how the Jews compassed Sea and Land to make a Proselyte; and when he was
made, they made him twofold more a Child of Hell etc* like you New England
Priests: and was not this to get him into a Form of Godliness without Life and
Power, and oppose Christ in his Light? But we can say, The Lord Jesus has
delivered us from the Wrath to come, 1 Thessalonians. 1, 10: and, God has not
appointed us to Wrath, but to obtain Salvation by our Lord Jesus Christ, who
dyed for us, awd we shall be saved from Wrath through him, (and so from Hell)
who are justified by his Blood, Romans 5, 9: and therefore, do not thou Treasure
up Wrath unto thy self against the Day of Wrath etc, Romans 2. And the Believers
in Christ do Enjoy in this Life an hundredfold, and in the World to come Life
Everlasting: so, our Joys are not Flashies of Heaven and Hell; neither do we
Cheat poor Souls (as thou falsely accusest us) with such Flashies; but do
believe according to the sound Doctrine of Christ and the Apostles.

R. W. And thou say (after thou have rambled a great while^t no purpose)
They do allow a time more or less, before they come into the perfect Heavenly
State, etc.

Answ. We say, There is a Growth from a Child to a Young Man, and to a Father
in the Truth; and God accepts of the Faithfulness of all. And as for Satan
enticing into proud vanities, thou might have kept at home.

R. W. And thou say; p. 37.
They have a mad Fancy of their Souls going into God, and becoming more God etc.

Answ. This is thy own mad Fancy: and let the Reader see, if there be any such
thing in G. F's. Answer? But this is a Word of thy own forging, and not ours,
to say. Our Souls becoming more God; but to say, Our Souls go to Christ, who is
the Bishop of them, that is true: and why should they not, who has Bought us
and them with his Blood? And do thou not Contradict thy self, in saying,
Their Souls go to Jesus? ( page 21, and page 37.)

R. W. And thou tellest of a State of Eternal Joy to the Righteous after this
Life, and a State of Eternal Misery, to the Ungodly etc.

Answ. Thou need not to tell us of this; though thou say, The exact
Knowledge of Particulars exceeds the present Sight of our Mortal Eyes, and the
Hearing of our Ears etc. Can these things, or the Joy of the Holy Ghost be Seen
with Mortal Eyes, or Heard with Mortal Ears? for does not Christ say, He that
has an Ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the Churches? And is it by
the Sight of the Mortal Eye, and the Hearing of the Mortal Ear, that sees and
hears the Joy and Comfort of the Holy Ghost, or the Spiritual Ear in this
Life? And the Apostle says, Ye have your Fruits unto Holiness, and your End
everlasting Life: now, did not the Apostle See and Hear this with a Spiritual
Eye and Ear, what the Saints did Enjoy both in this Life, and in Everlasting
Life, Romans 6? for what can thou See with thy Mortal Eye, or Hear with thy
Mortal Ear, but that which is Mortal? A Natural Man perceives not the things
of God (as thou have confessed) but the Apostle says, The Eye has not seen,
nor the Ear heard etc. the things which God has prepared for them that love
him; but God has revealed them unto us by his Spirit: for his Spirit searches
all things, yea the deep things of God.

R. W. And then thou runnest on and say, The first Fruits* and a Taste both
of the Heavenly Joys, and the Torments of the damned are given by God in this
Life; to the first in that Solid Peace and Joy, which they have in God; to the
other in that Horror and Despair, and Enmity against God.

Answ. This last R. W. may apply home to himself. For if ever he had known the
First Fruits of the heavenly peace, which God's people has in God, he would
never have written such a book against his people: but it is like, his Torments
are begun in this Life.

R. W. And thou say, There is three sorts of men especially will seek, there
is an Hell to come, above other sinners: The Voluptuous and Luxurious etc:
whose God is their belly etc. the devourers of the poor etc: The proud pufft up
with foolish confidences boldly crying, Lord open to us etc.

Answ. R. W. might have applied a great deal of this to himself, who has Hell
so often in his mouth against the Redeemed of the Lord.

R. W. And thou bring Jer. Ives, who said: [ The Pharisees were far enough
from having the Kingdom of heaven within them]. And G F. Ans. [Contrary to
Christ's words, who said, It was within them.] And R. W. replyeth and says, The
Kingdom of God and the Kingdom of heaven is one.

Answ. Who says to the Contrary? And then thou say, Of the Kingdom or
Government of God and Christ in the Soul, and the Government of God in his holy
Providence in the World, and his Government in the Churches and Saints, and the
Glorious State to come after this Life. Who says to the Contrary of this? not
the Quakers.

R. W. And then thou say, That his Journey-man G F. is a sit Instrument to
destroy all these, and to erect in their steed a dull, proud, dogged Confusion
or Babel within under the Name of God, Christ, Spirit, Light, Faith,
Righteousness, Resurrection.

Answ. All these be Lies. For let the Righteous and Honest Christian Judge, can
the Government of God in his holy Providence be destroyed? or Christ's
government in his Church be destroyed, when Christ says, The Gates of Hell
shall not prevail against his Church? Can Gods Glorious government and state
after this Life of his people be destroyed (which R. W. says, His Journey-man
G F. is a fit Instrument to destroy all these)? We say, Nay: But thy
Antichristian Religion may be destroyed -- And as for dull, proud, dogged
Confusion etc: under the Name of God, Christ, Spirit, Light, etc: which thou
talkest of without Life, is thy own Confused Babel, that may be destroyed. But
Christ, who is the Quickening Spirit, and the Author of Faith, and the Lord of
Righteousness, and the Resurrection, him thou can not destroy; he dies no
more: and he has enlightened us, and given us Faith, who is the Lord of
Righteousness and our Resurrection yea, now and at the last day.

R. W. And then thou tellest us, Christ knew, That the Jews and his own
Christian Followers were leavened with a Worldly Notion, that their Messiah
should be a Glorious Temporal King etc; and he tells them, That they were
mistaken; and says, That his Kingdom should not be such a Kingdom; p. 38.
but that it was within them. Hence the Kingdom of Heaven is a spiritual,
inward, and soul-Kingdom concerning God, and the Soul and Spiritual matters.

Answ. And this thou confessest, was to the Jews and his Christian Followers,
which were Leavened with a worldly Notion: And why do thou oppose G. F. there
for bringing his Words, who said, The Kingdom of Heaven was within the
Pharisees?

R. W. And thou runnest on and say; Sometimes it was In them, and sometimes
(thou say) it was Among them in the Streets; and make a pitiful Jumble
about Christ's Words in his saying, The Kingdom of God was within them. And
thou say, That the Kingdom of God, that is, God and Christ, and the Spirit
were literally in the Pharisees, and so in every Hyprocrite in the World etc.
though they know it not.

Answ. Did no^ thou say before, That the Kingdom of Heaven is spiritual,
inward, and a Soul-Kingdom? and that Christ said, It was within the Jews, as
thou say? And does not Christ say, That the Kingdom of Heaven is like unto
Leaven, or a Grain of Mustard Seed? and cannot this Kingdom be in the
Pharisees, except (as thou say) God and Christ must be literally in them?
-- And whereas thou say, Though the Pharisees knew it not; No more does
thou, (though it be in thee, as it was in the Pharisees) who jumblest things
together in this manner: and is this the Dividing the Word aright?

R. W. And then thou say; What Agreement is there betwixt Christ and Belial,
Light and Darkness, Righteousness and Unrighteousness?

Answ. No, there is no Agreement, nor the Spirit with the Flesh. Yet we must
not say, That the Light and Spirit is not within Man; for we do believe, thou,
that have not known this, have known little War in thy self.

R. W. And thou say; Whereas it is most improperly and impiously objected,
That the Light shines in Darkness etc.

Answ. Here thou chargest John and the Translators to be improper and impious,
not only the Quakers: here thou railest against John the Evangelist, (besides
thy Railing against the Quakers) that he speaks Impiously and Improperly; who
says, The Light shines in Darkness, and the Darkness comprehends it not.
And there thou, that abusest John and the Scripture, what are thy Words good
for?

R. W. And then thou ramblest on in thy Confusion, and say; But the Light is
at the Window, and the Eye etc; but the Eye, the Door is shut: and the Man
within is not only a sleep, but dead and rotten in Nature's Filthiness and
actual Transgressions and Abominations.

Answ. This is thy own Condition R. W. who have read it, whose Darkness cannot
comprehend the Light; but it comprehends thee in thy Darkness. But what Man
is this within, that is dead (to wit, within Man) and is rotten? how do thou
describe him? and him, that he is within? but thou, that hate the Light, then
Christ may knock at thy door, when Sin is gotten in, in thy Heart; and thou
love it better, than the Light of Christ. And John does not say, That the
Light is at the Window or Eye (as thou do) but In shines in Darkness: and
thou in thy Darkness think to give a better Meaning of John's Words, that he
himself; No, no.

R. W. Thou say; It is against all Color of Reason to imagine, that the
Lord Jesus should tell the Jews and Pharisees, and the rest of his bloody
Enemies (who some weakly, and some maliciously opposed his Kingdom and Coming
to rule by his Grace over them) that his Grace was King within them, what ever
their Hearts or Tongues said, or Hands did etc.

Answ. This is R. W's. Sense, who is confounded, as the Pharisees were with
Christ's Doctrine. And yet before he contradicts himself, and says; That the
Kingdom of Heaven was in the Pharisees, and Jews and Disciples a Spiritual,
inward and Soul-Kingdom etc: and thus he confounds himself with his own
Colors and ^easons.

R W. And thou say; It is contrary to what G. F. and his Clamor, that the
Kingdom of God consists in Righteousness, and Peace, and Joy in the Holy
Spirit, as opposite to the Kingdom in the Pharisees and all Hypocrites, p. 39.
as Hell to Heaven.

Answ. And why so? why may not the Kingdom of Heaven be compared to Leaven, and
a Grain of Mustard Seed, as the Kingdom of God, which the Saints are Heirs of,
that stands in Righteousness, and Peace and Joy in the Holy Spirit? Dare
thou say, That the Kingdom of Heaven that was within the Pharisees, was of the
Nature of Hell, or as Hell to Heaven? prove this by Scripture. And where was
that Holy Ghost, that Stephen told the Jews, they did resist, as their Fathers
did? and what was that, that pricked Saul, and made him kick again? But thou
Contradictest thy self here again, to what thou say ( page 38.) That
Christ's Kingdom in the Jews, Pharisees and Disciples was an inward
Soul-Kingdom within them, thou say there R. W.

R. W. thou go on, and make a great Gust (as thou call it) but to no
purpose; and thou say, The thing is so notoriously childish and ridiculous,
that a King should affirm, He was an Actual King in his Enemies Country, where
the Whole was up in Arms against him etc.

Answ. What Childish talk is this? Is not a King a King, though the Country be
up in Arms against him? and is not Christ King, though all do not obey him? and
did not Christ shed his Blood, and dye for all Men, though all Men do not live
to him? And does not the Reign, who says, All Power in Heaven and Earth is
given to him? and the Apostle says, They that Suffer with him, shall Reign
with him, 2 Timothy 2? And do thou not wickedly charge Christ to be Notoriously
Childish and Ridiculous, for saying, The Kingdom of Heaven was within the
Pharisees? (and thou say the same, page 38.) For thou and the Pharisees
being blind, would not receive Christ, the King, to Rule in their Hearts: and
therefore says the Apostle to the Saints, Let Christ Rule in your Hearts by
Faith. -- And then thou tellest a Story of a Lamb and a Wolf, and a Man
pretending to love a Woman in the way of Marriage, and she abhors to hear of
the Motion: This thou may apply at Home. For, God so loved the World, that
he gave his only begotten Son; that whosoever believed in him, should not
perish, but have Everlasting Life.

R. W. And then thou go on, and Contradictest thy self, and say; It Is
true, the Motions of War and Love are made and offered from the King Warring
etc.

Answ. But they rejected these Commands of Christ. And then thou say; But
that this Government and Kingdom should be within them, is nothing but impious,
impudent and childish Prating. But what are thy Words to the purpose here?
Christ does not say, That he Governed in the Pharisees, as he Governed in the
Saints: but it is Wickedness in thee to say, That Christ's Words are Childish
prating, and impious, which said, The Kingdom of Heaven was within the
Pharisees, Luke 17. And this Childish prating is thy own, and Contradictest thy
self, who says, That the Kingdom of Heaven is a Spiritual, inward
Soul-Kingdom, and was in the Pharisees, Jews and Disciples: So, thou have been
Fighting against that, which thou have granted.

R. W. And thou bring Thomas Weld's Saying, [ How clear the Scripture is,
Faith comes by Hearing, and not by Minding the Light within.] And G. F. Answ.
[Doth any Man know Christ but by the Light within? And is not Christ the Word?
and can any see without Christ the Word? Does it not make manifest? nay, does
it not give the Light of the Knowledge of the Glory of God in the Face of
Christ Jesus (2 Cor. 4.) from whence Faith comes? And so, Faith comes by
Minding the Light within, Christ the Author of it; and brings to look at him,
and hear him.] Very good Truth to them that know it. -- R. W. Replyeth and
says; My Eyes have seen a poor distracted aged Woman, walking in State,
boasting of her Majesty, Jewels and Crown, with a Straw in her hand for her
Scepter. And thus this poor and mad Soul walks even like Nebuchadnezar upon his
Babel; All is Christ, and he is Christ, Christ is Faith and all.

Answ. This confused Babel thou may apply to thy own Condition, of the
Distracted Woman, for it is not ours. And let the Reader see, if he has not
abused G. F's. Answer to T. W? Does he say, All is Christ? and, He is Christ?
and, Christ is Faith? for G. F. says, Faith comes from Christ, and the Light
comes from Christ, and Christ is the Author and Finisher of it.

R. W. And thou say; He slights this so known and unquestionable Record,
Faith comes by Hearing etc, and Romans 10. concerning true Salvation, true
Worshipping, Praying, Believing, Preaching, Sending; which Holy Writing Fox
dares not seriously and impartially, and in the Fear of the most-High consider,
as to the various means and ways of God's sending unto Man.

Answ. As for God's sending unto Man, all such we own; for they Preach Christ
the Word. For the Apostle says, The Word is nigh thee, even in thy Mouth, and
in thy Heart; and this is the Word of Faith, which we Preach: and thou
confessest, that the Lord opened Lydia's Heart, and then she received the
Word, Christ, which the Apostle Preached. But what is all this to your
Teachers, that Preach, and never were sent? and as many of you confess, you
never Heard the Voice of God and Christ from Heaven immediately? but thou have
wronged G. F's. Words, and have not set them right down, as they are in the
Book ( Folio). And can any Man believe, preach, pray or worship God, or see
their Salvation without the true Light of Christ Jesus, which comes from him,
the Word?

R. W. And thou say; For all G. F. his Scepter of Straw, his mad Fancy of
Light, that works Faith etc.

Answ. These are thy Railing Language, and abusing of G. F's. Words: for his
Words are not, Works by Faith; but Christ Jesus, who is the Author of Faith,
is the Light of the World. And then R. W. asks, p. 40.
What is Faith etc? It is (I say) the Gift of God; and thou may see, how the
Apostle describes it Heb. 11: and Christ, who dyed for the Sins of the World,
enlightneth every Man, that comes into the World, that they may believe in
him, that dyed for them. And then thou ramblest on, but to no purpose, in Reply
to G. F's. Answer.

R. W. And thou ask, What is Preaching, but a Publishing etc, or declaring,
what the Will or Mind of the King Eternal is, which he has revealed to the
Patriarchs, Moses and the Prophets from the beginning of the World? and what
did Christ Jesus declare to the Apostles, but that which Moses and the Prophets
did say should come to pass etc? and was not this Proclamation of Good News to
be made over all the World, and first at Jerusalem etc?

Answ. Who gain-sayeth this? the Quakers do not. But what is this to G F's
Answer to T. W. or to R. W. and all his Priests in New England? for did ever
they Hear the Eternal King's Voice immediately from Heaven, and Preach this
good News, as the Prophets and Apostles did, freely, as they had received
freely, to give, Act. 26. Luke 24. and as you may see in the Evangelists? But
they have gotten the Form of Godliness, and deny the Power thereof, and
persecute them, that be in the Power of Godliness.

R. W. And thou talkest of Four sorts of Hearers of the Glad News, that
received and believe with a false and overly, loose and Sandy Belief.

Answ. This is thy own Condition R. W. and the Priests in New England. And as
for those, that Receive Christ by believing in the Light, are grafted into him,
and united to God. And as for the Men of Samaria hearing the Woman, who
preached Christ to them, A Man that told her all, that ever she had done; this
may shame thee and the Priests in New England, that did not receive God's Sons
and Daughters, which Preached Christ to them, That told them all, that ever
they had done; and would have turned them and thee to Christ: and instead of
receiving them, you persecute them with Tongues and Hands.

Answ. And thou say; I know, these poor Foxians do hear a kind of a Motion
within them. [Then that is more than the Parrots, which thou speak of page
35: and so in this thou confoundest thy self.] But thou say; It is but as
poor Women, that go with False Conceptions, or with Tympanies of Wind and
Water, or with the Mole, that will resemble the Motion of a True Child: but
after all their Thoughts and Fancies by Day and Night, after all their Seeming
Feelings, Persuasions, Experience and Preparations this False Conception, False
Faith, False Christ, False Light shall vanish in shame and grief, as did Q.
Mary's after the Thanksgivings and Bell-Ringings for her Deliverance.

Answ. This is R. VV's. and the New England Priests and Professors Condition;
he knows it better, than the Quaker's Condition. For do not their Laws and
Persecutions declare it to the World, to be the Birth of the Flesh, that has
so Persecuted, Hanged and Whipped God's People, who are Born of the Spirit? Is
not their Faith proved false, and not that, which Christ is the Author of,
which works by Love? and is not their False Light, or False Christ made
manifest, who destroys Men's Lives about Religion? for the Quakers true
Christ said, he came To save Men's Lives, and bid them, Love Enemies And so R.
VV. and the New England Professors their False Birth of all their Experiences
appears to be but like a Tympany of VVind and Water (as he speaks) that
vanishes away: and all their Preparations with their Elders and Members, and
their persecuting Priests, that helped to beget this Birth, is it not all
passed away into Persecution with Tongue and Hand, and not the true Birth? and
into Grief, and Shame, and Sorrow? and did not the Indians say, That their own
God, they Professed, fought against them? And as for R. VV. bringing Q. Mary,
let them, that are concerned, answer for that: and thou art not to Speak Evil
of the Dead.

R. W. And whereas thou say; ( For my self) I dare these Self-Confident to
particularize any one Scripture, where the Spirit of God directs any poor Soul
to listen or hearken to a Light and Voice within him, affirming, that this is
the Hearing, by which Faith is wrought etc? I ask for some Solid Instances,
where Souls have been truly Converted (the whole Soul unto God) by any such
Notion; p. 41.
and not by some External Means, and out-ward Hearing of this Glad News and
Gospel.

Answ. In this thou have showed thy Ignorance of the Scriptures, and the Holy
Men of God Conditions. For did not the Jews hear the External Means and outward
Hearing of Christ and his Apostles, and yet were not Converted to God? Now, we
Challenge thee, and all the New England Priests, Where ever any one was
Converted to God by an Outward and External Hearing, to answer this by plain
Scripture? And whereas thou have said, Listening to the Light; but our Words are
commonly Take heed to the Light (as the Apostle does) until the Day dawn, and
the Day Star arise in your Hearts: and was not the Light the Means to take heed
unto? And what External Means had Abraham, that saw the Day of Christ and his
Gospel? and what External Means had Moses, when God spoke to him, or Outward
Hearing of Man's Preaching to him? And what External Means had Mary Magdalen
and other Women, when the Lord sent them to Preach the Resurrection? And what
External Means had Daniel, when he Heard the Voice of God? and was not this
Voice of God within? though we deny none, that God and Christ speaks to and
sends. But did not the Word come to Jacob? and was not that the Author of
his Faith? and was not he Converted? and did not all the Holy Men of God speak,
as they were Moved by the Holy Ghost? And does not Christ say, He that has an
Ear, let him hear, what the Spirit says to the Churches? and is that an
Outward Hearing or External? And does not the Apostle say; No Man knows the
things of God but by the Spirit of God, which Reveals them? and does not
Christ thank his Father for Revealing his things to his Disciples, and hid them
from such Wise, as you are? And can any come to Christ, but whom the Father
draws? and is that by an External and Outward Hearing? And does not the Lord
say, He opens the Mouth of Babes etc? And did not the Lord open Lydia's
Heart, to hear Christ, that Paul Preached, who was a Minister of the Spirit?
and did not he and the Apostles Sow to the Spirit? and was that an Outward and
External Means? And does not the Lord say, He will put his Laws in their Minds,
and write them in their Hearts; and he will be their God, and they shall be his
People: and they shall not teach every Man his Neighbor, and every Man his
Brother, saying, Know the Lord; for they shall all know me from the Least to
the Greatest, says the Lord: and is this your External Means (in New England)
and Outward Hearing, who persecute the Children of the New- Covenant, (that are
Taught of God) for not following of you?

R. W. And thou say: I ask, if it be not a Ridiculous Contradiction, to fill
the World with a Sound of their New He- and She- Apostles?

Answ. We say, Nay, who are sent of God, and have heard God and Christ's Voice,
as the Prophets and Apostles did. And you, who are feeding of your External
Means of your Outward Hearing, and hate the Light of Christ, and are Erred from
the Spirit, that gave forth the Scriptures, persecute us, as your Forefathers
did Christ and his Apostles.

R. W. And thou say; I ask, if this Light within (without and opposite to
the Hearing without, which is the Question) be the Means of Faith, how is it
possible, that so many serious, enquiring Men in all Ages should not per^eive a
Breath of this VVind, no, not in their own Bosoms? and that Famous Paul should
be Conscientiously and fully persuaded, that he ought to do many things against
Christ Jesus?

Answ. Have not thou here manifested thy Ignorance again? for the Light of
Christ within is not opposite to the Ministers of the Spirit, and such, as turn
them from Darkness to Light etc. And the Apostles bid the Saints, Look unto
Jesus, the Author and Finisher of their Faith, not unto them: and is not He the
Word, the Apostles Preached, and told them, it was nigh in their Hearts to
hear it and do it? And Moses describes the Righteousness of the Law etc: but
the Apostle says, The Righteousness of Faith, which speaks on this wise
(mark, Speaks) say not in thy Heart, who shall ascend into Heaven? that is,
to bring Christ down from above; or who shall descend into the deep? that is,
to bring Christ from the Grave etc: but what says it? The Word is nigh thee
in thy Heart, and in thy Mouth; and this is the Word of Faith which we Preach.
Now mark, the Apostle Preached the Word of Faith in Peoples Hearts and Mouths;
and was not this Word in Abraham's Mouth? and Jacob's Mouth? and Moses Mouth?
and the Prophet's Mouth? and do thou say, Enquiring Men in all Ages should
not perceive a Breath of this Wind? and because thou and the Priests in
New England do not perceive a Breath of it, therefore thou judge others, like
thy self. And how could all the Prophets see Christ without the Light, which
was Life in the Word, by which all things were made? -- And whereas the Apostle
says, How should they hear without a Preacher, and how should he Preach,
except he be sent; what is this to your Preachers, that never Heard the Voice
of God, and run, when God never sent them? And the Apostle says, But have they
not all heard? (mark) yes verily etc: so, Then (says the Apostle) Faith comes
by Hearing, and Hearing by the Word of God. And Paul, who was fully persuaded,
he ought to do many things against Christ Jesus etc; showing, that he had heard
of Christ with his External Ears and outward Means, and had heard the Prophets,
that spoke of Christ; yet was a Persecutor of Christ in his Members in his
False Conception, like thee, and the Priests in New England. And though Paul
heard Steven's Sermon, yet he was not Converted; but at his Conversion Christ
told him, It was hard to kick against that, which had pricked him: for Christ
knew, what had pricked him, that made him kick again, when he was a Persecutor
of Christ in his Members, like R. W. and the New England Priests and
Professors: and it is the way of the Persecutors about Religion, to kick
against that, which pricketh them.

R. W. And thou say; Therefore it is Grace, that does All; and yet thou
say; This is something, but reaches not home, [but what this something is,
thou have not told the World.] And thou say; If all Men in the world have
this Light, (which is sufficient without Hearing) why should not some
(especially the Wise and Enquirers etc.) perceive it, or something of it? as
Paul did not, until he heard something (and because God had a purpose to make
an Extraordinary Use of him) etc.

Answ. What is this to R. W. and the New England Priests, who are Strangers to
this Work? And Christ, who enlightneth every Man, that comes into the world,
he says; Learn of me etc: and God says; This is my beloved Son, HEAR YE HIM.
Yea, the Saints heard the Apostles, which were Ministers of the Spirit; but was
the Apostle therefore the Author of their Faith, and Finisher? or, were the
Apostles the Word, which they Preached? And as for thy Wise and Enquirers, some
ask and have not, because they ask amiss: but as Christ Enlightneth every Man,
that comes into the sworld; so, if they do not hate the Light, in that Light
they will ^ee more Light, and see Christ, their full Satisfaction. And thou
say, It is Grace, that does All: If so, what do the Scriptures and the
Teachers do then? which are thy only Sword, Weapon, Rule etc; and thy outward
Means, which thou have been busying thy self about? -- But R. W. the Scripture
says, Grace and Truth comes by Jesus Christ, which shed his Blood, and tasted
Death for every Man: and this Grace of God, which brings Salvation, has
appeared to all Men; and God said to Paul, It was Sufficient. So, it is
Sufficient to Teach People, and bring their Salvation, if they do not turn it
into Wantonness, and walk despitefully against the spirit of Grace: and such
are not like (though they do enquire) to perceive, that deny that, which they
should perceive withal.

R. W. And thou bring T. P. saying, [ To say, the Officers of the Church are
Invisible, it is plain of their Father the Devil]. G. F. Answ. to T. P. and
says, [The Holy Ghost made the Officers of the Church Overseers; and that made
the Officers the Overseers to be Invisible. For they saw with an Invisible Eye,
and so, they were in the Spirit, which is Invisible, and not in the Flesh, else
they could not be Overseers in the Church of God: and you are the Visible
Apostatized from them]. -- And R. W. replyeth, and says; This is one of the
most impudent Fooleries, that either Fox or (as the Proverb is) any Dog could
be impudent in.

Answ. Here you may see, how R. W. begins with Railing Language, which he
had better applied to his own Spirit, which comes from it: but he has not
proved out of the Holy Scripture his Lying Proverb.

R. W. And thou say, G. F. acknowledges a public Assembly of Christians, as
well as of other pretending worshippers Turks, Jews etc. and also he
acknowledges the Ministers, p. 42.
Officers and Overseers of their Assemblies.

Answ. Does G. F. here mention the Overseers made by the Holy Ghost of the
Turks and Jews, but them in the Apostles days? why do thou abuse his Words?

R. W. And thou say, G. P's. Reason is notoriously silly and impudent: why?
Because G. F. says, The Church is in God, and the Overseers are made by the
Holy Ghost.

Answ. Does not the Apostle say, The Overseers were made by the Holy Ghost?
and, the Church was in God, as Act. 20, 28, and These. 1? and is this Doctrine
of the Apostles notoriously silly and impudent? why? because you are not in the
same Holy Ghost, and your Church is not in God, as theirs was.

R. W. And thou say; Are the Secrets of God always secret, and never to be
Revealed? the Child in the Womb, the precious Stones etc. when brought forth,
are no more Invisible, than the Sun in the Firmament.

Answ. Were not the Children in the Womb, or precious Stones Invisible, before
they were brought forth in themselves? how proves R. W. and the New England
Priests that to be like unto the things of God? The Secrets of God are Revealed
by his Spirit, which is Invisible: and so, they are Secrets to them still, to
whom they are not Revealed by the same Spirit. And this Spirit, that does
Reveal the things of God, does make them Overseers.

R. W. And thou say; The Christian Profession and Professors, how-ever they
were wrought and prepared, and by diverse Means by God's Spirit; yet etc.

Answ. But what these diverse Means are, R. W. has not told the World. But what
is this in opposition, that the Holy Ghost made not Overseers in the Church in
the Apostles days? it is nothing to that.

R. W. And thou say; Yet the Lord Jesus Christ compares them to the most
Visible, Conspicuous, and Glorious Things and Persons, to the Sun and Moon in
the Heavens, and the Heavens and Stars also; to Mountains and Cities etc. and
to Kings, their Houses and Palaces etc.

R. W. What is all this to oppose the Apostle's Doctrine, and say, The Holy
Ghost did not make them Overseers? which is the Consequence of R. W's.
Jangling. For we do grant, what the Lord Jesus Christ does compare his Holy
People to in Scriptures; but that is not thy State.

R. W. And thou say; Although the Lord Mayor of London, and the several
Officers of the City are not made and ordained in the public Streets; nor
Generals etc. are they not therefore Visible etc.

Answ. What a Story is this! who opposes thee in this? who says, They are not
Visible? But what is this to oppose the Apostle's Doctrine still, who said, The
Holy Ghost ( that is Invisible) made them Overseers? Will R. W. say, It is the
Holy Ghost, that makes all Mayors, and Generals, and Officers, which are
Visible Officers by Visible Commissioners? else what does he bring this
Comparison for? The Work of Christ's Overseers is Spiritual; it is with a
Spiritual Eye and a Spiritual Discerning, and by a Spiritual Power, and to
watch over the Invisible Spirits of People, the Souls of Men and Women.

R. W. It is most true etc. that the Church is in God: [and then thou
Contradictest thy self, and say,] And is it not also true in one Sense
[that, is, thy Sense, not the Apostle's 1 Thessalonians.] We live in God, and move in
God, and have our being in God etc.

Answ. What Roger! one while a Church, and not in God, and yet Live in him, and
move in him, as thou confessest? Thou say, The whole Creation is Gloriously
Visible. Who says to the contrary of that, which is Outward?

R. W. And thou say; The Saints, their Assemblies and Officers are in God
Visible to the world etc. though in an Heavenly Spiritual Sense, transcending
the being of the Creation.

Answ. And yet R. W. brings J. M. to Contradict himself; [in his Append. page
21.] and says; The Wise Heathen- Philosophers had a greater measure of Light
in them ( which is the first Adam) than any I can find now. And R. W. opposes
G. F. for setting up Christ the Second Adam, and his New Covenant, and his New
Creatures above the First Adam and the Heathen-Philosophers; and now [ in his
42 Page] he confesses, This transcends the being of the First Creation: Why
did thou oppose G. F. then ( in thy 21 Page) and there Contradict, what thou
say in page 42? But where does the Scripture say, That the Saints, and their
Assemblies and Officers are in God Visible? for God is a Spirit, and they that
are joined to the Lord, and are in the Lord, it must be by the Spirit: for none
knows his things, but by his Spirit, that is Invisible. And G. F. never
denied, that the Bodies of the Saints and Officers, and Assemblies were Visible
now, and in the Apostles days, and they were and are to be seen with Visible
Eyes; or else how could they have been persecuted in the Apostles days, and in
New England? if you had not seen Quakers there, you could not have Hanged them.
-- And thou say; It is most true and most sweet; that the Church is in God:
yet again, G. F's. Reason is notoriously Silly and Impudent, [because he says
to the Priest, R. W. defends, that the Church is in God:] So Roger, put thy
Words together and see, what Sense thou can make of them?

R. W. Thou say; Yea, G. F. and his etc. for all their being in God, and
some of their proud and silly Answerings in Courts, that they Live in God, and
Dwell in God etc.

Answ. See R. W's. Contradiction before in the same page, where he says; We
live in God, and move in God, and have our Being in God etc: we must not now
confess this (that he just now owned) without being called Proud and Silly. But
why! must not we tell, where our Living and Being is, before your Courts? and
are not they Silly and Proud (as thou speak) and live not in God, that
cannot endure to hear People tell you, where their Living and Being is? And yet
thou say; They disown not their own Visible Congregations etc. Why should
they disown their Visible Assemblies, or Teachers, or Overseers? which are
gathered together in the Name of Jesus, and are Ministers of the Spirit; and
are made Overseers by the Holy Ghost, that is Invisible: and their Singing and
Praying in the Spirit they own. As for those Audible Performances thou speak
of, the Saints perform their Worship, Praying, Preaching etc. by the Spirit: is
the Spirit and Truth Visible, in which God is worshipped? let R. W. and all the
Priests prove that by Scripture, if they can.

R. W. And thou say; Why does this poor notoriously Visible Cheater thus
prate of Invisibilities, especially in times of Peace and not in Elias his
Case? p. 43.


Answ. What! must they not talk of Faith, by which the Invisible God is seen?
nor the Word of God, which was made Flesh, by which all things were made? nor
talk of the Holy Ghost, which made Overseers? And did not the Apostle say, Ye
are not in the Flesh, but in the Spirit, (Romans 8, 9.) and yet all these were
upon the Earth? but thou art dark, not knowing the things of God. But you
Professors, that prate so much of Visibility, are Invisible enough at Times,
running away and flying your Testimony: but the things that are seen, that are
Temporal, your striving is in: and so thou pleadst for Visibility. And though
we are for God's Invisible things, against your Carnal envious Minds; yet, have
we not been visible in Trials and Persecutions? did we hide from you?

R. W. And thou bringst M. Bine, which says [ The Scriptures may be understood
by the Help of Tongues.] And G. F. Answ. [All Scriptures were given forth by
Inspiration: and so without the same Inspiration it is not understood. Again,
Pilate had the Scriptures and Tongues, and yet did not understand the
Scriptures nor Christ the Substance of them: and this you have set up since the
Apostasy, your Tongues, you Raveners from the Spirit.] -- R. W. replyeth and
says, That G. F. confesses, that every Syllable or Title in the Scripture is
the Word, or immediately revealed Will of God, against his and the Quakers
common Song, has God any more Words than one?

Answ. Does G. F. speak these Words in his Answer? did ever G. F. or any called
Quakers deny, but the Scripture was given forth by Inspiration, and was
Revealed from God and Christ to his Prophets and Apostles, which were the
Words of God and Christ, and he the Word? And, Thou shall not kill, and steal
etc. was not that Revealed to Moses, and the Words of God? for Christ says; I
am the Door, and, I am the Bread of Life; he does not say, That he is an
outward Door, or outward Bread, that is made of Corn. And was not the Promise
of God Revealed, and his Commands? and must they not be known by the same
Spirit, to answer them in Man etc?

R. W. And thou say; I observe, the end of G. F. ( and especially of the old
Fox and Serpent that acts him) is, to destroy the coming of God's Holy Records
and Writings to poor lost Men to their Salvation.

Answ. Are the VVritings to Salvation to lost Men? is not Christ their
Salvation? May not the Devil and the Pharisees have the VVritings, and yet be
Enemies to Christ the Salvation? did not the Jews think to have Life in the
Scriptures, which testified of Christ, and would not come to him, that they
might have Life and Salvation? And do not thou say (in the same Page) That G.
F. confesses, how all Scripture was given forth etc; and now, do thou
Contradict thy self, and say; His end is, to destroy the Scriptures? No, no;
We love the Scriptures: and thou might have kept all thy bad Words at Home.
-- And thou say; He may foist and whisp in, what his Hellish Malice pleases
to their Damnation. -- Roger, this is thy own Condition, and not the Quakers,
as thy Lies have manifested.

R. W. And whereas thou say; If no Knowledge of the Tongues, in which the
Most-wise, Holy Lord penned his Letters or Writings to us, then no Preaching of
the Doctrine in them to the world without some New miraculous way, then no
Translating and Reading of them, which is, that the Devil in all Ages and at
this day aims at with all his might.

Answ. Does G. F. deny Tongues in themselves here, which are natural things?
and what must be inferred from thy Words, but that Men may understand the
Scriptures with Natural Tongues? then I query; How was it, that the Pharisees,
and the Grecians, and all other Languages did not understand them? and how is
it, that Christ says, He thanketh the Father, that he has revealed these
things unto Babes? And the Apostle says, No Man knows the things of God, but
by the Spirit: and G. F's Answer is, That all Scripture was given forth by
Inspiration; so without the same Inspiration it is not known: and if this be to
deny the Scripture, let the Righteous judge. And as for all thy bad Words here
against us, thou might have kept them at home.

R. W. And whereas thou say; I charge upon this proud Ignoramus, and all his
blind Disciples etc. the horrible Crime of Unthankfulness and Ingratitude; for
were it not for Tindal burnt to Ashes, and other Heavenly Spirits set on work
from Heaven to dig out the Knowledge of Hebrew and Greek, and turn it into
French, p. 44.
Dutch and English etc, how should these Seraphical Doctors know, whether there
were such a Creation of Heaven and Earth, and a Man and his Wife, which we
talk of.

Answ. Do thou not Contradict thy self (in thy 22 Page), when Plato grants
a Creation, and a kind of Father and Son, where thou set up the
Heathen-Philosophers? and do thou not say, what Aristotle confesses of the
Godhead? and what Scripture had they? and do thou not say, Thou find in
all Mankind a Conviction of the Eternal Power and Godhead? And does not the
Apostle say, He understood by Faith, the World was made or framed by the Word
of God, Heb. 11? and does not John say the same Joh. 1? And is not God the same
now to his People in Christ, as he was to Moses? and does he teach his People
in the New Covenant short of Moses? And as for thy Charge of Unthankfulness
etc. keep it to thy self: for we can praise the Lord for the Scriptures, and
such as honest Tindal, that did translate them; who was burnt and persecuted by
the same Bloody Murdering Spirit of New England, that killed our Friends. But
what have thou to do with W. Tindal? hear him in our Defense against thee and
thy Brethren, saying: It is impossible to understand in the Scriptures more
than a Turk, for who-so-ever has not the Law of God writ in his Heart to
fulfill it. Again: Without the Spirit it is Impossible to understand them ( W.
Tindal's Works p. 319, p. 80). What is this, if People have the Scriptures in
all the Languages, and yet oppose that, which must lead them into the Truth of
them, or inspire them to know them? and though they have the Scriptures in all
Languages, can any know Adam and Eve's State in Paradise, except they be
brought thither by Christ? And it is true, they may have an outward Knowledge by
reading of Adam and Eve etc; but in this thou confoundest thy self, and say,
A Parrot may talk of Heaven and Hell, and the Grace, and so, may not a Parrot
be taught to talk of Adam and Eve? (read thy 33 Page). And then R. W. tells
of a Question put to a Soul, and the dreadful end of that Party; but he has
particularized no body: so, it is like the rest of his Stories.

R. W. And then thou chargest the Quakers with Laziness, because they do not
study the Original Language themselves, saying; It is a shameful Trade, and
deceitful, when Persons have money in their hands, to take up all on Trust. And
further thou say, I never knew any of these Foxians so inclined; but
according to the Lazy Fool under the Fig Tree etc.

Answ. R. W. Contradicts himself: he says, ( page 43.) John Stubs vapour'd
and said; He understood as many Languages as I: [and in another place] That he
understood the Greek, Hebrew, and Latin. And the Quakers have their Schools,
that teach all these Naturals: but what is all this to know Christ and the
things of God, which are Revealed by his Spirit? And Christ says, Flesh and
Blood had not revealed him to Peter, but his Father: and was not Peter's and
the Jews Language Hebrew, that opposed Christ? And as for all thy foul Words,
thou might have kept them at Home* for they are not worth Answering. But we
challenge R. W. and all the New England Priests to prove by Scripture,
wherever Christ or his Apostles charged one of their Believers with the
Horrible Crime of Laziness, for not studying the Original Languages, as the
means, by which they might know the Scriptures and Christ, without the
Revelation of Christ and his Spirit?

R. W. And thou say; I judge, that G. F. with his Wild Spirit cannot prove,
that Pilate had the Hebrew, Greek and Latin.

Answ. That is not the Matter in hand: for G. F. his proof was, That the
Scriptures are known again by the same Inspiration: and that is thy part and
the New England Priests, to disprove, that Pilate had not the Hebrew, Greek and
Latin, which he caused to be set up upon Christ, when he Crucified him.

R. W. And thou say; Thou knows, that the Devil abounds in Tongues, and can
speak all Languages; and I know and have seen his Inspirations, Three thousand
Verses, in a show very Heavenly inspired by him, by an English Woman of this
Country.

Answ. But what this English Woman is, thou have not named in thy long Story of
her. And it is like, thou art more acquainted with the Devil and his Works, than
with Divine Inspiration: and if he knows all Languages, what is this in
opposition to G. F, that says, The Scripture is known by the same Inspiration,
that gave them forth? But I believe, the Devil and thee art little acquainted
with this Inspiration; if thou werest, thou would not give G. F. so much foul
Language, that holds it forth. And it is like, this Woman thou speak of,
is one of your own People; for if she had been a Quaker, we should have had her
Name in Print before now. And the Apostles were Inspired by the Holy Ghost with
Tongues: and if the Lord should Inspire any now, I question not, but you would
say, It was of the Devil. But we charge thee and the New England Priests, to
show us by Scripture, where Christ or his Apostles commanded to set up Schools,
and to Study Tongues and Languages, and then go to Preach? for the Scripture
says, That they had sometimes Interpreters (as 1 Cor. 14): and if they had
not, they were to be silent.

R. W. And whereas thou say; Thou art sure, that we talk (like little
Children) without the least Knowledge at all (generally) of any thing but the^r
Mother English; p. 45.
and yet so proudly and imperiously vapouring and triumphing etc: and yet thou
say; I perceive, that John Stubs was a Scholar; and had Hebrew, Greek, and
Latin; [He was a Quaker, that disputed with thee.]

Answ. And what Contradictions are these R. W! And what can thou tell, what
they do in their grave Consultations? what does Roger make himself here? But
what is all this as knowing the Scriptures again by Inspiration? and the
Quakers can praise God, for what they are through his Grace. -- And then thou
tellest a Story of Theora John, and say; The Quaker's Inspirations are like
unto his: Nay, this thou might have kept at home; for we own no Inspiration,
but by the sam Holy Ghost that gave forth Scriptures.

R. W. And thou say; G. F. is no wiser in affirming, that the Tongues came
in place ^f the Spirit since the Apostasy: for before the Apostasy the Lord
furnished his Servants with the Understanding of several Languages
miraculously; and with the Apostasy those Heavenly miraculous Gifts ceased.

Answ. And therefore you have studied the Tongues in the Apostasy, and set them
up in place of the Spirit: but are not the Gifts of the Spirit known again out
of the Apostasy? And is Inspiration known by studying Natural Languages? and
what is this to the purpose of the Apostles knowing Tongues by Inspiration? G.
F. opposes not that; by which Inspiration they gave forth Scriptures: which
Inspiration makes wise. And thou confessest, The Devil can speak all
Languages: so if you study to know all Languages, they are but Natural things,
and are you any thing wiser with your Natural Languages than he? for can any
know the Prophet's, and Christ's and the Apostle's Words, and Christ, but by
Revelation of the Holy Spirit and Inspiration -- the things of God?

R. W. And thou say; In the Apostasy the Father of Spirits gave to his Two
Witnesses Power, and Authority, and Ability etc.

Answ. But prove this out of the Revelations, that the Lord Commanded them to
set up Schools and Colleges to learn Languages to set up Ministers: for the
Papists (that thou speak of) had Schools and Colleges to make Ministers,
before Calvin and Luther rose; and so have you. And as for the true Protestants
and Martyrs, that suffered Persecution (as we have done by the same Spirit of
New England) we own all those true Protestants* and how the Lord upheld them in
their Testimony: and this is nothing to you Pro^essors of New England, who are
found like these Foxes and Popish Spirits, worrying the Lambs, and speaking
evi^ of things you know not.

R. W. And thou say; Thou will not discourage the weak^st English Man or
Woman (in Christian Humility) to sound forth the Praise of God in Writing,
Speaking and Printing in English, what they have Experimented of the Son of God
etc: And then thou Contradictest thy self, and have been speaking against
He-Apostles and She-Apostles of the Quakers, speaking by the same Spirit: and
thou say; But when they lift up their Horns on high ( or their Brutish
Ears, as Foxes do, instead of Horns) then I must tell G. F, that although he
prattles amongst the English, and they be cheated with his dying Spirit etc.

Answ. As for Cheating and dying Spirit, R. W. may keep at home, with the
Brutish Ears thou speak of, and his and the New England Men's Horns. For it
is with the Holy Spirit of God, that we do exalt the Horn of our Salvation;
through which Spirit we have had Experience of his Son, and of his Light,
Faith, and Mercy and Grace manifested to us: and this we have been moved of the
Lord to Speak, Write and Print; which has made the dark Spirit in thee and
the New England Priests to rage and persecute. And it was not a Simple
Pretending (as thou scoffingly say) of some of our going to the Turk and
Pope; but a Motion of God, whether they will hear or forbear. But R. W. may
Rail against them behind their Backs in his Tongues and Languages, but before
their Faces he dare not show his Face: and therefore the Laz^ Spirit he had
better applied at Home.

R. W. And then thou say; They must either be furnished with the Gifts of
Tongues Miraculously etc; or else they must fling off their Lazy Devil, and
Study the Tongues of other Nations, to whom they carry their (pretended) Glad
News.

Answ. Is the Devil Lazy, and can speak all Languages, as R. W. says? Must the
Quakers study the Tongues to Preach the Glad News? and what, if they have them
already? Did none speak by Interpreters? read 1 Cor. 14. And what, if they can
speak all these Tongues, and be out of the Spirit of Inspiration, that gave
forth Scriptures, and Reveals the Son, it would but bring People into a Form,
like the New England Professors and others, and to speak of Heaven, and Hell,
and Grace (as thou say) like the Parrot (in thy 35 Page). So, compare this
with thy 45 Page and see, what a great rambling thou have made against G. F.'s.
Words to no purpose, who says, [The Scripture must be known by the same
Inspiration, that gave them forth]; and for all thou have said, thou have not
