disproved it. And the Glad News of Christ and his Gospel was and is Preached by
his Spirit: for the false Christ's and Wolves may get the Sheeps-cloathing, as
you Priests have done, and have worryed the Lambs in New England.

R. W. Brings M. Bines ( fol. 86.) saying [ Notwithstanding thy passing
through the First and Second Resurrection (as he says) there remains a Torment
for thee at the last Day, p. 46.
and Woe. And G. F. Answ. [They are blessed, that have Part in the First
Resurrection, the Second Death has no Power over them; but are made free from
Wrath that is to come, and are passed from Death to Life: and are translated
into the Kingdom of the Son of God; and are in Union with the Son of God and
the Father both]. R. W. replyeth and says; G. F. arrogates to himself and his
Foxians, a passing through the First and Second Resurrection; he triumphs in
their Blessedness pronounced to their First Resurrection, viz. of Communion
with God, and Freedom from Wrath to come.

Answ. The Reader may see, how R. W. falsely applies the Priest's Words to G.
F, which speaks of the First and Second Resurrection: but does G. F. mention
the Word of passing through the Second Resurrection? For does not John say in
the Revelations (and is it Arrogance in him?) Blessed and Holy is he that has
part in the First Resurrection, on such the Second Death has no Power; for
they are Priests of God etc, ( Revel. 20)? And does not the Apostle say ( Romans
5, 9,) We shall be saved from Wrath through him (to wit, Christ etc)? and,
Thanks be to Jesus, which has delivered us from Wrath to come (1 Thessalonians. 1,
10)? and ( Chap. 5, 9) God has not appointed us to Wrath? And the Saints had
Fellowship with the Father and the Son (1 John 1)?

And R. W. says; That G. F. is in his Borough of Words of diverse
Significations etc. Nay Roger, G. F's. Words are plain; and thou art in thy
Borough, that see them not. And then thou say; G. F. wrests and winds,
what is for his wicked Ends. This is false, and thy own Condition; and wherein
does he wrest, when he speaks plain Scripture?

R. W. And thou say; You shall never take him in distinguishing and
defining, what is the First and Second Death, and what is the First and Second
Resurrection.

Answ. What need he, when John has plainly de^ined and distinguished it in his
Revelations?

R. W. And thou say; The Truth is, as soon as they hearken to this Familiar
Spirit, they are so elevated, that they be in Heavenly Glory: the Resurrection
is past, and ( with K. Agag's Dream) the Bitterness of Death and Wrath is past
for ever with them.

Answ. This thou might have applied at home, with thy Familiar Spirit, thou
speak of. And do thou not here again abuse G. F's. Words? does he say
here, That the Resurrection is past? and are they not the Priest's M. B's.
Words of Passing through the First and Second Resurrection? But where does the
Scripture say, They that have part in the First Resurrection, there remains a
Torment for such at the last day and VVo, as the Priest says? thou should
have made this good by Scripture. And as for the Thorns and Thistles, thou
may keep them at home, which grow in thy own Nature.

R. W. And thou say; If we talk of Escaping Wrath to come, and of Enjoying
Blessedness, we must prove it to others, as well as to our selves.

Answ. Roger, thou and the New England Professors have no more Ears to hear it,
than the Jews had to hear Christ and his Apostles, who said, Chirst had a
Devil: and Paul was a Babbler, and a Pestilent Fellow.

R. W. And thou tellest us; That the Expectation of the Jews and the Mahometans
expecting a Catnal Blessedness to come, is false: and We must prove, Papists
and Common Protestants ( for all their Prayers and Alms etc.) are under that
Sentence, Depart from me, ye Workers of Iniquity.

Answ. Thou did very well Roger, to confess thy self ( at last) to be One of
them; and we do believe, thou have spoken forth thy own Sentence. But do thou
believe, that none of the Papists and Common Protestants will repent? and Jews
and Mahometans? Cold Charity, Roger!

R. W. And thou say; The Lord Jesus being asked about the great Point of
Salvation, he seems to answer two things, 1. That the Most will hang their
Souls upon the Hedge, and venture like the Highways and Hedges etc.

Answ. We do charge R. W. and the rest of the Priests in New England to make
this good by Scripture, where ever Christ said, They hanged their Souls upon
Hedges, and ventured like the Highways ways and Hedges? or else acknowledge,
thou have abused Christ's words, as well as G. F's.

R. W. And thou say; Some will endeavor to seek to enter (I judge) both
^ews, Mahometans, Pagans, Papists and Protestants, and shall not be able.

Answ. And why did thou not put in thy self and the persecuting Professors
in New England? And why shall they not enter? is it not, because they do not
believe in the Light, as Christ commands? therefore they do not Enter into
the Rest because of Unbelief (as in Hebrews)?

R. W. And thou say Of such, as are sensible of the Narrowness of the Way,
and Streightness of the Door, and the Infinite Necessity incumbing, p. 47.
and the Infinite Excellency inviting, that fling away Preferments, Profits and
Pleasures, and choose to enjoy the Mediator, as lost and damned in our selves,
and follow him from his Cradle and Manger to his Cross and Gallowses, and
laboring to draw other poor drowning Souls out of the Pit of Eternal
Rottenness and Howling with us.

Answ. If R. W. and the New England Professors were in this, as he says, he
and and they would never have been so Envious (as they have been) against the
People called Quakers; for R. W's. Words, and the New England Priests and
Professors Actions give them the Lie. For he is persecuting God's People with
his Tongue, and desires, they may be punished: and the others have Hanged them
upon their Gallowses, and Banished and Whipped, and Spoiled Goods. And if this be
a Spirit, that follows Christ in his Cross, in his Straight way from his
Manger, and Cradle and Cross to the Gallowses, who rebuked them, that would
have had Men's Lives destroyed; and told them, They knew not, what Spirit they
were of, and said, He comes not to destroy Men's Lives, but to save them; let
all the Sober Christians judge.

R. W. And thou say; The Spirit of God tells us of three sorts of perished
Souls, 1. Those without the Law, of which are Millions of Millions innumerable.
And yet thou say ( Append. p. 28.) There is generally in all Mankind in the
world a Conviction of an Invisible, and Omnipotent and Eternal Power and
Godhead; and thou find, all Men will confess, that the Mind of God is pure
etc. that it was ever and is wickedness, to sin against it. All Mankind having
the Law etc.

Answ. How stand these together Roger, and with Rom 1, and 2, which thou
say, The Spirit of God tells thee, that those without the Law are Millions
of Millions innumerable? For if thou meanest the Outward written Law, whether
that of God in the Gentiles was not one with it, which did the things contained
in the Law?

R. W. And then thou say; 2. Such as had the Law and Will of God revealed
to them in the Covenant of Work etc. 3. Of such, to whom Infinite Pity has
vouchsafed the Joyful Tidings of the Son of God his Mediation and Intercession
etc.

Answ. Art not thou and the New England Professors like unto the Jews, that had
the Law of God, and did it not? that have the Joyful Tidings of the Son of God,
his Mediation and Intercession etc. who dyed for Enemies, and ye persecute his
Friends, like the Jews, that persecuted the Prophets, that had the Law? But
what is all this to G. F's Words, [Blessed are they, that have part in the
First Resurrection]? thou have gone beside the Matter, which thou took in hand
to reply to; for thou find fault with G. F. for not defining and
distinguishing, what the First and Second Death is; and yet thou have not done
it thy self.

R. W. And thou tellest us of a Story of the Papists, and Protestants against
the Papists etc.

Answ. This thou might very well applied to thy self and the Professors in
New England, that are crying against the Bloody Papists, and ye have been as
Bloody in this Age, as they.

R. W. And thou say; These Quakers pretend the Highest, but no otherwise,
then Thou O Capernaum, which art exalted etc. And thou say; Tire and Sidon,
Sodom and Gomorrah, and the poor Jews and Mahometans, yea the Papists and
Common Protestants shall have an easier Cup to drink, than these (thou here and
often elsewhere call Foxians) that are so high, pure and lofty, yet abound
with Luciferian Filthiness.

Answ. R. W, as thou Judge, thou will be Judged; thou would have it so: but
none of these things thou have proved, but misapplyed Christ's Words; which is
to thy self. And as for Capernaum, Tire, Sidon and Sodom etc. it may be well
said to thee and the New England Professors, who would neither hear Christ nor
his Servants, but slew them. And as for our Cup, trouble not thy self with it,
who know the Cup of Christ's Suffering, and the Cup of Salvation; who learn of
Christ to be Meek and Low, and to deal truly with Hypocrites. And as for
Luciferian Filthiness, thou might have kept that at home. And Christ does
teach and exhort, and makes his People Clean by his Blood; and they can praise
God for it, though thou scoffest at God's Work and them: and we know, that
Christ has taught thee none of this foul Language.

R. W. And thou bringst M. Bines (Fol. G. F. p. 89.) saying [The Saints are
neither in the Fullness of the Godhead, nor in part; away with this Blasphemy,
that says, this is]. G. F. Answ. The Work of the Ministry was, To bring People
to the Knowledge of the Son of God, to a perfect Man; to the Unity of the
Faith, to the Measure and Stature of the Fullness of Christ; and Christ would
dwell in the Saints, and God would dwell in them. And thou say, They have no
part of the Fullness of the Godhead; but John says, Of his Fullness we all have
received, in whom dwells the Godhead bodily. And ye be all in the Blasphemy,
that be out of this part of his Fulness]. R. W. replyeth to G. F. and says; It
was an Horrible Crime, which the Jews, though maliciously and falsely objected
against the Lord Jesus, that he being a Man makes himself God.

Answ. Who denies this, but the Jews did so? and what is this to the purpose?
but was Christ ever the worse for their Blasphemy? or his Servants the worse
for thy Railing against them, and for New England Professor's persecuting of
them?

R. W. And whereas thou say; What shall we say to these Brutish,
Blasphemous vile Worms of the Earth, Yesterday creeping out of their Holes,
Slaves, Hell Hounds (as we all by Nature are) so horribly to set their Faces
(as David speaks) against the Heavens, p. 48.
vapouring themselves to be in the Godhead, and that also Bodily: so that what
was applicable to the Body of the Son of God, is proper and applicable unto
them etc.

Answ. Let the Reader read G. F's. Answer and see, if there be any Color for
him to forge these Words, That which was applicable to the Son of God, we
should take to our selves? Or, is there any thing, that G. F. says, The Saints
are in the Fullness of the Godhead? but as the Apostle said, What was the Work
of their Ministry, which was for the perfecting of the Saints etc. and the
Edifying of the Body of Christ, till we all come in the Unity of the Faith, and
the Knowledge of the Son of God, and unto a Perfect Man, and unto the Measure
of the Stature and Fullness of Christ. And John says (1 John 16.) Of his
Fullness have we received Grace for Grace. And the Apostle speaking of Christ
says; He has put all things under his Feet, who gave him to be Head over all
things to the Church, which is his Body, the Fullness of him, that fills all
in all: And the Apostle says; To know the Love of Christ, which passes
Knowledge, that ye might be filled with all the Fullness of God ( Ephesians. 1, 23;
and 3, 19) And the Apostle says; In him (to wit, Christ) dwells all the
Fullness of the Godhead bodily; and ye are complete in him, which is the Head
etc. ( Coloss. 2, 9): was the Apostle a Blasphemer, and a Hell-hound etc. that
spoke these Words? and does not the Apostle say, That God will dwell in his
Saints? read Coloss. both the 1. and 2. Epist. And as for Setting Face against
Heaven, with all thy bad Words and Languages thou might have kept at Home.

R. W. And thou say; See the horrible Egyptian Darkness, the Lord has
justly poured upon these feigned Goshenites, they exclaim against us for using
the word God-man, and ask us, where we find such a Phrase in Scripture? [and
why should you not prove by the Scripture, what you do say?] And thou say;
They rest not in the Title Immanuel, God with us; nor the Fullness of the
Godhead bodily in Christ [that is Scripture-Language]. And R. W. says; But
Sacrilegious Robbers (in effect) Arrogate to themselves to be God-men and
God-women, the Godhead dwelling in them Bodily.

Answ. We do charge R. W. or any of the New England Professors, to show out of
our writings, and name the Persons, that ever spoke any such Language; but as
the Scripture says* Christ dwells in his Saints, and they shall sup with him;
and they are the Temples of God. And this the Scripture declares, which we are
Witnesses of, praised be the Lord for ever.

R. W. And thou say; Whereas G. F. here says, The Work of the Ministry was,
to bring the Saints to a Perfect Man; he grossly abuses that Heavenly Ephesians. 4,
which concerns the Fullness and Perfection of all the Elect of God etc.

Answ. Then were not the Ephesians concerned? And does G. F. mention the
Ephesians only in his Answer? are not his Words general? so the Gross Abuse is
thy own, and not G. F.'s.

R. W. And thou say; Applying it to every particular deluded Convert of
theirs, as being as much Holy, as much God as Christ Jesus etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see G. F's Answer, if R. W. has not grossly Abused his
Words here again? for there are no such Words in his Answer of the Saints being
as much God, as Christ. But does not the Apostle say, That we may present every
Man Perfect in Christ Jesus, Col. 1. 28.? And He spoke Wisdom among them that
were Perfect, 1 Cor. 2, 6? And Col. 4, 12, That ye may stand Perfect and
complete in all the Will of God. And does not God and Christ exhort to Holiness
and Perfection? and Without Holiness none shall see the Lord. And Christ says;
Be ye Perfect, as your Heavenly Father is Perfect, (Matthew. 5) and must they not
be perfect in their Love and Measure of the Spirit of God, which they have from
him the Fountain, who are Sealed by his Holy Spirit of Promise, Ephesians. 1, 13:
and 1 These. 4, 8? And does not Peter say, Ye are a Royal Priesthood, and Holy
Nation, (1 Pet. 2, 9)? and does not the Apostle Paul call the Saints Holy
Brethren (1 Thessalonians. 5, 26, 27)? And their hands were to be Holy, that they
lifted up to God (1 Timothy 2). And (2 Timothy 1) the Lord called them with a Holy
Calling: and (1 Pet. 1) Be ye Holy in all manner of Conversations; Be ye Holy,
for I am Holy, says the Lord. So, is not the Vessel to be Holy, and Potle,
that holds the Heavenly Treasure of his Spirit, which they have from the Holy
God, the Fountain? But to say, The Saints are as much God, as Christ,, I ask
thee, how the little Vessels or Potles can contain him, who fills Heaven and
Earth? But what is thy end in all this? that thou would not have God and
Christ dwell in his Saints by his Spirit, and by his Faith.

R. W. Thou say; I may use the Exprobrations of Moses against Korah, Dothan
and Abiram; Is it not enough for you, but ye will seek the Priesthood also?

Answ. This thou might well have applied to thy self, and the Priests of
New England, and not to the Quakers: for it is through the Grace and Mercy of
God, that we are, what we are.

R. W. And thou say; Is it not enough, that the Most-High Potter has made
us Men and Women, and not Serpents and Toads, and not Pagans, Turks, Jews,
Papists, but English Protestants.

Answ. Are not the New England Priests and thou in the same Nature and Spirit
(that the Turks, Pagans, Jews and Papists) that persecute with Tongue and
Hands, yea to DEATH, as witness the New England Laws? and did not Christ call
the persecuting Jews Serpents, and of their Father the Devil, that did not do
the Works of Abraham? and what may be said to you, that do not do the Works of
true Christians?

R. W. And further thou say; We must also be Infinites, Eternals,
Omniscients etc.

Answ. If thou chargest this upon the Quakers, we say, they are Words of thy
own forging; and do challenge thee to make it good out of the Quakers Writings,
or name the Persons that said so: which we know thou can not.

R. W. And further thou say; Will not the infinite Favor of Leave, to drink
of some Heavenly Drops of the Infinite and Inconc^ivable Ocean of his Goodness.
satisfy and content us; but we will be Gods with the Devil, and our first
Parents, we will be the Inconceivable Ocean it self.

Answ. I never did hear such Lies before come out of a Man's Mouth, that any of
the People of God used any such terms, as, They were the Inconceivable Ocean it
self, and that they would be Gods. They might say, they were God's People, and
he would dwell in them; and, Christ was in them, and all their Springs were in
him: and this is according to Scripture. But let the Reader see, if there be
any such Occasion in G. F's. Answer for him to use this forging Language. And
if thou werest one of those proud Rebels (thou speak of) that was fetched
from the Gallows by the Smile of a Prince, thou would never have used these
Expressions against us. But thou say; They must be the Prince and King
himself: Thou have not proved this; though we must tell thee, Christ makes his
Redeemed Saints both Kings and Priests, to Reign over the Devil, and offer up
Spiritual Sacrifice to God, ( Revel. 1).

R. W. And thou say; The Pagans of the World, as they are wild to all
Civility, so to all Divinity, and Heavenly matters. And then thou tellest a
great Story, p. 49.
what they Worship, Lions, Dragons etc. And such as cried out of Paul and said,
he was a God etc. And thou say; They apprehend a Doity, (it is like thou
meanest a Deity, if thou had Printed it right) etc.

Answ. And what is all this to the purpose, to prove, that the Saints did not
receive of Christ's Fullness, and grow up to a perfect Man? For may be some of
us have read the Story of these things, as well as thou: but thou should have
brought Paul's Answer to those.

R. W. And thou say; It pleased the Most-High etc. often to meet with
Pharaohs, Absoloms, Nebuchadnezars, Hamans, Herod's of this World, with Nations,
Cities, Armies for their Pride, as he did with Sodom with remarkable Strokes of
Judgment etc.

Answ. Let thee and New England take heed of this, who boast your selves
against God's People, Sons and Servants; take heed, that God's Remarkable
Stroke do not come upon you: for be sure it will, if you do not find a day of
Repentance.

R. W. And thou say; Paul in danger to be pufft up in Voices and Questions
out of the Whirlwind etc.

Answ. But it were well, if R. W. saw himself, then he would not be against the
Quakers, who say, God's Grace is sufficient both to teach and bring Salvation.

R. W. And thou say; Till we more and more come to see, how Perfect we are
in Dirt and Stink, and Filth and Death and Hell, Crawling like Monsters of
Pride and Self-conceitedness upon this Earth etc.

Answ. It seems, you do not see your Stink to the full yet, of Filth, Death
and Hell, and your Crawling, monstrous Pride of Self-conceitedness: and how
should you without the Light of Christ, which gives the Knowledge of Christ,
and his Blood, that cleanses from Sin, and makes their Garments white.

R. W. And thou bring'st M. B. (Fol. 90.) saying, [ There is a kind of
Infiniteness in the Soul, which cannot be Infinite in it self]. And G. F.
Answers and asks the Question [Is not the Soul without beginning, coming
from God, returns to God again, who has it in his hand? which Hand goes
against him that does Evil; which throws down that which warreth against it.
And Christ the Power of God, is not he the Bishop of the Soul, which brings
it up unto God, which came out from him? and has this a Beginning or Ending?
Is not this Infinite in it self more then all the World?] R. W. replyeth, but
he does not answer G. F's. Questions, that he asks; but falls a railing,
and says, That the Soul or Spirit of Man should be boundless or without
limits, without Beginning or Ending, and cries, A blasphemous Monster,
begotten of Hellish Pride the Father, and Hellish Ignorance the Mother: And
thus Roger falls a Railing instead of Answering. And then thou say; For
Infinity and Infiniteness in that Sense can be no other, but the Infinite and
Eternal Power and Godhead, transcending the Capacity of Men or Angels to
receive it, or conceive the Nature of it.

Answ. Did not the Apostles receive Christ by his Spirit, in whom the Eternal
Power and Godhead dwelt? how did they preach Christ then both in his Flesh and
Divinity? But what is this to G. F's. Question? he does not say, That the Soul
is God or Christ, and his Eternal Godhead; but he asks the Question, Whether
the Soul did not come out from God, that is, from his Breath, who breathed into
Man the Breath of Life, and he became a Living Soul? and whether or no the
Souls of the Righteous do not return to Christ and God?

R. W. And thou say; It is true in a Secondary way (a Posteriori) as they
say, the Spirit of Angels and Men are as Lamps, lighted up by the most-High and
Infinite Majesty never to go out or be extinguished in Joy or Sorrow etc.

Answ. And do not thou call the Spirits of Men the Soul? now if the Lighted
Spirits of Men etc. by the most-High and Infinite are never to go out, as thou
confessest, that the Spirits of Men etc. are Lighted, and never go out; are
they not Infinite then in a Secondary way?

R. W. This Notion dazles the most sober and steady Eye and Brain etc. [If G.
F's. Question dazzle the Eye and Brain, it is like it does thine.] And then thou
tellest a Story of Emperors, and the Sun and Moon, and Days and Nights etc.
And thou say; All have their Hitherto and No further, p. 50.
by the Infinite Eternal Arm [The Quakers do not deny that]. And thou say;
Of all the Opinions of the Soul's Being and Rise, this of Infinity, making it
God himself etc. and this is to destroy Souls, and the Infinite God himself.

Answ. How can G. F's Question destroy Souls or destroy God? for can he be
destroyed? no; he is a DESTROYER of the Destroyer: for G. F. in his Question
does not say, the Soul is God. Mag. Bine affirms, that there is a kind of
Infiniteness in the Soul; but what kind of Infiniteness it is, R. W. has not
explained: whether it be Infinite in it self, or Finite. And Job. 22, 5, Is not
thy Wickedness great, and thy Iniquities Infinite? R. W. will not say, that
this Infinite Wickedness was God, because he uses the Word Infinite. And
Habbakuk says; Ethiopia and Egypt were her Strength, and it was Infinite (
Nahum 3): now thou can not say, that this was God, because he uses the Word
Infinite: neither can thou say, The Soul is God, because M. B. says, There
is a kind of Infiniteness in the Soul. And G. F. asks, Whether it be not
Infinite in it self, and more than all the World? And does not Job say, In
whose Hand (to wit, the Lord's) is the Soul of every living thing, and the
Breath of all Mankind (Job. 12.9)? And is not Christ called the Bishop and
Shepherd of the Souls of the Saints (1 Pet. 2, 25)? and if Christ be the
Shepherd and the Bishop, is not he both the Nourisher and Feeder of the
Immortal Soul? And what! do not thou confess, the Soul is Immortal: and that
which is Immortal, is not that Everlasting? and now would it be well for G. F.
to conclude and to say, that R. W. says, The Soul is the Everlasting God,
acording to thy own Argument? nay, G. F. has more Charity. And does not R. W.
acknowledge the Soul to be Immortal, and the Souls of the Godly going unto
Jesus? and their Bodies uniting to the Spirit in Eternal Life? Well then, what
does R. W. make of the Bodies of the Saints, who is so offended at G. F's.
Question, because he asks, whether the Soul be not Infinite in it self? and
yet R. W. says; We use to say Hyperbolically, that such and such a doing is
Infinite Pride. But if G. F. should have said, Thou make Pride God, thou
would have been offended, who art offended at this Question, who asks,
Whether the Soul be not Infinite? and thou call him a Blasphemer: and yet
thou say, Pride is Infinite. And we know, that the Word Infinite properly
belongs to God: David says, His Understanding is Infinite: and thou say;
God proclaims his Infinite Power and Wisdom etc. Now my Question is to R. W
and the Priests of New England: Whether the Prophets and Apostles of God did
receive any of his Infinite Wisdom and Power by his Spirit from above, though
God be Infinite and Incomprehensible in himself in all his VVisdome and
Goodness and Justice? And did not God say, That Job was Perfect, though he
abhorred himself in Dust and Ashes? And thou confessest, that God is not only
Infinite, but Infinity it self, Omnipotency it self, VVisdome it self, Goodness
it self, Justice it self in all their Eminencies etc. But G. F. does not say,
the Soul is so: and if thou did own this in deed and in truth, thou would
not speak against the Quakers. And a great deal of Rambling thou make
concerning the Soul, but thou have not Answered G. F's. Questions, Whether the
Soul be in God's Hand? Whether Christ be the Bishop of it? And whether the
Souls of the Righteous Christ brings to God? or whether the Soul did come out
from God's Breath?

R. W. brings R. S. who says, [ The Mystical Body may be sometimes subject
to Distempers, and Humors, and Wants.] And G. F. answers, p. 51.
and questioneth [Are you Judges? can you judge of the Mystical Body, which the
Saints are Baptized into? are there Humors, Wants and Distempers in the Body,
which the Saints are Baptized into? are not the Wants, Distempers and Humors
in your Bodies? Do you here in this divide the Word aright? or distinguish
things in the Ground, and speak right of things? and yet ye would not be
judged, and say, Judge not: and is not Mystical Spiritual?] -- R. W. replyeth
and says, W. Edm. affirmed, God was a Spirit literally and properly.

Answ. Will thou say, That God is not a Spirit, as literally and properly as
the Scripture declares him? And thou say again, That W. Edm. showed but
little Philosophy and Divinity. Does not the Apostle bid the Saints, Beware of
Philosophy? and if they had known God and Divinity by it, the Apostle would not
have bidden them, beware of it, surely. And thou say, That W. Edm. affirmed,
that properly and really that Scripture of Wolves coming in Sheeps-Cloathing,
was to be understood Literally without Meaning. And what meaning will thou give
to Christ's Words? are not Men called Wolves really, that worry Christ's Sheep
about Religion? for Christ does not say, They are Wolves with four Feet; and
when Christ spoke Parables, he said, He that has an Ear, let him hear: and
sometimes he expounded them to his Disciples. And the Scripture calling God a
Father and a Husband, and Christ a Rock: and Christ's Believers are called a
Body, a House, a Flock, are they not really so? for it does not say, They are a
Flock of Sheep as outwardly, or other Creatures, nor an outward House etc. --
And then thou go on with a great Tale, and tell, What the Papists hold,
and what is amongst them. Roger, though thou and you of New England are
separated from the Church of Rome, yet you are found in the same Old Spirit of
Persecution.

R. W. And whereas thou say; By God's holy and wise Permission the Devil
sends out his old known Spirit of pure Invisibles, and pure Immediate, p. 52.
and pure Worshippers in Spirit and Truth.

Answ. Roger, do not Blaspheme against the Holy Spirit of God. For is not God's
Spirit and Truth Holy and Pure, in which he is Worshipped? and is not God's
Holy Spirit Invisible, or is it Mediate?

R. W. And thou say; This Spirit (to wit, of the Quakers) being Cozen German
to, or Sworn Brother in Hellish Equivocation with the Jesuits etc.

Answ. These are thine and the New England Priests Conditions, as your Fruits
have declared it: for the Quakers obey the Commands of Christ, who says, Swear
not at all.

R. W. For thou say; The Quakers Churches, they are (as they Childishly
vapor) Bodies without Wants or Distempers etc.

Answ. Reader see, if there be any such Words in G. F's. Answer: for G. F.
speaks of the Mystical or Spiritual Body, he does not speak of Naturals, nor
Bodies of outward Families, or Bodies of Nations and Cities, or Armies: Nor
Visible Churches, nor the Body of Visible Churches, but the Spiritual Body. For
does not the Apostle speak of a Spiritual Body, and a Natural Body? and so it
is God, that does supply both. And G. F. does not speak of the outward Bodies
of the Saints; for is that Mystical?

R. W. And then thou say; What known Divisions and Passions about J.
Naylor's and others Cases? what Envyings, Cursings, Apostasies and Moral
Idolatry: p. 53.
as that of Covetousness in this Colony known notoriously?

Answ. Thou have not particularized who they be, and what is their
Covetousness, who is known so notoriously (as thou say) in that Colony;
therefore we look upon this as a Slandering of thy Neighbors: for we question,
whether thou have admonished them (if it was so) before thou told the World.
And as for Cursings, and Envyings and Divisions, thou might have kept that
amongst you New England Professors: but if any one do not walk, as becomes the
Gospel, we do Admonish them. And if there be any Difference about outward
Matters, according to the Apostle's Doctrine, we do end it amongst our selves,
according to Truth and Righteousness, 1 Cor. 6; and God has given us Judgment
in such Matters, as well as Spiritual.

R. W. And thou say; I have fairly Collected, that the Spirit of the Quakers
tends to Incivility and Barbarism; and to sudden Assassinations, Murders and
Persecutions.

Answ. This is thine and the New England Spirits, whose Persecution is known,
for you have proved it already. And thou would have us punished, and yet thou
would not have it called Persecution (as in thy 200 page). Is not your Law
standing, by which you Murdered God's People; and do not your Laws, and thy
stirring up to Punishment, Collect or declare your own Spirit not to be the
Spirit of Christ? for where would it have any to be punished for Matters of
Religion and Conscience toward God? And so as for thy Lies and abusive
Speeches, we can say, The Lord forgive thee, if it be his Will.

R. W. And thou say; I believe, that I have, and can further make it good,
that the Eternal Father of Mercies stops millions of Mischiefs in the world
daily, which the Natures, Grounds and Principles of Men ( and the Quakers
Spirit also) now to turn and overwhelme the world withal.

Answ. Here thou have manifested thy self to be of the Spirit of them that
opposed Paul, who said, he was a Pestilent Fellow, and a Turner of the World
upside down. And as for the Principles of Men beside the Quakers, they may
answer for themselves: and thy Slanders may serve such, as are given up to
believe Lies; but sober People that know us, will not receive nor believe thy
Lies: but it will make more to believe the Truth, which thou can not stop.
But let the Reader see, if R. W. in all his Rambling Reply has said any thing
to the Spiritual or Mystical Body, which was G. F's. Question.

R. W. And thou bringst J. Clapham his saying, [ Men may be called of Men
Masters, and it is but a Cavel to deny it: and they may deny to be called
Father, as well as Master]. And G. F. Ans. [Thou have in this denied the
Doctrine of Christ, and slighted it, who says; Be not ye called of Men Master,
for ye have all one Master, which is Christ, and ye are all Brethren: and thou
have showed thy self out of that Brotherhood. And there is a Birth to be born,
which calls no Man Father upon Earth, which thou art ignorant of]. And R. W.
replyeth and falls a Railing, and calls it G. Foxs's lame Answer.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if it be not Christ's Doctrine; which he might as
well have called Christ's Doctrine Lame, which he Preached to his Disciples.

R. W. And thou say; Among other Foolish Passions and Affections haunting
all Men ( and the Quakers especially) these two are notorious, (viz.) Pride,
and a lazy Ignorance; these two are the Sir and Dame of most of these Wild
Monsters.

Answ. R. W. might have kept this at home, for it is his own Condition, who
kicketh at Christ's Doctrine, that G. F. brings, who says; Neither be ye
called of Men Master, for one is your Master even Christ, and ye are all
Brethren. And he manifests himself to be in the steps of the Pharisees, who
love to be called of Men Rabbi. And so for his Foolish Passion and Pride etc.
and Lazy Ignorance, and wild, Monstrous Spirit he may apply at home; who does
not obey Christ's Doctrine. -- And we know, that those Opposites have written
against Christ's Doctrine, (who love to be called of Men Masters) and against
us, because we hold it forth. -- And is it Scornful Pride, and a Robbing all
Mankind of their due, to obey Christ's Doctrine (as thou speak of)? for thou
say of their due Respects and favorable Glaunces of God's Care, of Order
and Prudent Distinctions and Differences amongst the Sons of Men in Families,
Cities, Nations, Armies, Natives etc. Answ. Does G. F. mention any of these,
either Families, Cities, Nations, etc? for G. F. speaks, how Christ taught
his disciples, that they should not be called of men Masters: And did Christ
Rob them of all these titles, and break God's care or order, when he said, Be
not yet called of men Masters?

R. W. Thou say: Sure he cannot but Remember, and his own, and all the Light
in the Quakers (if seriously minded) will tell them, that in robbing all the
world of their several due, moderate and sober Titles and Respects, they do it
but by a Judgling Hocas Pocas, a back door, etc. rob all others of their
Points, Ribbonds and Laces etc.

Answ. You may see, what work R. W. makes here agaiast Christ's doctrine to
his disciples, and how like the Scribes and Pharisees and Hypocrites he
appears? it is like, R. W. and the New England Priests are offended, because
the People called Quakers do not call them Masters. And thou say; The Pope
and the Quakers are compared. Nay, R. W. is nearer unto them, who pleads to
be called of men Master, like the Papists; for their Jesuits and Priests are
called of men Master, and plead for it, as thou do, and call them Civil
Respects: and therefore it is plain, that thou art found in their Spirit.

R. W. And then thou say; The Dogged and Scornful Quakers are far from,
their Spirit being prouder than the Papists. And thou Contradicts thy self and
say; p. 54.
The Pope and Quakers compared.

Answ. For the People of God called Quakers, obeying the Doctrine of Christ,
cannot call your Teachers Masters; and if you did not love it Pharisee-like,
you would never make such work about it: and Christ has interpreted, what the
Master signifies. And did Christ only condemn the Pharisees, and not such as
your Teachers, for being called of Men Masters? did not he teach his own
Disciples the contrary?

R. W. And thou say; The Foxians itch, of being called of Men Masters etc.
in Religion, undervaluing and slighting others.

Answ. These are False Charges, as our Practice declares it.

R. W. And then thou tellst a Story of James Naylor, and what one should call
G. F.

Answ. But who that One is, thou have not declared. And as for James Naylor, he
Repented, and the World knows it: therefore it is no Credit for thee to
Publish that.

R. W. Thou say; Half a Humane and sober Eye may see, that in all his
Declamations against the Pharisaical or Popish, or Foxians Rabbis etc.

Answ. These are Railing Accusations. For where do the Quakers own that Title
Rabbi, as they are Preachers of Christ (as thou and the Pharisees and the
Papists do) thou speak of, in a Religious Account, as they were Teachers?
but in a Civil Account, as Fathers, Masters and Mothers by Children and
Servants, we never deny this in a Civil account, but practice it. But what is
this to oppose Christ's Doctrine, and not to obey his Command, which thou art
now Fighting against? we believe, many a Priest could have wished, that
Doctrine of Christ had been torn out of the Bible, it cutteth your Pride so.

R. W. And thou say; How childishly does Fox Answer this his Opposite, viz.
That although it be unlawful to call Master, yet not unlawful to call Father:
for there is a Birth, which his Opposite is ignorant of.

Answ. We say, Yes, and thou too. But do thou say, It is Childish for Christ
to say, Call no Man Father upon the Earth, Matthew. 23, 9? is not this
Childishness or Ignorance in thee, to oppose his Doctrine? And did not the
Disciples of Christ believe in the Light, and so became Children of Light? and
as many as are led by the Spirit of God, are the Sons of God? ( John 12, Romans
8) And this is according to true Christian Regeneration and Change.

R. W. And thou say; Paul said, Though you have ten Thousand Teachers, yet I
have begotten you. Sure it is, their Immediate denies the Mediate.

Answ. What is all this to the purpose to oppose Christ's Doctrine in Matthew.
23? But R. W. has left out Paul's Instrument, through which he begot them, to
wit the Gospel, which the Apostle says, Is the Power of God unto Salvation
(Romans 1, and 1 Cor. 4, 15): and he told them, That they had not many Fathers in
Christ: and why did thou leave out that?

R. W. And thou say; How simple is that Consequence, that because God is an
Extraordinary Father, therefore I may call all Men Fathers, p. 55.
but not Masters, when God is both Father and Master; and both Titles are
forbidden in a true Sense etc.

Answ. And yet thou will not obey them thy self, but railest against the
Quakers that do: and God is the Father of his People, and Christ is the Master
of his Followers. But come R. W. and the New England Priests, show us a
Scripture out of all the New Testament of Master Matthew, Mr. Mark, Mr. Luke,
Mr. John, or Mr. Peter, and Mr. Paul, and Mr. James etc? and if Roger Williams
and the Priests of New England will be called of Men Master, how is it, that
they do not give the Title Master to the Apostles, when they read their
Epistles, or to the Evangelists? And have not thou written in thy Book, and
applauded thy self to the World, how that one called thee Master Williams? and
so have set forth thy Title to the World, in opposition to Christ's Doctrine.

R. W. Brings W. Thomas's saying, [Men are saved, but not by Christ within
us]. G. F. (Fol. 106) Answers W. T. [How is Man's Salvation wrought out, but
by the Power of Christ within? How is the Old Man destroyed, but by Christ
within? how is Justification felt, but by Christ within? Here he quotes G. F's
Words falsely, saying [Seeds we manifest] to mak^ them Nonsense, which are not
G. F's Words.
And the Seed Christ made manifest, that suffered without, is made manifest
within, there is Redemption and Life. He that has the Son of God, has Life:
Redemption to God out of the First Adam; and who feel Christ within, feel
Salvation; and who do not, are Reprobates, though they may talk of him.] -- R.
W. replies to G. F. and says; This Subtle Fox is in his Borough, confounding
( under the Term Christ) the Person of Christ, and the Love and Spirit und
Grace or Fovour of Christ, as if they were all one.

Answ. Let the Gentle Reader judge, Is not the Love, and Spirit, and Grace and
Favor of Christ to be manifest within, who suffered without? But let the
Reader read my Words here, and mine in R. W's. Book, and compare them together
and see, how many he has left out. And see the Abusive Words of R. W.'s. who
says, Confounding under the Term of Christ the Person of Christ. etc. And how
can G. F. say, That Christ suffered without his Person without the Gates of
Jerusalem, who yet is manifest within his People, according to the Apostle's
Doctrine? And it was the Favor of Christ and the Love of God, that Christ
should die for Sinners; and it is the Love and Favor of God, that he should be
made manifest in his People.

R. W. And then thou tellest a story of a King, and General or Admiral, which
is to no purpose: And the writings of G. F. where they come, there is not G. F.
except he be there.

Answ. But what is this to the purpose, that Christ, that suffered without the
Gates of Jerusalem, must not be manifest in his people by his Spirit? Many may
have the Scriptures, that speak of Christ, but if they have not the Son, they
have not Life; as John says. And if thou owned'st that in the Truth, which is
spoken of Ephesians. 2. and Gal. 2. thou would not oppose the Quakers.

R. W. And thou confessest, Faith is given of God, etc. and this Faith and
belief is wrought by Christ Jesus, and finished by him; and may with a good
sense be called Christ himself.

Answ. Let the sober Reader see, if G. F. do mention in his Answer (or any
where else) that Christ is Faith; but the Author and Finisher of it. And how
can Faith be wrought in Men's Hearts, if Christ the Worker of it, be not there
also by his Spirit? And then thou go on in thy Story, and tellst us a Story
of Humph. p. 56.
Norton, That he resolved Christ only into a Spirit etc. This is like the rest
of thy Slanders; for we do not believe thee, that Humphry Norton owned not the
Man Christ Jesus: but the Question is, Whether R. W. and the New England
Priests will own Christ to be a quickening Spirit? And as for Paul's saying to
the Corinthians, He was absent in Body, yet present in Spirit; this will prove,
that Christ by his Spirit is in his People, though he be at the Right Hand of
God.

And then thou tellest us a Story of Soldiers to no purpose against G. F's.
Answer, of Christ being manifest in his Saints, that suffered without. And can
any see Christ Jesus at the Right Hand of God, but by his Spirit and his Light
within? did not Stephen see him by the Holy Ghost, and was not that within? And
that is true, which was sent to them that stood gazing, As they saw him go, so
should he come; (as in Acts 1, 10, 11,) which also said, Ye men of Gallilee,
why stand ye gazing up into heaven? the same Jesus, which is taken up from you
into Heaven, shall come in like manner, as ye have seen him go into Heaven. And
did not Christ, appear to his Disciples after his Ascension? and to Paul? and
was manifest in his Saints? and will come and Reward every man according to his
Works, (as in Revelations.)

And thou go on, and usest many words, but to no purpose. And if Christ be
felt in the bruised Reed, and the smoking flax, and the poor in Spirit, and to
feed the Hungry and Thirsty, is not this all within? and is not he the Hope of
Glory manifested within his People? and does not the sup with the Saints, and
the Saints sup with him the Heavenly Supper? And does not he stand at the door
and knock? but you will not open, and cleave to his Light, and receive him. And
without his Light you may seek Day and Night, and grope in the dark, and never
find him.

R. W. And thou say. There is a false Feeling of Christ, a false Conception
in a Woman: and how many are bold to cry, Lord, Lord open, for we have
Prophesied in thy Name.

Answ. Truly Roger, this is thy own Condition and the New England Priests and
Professors, in the False Feeling and Conception, that do not believe in the
Light, as Christ Commands; but persecute them that believe in the Light, and
truly feel, and are become Children of the Light, and have brought forth the
true Birth, and are graffted into Christ.

R. W. Thou say; I will not say as G. F. has said, All that have not my
Feeling or Working of Christ, are Repr^bates.

Answ. G. F's. Words are the Apostle's Doctrine, who says, If Christ be not in
you, you are Reprobates etc. (2 Cor. 13) and therefore he bids them, Prove and
Examine themselves; and so it is every true Christian's Duty.

R. W. And whereas thou say; Yet this I say, as Solomon, A Whore is loud and
clamorous: [Truly R. W. thou art of her: for I never heard so many clamorous
Words from a Man's Mouth in my Life, as from thine: but it is well thou have
showed thy Spirit, which will be abhorred by all sober Men and Women.] -- And
then thou say; The Devil spoke as Holy and Heavenly Words, as Angels could
have spoken, yet it was but the Devil in Samuel's Mantle.

Answ. R. W. this is thy own Condition; for thou may bring the Scriptures,
as the Jews and the Devil did, that tempted Christ, and oppose him, as the Jews
did in they days of his flesh, as he being the man Christ: So now thou opposest
his Divinity, and the divine Light, which is the Life in the Word, which Light
his believers believed in, and which Light shines in their hearts, and gives
them the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Christ Jesus (2 Cor. 4.)

R. W. And thou bring'st Giles Ferman ( G. F. Fol. 117.) Saying [Paul Swore
after Christ, and the Angels Swore: I wonder Paul should so forget himself, p.
57.
and Sin so fearfully in Swearing. So the Quakers Light that denies Swearing,
is of Satan, and not the Light of Christ.] G. F. Answers to G. Ferman [Christ
the Light (which Satan is out of) who is the Oath of God, ends all Oaths
Sworn by Prophets or Angels whatsoever: and who Swear, be fallen into the
Condemnation of the Devil. And it is no where said, that Paul Swore; but such
as thou art, matter not what you speak: So that spirit, that Preaches for
Swearing, is not the spirit of Christ. But the Spirit of Antichrist Preaches
up that, which Christ and the Apostles Preached down, and Preached condemnation
to them that Swear.] R. W. Replyeth. [though he has left out, [ Preaches
Condemnation to them that Swear] of G. F. words, and also has left out, That
which thou preachest up, to wit Swearing, Christ and the Apostles Preached
down. So here and there thou have taken some of G. F's Words] And further thou
say, that G. F. dare not deny, but the Angel and Paul Swore after Christ;
and yet thou say, that Christ put an end to Swearing, and that it is not
said, that Paul Swore, and call it G. F.'s old Song.

Answ. Here thou contradicts thy self; for G. F. says, It is no where said,
that Paul Swore. And if the Angel did Swear, is it not said in the Scripture, I
will bring forth my Begotten into the world, let all the Angels worship him;
that says, Swear not at all? But what is this to the purpose? the Command was
to men, not to Swear, and to the Apostles; to whom Christ and the Apostle
forbids all Swearing.

R. W. And thou say; If the Attestation in the Name of God be the formality
of an Oath, then if ever any man Swore in this world, Paul did, Saying to the
Corinthians, I call God to Record on my Soul: etc.

Answ. Roger does not speak plainly, whether Paul Swore, or no, but is in his
Ifs. And we know, that this, which Paul speaks to the Corinthians, will not
be taken for an Oath.

R. W. And thou tellest us, How Nations used to Swear, and appealed to the Gods
etc: And how they used to put Creatures in the Room of God, as the Jews did:
And some write out of a Superstitious Reverence, in forbearing the Name of God,
and indeed the Reasons that Christ gives, look that way.

Answ. Christ and the Apostles forbid all Oaths (as in Mat. 5. and Jam. 5.) not
only to Creatures, but the Oaths that were to be performed to the Lord.

R. W. Thou Say: There seems to be a very fair Color put on an universal
prohibition of Swearing by Christ Jesus, by his Apostle James, Swear not etc.
[Is it no more, but a seeming fair Color? are not Christ and the Apostle's
words real?] and yet R. W. says, I must proclaim against G. F. in his lame and
simple Return to his Opposite Concerning Paul and the Angel: p. 58.
and further thou say, Why may not Paul and all the Apostles etc. and all
the Angels of heaven, and all the Saints of God upon the Earth in Paul's words
call God to Record upon their Souls etc. in case of Truth?

Answ. Yes, they may, and G. F. does not deny it: and if thou say, that was
an Oath, thou art both Lame and Simple, and have not proved it so. And as I
said before, Christ forbidding Swearing, and the Apostles, it was to men that
had Oaths and Shaddows, yea and all Oaths were forbidden, as well as the true.
And the Angel Swearing (in the Revelations) was, that time should be no longer
etc. (Rev. 10.) but what is this to Christ's forbidding men not to Swear at
all? And this we can say Instead of an Oath, and have proffered to Rulers and
Magistrates, that If we break our Yea, Yea, and Nay Nay, then let us suffer the
same punishment, as they do, that are perjured persons: for our NOT SWEARING
is in obedience to the Command of Christ and the Apostle's Doctrine, who says,
Swear not at all.

R. W. And thou say: As the fear of God is put for the whole worship of God,
so also is Swearing in the holy Scripture.

Answ. This is but R. W's Saying so; but he has brought no Chapter and Verse
for it, nor tells us, where it is written so? but speaks contrary to Christ
and the Apostle's Doctrine, who says, Swear not at all. And where does R. W.
prove, that God commanded Swearing, before Moses was born?

R. W. And thou say. Thou know, the Foxians make Baptism etc. And ere
long, if they continue to hearken to Samuel within them, they will account
Prayer and Preaching but Types and Shaddows.

Answ. These are Scoffing and Jearing expressions, as any sober people may see.
And John says, that he must decrease, and Christ must increase, that comes
after him, who is mightier then he, that was preferred before him (who is
Mightier in birth and in power etc.) and he shall Baptize you with fire and the
Holy Ghost, and he shall increase. Now I query of R. W. Whether he has known
John? whether his Rough way be made Smooth, and his Crooked way straight, and
his Mountain be down? and whether he does believe, that Christ Jesus is come
after John? And what reason has R. W. to say, that the Quakers will look upon
preaching and praying to be Types and Shaddows, if they hearken to Samuel
within them? do these words savor of the Spirit of God, let the sober Reader
Judge.

R. W. And thou say, That Swearing is as real worship of God, as preaching
etc: and the fear of God and Swearing by him is put for his whole worship.

Answ. And were not Offerings and Sacrifices the Worship of God in the time of
the Law? and does not Christ say, before Abraham was, I am? who says, Swear
not at all? and does not Christ end the Offerings and Swearing as well before
the Law, as after the Law, and so all Oaths? For the Apostle that forbids
Swearing, Exhorts to prayer: and therefore thou Preachest a false Doctrine,
to bring people into Evil and Condemnation, that preachest up Swearing, against
Mat. 5. James 5.

R. W. And thou say; It is a gross fancy to Imagine, that the Lord Jesus in
Mat. 5. gave New Commands to contradict the holy pleasure of his Father
Concerning Oaths etc.

Answ. Christ there expounds the Law, and tells them, how they were not to
forswear themselves, but perform their Oaths to the Lord in the Old time: and
what Old time was that? But Christ says, I say unto you, Swear NOT AT ALL: so
this was the true Oath of God, that he forbids amongst the Jews, which was a
part of their worship. And Christ, he puts down their Worship at Jerusalem,
which the Jews went there yearly to worship; and sets up a worship in Spirit
and Truth: and do thou say, that the Jews worship lay in nothing but the fear
of God, Swearing, and Prayer? and were they not to obey many other things in
their Worship? And for all frivolous Oaths Christ reproved the Jews, and the
Law forbad false Swearing, as well as Christ: and what the Prophet under the
Law called Swearing, the Apostle under the Gospel calls Confessing, (Phil. 2,
10, 11.)

R. W. And thou say: A Sober Eye may see, that Christ intends only to reduce
them to an Holy Swearing, only by God's way.

Answ. Thou have not proved this out of the New Testament, but they proceed
from thy own dark Imaginations. And are thy own Traditions contrary to the mind
of Christ and the Apostle, who denis all Swearing, and sets up Yea and Nay
in the Lieu of it? and he plainly forbids that Oath, that the Jews were to
perform to the Lord in the old time.

R. W. And thou bring'st F. H. and say; The Quakers plainly Confess Swearing
in cases Lawful.

Answ. In this thou abusest F. H. and the Quakers: but to use those words, as
F. H. and the Apostle do, is not Swearing. And had thou been in the same
tenderness of Usher or the Waldenses, thou would not have pleaded so much for
Swearing. And do not thou tell in one place of thy Book, how thou
Suffered'st, because thou could not take an Oath (but now it seems, thou
art hardened) as in page 60. wherein thou say, thou could not yield to the
formality of an Oath; and it seems, now thou can Swear, and deny Christ and
the Apostle's Doctrine, and plead for it.

And why should the Parliament and all Lawiers search well and appoint a
Committee to examine, if their Laws upon New appearances from Heaven have not
need of Rectifying? p. 60.
etc. And (as R.W. says) If Swearing be a part of God's worship etc then did
not R. W. Sin in not Swearing in the Chancery in England, in leaving off a part
of God's worship, which he says, Swearing is? But in this you may see, how R.
W. Contradicts himself, and has manifested, what Love he has to Christ and
his Apostles, who perverteth their words (as he does G. F's) and Slights their
Doctrine, who says, Swear not at all.

R. W. And thou bring'st T. Moor saying [ It is not properly, nor in a full
sense, that God is manifested in the flesh of his Saints.] (but Roger has
quoted no page for this.) G. F. Answ. [The Saints are the Temples of God, and
God dwells in them: and they come to witness the Flesh of Christ, and they
glorify him in their Souls and bodies, and the Lord is Glorified in their
bringing forth much fruit, and they witness his Seed (to wit Christ) the one
Offering for Sin to be manifested within. And such are not Reprobates, that
witness the One Offering, Christ Jesus; and they that have not him within, they
are Reprobates.] R. W. replyeth and says, A great design of the Devil in all
Ages has been to Cavil at, and hinder God's Love to mankind.

Answ. What! does this hinder the Love of God to mankind, and to have Christ
manifest within them, which is God's Love to the World? And is it not the
Devil's design, to deceive Man and keep his house, and will suffer him to talk
of Christ as long as he will, but will not suffer the strong one to be bound
and cast out? And they that are Married to Christ (who bruiseth the Serpent's
head) are they not of his flesh and of his bones? and they that have the Son,
can praise God for his Love to fallen mankind.

R. W. And thou say: Against this Lord Jesus Christ this old Serpent hisseth
and rages before his birth, at his birth and after his birth etc.

Answ. We, who have Christ formed in us, have felt the Rage of the Old Serpent
in this Age both in R.W. and the New England-Priests and professors, as Christ
and the Prophets and Apostles did in their Age by the professors of Christ in
words, as the Jews professed him to come in words.

And whereas thou rank'st the people of God called Quakers amongst the
Libertines, Manicheans, Adamites, Ranters etc. these R. W. and the
New-England-Priests might very well applied at home, p. 61.
who have manifested your Order in the Dragon's power, thou speak of,
persecuting with Tongue and Hands, as Michael the Archangel, when Contending
with the Devil he disputed about the Body of Moses, durst not bring against him
a Railing Accusation, but said, The Lord Rebuke thee. And now art not thou with
thy Railing Accusations disputing about the Body and Flesh of Christ? as thou
may see in Jude and Zach: 3.

R. W. And whereas thou tell us, What the Arrians hold [But thou had
better to see, what thou held'st and did possess of Christ thy self.] And
thou say, But with Christ's Manhood and the Scriptures the Devil and the
Papists and the Quakers for the most part of them could with all their heart
make an Everlasting parting. The Devil 's End is, to destroy this Savior and
Salvation to poor lost man; she Quakers pretend, their End to be the Exalting
and Glorifying God in the Flesh of his Saints.

Answ. As for what the Papists and the Devil do, thou may apply that at
home, who so often have the Devil in thy Mouth. And as for parting Christ Jesus
from his Godhead, that is not our work; for he is called the heavenly man, the
Second Adam, a quickening Spirit. And the Scripture we own: and also are to
Glorify God with our Souls and bodies, which are his. And we tell thee, the
Devil cannot destroy our Savior Christ Jesus, for he destroys the Devil and
his Works: but it is like, he may destroy your Imaginary Christ or Antichrist,
and set up another; for Christ was dead, and is alive, and lives for Evermore.
(Revel. 1, 18)

R. W. And thou say, that G. F. plays upon the various meaning of the word
Flesh; he plays also upon those holy Scriptures, viz: God is glorified in the
Souls and bodies of his Saints. etc.

Answ. As for saying, G. F. plays, that thou might have applied at home; for
his words are Scripture-phrases. For must not all the Children of the New
Covenant witness their bodies the Temp^es of God, and him to dwell in them, and
wa^k in them by his Spirit? and they to bring forth fruits of his Spirit, and
to Glorify God in their bodies and Souls etc? And we do know, what the
Protestants do hold, and what you do hold in words concerning Christ, who
persecute us, that do possess him: and you had better possess him, and let him
Rule in your hearts by Faith, and not the Dragon, the Old persecutor. For we
own Christ in the promise in the prophecies, who was born of a Virgin, his
Sufferings, Resurrection, in whom the fullness of the Godhead dwells bodily;
and of his fullness have we Received Grace for Grace (Col. 4)

R. W. And thou say; That G. F knows, his Opposite intends such a
manifestation of God in the Flesh, that renders the one Single person Christ
Jesus the head of the Church: and that they hold, there is as much difference
between that one Individual person Christ Jesus the Head, and his Followers, as
between our heads and our bodies etc.

Answ. If you hold this, this is a Nighness betwixt Christ and his Church; but
do you possess it? And G. F knows his Opposites in the other Power's days; it
was a wonder to them, to hear of Christ's dwelling in people: so G. F. knew
their meaning very well. And must not God, that was manifested in the Flesh of
Christ, that one Single person, must not he and his Father be manifest in his
people by his Spirit, and he to dwell in them Now, as he did in the Apostle's
days?

R. W. And thou say; How poor and lame is it, that because the Saints are
God's Temple, therefore they must be God himself? p. 62.


Answ. Let the Reader see if there be any such words as these, in G.F's Answer:
for G F's. words are, The Saints are the Temples of God, and God will dwell in
them (as 1 Cor. 6. and 2 Cor. 6.) G. F. does not say, The Saints are God, as
thou have falsely forged. And does not the Apostle Exhort the Saints* that
Christ may dwell in their hearts by Faith? (Ephesians. 3.) and therefore thou say,
They say, they are Christ himself: Let the Reader see, if there be any such
word in G. F's. Answer? and whether he has not abused G. F's. words here also?
Must not Christ dwell in his people? and are not the Saints bodies members of
Christ? and are they not Christ's Temple for to dwell in? And does not the
Apostle say, Ye are not your own, ye are bought with a price? etc. is this to
affirm, They are Christ himself? Or does it hence follow, That those
particulars affirmed of the man Christ Jesus (1 Timothy 3.) are inverted, and
dreadfully turned upon their proud, devilish Flesh, because God was Manifested
in the Flesh etc? (1 Timothy 3, 16.) see, what false Charges and Inferences he
frames! But does not Christ destroy the Devil, and proud Flesh in people? for
does not the Apostle say, If Christ be in you, the body is dead, because of
Sin: but the Spirit is life, because of Righteousness. (Romans 8.)

R. W. And thou say: The Devil is manifest in their Flesh, Condemned of the
holy Spirit of God, abhorred of the heavenly Angels, the world shall abhor
their Memory, and except Repentance they shall descend with all the Enemies of
the true Lord Jesus into the Lake, that burns with unquenchable fire etc.

Answ. R. Williams might have applied this Judgment of his, to his own Spirit,
and the professors of New England, of the Devil being manifested in their
Flesh* whose work of Lying, Murder and Persecution they have done; and its
well, if they do see a day of Repentance, that they and he may escape the Lake.
Thus we do Confess with the Apostle, The Law of the Spirit of Life in Christ
Jesus has made us free from the Law of Sin and death: for what the Law could
not do, in that it was weak through the Flesh, God sending his own Son in the
likeness of Sinful Flesh, for sin Condemns Sin in the Flesh, that the
Righteousness of the Law might be fullfilled in u^, who walk not after the
Flesh, but after the Spirit, (Romans 8.) And as for R. W's. saying, The world
abhorring of our memory etc. we know, the World hated Christ our Lord and
Master, and so it is no marvel, if such worldly minds, as R. W. is, hate us.
God Loved his people, yea all his Saints are in his hand, and they sit down at
his feet, and receive his words, and his Angels do pitch their Tents about
them: and we know, that their Ministering Spirits are sent forth to Minister to
them, that be Heirs of Salvation (Deuteronomy. 33. Hebr: 1.)

R. W. And thou bring'st Tho. Moor saying [ Christ is distinct from from every
one of us, and without us and our particular persons.] And G. F. Answers T.M.
[The Apostle says, Christ was in them, except they were Reprobates; and they
were of his Flesh and of his Bone, and they eat his flesh, and drank his blood,
then it was within them. And he is distinct from none, but Reprobates, who hate
the Light.] And is not this truth according to Scripture? for the Apostle
says, We are members of his body, of his flesh and of his bone (Ephesians. 5, 30:)
and (2 Cor. 13) Christ is in you, except ye be Reprobates. And does not Christ
say, he is the Living bread, that comes down from heaven? and Whosoever eats my
flesh, and drinks my blood, has Eternal Life, and I will raise him up at the
last day; for my flesh is meat indeed, and my blood is drink indeed; he that
eats my flesh, and drinks my blood, dwells in me, and I in him: and is
not this Scripture? R. W. Replyeth to G. F. and falls a Railing (as he used
to do) and says, G. F's. words carry two faces, one to God, and another to the
Devil.

Answ. As for that word, face to the Devil, he might have kept it at home, for
it is his own. And as for the Papist's Transubstantiation, which he calls
Rome on Hell, let them answer for themselves, we have nothing to do with them:
and Christ says, his words are Spirit and Life, and flesh profits nothing. And
as for thy saying, that the Quakers have printed, that their flesh and blood is
as good as Christ's and of as much virtue etc. These are more of thy Lies, but
no book nor page have thou mentioned for this.

R. W. And whereas thou bring'st Act. 20. and say; Hence many of them
contend, that God's blood and God's flesh redeems them. p. 63.


Answ. What! must they not use the Apostle's Expressions, who said, Take heed
unto your selves, and to feed the Flock, which the Holy Ghost has made you
Overseers to feed the Church of God, which he has purchased with his own
blood? And in Contradiction to thy self thou say, That God paid his blood
to redeem thee (page 156): but I must tell thee, Christ as God, did not die;
but Christ suffered according to the Flesh.

R. W. And thou say, Gods Flesh redeemes us.

Answ. Was not Christ God? and does not the Scripture say ( Romans 9, 5.) Christ
is God? but God is a Spirit. And where did ever the Quakers print or say, it
was God's Flesh? it is called, the Flesh of Christ: but what, if the Quakers
use the Apostle's words, Great is the Mystery of Godliness! God was manifested
in the Flesh, justified in the Spirit etc. (1 Timothy 3).

R. W. And thou say, That their blood and their sufferings are God's Flesh
and Blood Redeeming and Saving etc.

Answ. The Reader may see, there are no such words in G. F.'s Answer. For I
say, It Is Christ's blood, who dyed at Jerusalem, that saves; and yet the
Saints cannot deny, but that they are Christ's, and Christ is God's, and their
bodies are his to dwell in. And thou tell of One, that would not speak all
at once; but who it is, thou tell us not: so its like, thou have Abused him,
as thou have done others.

R. W. And thou say: These Foxians are God and Christ, Spirit, Resurrection,
Life and Heaven.

Answ. These are more of thy Lies and Forgeries, let the Reader see, if there
be any such thing in G. F's. Answer, and whether thou have not abused his
Answer. And must not Christ dwell in his people, who is the Resurrection and
the Life, and his Kingdom be in them? and does not he dwell in all his true
believers? And did not Christ appear again to his Disciples according to his
Promise? and Christ says, He that loves me, and keeps my words, my Father
will Love him, and we will come unto him, and make our Abode with him (John 14)
And that of Joh. 16. is true, as Christ speaks, and the true believers do
behold his Glory (as in Joh. 17).

R. W. And thou say, I know, these poor Foxians say, that he did come again
to them (to wit Christ) and I know also, that a man may feel this Lie with a
pair of Mittins: for I know, the Comforter came not unto them upon his
Resurrection, ( for then he was forty days with them) but after his Ascension.

Answ. As for poor and Foxians, thou might have kept to thy self, and Lie
(for thou call'st it Uncivil for G. F. to speak the word Lie, and is it Civil
for thee?) with the Mittins. And we know, that Christ after his Resurrection
appeared unto his Disciples, and that the Holy Ghost came to his Disciples
after his Ascension: but what is all this to the purpose, to disprove G. F's.
Answer, That Christ does not dwell in his Saints now, and that the Holy Ghost
is not in them now? And we do believe of Christ's birth, sufferings, Death and
Resurrection, and Manifest in people, who will Judge the world in Righteousness.

R. W. And thou say, That we maintain Christ's Second Coming to be
Spiritual. [And does R. W. maintain his coming to be Carnal?] And thou say,
They count all gazing fools, that look after a man; for Christ is come unto
them in Spirit, and in them he maintains his great Assizes, and now passes
Judgment upon men by them etc.

Answ. Does not Christ dwell in his peoples hearts by his Spirit? and does not
he there Judge down Sin and Evil, that is in the hearts of Men? and does not he
give a Judgment to his Saints to Judge the Evil of the world? (read 1 Cor. 5)
And must the Saints deny this Judgment, that he gives his people, because
Christ will Judge the world in Righteousness, and reward every man according to
his works? Nay Roger, thou must feel it for belying and vilifying his people.
And if you look after Christ, as a Carnal Man, may they not call you Fools? who
is called the Second Adam, THE LORD FROM HEAVEN.

R. W. And thou say: If these poor, filthy dreamers lived without food and
Physic etc. without procreation etc.

Answ. We may say to thee, as Christ said to the Devil, Man lives not by bread
alone, but by every word, that proceeds out of the mouth of God. And as for
thy saying, Without procreation, and bringing forth of Children without the
Stinks of Nature etc. and a great deal of such Rambling stuff, which thou have
filled thy book up withal, thou may keep at home: and where did ever the
Prophets or Apostles use such Language concerning Marriage, which is an
Ordinance of God, or of Nature, which is good in it self? And as for thy
speaking of Eating of the flesh of Christ, until they b^come Christ himself,
which thou say, is Simple, Monstrous and Blasphemous etc. let the Reader
see, if there be any such words in G. F's Answer, or if they be not words of
his own forging, and Lies. But we cannot deny our bread from Heaven, for all R.
W's. Lies and Slanders, for which we can praise God for it, as the Apostles
did, who are flesh of his flesh, and bone of his bone. And thou tell of
Manicheans, and of a Frantic Spirit: As for the Manicheans, these thou
might have kept at home.

R. W. And thou say, This Frantic Spirit says, Is not Christ in us? how is
he distinct from us? what need you ask me, how I do? can Christ be sick? can
Christ do but well (speaking of themselves) And thou Observest God's wonderful
Stroke in this world upon three sorts of persons etc. p. 64.


Answ. It were well, if R. W. did see the Stroke of God upon himself, and let
others alone, to stand or fall to their own Master. And Reader, is there any of
these Expressions in G. F's. Answer to Tho. Moor? for he has not named any,
that has spoken such words, as he has forged here. And was that a Frantic
Spirit in the Apostle, who said, Christ is in you, except ye be Reprobates? but
does not Christ say, I was thirsty, hungry, naked, in prison, a stranger and
sick etc. whether this was not Christ in his members? and if so; then whether
R. W. and the New-England-Professors have not been persecuting him all this
while, as the persecuting Jews did, who looked on him as a Deceiver? And as for
the other Scoffing words, we leave them, they are not worth mentioning, (as in
the 62, 63, 64 pages may be seen).

R. W. And thou bring'st S. Hamond (Fol. 186) who says, [ What Warrant have
you to go out to the Quakers? shall a Man go hear the Jews and Popish Mass,
because Paul bids, Try all things? No, no.] And G. F. answers, [Paul bids
us, Quench not the Spirit; and where the Spirit is not quenched, they may try
Papists, Jews, Protestants, who quench not the Spirit: But who quench the
Spirit, and draw People from the Light within, they draw them from that they
should See withal: then you stuff them up with Old Authors and Lying Stories,
as you Print abroad.] R. W. instead of Replying he asks Questions, Whether
the Jews, Papists or Idolaters have the Holy Spirit? and whether they may go to
hear God speaking in his Holy Promise among them? etc.

Answ. Have not the Jews the Old Testament? and the Papists the Old and New, as
well as thou to speak of? And do not they hate the Light of Christ, and quench
the Spirit as well as thou, and persecute them that believe and walk in it? and
I ask R. W, Whether he can judge of them, without hearing of them, or reading
of their Books? And does not the Lord say, He would pour out of his Spirit upon
all Flesh, as well as thee, though they grieve it? and lights all as well as
thee, though they and thou hate it.

R. W. And thou say; May I hear a Papist, a Jew or an Idolater, a False
Worshipper etc. when I am convinced, that they speak not from the Holy Spirit?
etc. Or, May I go to worship God with them, when thou believe, they worship a
False God.

Answ. If thou wast convinced with the Holy Spirit of God, as we are, then thou
could not join with any false Worship, nor hear them to uphold them in it:
for with the Spirit they are tried, and not followed, in which Spirit of Truth
God is worshipped. But is it not Sam. Hamond's and R. William's Intent here,
that they would not have the People to hear the Quakers, and to worship God in
the Spirit and Truth? Though the Apostles went up and down into all Nations to
Preach the Gospel, yet they did not join with their Worships, and hold them
up: and they that are convinced of the Falseness of them, they have tried them.

R. W. And thou say; May I hear a False Prophet, or be present at any False
Worship, but with Actual Reproving of them, and laboring to reduce them etc.

Answ. If thou werest in the true Spirit out of the false, lying, slandering
Spirit, thou might Admonish and Reprove, if thou wast in the Spirit of God,
as the Apostles were in: but how comes it to pass, that the New England
Professors, who are the Pesecutors and False Prophets, cannot bear such, as
Actually reprove them? And why do the New England Professors make the Quakers
pay Five shillings a day, that do not go to hear them, when they are convinced
and have proved them, and tried them that they do not speak from the Spirit of
God, and know them to be in the same Persecuting Spirit, that the Jews and
Papists were in?

R. W. And thou say; Thou wast stopped by a Sudden Spirit of Prayer in a Woman
at Newport, and an Unseasonable Spirit of Prayer in a Man, which forced me to
stop, and occasioned me to take this way and Dispute with them.

Answ. And why could not R. W. have had Patience to have stayed, till they had
done Prayer? but he has showed his bad Spirit against Prayer, who calls it
unseasonable. And I do believe, that the Spirit of God, that led the Man and
Woman to pray, stopped thee, and therefore thou have brought forth this bad
Birth of Lies and Slanders, which thou have cast upon God's People: and before
thou come to try False Worships, or Prophets, or Preachers, thou must deny
the False Spirit in thy self.

R. W. And thou say; I ask, May any Soul out of Curiosity go to hear a
Strange Preacher, in whom I have not Faith, that he is sent from God? p. 65.
especially if there be not a Free Liberty for my Quaeries, and Objections and
Searchings, as the Bereans did.

Answ. Does not R. W. find fault with G. F's. Sense of English, who says, I or
any Soul? but others may have Liberty to go, where thou have not Faith. But if
R. W. and the New England Priests and Professors do practice this Question,
which he asks, then why do not they practice the Royal Law, To do to another,
and let them have the same Liberty, as they would have themselves, which G.
F's. Opposites (which R. W. seems to maintain) would not grant? for Tho.
Good-year was cast into Prison for saying HVM, when R. Baxter was Preaching in
Oliver's days. And why is there not so much Liberty then amongst the
New England Professors and Meeting-Places, but they must be FINED for not going
to hear a Preacher, on whom they have no Faith, nor Liberty to object and
quaery, nor search, as the Bereans did? if R. W. and the New England Priests
granted this Liberty to others, as they would have themselves, their Foundation
had been down ere now: and they needed not to have made Laws, to HANG, WHIP,
BANISH and IMPRISON. And we do take heed what we hear, and how we hear, and
what we join unto, with the Light and Spirit of God; though we are commanded to
try all things, and hold fast that which is Good. And why do thou say, it was
the Unseasonable Spirit of Prayer? because it crossed thee in thy Imaginations
and Evil Work then, which thou now have brought forth?

R. W. And thou say; What do we mean by the Spirit's Quenching? can the
Spirit of God be Really quenched?

Answ. Have not thou often quenched the Motions of it, by following thy
Imaginations, and thy own dark Spirit, and not being led by it? and therefore
does the Apostle Exhort the Saints, Not to quench the Spirit. And when thou
come to obey it, either in Praying or Prophesying, or Rejoicing, or Giving of
Thanks, or Proving all things with it, then thou will know, what it is to
quench it, and to see thy self in the Spirit of the Jews, who were so much
against Christ and his Apostles, and thought, they did God Service in so doing:
and that Light of Christ which thou hate, and the Spirit of God which thou
quenchest, will be thy Condemnation, except thou Repent. But if the
Thessalonians should have asked Paul, Can the Spirit of God be quenched, as
thou do? they that go from the Motions of it, quench it as to themselves, and
come to be led by an Evil, false Spirit, as leads thee; and such come to err
from it and grieve it: but they that obey the motions of it, do receive from
God his Heavenly Refreshings, and are sealed with the Spirit of Promise, Ephesians.
1, 11.

R. W. And thou say; Why do these Lazy Souls so horribly slight Reading and
Studying Books, yea God's Book, as one of their Chief said to me, laying his
hand upon the Bible of Junius, Art not thou past these yet?

Answ. What this One is, he has not named; if this One had been a Quaker, it is
like we should have had his Name in Print: and so this is like the rest of his
Lies. And we do read the Scriptures (if he do mean that to be God's Book) and
also may be some of us have Read other Boo^s, as well as he: and as for his
Scornful Expressions of Proud and Lazy Souls, and Horrible Slighting, these are
the Fruits of his bad Spirit, which he may apply at home. And what good has it
done R. W. all this time, Reading and Studying Books, or God's Book, and bring
forth no better Fruits?

R. W. And thou say; And why do they worship a Dumb Devil in their Dumb
Meetings, and stand still and listen, and lie upon their Beds of Laziness for
Revelations and Notions etc.

Answ. Let the Gentle Reader see, if this be not from R. W's. malicious Spirit.
For first, he has not proved, that we Worship a Dumb Devil in Dumb Meetings;
for he says ( page 64, and 65) That at the General Assembly of the Quakers at
New-port he was stopped by a Woman's Praying and a Man's Praying: Now is not
this a plain Contradiction? and has not R. W. confounded himself here, and his
Evil Birth he has brought forth? We do Wait upon the Lord God in his Spirit
and Light, who Reveals his things unto us by his Spirit: and he does Teach
and Instruct us in the Night-season, and gives us of his Songs, and to stand
still and see our Salvation, and to worship God in the Spirit and Truth, which
thou and the Devil is out of: and to Look unto Jesus, the Author and Finisher
of our Faith. And why do thou scoff at our Listening unto the Lord? for does
not the Lord say; Listen, O ye Isles, unto me, and hearken unto me ye People
afar, for the Lord has called me from the Womb, from the Bowels of my Mother
has he made mention of my Name etc. ( Isai. 49, 1). And as for Lazy
Revelations and Notions, thou must keep that at home, for they are none of
ours; who are Diligent in serving the Lord. And G. F. does not slight any Old
Authors, (who has labored in God's Service, and broken the Ice) as thou
falsely say; but such, as draw People from the Light of Christ within, that
they should see withal, and then stuff People with Old Authors and Lies, which
they Print abroad, as thine is here. And thou say, W. Edm. did frequently
call thee at Newport, Old Man Old Man; which (it seems) thou countest as a
great Disgrace to thee; but that is not to be compared with all thy soul and
ungracious Words in thy Book against us. And do thou see thy self, and how
thou call thy Neighbor White Devil? and what Abusive Names thou have given
to the People of God in scorn called Quakers?

R. W. And thou bring in John Burton (Fol. 206) saying [ It is a Scripture
of the Devil's making, to apprehend Christ within]. G. F. Answers, [If there
be any other Christ, but he who was Crucified, within, he is the False Christ:
and the Scripture holds sorth this, and the Devil never made it; but he and his
Messengers are against it. And he that has not this Christ (that was Crucified
and Risen) within, is a Reprobate; though Devils and Reprobates may talk of him
without.] And R. W. replyeth, p. 66.
and tells a Story of Pagans, Mahometans and Christians and Jews, of their
Dispute about Christ, which is to no purpose.

Answ. The Quakers do acknowledge the Birth, Death and Resurrection of Christ;
and it is to no purpose for thee to allege the contrary (and his Doctrine and
