and is it not come upon some of them, since R. W. writ this Book? And let the
Reader see, if R. W. have touched upon G. F's. Answer, which says, They that
do not bring People to the Light of Christ within, are of Korah and Dathan etc.
and the Priest says; They that bring People to the Light of Christ within, are
as Korah, Dathan etc. And now, what must we observe from R. W's. and J. B's.
Doctrine? but that They, that turn People from the Light, are not Korah; and
they that Observe, Here R. W. etc. makes the Apostle Korah, who turned People
from Darkness to the Light, Act. 26, 18.
turn People from the Darkness to the Light, are Korah. So then, the Preachers
of Christ the Light within are Korah; and the Rebellers against the Light of
Christ within are not Korah: and they, that will not believe the Doctrine of R.
W. and the New-England-Priests, must be Korahs, Dathans etc. by them, and must
be Punished, Goods SPOILED, IMPRISONED, BANISHED, WHIPPED, BVRNT in the Hand, and
EARS CVT OFF etc. And are not ye herein worse than Korah? And a great deal more
Railing Language thou have here, not worth the taking notice of.

R. W. Brings George Johnson (from G. F's. Fol. 262.) saying; [ The Americans
were never ordained for Grace and Salvation; p. 93.
and the Grace of God never appeared to the Americans] G. F. Answ. [Which is
contrary to the Scripture, which says; The Grace of God, which brings
Salvation, has appeared unto ALL MEN etc. and, I will give him for a Light and
for a Covenant to the Gentiles, a New Covenant to the House of Israel and
Judah; and that he may be my Salvation to the Ends of the Earth. And many in
America have received Truth and Salvation.] R. W. replyeth; To the Covenant or
Bargain of Ged with Man, First and Secondly, I have spoken, [Thou say, Thou
have spoken; but thou have proved no where in the Scripture, where it is called
a Bargain] And also thou say, Thou have spoken to the Figurative Calling of
Christ to the Jews and Gentiles; and that this blind Soul taking it Literally,
he runs upon the Rocks of the Arminian General Redemption, and the
Universalists General Salvation, and that with a known Contradiction against
their own Foundation of none having any Benefit of Christ, that own not their
Light: as also with a known Contradiction to Experience, which says, The whole
World lies in Wickedness.

Answ. R. W. says, G. F. has contradicted themselves: I say, Nay. For R. W.
says, that G. F. is a blind Soul, and takes Christ the Covenant literally;
for he calls Christ the Covenant Figurative; but he has not proved it by
Scripture, neither told us, what Christ the Covenant Figureth forth? and then
in plain Words contradicts himself (in the same page) saying, Christ is the
Light, the Covenant etc. as the Sun in the Heavens to all the World. And G. F.
does not say, that any are saved; but who believe in the Light, as Christ
commands, and so have Faith in him: this is no Contradiction to Christ our
Foundation. And God says, I will give thee for a Covenant to the people (Esa.
42.) and what THEE is this, if it be not Christ? And, I will give thee for a
Covenant of the people to establish the Earth (Esa. 49.) and thou blasphemously
call this Covenant of Life (which lights every man, that comes into the
World) our New black Image of Light within. R. W. why do thou Blaspheme
against Christ and his Light, which shines in our hearts to give us the
Knowledge of the Glory of God in the Face of Christ Jesus? where was ever any
of the Antichrists and false prophets, thy Forefathers so gross, as to call
the Light of Christ a black Image?

R. W. And thou call the Light of Christ Jesus within a false Light and
Spirit, p. 94.
which we would infect the Indians with.

Answ. What does R. W. and the New-England-Priests preach to the Indians, if it
be not Christ his Light and Spirit? and does the Light of Christ Poison and
Bewitch People with Hellish Sorceries? And what must we understand by R. W's.
Words, but that he draws them from the Light of Christ and his Spirit? but
the Apostle was sent to Open the Eyes of the Blind, turning them from the
Darkness to the Light. And do not they, that Draw People from the Spirit,
bewitch People? read Gal. 3.

R. W. says, What G. F. means by saying, Some in America have received Truth
and Salvation, I can but guess at; it is known, that he owns nothing of God in
the Indians or English, until they bow down to their Idol. --

Answ. Let the Reader see, and consider the Wickedness of this Man against the
Light of Christ and the Grace of God, which G. F. says, has appeared to all
Men, which brings Salvation! and are not the Indians Men? And God has given
Christ for a Covenant of Light to be his Salvation to the Ends of the Earth;
and this Covenant of Light and Grace he enviously calls our Idol, and says,
We own nothing of God in Indians or English. So, let the Reader read my Answer
to G. J. and judge: but such as hate the Light of Christ, which they should
believe in, and turn the Grace of God unto Wantonness, which should teach them,
and bring them Salvation, how should they be saved? Now by this the Reader may
see, what R. W. and the New-England-Priests have brought the Indians and the
People to? seeing, to turn People from Darkness to the Light of Christ, and to
Preach the Grace of God, by which the Saints were saved, Poysoneth and
Bewitcheth People with Hellish Sorcery: and to bow down to Christ the Light and
his Grace, is to bow down to an Idol: as you may see his Blasphemous Doctrine
in his Reply to G. F. And many more Malicious Words are here, which are not
worth the taking notice of.

R. W. Brings John Owen ( G. F. Fol. 263.) saying, [ All Truth concerning God
and our selves is to be learned from the Holy Scripture, the Word of God.] G.
F. Answ. [There was Truth learned, before the Scripture was Written; and the
Scriptures of Truth are the Words of God, which end in Christ the Word: and
there are no Truths learned, but as the Spirit does lead into all Truth. And
many have the Scriptures, but know not Christ and the Truth etc. so he has
thrown out Christ and the Spirit.] R. W. replyeth, and calls it a Childish
Answer, and says, There was Truth (and Spirit, and Christ and Light) before
Scripture. [So here R. W. and J. Owen are in Confusion; they Contradict one
another.] And further R. W. says, That the Scriptures, nor Preaching, nor
Baptism, nor the Supper, nor Afflictions avail, except the Spirit of God set
them home upon us: -- and many have the Scriptures, and yet know not Christ. --
So that this Answer is so Loose and Childish, that none but Fools and Children,
and Frantic Persons can find any Savor in it.

Answ. The Reader may see, how R. W. Contradicts himself. He says, The
Scripture does not avail, except the Spirit of God set it home upon us: and,
Many have the Scripture, and yet know not Christ: and yet, The Scripture is the
Sword, the Only Sword, and is counted the Sword, with which the Lord Jesus
vanquished the Devil; and the Touchstone and Judge, and Tryer of Spirits, and
the Ground of Christ's and the Saints Faith, says R. W. And thou say, This
Choice Sword may be put in a Mad-Man's Hand, whereby he may mischief, and wound
and kill himself and others, ( page 88, 89:) and ( page 94.) he says, The
Scriptures do not avail, except the Power of God set them home upon us; and
confesses, Many have the Scriptures, and not Christ. Now R. W. and ye
New-England-Priests, how can the Scripture, which will not avail without the
Spirit, in the Hand of the Wicked or Madmen, Wound, and Kill themselves and
others, and be the Only Sword and the Means to resist the Devil, and yet will
not avail? which Scriptures they may have, and not know Christ: is this your
Great Orator, that must steer the Church of New-England's Helm? see his
Contradictions. And as for Fools, Childishness, Poison, Frantickness, and no
Savor nor Taste in my Answers, this he might have kept at home with his
Contradictions, with his False Birth, he has struggled to bring forth.

R. W. For further Answer to this thou bidst, Read Owen's Writings, p. 95.
how he proves the Scriptures every Title of them to be the Word of God.

Answ. The People of God called Quakers never denied, the Scripture to be a
Declaration of the Will or Mind of God; and so R. W's. and Owen's Work is
Childish and Vain, to prove that against the Quakers, which they never denied,
but maintain. And Owen and R. W. how comes it to pass, that you have not
written against the English Schoolmaster (which does not tell us, that the
Scripture signifies the Word; but the Scripture signifies Writing) and put it
down, and called it in before now?

R. W. Thou bringst Samuel Palmer (from G. F's. Fol. 264.) saying, [ The State
of the Soul in this Life is threefold; Creation, Corruption and Regeneration..]
G. F. Answ. [In Regeneration the Life is changed from the Life which is in the
Fall. So Regeneration and Corruption is not one in the New Life.] R. W.
Replyeth and says, Regenerations and Corruptions are not one in the New Life.

Answ. But must they have this New Life, while they be upon the Earth, without
Corruptions? if so, then how have the Saints a Battle and a Warfare all their
days? (as in thy page 68.) is not this a Contradiction?

R. W. says, What a foul Trick is this of a False Man, to impute this to his
Opposite, which he abhors. I guess, or he means, that in Regeneration there
is a Perfection, and no Sin or Corruption left.

Answ. Do thou Abhor (and J. O.) a Sinless Regeneration without Corruption
and Sin? what Regeneration is that, that must have Sin, Corruption and
Imperfection, and what are People Regenerated from? and are not they
Regenerated and Born again, etc.

R. W. Thou say; Hence the poor Frantic Souls cry out, that the Protestants
plead for Sin Term of Life.

Answ. Do not thou make it good, and maintainest a Battle betwixt Flesh and
Spirit all the Days? (page 68.) and how therefore can thou call us Poor
Frantic Souls, for declaring that, which thou maintainest? And bring Paul
to prove it; when Paul tells thee, The Law of the Spirit of Life has made
him free from the Law of Sin and Death ( Romans 8.) and that he had Fought a good
Fight, and kept the Faith: then he was not FIGHTING, when he had FOVGHT; nor
Crying, nor Complaining, nor Wailing (as thou say from Romans 7.) And call
us Foolish, poor Souls, with Simple Answers; and this thou might have kept
at home, who do not understand Paul's Condition: for Paul was not all his
Days Complaining, Crying and Bewailing in that Condition; for he Preached the
Gospel, and bid others to rejoice, and rejoiced himself.

R. W. Thou say, The Devil deals with Us, as Pirates do with Ships; he makes
no Opposition against such he has taken, and is possessed of.

Answ. R. W. Thou and the New-England-Priests might have kept those Railing
Words at home, who do the Devil's Works, not Christ's nor God's. For thou and
they out of the Light of Christ and his Spirit would gather all to your selves;
but Christ is Risen, and is gathering People to God by his Light and Spirit,
that makes thee to rage, whose Ship is split in the Sea.

R. W. So that no question, but the Quakers may be freed from many
Transgressions and Temptations to them, which others are assaulted with.

Answ. But R. W. how can the Quakers be freed from many Transgressions and
Temptations to them, which others are assaulted with, when the Devil deals with
them, as the Pirate with Ships, and he has taken them, and does possess them,
and is possessed of? how can these be freed from Transgressions and Temptations?
do not thou herein Contradict thy self, R. W?

R. W. It is a great Mystery, which neither Jews, Turks, Atheists, p. 96.
Papists or Quakers know, how the Seed of all Grace may be in the Newborn, and
yet the Seed of all Sin.

Answ. This is R. W's. Mystery: but he has not proved it by Scripture, That
the Seed of all Sin is in the Newborn, and the Seed of all Grace; we charge R.
W. and all the New-England-Priests, to make this good by plain Text of
Scripture ( as in his 96 Page). And the Apostle says, If any Man be in Christ,
he is a New Creature: Old things are past away; behold, all is become New (2
Cor. 5): and the Apostle says, Put off the Old Man, which is Corrupt,
according to the deceitful Lusts; and put on the New Man, which after God is
created in Righteousness and true Holiness (Ephesians. 4.): Now, is it not
Blasphemy for R. W. to say, The Seeds of all Sin are in the Newborn, and the
Seeds of all Grace? so R. W. has masht all together. For there are Seeds of
Sin in the Old Man, which is to be Put off: for John says, (1 John 3.)
Whosoever is Born of God, does not commit Sin, for his Seed remains in him,
and he cannot Sin, because he is Born of God. And whosoever is Born of God,
overcomes the World: and this is the Victory, that overcomes the World, even
our Faith. Whosoever is Born of God, Sins not; but he that is begotten of
God, keeps himself, that the Wicked One touches him not. So the Seed of Sins
are not in the Newborn, but in the Old Born, the First Birth in the Flesh,
that persecuteth him, that is Born after the Spirit, like R. W.

R. W. Thou say; The Quakers Pride; they say: We are come to a more Perfect
and Pure Estate, than Paul at First was in, or John, who says, If we Confess
our Sin: and James, who says, In many things we offend all.

Answ. We do know the Apostles First Conversion, and Paul's Crying out of sin;
but that was not the Cry all their life time: If it had, Paul would not have
said, he had Victory and was made free, and had fought a good Fight: and John
would not have said, He that is born of God, overcomes the World: and such,
that had overcome the wicked One, and were strong, and the Word of God abode in
them (1 John 2). And it is true, In many things You offend all; and therefore
we keep to the One thing, Christ Jesus, in whom there is no sin. And John, who
says; If we confess our Sin, he is Faithful and Just to forgive us all our
sins, and cleanses us from ALL unrighteousness: Mark ALL; but this thou have
left out, for it makes against thee. And as for Pride, Ambition, Unbelief,
Unthankfulness, Intemperance, Covetousness, full of rash Anger, bitter
Railings, dreadful Blasphemies against Heaven, R. W. which thou speak of,
thou might have kept it at home, and the Whore wiping her Mouth, for thy
bottle is full of it, and the New England Priests whose fruits do declare it.

R. W. He brings Richard Mayo (G. F. Fol. 275) the Priest's sayings, that
says [ To say, the Gospel is the Power of God, is but a Metaphorical Speech:
and that the Gospel is no more the Power of God, then the Rose-Cake, that lay
in his Window. [But these blasphemous Words R. W. takes no Notice of, nor his
New England Priests, of Priest Mayo's Blasphemy.] G. F. Answ: [The Apostle does
not say so; for the Apostle says, The Gospel is the Power of God unto
Salvation to every one, that believes, in plain Words ( Romans 1.): but let the
Reader read and see in all his Reply, if ever he does confess and own, that the
Gospel is the Power of God to Salvation to every one that believes, as Paul
does ( Romans 1). And we do believe, that his dark Spirit will not suffer him;
though in Words he does confess, that the Gospel is Glad Tidings: but goes
about to prove, that to say, The Gospel is the power of God, is a Metaphorical
Speech; and makes a great Rambling about it over and over, but to no purpose.

R. W. And he says; The Gospel is Christ, it is the Spirit, it is the Light
and God himself etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if there be any of those Words in G. F's answer? But
did not Christ dye for Sinners, and shed his blood for them, and is not this
Glad Tidings? and was it not to Paul? and is it not so to Sinners now?

R. W. And thou tellest, The Devil hates glad News of Christ etc. and tellest
of Kings Proclamations of Pardons or Liberty. p. 97.


Answ. All this does not disprove Paul's Words, the Gospel to be the Power of
God: and thou, that hate the light of Christ within, thou hate- Gospel, as
the Devil does. And we do own, the Gospel is the Glad Tidings preached by the
Apostles and Shepherds, and by us, God's people now, the same Gospel, as ever
it was; though thou and the New-England-priests persecute us for preaching it
freely unto you.

R. W. And thou say (page 96) That the Great Fox, the Devil, who thirst
after the blood of the Quakers -- and (page 95.) thou say; The Devil deals
with the Quakers as Pirates do with Ships; he makes no Opposition against such
he has taken and he possesses, and is possessed of.

Answ. R. W. Do not thou here contradict thy self? how does he thirst after
blood, when he has possessed them? as thou wicked-and lyingly say.

R. W. And thou say, If our Gospel be hid, it is hid to them that are lost:
p. 98.
and bring'st 2 Cor. 4. In whom the God of this World has blinded their minds
-- and believe not etc.

Answ. If the outward Writings be the Gospel, not the Power of God, that Gospel
or Bible, which be Writings, are not hid. It is the Power: for Unbelievers have
the Scriptures or the Writings and Persecutors, that have the Form, and deny
the Power, the Gospel: and a Condemned Person may see an outward pardon. And
therefore the Gospel, it is the Power of God, which opens the blind Eyes,
which the God of this World has blinded: and so does not the Scripture, for
that is not hid. And the Light, that shines in the heart, gives the knowledge
of the Glory of God in the face of Christ Jesus, of his Gospel (2 Cor. 4.) And
a many Stories and Ill-favored language thou have in this Reply, not worthy to
be taken notice of; of the Devil and Atheist etc.

R. W. thou bring'st Daniel Gawdry (G. F. fol. 282.) saying [ The Saints were
come to the Spirits of Just Men made perfect, but not on Earth.] G P's Answ.
[The Just Men's Spirit, that led them to give forth the Scriptures, was the
Spirit of God, and that was Perfect (which perfected them) and was, while they
were upon the Earth, the Saints were come to, (which was Christ, the End of all
Words) and so to God, the Judge of all the World.] R. W. replyeth, [but let the
Reader see, what a lame and pitiful Reply it is.] He tells us of the Spirit's
being in Prison (1 Pet. 3.) He tells of Mary's Spirit rejoicing in God her
Savior, Opposite to the Spirits of the Wicked in the Old World ( that Peter
tells of) now in Prison.

Answ. Let the Reader see, if it be G. F's. Answer, that says, That Mary
Magdalen's Spirit, with which she praised God, was the same with them in the
Wicked World in the days of Noah? but Peter does not say, that these Wicked
Spirits in the Old World are in prison NOW; he has added this to Peter's words
(as you may see 1 Pet. 3.)

R. W. Thou say; The Spirit of God (Heb. 12) speaks not of the Bodies of
the Saints neither Con-joyned, nor a Part: nor 2dly, of the Righteous made
Perfect; but the Spirits of (First) the Righteous. Therefore it seems to hold
forth not a Perfect State of the Saints in this Life consisting of Spirit and
Body, which our Proud Boasters say of themselves etc. nor (Secondly) in the
Estate of the Saints in the World to come.

Answ. What is this to G. F's. Reply? and why does not he speak plainly,
Whether the Saints are come to Mount Zion, the City of the Living God, the
Heavenly Jerusalem, to an Innumerable Company of Angels, unto the Church of the
Firstborn in Heaven, unto God the Judge of all, and to the Spirits of Just Men
made Perfect? And can any come hither without the Spirit of God? seeing thou
say, That the Scripture speaks of the Spirit of God nothing at all, but of
the Spirits of Men? So, the Question lies here, Whether or no the Saints do
come, while they are upon the Earth, to the Just Men's Spirits made Perfect, and
to God the Judge of all, and to the Heavenly Jerusalem, the City of the Living
God? For the Apostle says, Ye are come hither, YE ARE COME; and the Apostle
and the Saints were alive upon the Earth, when he spoke this. And thou make a
jumble about the Saints Bodies, and say, We are proud Boasters: and we never
said of ourselves, that we were Perfect of our selves; but perfect by Christ,
who does perfect for ever by one Offering them that are Sanctified (Heb. 10,
14.) mark, them that are Sanctified. And we do own the States of the Saints in
this World, and the States in the World to come, Life Everlasting: and so we
can truly turn thy lies back again, seeing they are not ours. -- And the Spirit
in the Apostles encourages the Saints to Perfection: and the Apostle says, he
spoke Wisdom amongst them that are perfect (1 Cor. 2). And, Be ye Perfect, and
of good Comfort (2 Cor. 13). Let us, as many as be perfect (Phil. 3, 12); and (
Col 1) their work was, that they might present every man perfect in Christ
Jesus: so the Imperfection was in Old Adam. That ye may stand perfect and
complete (Col. 4): how should they stand perfect and complete, if they were not
in it? That the Man of God may be Perfect (2 Timothy 3): and Christ says, Be ye
Perfect, as your Heavenly Father, which is in Heaven, is Perfect: Christ says,
Every one that is Perfect, shall be as his Master (Luke 6). David says, Mark
the Perfect Man (Psalm. 37): and David says, Many shoot in Secret at them that
are Perfect: but if R. W. and the New-England-Priests say, There is none
disseit the Grave to be Perfect, then there is none to shoot at, nor to be
marked at. And Christ says, Be ye Perfect, as your Heavenly Father is Perfect (
Matthew. 5): and Peter says, After you have suffered a while, make you Perfect:
Signifying, that it is Attainable, or else Peter would not have encouraged to
it. And God says, Job was a Perfect Man, and upright, and one that feared God:
and by one Offering has Perfected for ever them that are Sanctified, (Heb. 10,
14). And the Apostle says, An Inheritance amongst them that are Sanctified:
mark, that ARE SANCTIFIED; were not these upon the Earth? the Apostle says, He
that Sanctifies, and they that are Sanctified, are all of One (Heb. 2). And
the Apostle says, I beseech you Brethren, through the Mercies of God, that you
present your Bodies a Living Sacrifice, Holy, and acceptable to God, which is
your Reasonable Service (Romans 12): Now, must not the Saints (R. W.) present
their Bodies thus Holy and a Living Sacrifice to God, while they be upon the
Earth? and how can they present them to God, if they must not be Perfect, but
carry a body of Sin to the Grave? or must they present their Bodies, when they
are Dead? and does not Sin make their Bodies dead, while they be upon the
Earth, before they be dead outwardly? Now, if the Spirit of Christ, that raised
him from the Dead, dwell in you, he that raised up Christ from the Dead, shall
quicken your Mortal Bodies: and this we witness. ( Romans 8.)

R. W. Thou ask, What Truth is in these Words, Christ is the End of all
Words? p. 99.
and further thou say, The truth is, their horrible, unclean and foul Spirit
would fain be rid of all Scripture-words and Learning also, that he may bring
the more of miserable mankind ( under the Cheating sound of Light) into his
Eternal Darkness.

Answ. R. W. that is thy own Condition, with the Cheating sound of Light, and
these reviling Words of thine I abhor. And the Scripture Words we own, and all
true Learning of that which is Good, both Natural and Spiritual: but thou
would rid the Spirit and Light out of the Peoples Hearts (if thou could)
who hate, and grievest and vexest it in thy self; and so railest against
them, that walk in it. And I tell thee, Christ is the End of all these Words
that are spoken of him, and does fulfill them: and that is my Meaning, if thou will have a Meaning.

R. W. brings Timothy Travers ( G. F. Fol. 325.) saying, [ God has Ordained
to Eternal Life all that shall be saved, before they had a Being in the World:
but none comes to Possession of this Salvation, but through the Obedience of
the Spirit.] G. F. Answ. [The Ground of Man's Belief and Obedience is Christ,
who does Enlighten him to the Intent, that he might Believe and Obey the Truth.
And who knows the Seed. knows the Election, before the World was made.
etc.] R. W. replyeth, and says, If he means, that Christ is the Ground or
Author, the Giver of Repentance and Faith to all the Elect, whom God the Father
has given him, we say so.

Answ. You say so in Words, but not in the Faith and in the Repentance; if you
did, we should have Unity with you; for, who should be the Author of Faith, and
Caller and Giver of Repentance, but Christ Jesus?

R. W. Thou say; But if he put in their Invented Light in the Room of God's
Election and Predestination, as the Efficient and First Cause, p. 100.
and of Christ as the Mediator etc. he speaks Blasphemously of God and of his
Son etc. he is now in the Borough etc. who destroys God's Election, before the
World was, and says, That when a Man Believes, he is Elected, when he is
Predestinate etc. Contrary to all the Precious Beds of Flowers in the Garden of
the Scriptures, etc. Contrary to the Wit and Skill of Men, who frame a Book, or
a House, or a Ship etc.

Answ. Let the Reader see, how R. W. wrongeth G. F's Words, or if there be any
such Words in his Answer to T. T. the great Ranter? But what are all R. W's.
Words, which he has framed here, which are not G. F's? Can a Man know
Election, Ordination, Reprobation or Predestination, or Christ the Mediator
and Redeemer and Savior, without the Light of Christ Jesus? must not he first
be turned from Darkness to Light, and from the Power of Satan to Christ and
God, in whom the Election is before the World began? [In whom the Election is].
And does not Christ command to believe in the Light, and the Light gives him
the Knowledge etc is not this Blasphemy in thee R. W. to say, That I Invent the
Light of Christ, which lights every Man that comes into the World, which is
Life in the Word (Joh. 1)? and ( Romans 8. Ephesians. 1.) those Scriptures we own, as
they speak. And can God's Election be destroyed before the World began? thou
say, Who destroy God's Election, before the World began; I tell thee, that
neither thou, nor the Devil can destroy God's Election, before the World began:
it is like, Thy Election (which is Reprobation) may be destroyed; but God's
Election cannot be destroyed. Is not Christ called the Elect? and are not all
his Saints Elect in him, and dies no more? and they cannot pluck them out of
his Father's Hand? but thy Knowledge of this is like the Skill of Men framing
of Books, Houses and Ships, which thou call Vanity. -- And as for the
Scriptures, the Light of Christ is not Contrary to them, but owneth them, which
Light and Spirit we are in (blessed be the Lord for ever!) which leads into
all Truth of them.

R. W. Thou say; As to the Seed and Election we know, they make themselves
the Seed and Election. 2. They make Christ the Seed, that is, themselves. 3.
They make God, and the Spirit of God the Seed, the Seed in every Man, which
they Preach to; by them the Imprisoned Seed: and when one turns Quaker, then
God comes out of Prison etc. They make no Distinction between God, and Christ,
and Spirit, and Themselves, as Fox in his Book plainly tells us etc. God
himself is hearkened to; then the Soul so Hearkening becomes God, Deified with
God, and God with God etc. whose Infinite Being and Essence these poor Proud
Bruits have not so much Sight of, as the Devil.

Answ. These Words are R. William's own Blasphemous Words and Forgeries from
his Lying Imaginations: let the Reader see, if there be any such Words in all
G. F's. Book to T. T. the Great Ranter, which R. W. is joined withal against
us. But is not Christ called the Seed? and how the Promise was to the Seed? not
to the Seeds as many, but one? and to thy Seed, which is Christ? ( Gal. 3.) And
is not Christ called the Seeds-man, that sows his Seed upon all Grounds? and
are not these Grounds in the Heart of Man? and were not the Apostles Ministers,
Sowers to the Spirit? and was not the Spirit in Man, of which they reap Life
Eternal? but R. W. and his New-England-Priests, it seems, Sow to the Flesh in
Man, of which they may Reap a great Crop of Corruptions. And is not this Seed
Spiritual, that Christ Sows? but is not the Seed in the Prison in thee, or
under the Clods, which Christ sows, as scorch't or choked, that thou railest
so much at it, where it brings forth Fruits to God (who is a Spirit) in the
Good Ground?

And we do not make Our selves the Seeds-Man, God, and Christ and Spirit, as
thou belyest us; for we make a Distinction, the Lord knows: the Seed teaches
us to deny our selves, and to follow Christ the Seeds-man. And do not I make a
Distinction between God and Christ, when I say often, that God did not dye, but
Christ according to the Flesh? And never did we say, By Hearkening the Soul
became God, or God Deifyed, and God with God; for God, who breathed into Man
the Breath of Life, and he became a Living Soul, is not that part of his
Breath? And when thou have framed a Meaning of thy own Words, which are not of
ours, thou call it our Ignorance, and say, We are fallen, like the fallen
Spirits; and we have not so much Sight as the Devil: and yet ( page 74.) thou
say, That God has endowed me with Excellent Natural Parts, and many of us,
yea with the Light of the Holy Scripture, a Light of Experience and Common
Motions from God's Holy Spirit: so, R. W. see, how thou Confoundest thy self!
But blessed be the Lord, we are in Christ Jesus, who bruiseth the Devil, the
Serpent's Head, who is the Author of these Lies and Forgeries against us in
thee, and they touch us not. And we never said (as thou wickedly say), That
God was in Prison, or comes out of Prison; it is He and his Son, that puts
us out of Prison.

R. W. brings Tim. Trav. the Ranter's Words ( Fol. G. F. 326.) saying, p. 101.
[ The Manifestation of the Spirit is given to every Man in the Church to
profit withal; and not to every Every Man in the World.] G. F. Answ. [The
Manifestation is given to Every Man to profit withal WITHOUT DISTINCTION, the
Apostle says: I will pour out of my S^irit upon ALL FLESH, says the Lord, and
the Spirit of Truth shall lead the Saints into all Truth, and he shall Reprove
the World: and that which Reproves the World, is manifested to the World.] R.
W. replyeth, G. F. is like a Cow with a Kettle on her Head, giving every one
warning to stand clear; he boldly slanders on, and tumbles Heaven, Earth* and
Hell together.

Answ. Let the Reader see, what vain, wild, frothy Words this Old Doting Man
utters forth scornfully, and see if there be any such Words, as his are* in
G. F.'s. Answer? And we do charge R. W. and his New-England-Priests to make
this good by Scripture, and let us see, where it is written, that Heaven,
Earth, and Hell can be tumbled together, according to R. W.'s Doctrine, that he
has Published to the World in Print.

R. W. Thou bring 1 Cor. 12. and Rom: 12. Ephesians. 4. and tell, How God
bestowed Gifts and Endowments on such, whom he pleases, and how he gave his
Gifts and Ministrations to his Church etc. and then thou say; But this
Profane Mouth has something to say for it self: and then thou say; Was this
(as he speaks) without all Distinction done Actually? p. 102.
was it Universally so with all the Individual Men in the World etc? was not
there a wonderful Wall of Separation between Jews and all other Nations? etc.
And further thou say; Thou observest, how vainly this Deluded Soul cheats
himself and others with the Term of All Flesh, Every Man, All the World; and so
with the Term Light, Christ, Spirit etc. and thou ask, Whether all the
Believers had these Gifts, to wit, Prophecies and Fiery Tongues? belong they to
all the Men and Women in the World, who never saw nor heard of any Glimps of
the Sun of Righteousness? etc.

Answ. The Scriptures (1 Cor. 12. Romans 12. Ephesians. 4.) we own, and the Order and
Practice of the Gifted Men in the Church of God: but the Apostle he makes no
Distinction; he says in plain Words, The Manifestation of the Spirit of God is
given to Every M^n to profit withal (he does not say, Only to the Saints:) So
he makes no Distinction; not only the Saints, the Corinthians. And the
Separation betwixt Jews and Gentiles Christ has broken down, and of Twain
makes One New Man: and does not Christ Enlighten the Jews with his Divine,
Heavenly Light, which is the Life in the Word, as well as the Gentiles, and
says, Believe in the Light? they that Believe in the Light, are One in Christ;
and if not, with the Light they are Condemned? And we do not say, that All the
Churches had the Fiery Tongues etc. there is no such thing in my Answer to T.
T: and so, neither have all the Men and Women in the World these Gifts,
belonging to the Church; how should they, if they hate the Light of Christ's,
and quench and err from his Spirit, and resist the Holy Ghost?

But thou say; The Men and Women in the World have never seen or heard of
any Glimps of the Sun of Righteousness. What! have they never heard of Christ
the Sun of Righteousness? I believe, there is Millions of Men and Women in the
World, that will say, thou art a Liar. For, were not the Apostles to Preach the
Gospel Christ Jesus, the Sun of Righteousness, to all Nations? and does not the
Apostle say, The Gospel was preached to EVERY CREATVRE UNDER HEAVEN, whereof he
was made a Minister? ( Col. 1, 23.) and the Apostle says, Have they not all
heard? YES VERILY ( Romans 10): and the Profane Mouth thou speak with, is thy
own. If they hate the Light of Christ and quench his Spirit, that God has
poured upon them, and erred from his Spirit, then they are not like to See him
indeed; and will not Hear him in the Spirit, and his Light, they will not See
him nor Hear him, like the Pharisees and thou R. W.

And why do thou fret thy self about the Light, and the word ALL and EVERY
MAN? but thy Spirit is the Sect-maker, and would not have ALL nor EVERY MAN,
who art opposite to the Prophets and Apostles Doctrine. Peter says, It shall
come to pass in the last Days, says the Lord, I will pour out my Spirit upon
ALL FLESH (to wit, Sons, Daughters, Young Men, Old Men, Servants, Handmaids)
Joel 2. Act. 2: and John says, This is the true Light, which was Life in the
Word, which lights EVERY Man, that comes into the World. And Paul says to
Titus; The Grace of God, which brings Salvation, has appeared unto ALL MEN:
and Christ bid his Disciples, To go into All Nations to Preach the Gospel unto
Every Creature: and the Apostle says, That the Gospel was Preached unto Every
Creature under Heaven. But R. W. says, Men and Women in the World, who have
never seen or heard of any Glimps of the Sun of Righteousness: and yet thou
say ( page 28.) I find in all Mankind a Conviction, that God is JUST and
Powerful: and again; I find all Men confess, that the Will, or Word or Mind of
God is PVRE: I find, that First, There is Generally in all Mankind in the World
a Conviction of an Invisible, Omnipotent and Eternal Power and Godhead; and (
page 102.) Men and Women in the World have never seen or heard any Glimps of
the Sun of Righteousness, thou say: how now R. W. do not thou Contradict
thy self here? do thou Divide the Word here, as thou accusest me? is this
New-England's Great Orator? And so, as for Unclean Beast, and Proud Fancy, and
Vainly and Wickedly deluding, and Soul-Cheating thou might have kept this in
thy own Bottle.

R. W. Thou say; G. F's 2d. Answer here is, to wit, [The Spirit of God shall
lead the Saints into all Truth] and R. W. says; I observe here, how like a
Skittish Jade this Wild Soul runs in and out etc. before he brings in, the
Spirit of God poured out upon the Common World; and now he brings in, the
Spirit leading the Saints: the next word he concludes, is, Every Man in the
World to have the Spirit etc.

Answ. Do not thou confess, that the Holy Spirit testifies, that he is the
Comforter of the Saints, and is he not the Leader also? and do not thou
confess, that the Spirit is the Reprover of the World? (p. 102, 103.) then,
have not thou made thy self the Skittish Jade thou speak of, and Running in
and out? are not these Unsavory and Unseemly Words out of an Old Man's Mouth,
that professes Christianity? And if the Spirit of Truth does Reprove the
World, and God has poured his Spirit upon All Flesh; then, is not this the
Common World? and if it be upon All Flesh, is not Every Man come into the
World? else how will God Judge the World in Righteousness according to the
Gospel? Thou confessest, [ That the Holy Ghost is a Reprover of the World, and
that he Reproves the World in his Threatenings and Judgments;] and does not he
then Reprove the World for its Unrighteousness, Judgment and Unbelief also? and
if thou did not Resist it, it would Reprove thee for thy Unrighteousness,
False Judgment and Unbelief, as Christ says.

R. W. Do not thou say, The World mocks at this Holy Spirit, p. 103.
Banisheth, Imprisoneth and Murdereth such, in whom the true Spirit of God
appears. And further thou say; It is Lying Peor tells us, That all the
World (without Distinction) have the Manifestation of the Spirit of God to
profit withal. There have been Persons professing the Order of the Holy Ghost,
yet are far from the Savor of the Holy Spirit.

Answ. This is thy own Condition R. W. and thy own New-England-Professors, who
Resist it (as Stephen says Act. 7.) and Mock at it, and BANISH, IMPRISON and
MVRTHER such, in whom the Spirit of God appears: this has been the Practice
of the New-England-Priests and Professors to the Dishonor of Christianity. --
And does not the Apostle say; God will pour out his Spirit upon all Flesh
WITHOUT DISTINCTION, as Peter says? and is not this All the Men and Women of
the World? what Flesh dare say, but they have the Reproofs of God's Spirit,
when they do Ill? except it be such, as R. W. and R. W's. Professors, that
quench it, and have erred from it: so, thou may take thy Lying Peor to thy
self. And so, it is thou, that art resisting and fighting against the holy
Spirit of God. And can any profit in the things of God without the
Manifestation of the Holy Spirit, that is given to profit withal (and Peter and
Paul say) to All flesh, and to Every Man? so it is their Doctrine thou
oppossest, not with the Spirit, but with the dark fleshly mind. And thou
tellest a story of Babilonish Orders, and of Absalom; which if thou did see
that, thy own Condition in the Light of Christ thou hate, it would be better
for thee.

R. W. Thou say; Oh! what Reproofs of God's Spirit has G. F. and others of
their Leaders had in and by so many Excellent Opposites and Scriptures and
Arguments, which G. F. here trampleth under his Profane Feet, without any
Savor of the Spirit of God.

Answ. R. W. thou highly extollest the Ranters here, Tim. Trav. the great
Ranter, one of our Opposites: but thou have manifest thy Spirit, and what thou
take part with-al against the People of God. And we have a Savor of the Holy
Spirit of God, and in it can Savor our Opposites or Old Persecutors Spirits
not to be of Christ: and it has been the Evil Spirit, is in thee and them,
that has stroven against us. And we know, you may bring Scripture to a wrong
End, as the Devil did to Christ; and the Lord has given us Power over the
Devil's Spirit, blessed be his Name for ever! and he has blasted it, and
brought down, which was up in Oliver's Days, that Persecuting Spirit. And we do
own the Scriptures, let^it be out of whose Mouths it be: though we cannot own
their Meanings, nor have Unity with such, as hold up the Truth in
Unrighteousness. And as for Trampling, we trample nothing that is good, under
our Feet, that is thy own Condition: but we do own the Appearance of God in all
People -- But R. W. thou say; Without any Savor of the Spirit of God: and
yet thou say; I find in all Mankind a Conviction, that God is Just and
Powerful: and, I find Generally in all Mankind a Conviction of an Invisible,
Omnipotent and Eternal Power and Godhead; yet thou say, Without any Savor
of the Spirit of God: read ( page 28. 102.) thy Contradiction. -- And thou
say; It pleases God to strive with Men by Preaching: but not by such, as
thou and the New-England-Priests are, that stir up the Punishment, Persecution
and HANGING.

R. W. Thou ask, Why David complains (Psalm. 53.) that all the Children of
Men, not one excepted, are Unprofitable etc. are Abominable to Spiritual
Matters and Heavenly Things, p. 104.
(and further thou say) until the Spirit of God comes, and truly change the
Heart and whole Frame of Nature: until then we are as profitable as Hogs and
Moles in a Garden etc. and as devouring Foxes amongst the true Lambs and
Chickkins of Christ Jesus.

Answ. R. W. thou have writ thy Condition and the New-England-Priests there, to
wit, the Devouring Foxes (and Hogs) of the Lambs of Christ and his Chickkins.
For mark the Word, UNTIL the Spirit of God change their Hearts etc. and we
believe, your Hearts and Natures are not changed, but you are Unprofitable: for
how can it be, when thou say, There is no Voice nor Motion within in
Heavenly things in Matters of Supernatural Light to hearken to, to turn to, to
listen to? (p 83.) -- And was David's Complaint of the Children of Men
Unprofitable? -- And does not David bid, All that has Breath, praise the Lord?
and how can they Praise the Lord, if there be nothing of the Spirit of God in
them? And do not they quench that, which God has manifested in them, which God
has shown unto them, and which convinces them of an Invisible and Omnipotent
and Eternal Power and Godhead? so, is not this Conviction of the Spirit of God
in them? and will not the Lord pour out his Wrath upon all the Heathen, that
call not upon his Name? And now, is there not a further Manifestation in these
Last Days by Christ, who Enlightneth every Man, that comes into the World? and
the Grace of God, which brings Salvation, has appeared to All Men? and God
pours out his Spirit upon All Flesh? but from this Spirit, Grace and Light in
all Men thou art erred from, and can not endure to hear of it.

R. W. Brings Hugh Archbal ( G. F. Fol. 328.) saying, [ Christ does Enlighten
none, but those that do receive him.] G. F. Answ. [Contrary to John 3. which
speaks of them, that hate the Light, and are Enlightened, and will not come to
it, because the Light will Reprove them: so he, that hates the Light, is
Enlightened, and will not Receive Christ.] To which R. W. replyeth (and after
his wonted manner, p. 105.
with foul Expressions) and says; G. F. abuses 2 Cor. 4. and says: Joh. 1.
is not Enlightneth, but Lighted; and the word (...) may signify both, etc. They
which hate the Light, are Enlightened, no question, but with the General Offer
of Mercy, as of a Candle or Sun to the Eyes of a Blind Man, which is yet their
Condemnation etc. And before thou say, There is a Higher Light, which some
are affected, tinctured and Enlightened with, and yet not the True and Saving
Light; that in Heb. 6. where some Persons (as the pretended Quakers etc.) have
seen much of the Nature of God, of his Holiness and Justice etc. and had a Taste
of the Joys of the Next World.

Answ. If ENLIGHTENING and LIGHTED signify both, then do not oppose it. And here
thou confessest, They that hate the Light, are Enlightened, as well as the
Believers in the Light; it is the same Light: but thou say, It is a General
Offer, as a Candle or the Sun to the Eyes; That is an Outward Light, and a
Blind Man can neither see Candle nor Fire: and so that which he does not see,
is his Condemnation, according to thy Doctrine. But is this according to
Christ's Words? ( Joh. 3.) are his Words no more, than a General Offer, as a
Candle or the Sun to the Eyes of a Blind Man? for Christ says? One Hates the
Light, and the other Loves the Light, and brings the Deeds to the Light,
that they may see, they are wrought in God: so that is not Natural, which
gives the Knowledge of God, which shines in his Heart (as in 2 Cor. 4. which
I do not abuse; but it is thou, that abusest it). And Christ says, This is the
Condemnation, the Light is come in the World, and Men love Darkness rather than
the Light, because their Deeds be evil: here Christ gives the Reason; for the
Light discovers the Darkness, and their evil Deeds, or else how should they
know them. For Every one, that does evil, hates the Light (mark, Every one)
neither comes to the Light, least his deeds should be reproved: and so by the
Light he knows this Evil Deeds, and knows he does Evil, and knows he
hates it: and that is his Condemnation. And this is more, than a Candle or the
Sun to the Blind Man's Eyes, that cannot see it: and every one, that does the
Truth, comes to the Light; so it is the same Light, that he that does Evil,
hates, and he that does the Truth, loves: and this is the Light of Christ.
And how dare thou say, the Light was or is not Saving (Hebr. 6)? was not the
Holy Ghost Saving? and the Word of God Saving? or, is not the Word of God
Sufficient to reconcile to God? and the Holy Ghost Sufficient to lead into all
Truth? But thou say; In Hebr. 6. the higher Light, which enlightneth; and
yet not the True and Saving Light: we charge thee to make this good (and all
the New England priests) by the Scripture, That the Light (spoken of in Hebr.
6.) is not the True and Saving Light? it is like, thou never tryed'st it. But
thou art such as they, that are fallen away from the good Word of God; and
resist the Holy Ghost, and become a Hater of this Light; though thou have
tasted of the Gift: and Crucifiest the Son of God a fresh to thy self, as the
New-England-priests, and put him to open shame; and then HANG, punish and
persecute others, where he is manifest. I tell you, your Earth bears Thorns
and Briars: and read, what will be your End. ( Heb. 6.)

R. W. brings James Dorram, saying [ The Believer is not in Sin, p. 106.
as the Unbeliever is; he sins not, as the Unbeliever does.] And in another
place he says [ That the Law is the same to the Believers, that it is to the
Unbelievers.] G. F. answers ( Fol. 330.) [Here any may read thy Confusion:
but I say unto thee, He that believes, does not commit Sin; but Unbelief is
Sin ( Romans 12, 20). And Christ is the End of the Law to every one that
believes, for Righteousness sake ( Romans 10, 4): and yet thou put both
Believers and Unbelievers under the power of the Law.] R. W. replieth and
tells, How the Devil sins, and Saul and Judas, and Robbers, and
Murderers; (and says) It is not so with the Regenerate or Newborn.

Answ. who says, it is? But thou say, That the Seed of all Sin is in the
Newborn ( Append. page 96.) and here thou say, They can no more touch Sin,
( unless deceived or circumvented) then Fire can delight in Water, or Light in
Darkness. How is all their Seeds in the Newborn then, if it does not touch
them? for mark, thy words are, In the Newborn. For the Newborn are born of
the Spirit, are they not? Newborn Babes are born of the Immortal Seed of God:
how proves R. W. (with the New-England-priests) that all the Seeds of Sin are
in the Newborn, and yet it does not touch them, no more then Fire can delight
in Water?

R. W. And further thou say, That the Protestants have proved from the
Scripture and Experience of all true Saints, p. 107.
that Sin and Grace, the Flesh and Spirit, the Law of the Spirit and the Law of
Sin may and do continue in the Regenerate or Newborn; contrary to that proud
Perfection of Papists and Quakers in this Life, etc. And G. F.'s silly Shift,
saying, that Paul was perfect, and thanketh God for Victory, etc.

Answ. We never read in the Scripture of such a Doctrine, till R. W.
New-England's Orator, has published it, That Flesh and Spirit and the Law of
Sin should be in the New Birth in this Life. This is contrary to the Apostle;
for he says, With his mind he served the Law of God, but with the flesh, the
Law of sin; so, this was in the Flesh or Old Man Unmortified or put off: so
this Law of Sin and Flesh and Spirit was not in the Regenerate part or
New Birth (as Doting R. W. says) but in the contrary Birth, the Old Man. And
Paul did cry out, Wretched man, who shall deliver him: and he saw no Man, but
Christ Jesus; and thanketh God through him, who gave him the Victory: and was
not Paul Perfect, when he said; As many as are perfect, be thus minded? But why
cannot R. W. read as well Romans 8. as Romans 7. where the Apostle says; There is
no Condemnation to them, that are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the
Flesh, but after the Spirit: and the Law of the Spirit of Life makes him free
from the Law of Sin and Death: so the Apostle says, he was a free Man from the
Law of Sin and Death; but R. W. gives him the lie, and says, There is a
Combat with the Law of Sin in the Newborn in this Life. And, so as for
Silliness and Ignorance of the Saints Life R. W. and his New England professors
and priests may keep at home.

R. W. And thou say: They are to strive after Perfection and Holiness, etc.
as a Child going after his Father, the Scholar or Maidens following their
Copies and Samplers, though they never come near the full Exactness and
Perfection of them.

Answ. R. W. does confound Reason among men, and Short of the Truth. What!
shall the Scholar never learn his Lesson, nor the Maidens learn their Samplars,
to be as perfect as their Masters and Teachers? So, the Children shall never
come to an Exact Perfectness of Copies and Samplars, nor a Child never to come
to go, as his Father does? nor to be in the Strength and Knowledge of outward
things, as his Father? then what do all these learn their Copies and Samplars
for, if they never be to come near the full Exactness and Perfection of them?
But what shall we understand from R. W.'s Words and Doctrine in this? That
they, that learn of Christ, shall not be perfect, as their Heavenly Father is
Perfect, Should Christ Command that, which is Impossible to be attained to?
as Christ commands? and that the Saints shall not be sanctified throughout
Body, Soul and Spirit, whilst they be upon Earth? and, That Christ does not
sanctify his Church without Spot or Wrinkle and Blemish, or any such thing, and
present them to God, as on this side the Grave (as Ephesians. 5)? But what does R.
W. and the New England priests say to John (1 John 2); He that abides in
Christ, ought himself even also to walk, as Christ walked? and in another
place: So as he is, so are we in this present World? but let the Reader see,
what a silly Reply he has given to G. F. here; he speaks nothing of Romans 10.
and 11. to the contradicting of them, that which G. F. has asserted.

R. W. brings in (from G. F.'s fol. 338) John Nasmith (Priest from Scotland)
saying [ That the Evil Spirits are both Sinful and Reasonable] G. F. answers,
p. 108.
[This is a Lie: for Reasonable is not Sinful; Unreasonable is Sinful (1 Thessalonians.
3): They have not the Faith. And if the Evil Spirit be Reasonable, and the Good
Spirit, they are both One: who then is Unreasonable, if the Evil Spirit be
Reasonable? Thou put no Difference betwixt the precious and the vile: thou
have the Mark of a blind Guide, and of a false Prophet in thy Forehead.] R. W.
Replieth and begins with Railing, and says; First, The filthy, rash Fury of
his Mind and Pen -- and says, 2dly, This proud Pharisee will appear to be a
Sadducee also, and to bold no Angels nor Spirits. It Is true, they pretend to
own Scripture, Christ and Resurrection, they with the Jesuites-Equivocations
name Angels and Spirits; but the bottom (as some of them, and that in Print,
discover) is, They hold, there is but one Spirit, which is in all, into which
all return; and the Soul of Judas is as Happy, as the Soul of Peter.

Answ. Reader, this is nothing to G. F.'s Answer; neither has he, nor can he
make out any of these False Charges, which he has forged (which be not our
Words) against us: and therefore we can say, When he speaks a Lie, he
speaks of himself, and is the Father of it. For, where did ever any read in
any of our Books, or, is there any thing in G. F.'s Answer, that we hold, There
is but One Spirit in Man? R. W. and the New-England-Priests, have not we often
told you, that you have vexed, and grieved and quenched the Spirit of God? And
we never said, That Judas's Soul was as Happy, as Peter's; it was not like: for
Peter had fed the Lambs of Christ; and Judas betrayed him to the Chief Priests,
as thou art doing now in his Saints, who have Crucified him to thy self a
fresh. And Christ, and Scripture and Resurrection we own according to Scripture
Really, without any Pretense or Equivocation; that is thy own Condition. And R.
W. thou say, They hold neither Angel nor Spirit: then again thou say;
There is but One Spirit, and that in all: And all in one Sentence confoundest
thy self. And so, as for Silly, Rash Fury of Mind and Pen, thou might have
kept this at home.

R. W. Thou say; A Man is a Reasonable Creature, as opposite to a Woolf and
Fox etc. and yet he may be Unreasonable in his Actings, as a Woolf and Fox:
who, though Unreasonable in their Natures, are not Sinful, though a Plague to a
Man, since his Fall.

Answ. Let the Reader see, what a Silly Reply R. W. brings here to G. F.'s.
Answer to J. N. G. F. does not speak of Wolves and Foxes Unreasonableness; but
he speaks of Men, that have not Faith, are Unreasonable, and that have Faith,
are Reasonable: and the Priest J. N. maintains, that Evil Spirits are Sinful
and Reasonable; which R. W. says nothing unto, but tells us of Wolves and
Foxes, though Unreasonable, yet not Sinful, that have been a Plague to Man
since the Fall: and falls a Railing. And who knows not, that a Man is a
Reasonable Creature, and opposite to a Woolf and Fox? and his Actings
Unreasonable, like a Woolf or Fox, out of the Faith of Christ, as thou and the
New-England-Priests and Professors have done to the People of God, and Herod,
and the Chief-Priests against Christ and his Apostles.

R. W.) Oh! Happy were it for G. F. that he had been a Wild Fox in the Woods,
and had not been so Sinful, by so horribly abusing so great a Talent of Wit and
Reason, which the Father of Lights has given him! [and yet Knows no more,
than a Parret? p. 35.]

Answ. And why would R. W. have G. F. to have been a Wild Fox in the Woods?
because he would not follow his Imaginations, and such like in others, but
follows Christ Jesus? and he is his Prophet, his Bishop and Shepherd,
Counselor and High Priest. But R. W. thou say; G. F. has so great a Talent
of Wit and Reason, which the Father of Lights has given him: but it is thou,
that so Sinfully and Horribly abusest it, not he. And then thou Contradictest
thy self, and say ( page 87.) They cry out Light, Light, and there is none (
as Isaiah speaks) not a Spark of Light within them: and here thou abusest
Isaiah; for Isaiah does not speak so ( Isa. 8.) as let all read. And thou
may see in the Margin, There is no Morning in them: and there are many Stars
Outwardly, before people comes to the Morning; and is it not so Inwardly, as
it is Outwardly? But do not thou deny the Prophecy of Isaiah of Christ, who
says, I give him for a Covenant of Light to enlighten the Gentiles? I must
tell thee, we Gentiles have received this Light according to John's Witness,
who Enlightneth every man, that comes into the World, Christ Jesus. And page
100. R. W. says, These poor proud Bruits have not so much sight of, as the
Devil, (to wit, of God): and page 108, So great a Talent of Wit and Reason,
which the Father of Lights has given him, etc. so here R. W. New-England's
Mouth and Orator may see, how he contradicts himself.

R. W. says, We know the Nature of the Devils, Admirable Wit and Reason, as
well as the Power of those Unclean Spirits the Lord Jesus Christ cast out, they
did believe and confess the Lord Jesus Christ etc. and, This their Knowledge
and Ability is from God; though their Sinful Hardness by God's Just Sentence
runs them upon such mad and desperate Courses: as it is with the Sons of Men,
when the most holy Judge deliveres them up to the Counsels and Projects of
their Proud and Deceitful hearts and Spirits.

Answ. R. W. thou have spoken thy own Belief, and the Belief of New-England's
priests and professors; and the Practice of your proud, deceitful hearts and
Spirits has manifested themselves. But R. W. is the Unclean Spirits, their Wit
and Reason so Admirable with thee? and thou say, Their Knowledge and Ability
is from God: but where did ever Christ and the Apostle say so? For Christ (will thou give him the Lie?) he says, He was a Murderer from the beginning, and he
abode not in the Truth, because there is no Truth in him; and when he speaks
a Lie, he speaks it of his own ( mark, not from God) for he is a Liar, and
the Father of it, (Joh. 8, 44.) Now, I query from R. W. and the New England
Priests, Note: Is not this a Ranters Principle of R. Was?
What Knowledge and Ability has the Devil from God, and what Admirable Wit and
Reason, seeing Christ says, There is no Truth in him? and what Wit and Reason
can a Murderer have, which Christ calls a Murderer from the Beginning? And he
that is called a Murderer from the Beginning, thou allowest Admirable Wit and
Reason, and say, you know it: and say; that their Knowledge and Ability
is from God: If from God, it must be Truth; and Christ tells thee, There is
no Truth in him. And it is like, R. W. and the New-England-priests have more
Knowledge and Acquaintance with the Devil and Unclean Spirits, than with God
and Christ Jesus, and your Belief and Confession is like theirs. And though the
Devil did Confess the Son of God, yet this was not Truth in the Devil; but in
the Son of God; for in the Devil is no Truth: and if there be no Truth, there
can be no true Reason; and Reason does not run into mad and desperate Courses,
as thou say, the Evil Spirits run into. And have the Saints their Knowledge
and Abilities from God; and the Devils their Knowledge and Abilities from God
too? but is not the Devil's Knowledge and Ability, Wit and Reason, SIN and
EVIL, seeing Christ says, There is no Truth in him? then how is the Truth in
his Knowledge and Abilities, Admirable Wit and Reason? seeing, when he speaks
a Lie, he speaks of his own; for he is a Liar, and the Father of it: so his
Abilities, nor Wit nor Reason is not from God. And he abode not in the Truth,
because there is no Truth in him: then what can all his Abilities and
Knowledge, Admirable Wit and Reason be? And Christ destroys the Devil and his
Works: what! does Christ destroy Admirable Wit and Reason, and the Knowledge
and Ability, that is from God? no surely, that was out of the Truth, in whom
there was no Truth, whom Christ the Truth destroys, the Liar, the Murderer,
who abode not in the Truth.

R. W. Brings Henry Foreside, a Scotch Priest ( G. F. Fol. 345.) saying,
[Concerning those Words of Ezekiel. 18, 28. If the Righteous Man turn away from
his Righteousness, p. 109.
his Former Righteousness shall be no more remembered: and he said, The Meaning
of that Scripture was, They thought, they had been Righteous, and were not; but
supposed, they had been so.] G. F. Answ. [Here-in thou art a Minister of
Unrighteousness, and thou go about to make God a Liar, and the Prophets, and
pervertest the Scripture. For, if he forsake his Righteousness, and commit Sin
and Iniquity, and trespass, he shall die, and not live in the Righteousness;
but if he forsake his Sins, Trespasses and Transgressions, in the
Righteousness, that he has done and does, he shall live: (and so God's Ways
are Equal, Ezekiel. 18.) And thou say; They thought, they had been Righteous;
but it was not so. And the Lord by his Prophets said, It was so, that he should
live in the Righteousness; and die, if he departed from it, and transgressed:
here thou art a Diminisher from the Prophets and Apostles Words, whose Name is
to be diminished out of the Book of Life, Rev. 22, 19.] -- R. W. replyeth, and
says; The Question is about Falling away from Saving Grace and Righteousness:
wherein it is notorious, that the Quakers etc. And then thou go on, and
tellest of a Story of the Papists, Pope and Arminians, [which thou had better
kept at home, or gone and told them to their Faces.] And further thou say;
That the Quakers maintain, that the least, that hearken to the Light, are Born
again: they that are Born again, cannot sin; and that they which cannot sin,
are Pure, as God is Pure. And therefore they Falling away from them, they must
necessarily hold that which is Blasphemous, and that God himself may fall from
Grace etc. being kept down, as a Cart laden with Sheaves (perverting
Scriptures) by Wickedness and wicked Spirits, which are too hard for God, and
Christ and Spirit in all the Men and Women in the World, that do not hearken to
their Feigned Light. etc.

Answ. Here are a many Horrid Lies of R. W.'s that he has invented and forged:
and let the Reader see, if there be any such Words in G. F.'s Answer, or any of
their Books; and does not say, as thou say God can fall from Grace (who is
the GOD OF ALL GRACE): which is thy own Blasphemy, and Evil Consequence, not
ours: but as the Apostle says, The Grace of God has appeared unto all Men.
And they, that walk despitefully to the Spirit of Grace, and turn it to
Wantonness, do not they fall from it? (as in Jude:) and we charge thee, to make
it good by Scripture, for there is no such thing in G. F's. Answer. And we do
not pervert the Scriptures: and it is wickedness in thee to say, The wicked
Spirits are too hard for Christ, his Spirit and Light in Men and Women; etc.
but, as the Scripture says, such as thou do quench the Spirit, and vex and
grieve it, and may imprison Christ in his members, who Crucify him a fresh to
your selves. And as for thy Scoffing Words, Hearkening to their feigned Light,
and let loose the imprisoned God and Christ, These are thy own Blasphemous
words, not ours: for let the Reader see, is there any such Expression, as a God
in Prison, in G. F^'s words, or the Scripture either? though the Lord by his
Prophet speaks, how he was laden, like a Cart with Sheaves. And do not thou
Scoff and Mock at such, as hearken to the Light of Christ, who is the Light of
the World, and enlightneth every one, that comes into the World? I tell thee,
this Light will be thy Condemnation. And the Light, and the Spirit and Holy
Ghost, which thou art erred from and resists, the Evil Spirits are not too hard
for it; but it will be too hard for thee and them in the End, thou shall know
it, when thou and they are Judged and Condemned by the Spirit and Light.

And do not thou give the Prophet Ezekiel the Lie? did not they fall from
Righteousness (in Ezekiel) that forsook it, and committed Iniquity? did not
they dye, and not live? and do thou tell God and his Prophet, It is
notorious, that they fell from Righteousness? and do thou tell the Apostle,
It was notorious, they fell from Saving Grace, who turned it into wantonness,
and walked despitefully against the Spirit of Grace? And does not Christ say,
He that believes in the Light, becomes a Child of Light? and John says; He
that believes, is born of God: and whosoever is born of God, does not commit
Sin; for his seed remains in him, and he cannot Sin, because he is born of
God: in this the Children of God are manifest, and the Children of the Devil:
Is not this Scripture (1 John 3.)? And, He that is born of God, overcomes the
World: so, does not he overcome the Sin, (1 John 5.)? and he that does
Righteousness, is not he Righteous, as he is Righteous? and he that commits
Sin, is of the Devil: let no man deceive you. (1 John 3, 7.) And does not
Christ say; Be ye perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect? And what! must
all these Scriptures be denied, and say, They are not Attainable in this life?

R. W. Thou tell of the Imputed Righteousness of God in Christ (Ezekiel. 18.),
p. 110.
Of the Sanctifying Righteousness in Christ, and of an Indians Righteousness,
and of ^ Civil Righteousness, and of a Pharisaical Righteousness, etc.

Answ. What is all this to the purpose? for the Righteousness, that Ezekiel
spoke of; was the Righteousness of the Law, which they were to do, and live-in
in their time: and where does the New Testament speak of Two Righteousnesses,
of Christ and the Foolish Virgins? make this good by Scripture R. W. And
Christ's Righteousness does exceed the Scribes and Pharisees Righteousness, or
the Indians either, that may free them from Outward Crimes: and for the Foolish
Virgins Righteousness, who make a fair Show of the Building upon the Rock
without Light, thou might have kept at home.

R. W. And thou say, Adam shall live, if he keep his Bargain: so shall all
his Posterity, if they keep the first Covenant.

Answ. Did not God give Adam Power and Dominion over all that he made? and when
he bad him to subdue the Earth, did not he give him power to subdue it? and
charged him, that he should not Eat of the Tree of the Knowledge of Good and
Evil? And did not God pour out his Spirit upon the House of Israel, to whom he
gave his Statutes, and commands and bid them to live in them? and were not
God's ways Equal? and when they Erred from the Spirit, and Rebelled against it,
did not they cast the Law of God behind their backs, and forsook the Lord? And
did not the Apostle say, I through the Law am dead to the Law? and the
Righteousness of the Law was fulfilled in him; and he did not make the Law of
none Effect? but where does the Scripture call the Law of God or his Command a
Bargain? Now, do not you Christians cast the Law of Life, which is in Christ
Jesus, which makes free from the Law of Sin, behind your backs, saying; None
can be made free, while they live upon the Earth?

R.W. Thou fall'st a railing, and say: Does this Face of Brass, who has so
horribly slighted the Scriptures, now adore them? p. 111.
is he so zealous for them, and against the Violation of them? etc. Does he not
throughout all his Book, and all of them in Word and Writing deny the
Scriptures to be the Word of God? and only that Frantic Light of Christ
(imagined by them to be in all Mankind) to be the only Word of God? yea, is it
of any use or more Value to them, that have the Scriptures in their hearts, as
they say, then a Dead Letter, and an Old Almanac? etc. and thou say, They
undermine the Scriptures.

Answ. As for Face of Brass, R. W. might have kept for himself his Face of
Brass and Frantic Spirit he speaks of: we do not in no place in any of our
Books or Writings (as the Reader may see) deny, undermine or slight the
Scriptures; but do esteem them with the Spirit, that led the Holy Men, that
gave them forth, who learned them of God. And they are called the Words of God;
and Christ is the Word of God, who lights every man, that comes into the
World, with the Light, which is the Life in the Word. And this we must own, if
we own God, and Christ and the Scriptures; and are not a shamed of it before
men, to wit, of- Christ the Light, which lights every man, that comes into
the World: which thou call Blasphemously that Frantic Light or Christ; but
Roger, it will be thy Condemnation. -- And we never compared the Scriptures
with an Old Almanac, or esteemed them so, in that thou belyest us; and we
cannot give the Titles to Scriptures, which are belonging to God and Christ:
for the Word became Flesh; and so, not the Scriptures. And Christ does not say,
that the Life is in the Letter; but in him: and they testify of him, who is the
Life. But R. W. is the Life in the Letter, and is the Letter Living? seeing
thou say, The Scripture avails nothing, except the Spirit of God set them
home upon us (page 94)? and do thou not say then, The Word is good for
nothing (as thou call the Scripture) without Life? and what sense is this
R.W? And can any people know the Scriptures, except by the Spirit of God, which
leads into all Truth of them? which we say in Truth and Sincerity (as Christ
and his Prophets call them) to be the Words of God; and thou that say
otherwise, do not thou Add to the Scriptures? and read thy Portion, Revelat.
the last. And when thou have forged many Words of thy own, then thou make a
Reply to them, and fall'st a railing at them, and do not reply, to G. F's
Words: and the Reader may see, there is none of these bad Words in G. F's
answer, as thou here falsely assertest.

R. W. quoteth a Book from Holland ( G. F.'s fol. 356*) saying, p. 112.
That [God has put out the Remembrance of your sins, and the Corruptions
within you, wherein you must fight all your life time.] G. F. Answ. [Whilst the
Sins you are fighting with-al, are not blotted out in your own Particulars,
this is not the Life of the Saints, that are not fighting all their Lifetime,
but come to the Kingdom of God, witnessing Sin and Iniquity blotted out; and
the Everlasting Covenant of Peace and Life with God.] R. W. replyeth, and
falls a railing with many Unsavory Words, and says: He shows no Knowledge
of the Hebrew and Greek, ( whence our English Scriptures come from them, as a
Daughter from the Mother) and falls short of many English Writers, who scorn to
disgrace their Mother English ( by so much Bastard and False English) etc.

Answ. Here R. W. would seem to be some Body in his Hebrew, Greek and Latin;
and let the Reader see, if he has not Condemned himself in Judging G. F?
though some Words may have been mist in the Printing or in Paging, as many have
in his; but he has not shown, which is the False English in this Place.

R. W. says further; If ever any poor empty Soul have talked of God without
God, and the Holy Spirit within, without them, or any true Savor of them, and
of the Holy Writings, etc. without them, or any true Reverence of them, and
Love to them; of Light, without any Spark of true Illumination, etc.

Answ. How angry and furious is R. W. here! this is thy own Talk, R. W. and not
G. F's. And Poor Empty Soul thou might have kept at home: for can any Talk of
the Holy Spirit within, and have not a Savor or Sense (if it be truly there)
within, which we witness? and we do Reverence the Scriptures, and God and
Christ with his Holy Ghost, by which the Holy Men of God did speak them forth.
But how now R. W.! do I Talk of the Light without any Spark of true
Illumination? and yet so great a Talent of Wit and Reason, which the Father of
Lights has given me? what! have thou forgotten this? (in thy App. p. 108.)

R. W. Thou say; That no Sin is blotted ou^, until there be no more Root or
Seed of it in the Soul to Fight against: [and these are thy own Words (of which
thou make a large Reply) and not mine: for my Words are; The Saints are not
Fighting all their Lifetime.] And thou bring Paul and the Galatians to
Combat with Flesh and Spirit* (Gal. 5.) and, p. 113.
Paul did not the things, that he would, etc. and Ephesians. 6, and Luke 21, and 2
Cor. 7. etc. and Christ speaking to the Churches to Watch, to Overcome, to
Repent, etc.

Answ. What is all this to the purpose, to prove, That the Saints were Fighting
all their Lifetime, and had a Combat all their Lifetime? all these
Scriptures do not prove it, nor Paul's Warfare. For Paul (as I said before to
thee) said, He had FOVGHT the good Fight, and he was made free by the Law of
the Spirit of Life in Christ Jesus from the Law of Sin and Death: though the
Apostles and the Saints went through many Conditions, before they came to this.
And the Prayer of Christ, to Pray against Temptations etc. so, it is not a Sin,
to be tempted; but a Sin to Enter into Temptation, is owned. And Christ's
Prayer, Forgive us, as we forgive others, etc. if New-England-Priests and
Professors had minded the Practice of this Prayer, they had not CVT OFF THE
EARS, nor WHIPPED or BANISHED, SPOILED Goods and HANGED God's People. And does not
the Lord say, I will blot out your Sins, and your Sins and Iniquities I will
remember no more? and must not the Saints witness this upon the Earth in Growth
in Grace, and in the Knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ, and in the
New Covenant of Light?

R. W. says; If all, that are in their Fancied Kingdom, are freed from Sin,
and come to Peace and Joy, why then do they themselves still confess to be
subject to Quaking and Trembling, as if they were at the Foot of Mount Sinai?
which indeed they are --. And then thou tellst of a False Peace, Joy, False
Repentance, Mortification, Sanctification and Salvation etc.

Answ. R. W. that is thy own, and Priests and Professors in New England
Condition, and not ours. And to Mount Sinai, the Receiving of the Law, you
never came; though ye may boast of Mount Zion. And G. F's. Words, The Saints
are come to the Kingdom of God, and witness Sin and Iniquity blotted out, and
Everlasting Covenant and Peace and Life with the God of the Life; and thou
Blasphemously call it our Fancied Kingdom. But R. W. does any Sin or unclean
thing enter the Kingdom of God? and did not Christ and the Apostles Preach the
Kingdom of God, and said, No Unrighteousness should inherit the Kingdom of God?
Be not deceived, etc. and (1 Cor. 6, 9.) Envyings, Murders, Drunkenness,
Revilings and such like, they which do such things, shall not inherit the
Kingdom of God ( Gal. 5): and does not John say, He was in the Kingdom and
Patience of Jesus? ( Rev. 1, 9.) And was Paul come no further, then to Mount
Sinai, when he Trembled among the Corinthians? and R. W. thou art as Ignorant
of our Condition, as thou art of his. Is there no Fear and Trembling at the
Word of God, but at the Foot of Mount Sinai? and was not this among the Jews,
after they came into Canaan? and was Paul at Mount Sinai, when he Came to the
Corinthians in much Fear and Trembling? Well! we do hear him, whose Voice
shakes the Earth; and not the Earth only, but the Heavens also, that that,
which can be Shaken, may be Removed; and that which cannot be Shaken, may
Remain: and that is appeared, Glory to God for ever! which this Condition, I
see, neither R. W. neither Priests in New England have gone through.

R. W. Thou bringst Robert Tuchin (from G. F.'s Fol. 365.) his Saying, [ The
Most-Faithful Messengers of Christ have acknowledged, p. 114.
that they came short of their Duty.] G. F.'s Answ. [They that are Faithful
Messengers of Christ, have their Answer; Well done, Good and Faithful Servant.
Where did Paul, John and Peter acknowledge, they came Short of their Duty? have
not thou slandered the Servants of the Lord, thinking them to be like your
selves? and falsely accusest them, that Ye may seem Justified; who are False
Messengers, and come in his Name, when you have no Commission from him: and you
come short of every good Work* But it is not so with Christ's true Messengers;
for they Fulfill his Will, that sent them: it is the Lord, that works in them,
whose they are, whose Duty they perform by his Spirit.] R. W. replyeth, and
begins with Railing and says; The Heavens were not Pure in his Sight (to
wit, God) and he laid Folly to the Charge of his Angels, etc.

Answ. This Eliphas, the Temanite speak against Job, as R. W. does against us,
( Job 4.) when he Contended against Job, and Reproved him; of whom God said, He
was a Perfect man: so this is thy Ignorance. As for my Endowments, and our
Endowments, they are from the Lord: and I do grant, That Adam and Eve was
Perfect, and yet they Fell; and (thou say R. W.) We all by them are Fallen
Short of the Glory and Love of God, into the Dunghill of Hellish Darkness. THERE
YOU ARE, this is true R. W. in that which cannot Comprehend the Light of
Christ, which he Enlightneth every Man, that comes into the World, withal; but
call it an Idol: which Shines in your Darkness, and your Darkness
comprehends it not. And thou bringst David's Sayings, ( Psalm. 143: and Psalm.
19.) Enter not into Judgment, p. 115.
nor reckon with thy Servant, etc. Cleanse me from my Secret Sins, etc. but
what is David's Adultery and Murder, that the Most-Faithful Messengers of
Christ come short of their Duty? for thou must bring a Text of Scripture, where
they said, They acknowledged, they came short of their Duty? let us have
Chapter and Verse for this, then thou have said something. And then thou
speak of Abraham and Isaac: -- But where is the Charge of Abraham, that he
said, he came short of his Duty? or Enoch? or Abel? but as it is said, The
Righteous may fall, but rise again; but the Wicked shall fall into Mischief.
And does John cry out (1 John 2.) that he acknowledges, that he came short of
his Duty? there is no such saying there; and thou wrong'st John: but he writes
to the Young Men, because ye are strong, and the Word of God abides in you,
and ye have OVERCOME the Wicked One. And John says, If we confess our Sins, he
is Faithful and Just to forgive us our Sins, and to CLEANSE US FROM ALL
VNRIGHTEOVSNESS (1 John 1.): and further says, If we walk in the Light, as he
is in the Light, we have fellowship one with another* and the Blood of Christ
CLEANSES US FROM ALL SIN.

R. W. And thou say, Paul confessed and bewailed his Coming short; The Good,
that he would do, he did not; etc. With his Flesh he served the Law of Sin: and
though it was not Paul, that sinned, but Sin, that dwelt in him; and thou more
then fear, this Mystery is hidden from the poor Quakers.

Answ. But R. W. thou said now, It was not Paul, that sinned, but Sin, that
dwelt in him: and thou said (page 96.) of another Great Mystery, How the
Seeds of all Sin dwelt in the Newborn: and yet, It was not Paul that sinned,
thou say; for Paul says, It is not I: but he speaks of the Two I's, and
the Two ME's; which thou say the Seeds of all Sin is the [^], and in the ME,
that serves the Law of God. But Paul, Peter, and John were not always in that
Condition, Peter of denying his Master, and Paul crying out of Sin, and the Law
of Sin, and coming short of their Duty, thou call: for Peter Exhorted to
Perfection; and Paul said, he was made free, with the Law of the Spirit of Life
in Christ Jesus (as I often said before): and he had fought a good Fight, and
kept Faith; and there was a Crown laid up for him. And John said; As he is, so
are we in this present World: and he was in the Kingdom: and Paul said, The
Life that I now live, is by the Faith of the Son of God: and I live, yet not I,
but Christ lives in me, etc. Therefore, how did the Most-faithful Messengers
of Christ acknowledge, they came short of their Duty, etc. in the New Covenant
to the End? did they fall like Adam and Eve? and we have had full Experience of
the Saints Trials, Sufferings and Temptations both within and without. And G.
F. does not say, That the Servants of God never failed in Word or in Thought:
there is no such thing in G. F.'s Answer; and therefore thou might have
spared those Words: but there is no Comparison to be made with the Faithful
Messengers of Christ ( G. F. says) and your Pretended Messengers, that never
heard his Voice; and so have no Commission from him. And I must tell thee R. W.
and you New-England-Priests, that deny Christ the Light, with which he
Englightneth every Man, that comes into the World, which is the Life in the
Word, and call it a Frantic Light and an Idol; thou and they deny Christ
that bought you, Worse than Peter, that Deny the Light, which he Commands to
believe in. And so you are Come Short of every Good Work, but not of the Evil,
who would parallel your selves with the Faithful Messengers of Christ, and
finding Fault with them, ye do not see your own selves: for the Faithful had
Victory.

R. W. He brings Thomas Hodges ( G.F. Fol 372.) saying; [ The Scripture
speaks of God after the Manner of Men.] G. F. Ans. [ The Scripture speaks
of God after the Manner of the Spirit, p. 116.
and to the Spirit, whereby Men may receive him, and know him by the Spirit;
which Natural Man cannot.] R. W. replyeth, and begins with Railing Language
(as he uses to do) and says; Here he denies the Heavenly Mystery of God
revealing himself to us after the Manner of Men, having Head, Eyes and Mouth,
etc.

Answ. His Heavenly Mysteries God Reveals by his Spirit, does he not? does
not the Apostle say, The Mysteries and Things of God are Revealed by the
